div1.p: DUKE, MAYOR.
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT.
MINUTES OF EVIDENCE,
Taken in Short-hand
BY
JAMES DROVER BARNETT
AND
ALEXANDER BUCKLER,
33, Southampton-street, Strand.
VOLUME XXIX.
SESSION I. TO SESSION VI.
LONDON:
GEORGE HEBERT, CHEAPSIDE.
TYLER & REED, PRINTERS, BOLT-COURT, FLEET-STREET.
THE
WHOLE PROCEEDINGS
On the Queen's Commission of the Peace,
OYER AND TERMINER, AND GAOL DELIVERY
FOR
The City of London,
AND GAOL DELIVERY FOR THE
COUNTY OF MIDDLESEX, AND THE PARTS OF THE COUNTIES OF ESSEX, KENT, AND SURREY, WITHIN THE JURISDICTION
OF THE
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT,
Held on Monday, November 27th, 1848, and following Days.
THOMAS QUESTED FINNIS, Esq.,
JACOB EMANUEL GOODHART, Esq.,
JAMES EDWARD SHEARMAN, Esq.
GEORGE TAMPLIN, Esq.
LIST OF JURORS.
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT.
DUKE, MAYOR. FIRST SESSION.

A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”Two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”An obelisk (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad characters.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; Mr. Ald. GIBBS; Mr. RECORDER; Mr. Ald. WILLIAM HUNTER; Mr. Ald. CHALLIS; and Mr. Ald. MOON.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the First Jury.

div1.p:
1.
JAMES ALLEN
, stealing 30 yards of cloth, value 3l., the goods of
James Wood, in his dwelling-house; to which he pleaded
GUILTY .

2.
JAMES ALLEN was again indicted
for stealing 40 yards of cloth, value 15l.; the goods of
Thomas Tillman, in his dwelling-house.

JAMES BATTLEBURY . I am in the employ of Thomas Tillman, a tailor, of 200, Whitechapel-road, in the parish of St. Mary, Whitechapel, it is his dwelling-house. On 1st Nov., about half-past six o'clock, the prisoner came in, said, "Good evening," took up eight lengths of cloth, and ran outâ€”I am lame, and before I could get up he was half way out of the shopâ€”I called, "Stop thief!" but could not find a policemanâ€”a parcel of boys surrounded meâ€”I afterwards recognized him at the Mansion-houseâ€”I know him by his cap and dress, and also by his featuresâ€”this is like the cap (produced)â€”I was discharged in consequence, as it was thought I had a hand in it, but have been taken back.
WILLIAM LOCKYER (City policeman, 264). On 10th Nov. the prisoner was in my charge at the Mansion-house in the other case; Battlebury was brought there and identified him.

GUILTY . Aged 20.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. MOON and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock Esq. and the Fifth Jury.

div1.p:
3.
WILLIAM HAMILTON
, stealing 1 half-crown of
William Turrell; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.â€”
Confined Six Months.

4.
GEORGE NEIGHBOUR and
JAMES GRANT
, stealing 1 cwt. coals, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Henry Nash, in a-barge on the Grand Junction Canal; to which

NEIGHBOUR pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 39.

GRANT pleaded
GUILTY Aged 26.

5.
JOHN WILLIAMS
, stealing 1 fork, value 18s., the goods of
Frank Clemow; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 15.â€”
Confined Six Months.

6.
JAMES KIFF
, stealing 2 bushels of potatoes, value 5s.; the goods of
James Hitchcock, his master.
JAMES HITCHCOCK . I am a farmer, of Northall. On 10th Oct. I missed some potatoes from a place which was locked upâ€”on the 12th I missed moreâ€”the prisoner was at work for me on the 9th.

GEORGE CARTER . I am in Mr. Hitchcock's employ. On 9th Oct., about four in the day, I was in the stable, and saw the prisoner go to the place where the potatoes were, pull down a board, pull out some potatoes, put them into a basket, and fill his pockets with them. and go awayâ€”he afterwards said to me, "You must be wide awake if you live with Mr. Hitchcock"â€”I left four days afterwardsâ€”Mr. Hitchcock came to me and said he had missed potatoesâ€”I told him who took them.

JOHN LONG . I was working for Mr. Hitchcock. On 9th Oct., near five o'clock, the prisoner was working thereâ€”I am his step-sonâ€”I saw him take a few potatoes out of a hole and put them into bis pocketâ€”he did not take near a pocketfullâ€”Carter was in the other stable.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up a few which fell out of a hole; it is only done out of spite.
NOT GUILTY .

7.
THOMAS NEWELL
, stealing 3 pecks of beans, and one sack, value 6s.; the goods of
Richard Le Bas.

RICHARD LE BAS . I am a coal-merchant, of Hillingdon. I had some beans in a loft over a shed in my yardâ€”I last saw them safe on Monday, 20th Nov., between four and five o'clock, when I went to close the loft doorâ€”a person spoke to me, and I went on the Wednesday and missed some
thing less than a bushel of the beans and a sackâ€”this sack and beans are mineâ€”they were old beans, and insects had got into themâ€”the prisoner has been occasionally employed in unloading the boatsâ€”he knew my premises perfectly well.

STEPHEN MASTERS (policeman, T 199). I was on duty on Uxbridge
moor on 21st Nov., a few minutes before five o'clockâ€”I saw the prisoner coming from the direction of the prosecutor's premises towards his own home with something on his shoulder which he threw away before he came to meâ€”he passed meâ€”I went and found this sack with nearly a bushel of beansâ€”I took them, and then the prisonerâ€”he denied all knowledge of the beansâ€”I have known him perfectly well for yearsâ€”it was not very darkâ€”no other person passed me.

GUILTY . Aged 35.â€”
Confined. Six Months.

8.
WILLIAM FLITNEY
, feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
George Lane.

GEORGE LANE. I am a draper, of Uxbridge. On 28th Sept., between eleven and twelve o'clock, the prisoner brought this order, and said he brought it from his motherâ€”I let him have a pair of shoes and a coatâ€”I sent the account to his mother by my young man, about a fortnight after
wards.
Cross-examined by Mr. COOPER. Q. Where did he live? A. About a mile and a half from meâ€”I had seen him once before, with his motherâ€”I sent Clarence for the moneyâ€”he is not here.

RICHARD ROADKNIGHT (police-sergeant, T 11). I took the prisonerâ€”he said he did not write the note, nor his mother, neither of them could write, that a man named Smith wrote itâ€”I found the shoes at his lodging, and the duplicate for the coat.

ELIZABETH PUTNEY . I am the wife of William Flitney. The prisoner is my sonâ€”I told him to get these thingsâ€”this note is not my writingâ€”I cannot writeâ€”I do not know whether I told anybody to write itâ€”I told my son he might have the thingsâ€”I should have paid for them.
NOT GUILTY .

9.
JOHN CHAPLIN
, stealing 1 coat, value 3l.; the goods of
William Gibson; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 52.â€”
Confined Four Months.

10.
WILLIAM ROBERTSON
, stealing 2 pairs of boots, value 8s.; the goods of
Aaron Hart and another, his masters.

AARON HART . On 17th Nov. my brother, who is my partner, told me somethingâ€”I went into my warehouse, and saw the prisoner about to leaveâ€”my brother said to him, "Robertson, I miss a pair of cloth boots, you must know something about them"â€”he said, "It is no use denying it, I have taken them; it is the first time I did anything of the sort"â€”we sent for a policeman, and just before he came the prisoner took a pair of women's boots from his pocketâ€”when we got to the station, he put his hand behind him, and said, "Here is another pair that I have, I hope you will be mer
ciful, it is my first offence"â€”these are the bootsâ€”they are mine and my brother's.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was not what he said that he hoped you would not be hard with him? A. They were nearly the wordsâ€”I did not recollect them beforeâ€”he has a wife and four childrenâ€”I am of the Jewish persuasion; the prisoner is notâ€”he would only have five days' work in a week with meâ€”he said before the Magistrate that he had taken the boots for samples, as he thought he should be able to do something on Saturdays if he took samples.

ALEXANDER SANDERSON (City-policeman, 70). I was called, and saw the prisoner standing with a pair of boots in his handâ€”he said it was the first time he bad ever done anything of the kind, and begged for mercyâ€”at the station he handed over this other pair of boots to Mr. Hart.
Cross-examined. Q. What day of the week was this? A. On Friday, about ten minutes before four o'clock, just about the time that persons of the Jewish persuasion would leave off business.

GUILTY . Aged 37.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury.â€”
Confined Four Months.

11.
JAMES EAST,
ALFRED HUMPHRIES , and
FREDERICK BURRELL
, stealing 4 loaves of bread, value 1s. 7d.; the goods of
James Morris; East having been before convicted; to which

EAST * pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.

HUMPHRIES * pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 16.

JOHN WEBB . I am in the service of Mr. James Morris, a baker, at Uxbridge. On 3rd Nov., about one o'clock in the day, I was on Uxbridge-common, and left my barrow at agate, with two quartern and sis half-quartern loaves in it; and went into a house to serve a customerâ€”I was away six or
seven minutesâ€”I came back, and missed one quartern and three half-quartern leavesâ€”Boddington afterwards produced some breadâ€”it was my master's.

WILLIAM BODDINGTON . I am a carpenter. I was on Uxbridge-commonâ€”I met the prosecutor and anotherâ€”I cannot be positive of Burrellâ€”one of them threw a half-quartern loaf pulled in two, over into a plantationâ€”I got over and got it, and gave it to Webb.

WILLIAM LOWE . I was on the common, and saw the prisoners and another boy about 150 yards from the barrow, handing some bread from one to the otherâ€”I afterwards saw one of them throw some bread away.
Burrell. I was not there. Witness. You wereâ€”I knew you before.

WILLIAM BEFCHY (policeman. T 182). On 3rd Nov., about two o'clock, I saw the three prisoners together near the market-place, Uxbridgeâ€”as soon as they saw me they ran awayâ€”I ran and took East and Humphriesâ€”East said he knew nothing about the breadâ€”Humphries said he meant to pay for it at night.

JOHN VAGG (policeman, T 141). I took Burrellâ€”he said he meant pay
ing for his share of the bread at night.

BURRELLâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

12.
JOHN ROLFE
, stealing 5 quarts of wine, and 8 bottles, value 2l. 1s.; the good of
William Manoah Chambers and another.

JAMES BOWMAN . I am cellarman to Mr. William Manoah Chambers, and his partner. On 17th June the prisoner came to the window at half-past seven in the morningâ€”we had some sherry in the cellarâ€”I went up stairs, came down again. and missed six or seven bottles of itâ€”the prisoner was then in front of the houseâ€”I asked him if he had taken any of the wineâ€”he said, "No"â€”there was another person with him.

Cross-examined. Q. How many were there altogether? A. Four, I, Duck, and the prisoner, and another were cleaning the windowsâ€”there were persons in the top of the houseâ€”my masters were not come to town.

HENRY DUCK . I was spoken to about this wineâ€”I saw the prisoner, who was cleaning the windows, come down about half-past eight o'clock, and go across the warehouse into the cellar with a basketâ€”I followed him towards a bin where the wine was, and was putting it on the binâ€”I said, "Don't put it there; put it on this cask"â€”he took eight bottles out of the basket, one by one, and put them on the cask, then went up again and began to clean the windowsâ€”a policeman came, and we marked the bottles with inkâ€”Mr. Chambers afterwards sent them away, as the wine was sold.
Cross-examined. Q. This was six moths ago? A. Yesâ€”the other man who was with the prisoner went away and left the prisoner there.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Sir PETER LAURIE, Knt.; Mr. RECORDER; and Mr. Ald. MOON.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Second Jury.

div1.p:
13.
SARAH HUXFORD
, stealing a leather-bag, value 4d., four sove-reigns, 6 half-sovereigns, I crown, 16 half-crowns, 14 shillings, and 6 pence; the property of
Robert Reeve, in his dwelling-house; and
HENRY GOOD
SON
, feloniously meaning the same to which

HUXFORD pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

ROBERT REEVE . I live at 10, Old Fish-street, Doctors'-commons. On 28th Oct. I had 11l. 12s. 6d. in a box in my bed-roomâ€”I was fetched home from work about seven o'clock, and it was goneâ€”Huxford was employed in my house that day cleaning the placeâ€”her sister was in my service.

MARY ANN REEVE . I missed the money as soon as Huxford left, a little after five on 28th Oct.â€”I have seen Goodson in my place when we lived next door, but not in this houseâ€”he is a picture-frame makerâ€”I had told Huxford on Friday that Mr. Reeve had got his rent money, and was going to pay it next morning, but we had not enough by 1s. 3d. to do soâ€”the box in which the money was kept was not locked.

SAMUEL MARTIN . I keep the Forester's Arms beer-shop, in Union-street, Borough. Goodson was my waiter for nearly three monthsâ€”he left me of his own accord, on 23rd Oct.â€”he came back on 28th, and saw my wifeâ€”I was not presentâ€”he came on Sunday the 29th, about ten o'clock, and said he had met with a friend who had lent him a few pounds, and gave me 2l.â€”he owed me about 1l. 14s.â€”I gave him an I O U for itâ€”the officer came and apprehended him that same night, about a quarter to twelveâ€”I went to the door to see what was the matterâ€”Goodson put out his hand, and some money dropped from it which the officer picked upâ€”Huxford had come to the house with him, but had gone out at the time the officer cameâ€”they had been up stairs in the club-roomâ€”a number of other persons were thereâ€”during the time Goodson lived with me I had seen Huxford there several times, but I did not know that there was any particular intimacy between them.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Has Goodson borne a good character? A. He hasâ€”when the money dropped from his hand he was hold
ing it out to me, but I did not take it, and it fell.

JOHN STOREY (City-policeman, 414). I went with Mr. and Mrs. Reeve to Martin's beer-shop, on Sunday night, 29th Oct., about twelve o'clockâ€”I saw Huxford come out with another female, and go to an oyster-shopâ€”I then went in, and took Goodsonâ€”in coming out, he took some money out of his pocket, and endeavoured to pass it to the landlordâ€”it dropped in the streetâ€”I picked it upâ€”it was four half-sovereigns, and a sovereign he had in his handâ€”I found on him this I O U for 2l. and 1s. 8d., in copperâ€”he struggled, and tried to get awayâ€”Huxford came up, and passed 1s. to another female which I took out of her handâ€”I asked Goodson at the sta
tion where he had got the money fromâ€”he said he had picked up a purse in one of the recesses on London-bridge with 5l. in itâ€”he afterwards said it was 6l. 13s.â€”I was present when he was under examination before the late Lord Mayor, and made a statementâ€”this is the Lord Mayor's signatureâ€”the pri
soner also signed it, but I am not sure that I saw him do soâ€”the part that is printed was also read over to himâ€”(readâ€”"Henry Goodson saith as follows: I have kept company with her a long while; on Saturday night we stopped out together, and going over London-bridge in the morning I picked up in one of the recesses an old green purse with 6l. 13s. in it, and we were so pleased that we would not go home, and we went to enjoy ourselves a little, and then I went to Mr. Martin's as usual; I had not been there a great while when the officer came, and took me into custody; in coming down stairs I took the money out of my waistcoat-pocket to give to Mr. Martin to take care of it for me, and it dropped down; that is all I know about it."
(Goodson received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

14.
WILLIAM BENNETT
, stealing 34 yards of Coburg cloth, value 37s.; also, 29 yards of Alpaca cloth, 20s.; the goods of
James Keighley and another; to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined Six Months.

15.
CHARLES LEN
, stealing 8 yards of velvet, value 6s.; the goods of
William Couchman.

JOSEPH MARK . I live at 56, Cornwall-road. On 18th Nov., I saw the prisoner, and a younger one at the corner of Farringdon-marketâ€”the young one drew a piece of velvet from Mr. Couchman's doorâ€”the prisoner opened his coat and received itâ€”I collared him, he struck me in the eye, and dropped the velvet in the scuffleâ€”he said he picked it up, and was going to take it into the shopâ€”the other got away.
WILLIAM COUCHMAN . This velvet is mineâ€”I was in the shop, but did not miss it till it was brought by Brownâ€”the string was cut.
THOMAS BROWN (City-policeman, 215). I found Mark struggling with the prisonerâ€”I took him, and the velvet which was on the ground, about two yards from the doorâ€”there was a pile of goods there.

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Six Months.

16.
JOHN SMITH
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
James Montague, from his person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . ** Aged 20.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

17.
WILLIAM WALKER was indicted
for embezzling 8l. 8s. 3d.; the moneys of
Charles Shaw, his master: also, unlawfully obtaining by false pretences a check for the payment of 55l. 2s., with intent to defraud
Charles Shaw; to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 28.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Sir PETER LAURIE, Knt., Ald.; Sir CHAPMAN MARSHALL, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. GIBBS; Mr. Ald. MOON; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Sixth Jury.

div1.p:
18.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

19.
WILLIAM FRENCH was indicted
for a like offence.

FREDERICK RAYNER . I keep an eating-house, in Broad-street, Ratcliffe. On 7th Oct., the prisoner came between seven and eight o'clock for a quarter of a pourd of meatâ€”it came to 3d.â€”he offered me a bad crownâ€”I did not find it to be had, and put it into ray pocket where I had no other, and gave the prisoner changeâ€”he went awayâ€”in ten minutes, or a quarter of an hour my wife came into the parlour, and brought me a crown-piece, and asked me to give changeâ€”I thought it was bad, took it to the prisoner in my shop, and told him it was badâ€”I gave it him, and told him he was the man who tendered the firstâ€”he said he was not, he never was in the shop beforeâ€”I gave him into custody, and gave the first crown to the policeman.
ELIZABETH RAYNER . On 7th Oct., I was in the shopâ€”the prisoner came in for a quarter of a pound of beefâ€”it came to 2 1/4 d. I served himâ€”he gave

me a 5s. pieceâ€”I went into the parlour to my husband to get change for itâ€”he tried it with his teeth, came with me to the shop, and told the prisoner it was bad, and that he was the man that had passed the first crownâ€”he said he did not know it was bad, and he had never been in the shop beforeâ€”a policeman was sent for, and he was taken into custody.

MORRIS LANE (policeman, K 397). I took the prisoner for passing two bad crown piecesâ€”he denied uttering the first, and said he had never been in the shopâ€”I found on him this crown-pieceâ€”this other was given me by Mr. Raynor.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mintâ€”these crowns are both counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined One Year ,

20.
THOMAS BLAND and
JOHN FRANCIS was indicted for
a like offence.

FRANCIS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

JOSEPH SMITH . I am a grocer, and live in Union-street, Hackoey-road. On 27th Oct., the prisoner Bland came to my shop a little before eleven o'clock in the morning for a quarter of an ounce of tobaccoâ€”I served himâ€”he tendered me a bad sixpenceâ€”I noticed that it was bad, and I bent it a littleâ€”I told him that would not do for meâ€”he said he had taken it at a pawnbroker's in Shoreditch, where he had pledged a handkerchief, and he must take it back directlyâ€”I let him take it, and he gave me a good sixpenceâ€”I gave him change, and be leftâ€”my little girl spoke to me, and I went out and saw Bland about two doors from my houseâ€”he went round the corner and joined Francis who was standing still, and appeared to be waiting for himâ€”I followed themâ€”they went to a pawnbroker's shop in Hackney-roadâ€”Bland went up a passage by the side of the shopâ€”Francis went on a little way, and waited for himâ€”Bland came out of the passage, and they went onâ€”I followed them to a shop kept by Crisp in Maria-streetâ€”Bland went in there, and Francis waited outsideâ€”Bland came out, they joined in company, and went to Huntingdon-street, to a shop kept by Goddardâ€”Francis went in there, and Bland watted outside under an archwayâ€”they joined againâ€”I continued to follow them to a good many shopsâ€”they at last went to Mr. Aylin'sâ€”I told an officer, and I went in there with himâ€”I found Francis thereâ€”I secured him, and the officer went after Blandâ€”he brought him back, and they were taken to the station.

Bland. Q. Did I go into the shop in Maria-street? A. Yes, and you offered me a bad sixpenceâ€”I gave you the sixpence backâ€”I marked it with my nail when I tried it on the counterâ€”this is itâ€”here is my mark.

MARY CRISP . I am a widow, and keep a tobacconist's shop in Maria-street. On the 27th Oct., Bland came for a quarter of an ounce of tobacco, and gave me a sixpenceâ€”I gave him change and put the sixpence into the tillâ€”there was no other sixpence thereâ€”Mr. Smith came and told me somethingâ€”I looked at the sixpence and found it was badâ€”no one had been to the till in the mean timeâ€”I gave the sixpence to the policeman.

MARY HOUSE . I assist Mr. Goddard, who keeps a shop in Huntingdon-street. On 27th Oct. Francis came to the shop for a quarter of an ounce of tobaccoâ€”he gave me a six
pence; I gave him 5 1/4 d. in changeâ€”I put the sixpence into the till, there was no other thereâ€”my daughter came in in about ten minutes, and said, "Mother you have taken a bad sixpence"â€”no one had been to the till in the meantime.

ROSETTA GODDARD . I had been serving in the shop that morningâ€”I went up stairs for five or ten minutesâ€”when I came clown I found only one sixpence in the till, and it was is bad oneâ€”I sand, "Mother you have taken a bad sixpence"â€”I give the sixpence to the officerâ€”this is it.
JOHN CHURCHILL . (policeman, G 187). I took the prisoner, and have the sixpencesâ€”I found on Bland 1s. 3 1/2 d. in copper, and a sixpenceâ€”there were four farthings on him.
CALEB, EDWARD POWELL . Those sixpences arc both counterfeit, and from the same mould.

Bland's Defence. I pawnel a handkerchief for 2s.; on 27th Oct. I was going to market; I went into the shop for a quarter of an ounce of tobacco; the man refused the sixpence, and I gave him a good one; I went out and went down the Hickney-road; I met Francis; he walked with me; he went into the shop in Maria-street; it was not me.
Francis. This man knows no more of the base coin than a stranger; I went into the shop in Maria-street myself.

BLANDâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined One Year .

21.
ANN RAMSDEN was indicted
for a like offence.

ROBERT SAUNDERSON . I keep the Black Horse, in Poplar. On 25th Oct. the prisoner came to my house, about a quarter-past eight o'clock in the eveningâ€”she brought a jug, asked for half a pint of sixpenny ale, and tendered me a counterfeit crown-pieceâ€”I did not then think it was bad, and gave her changeâ€”I put the crown into the tillâ€”there was no other crown thereâ€”in about three minutes after she leftâ€”I looked at the crown again, and discovered it was badâ€”I went in pursuit of the prisoner, but could not find herâ€”I returned, and put a mark on the crown-pieceâ€”I kept it apart from other money, and ultimately gave it to the officerâ€”the prisoner was not in my place more than three minutesâ€”I had an opportunity of seeing her featuresâ€”I do not remember that I had seen her beforeâ€”I saw her again about seventeen days afterwardsâ€”she was not then in custody, but was in the street at largeâ€”Mr. Bottjer asked me to come over and look at herâ€”I went, and said that was the womanâ€”she was going away from the houseâ€”I went in front of her, and recognised her as the personâ€”I have not the slightest doubt that she is the person.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Mr. Bottjer lives just opposite you? A. Yesâ€”when I came, he asked me it the prisoner was the person, he had hold of her armâ€”I said she was the person who passed the crown at my placeâ€”it was on 25th Oct. she passed it at my house, and on 11th Nov. Mr. Bottjer sent for meâ€”there were from fourteen to twenty persons close by the spot.

MR. BODKIN. Q. When you first saw her on 11th Nov., had anybody hold of her? A. Noâ€”after that I saw Mr. Bottjer take hold of her armâ€”when I saw her face, I recognised her, and said, "That is the woman that passed a bad 5s. piece at my house"â€”I believe I said that loud enough for her to hear meâ€”I was within four feet of herâ€”she said she was quite confi
dent, or something to that effect, that I had never seen her before.

JOHN MAWSON I am a grocer, in High-street, Poplar. On Thursday, 2nd Nov., the prisoner came to my shopâ€”I am sure she is the same personâ€”I had never seen her before to my knowledgeâ€”she bought half a pound of sugar. winch came to 2d.â€”she gave me a 3s. pieceâ€”I gave her change, and put the crown into the tillâ€”there was other silver there, but no other 5s. pieceâ€”next day I offered it with souk oilier money, and it was refusedâ€”I
then found it was badâ€”I afterwards gave it to the policemanâ€”I saw the prisoner at the station on 21st Nov.â€”I was taken to look at her.
JAMES HARRIS (police-sergeant, K 21). I got this bad crown from Mr. Moxson.

FRANCES PHILLIPS . I am the wife of Robert Matthew Phillips, a green-grocer, of Greenfield-street, Commercial-road. On 4th Nov., at half-past nine o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came for a bunch of greensâ€”she offered me half a crown, I had no changeâ€”she took a penny herring, and left the greensâ€”I am quite sure she is the same personâ€”I was in conversation with her five minutesâ€”I got her 2s. 5d. changeâ€”I put the half-crown into my pocket, where I had no more money whateverâ€”I gave it the next day to a person in Spitalfields-market, and found it was badâ€”I took it home, and gave it to my husband.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you next see the prisoner? A. At the stationâ€”when I saw her, it gave me a bit of a turn to see her there againâ€”I did not shake my head to intimate that she was not the personâ€”the officer brought her from the cellâ€”she had an apron up to her mouth, and the policeman pulled it downâ€”I most likely went to a public-house afterwards, but not with the policeman.
COURT. Q. Are you sure she was the woman? A. Yes I am.
ROBERT MATTHEW PHILLIPS . My wife gave me the half-crownâ€”I put a mark on it, and gave it to Madden.
PATRICK MADDEN * (police-sergeant, H 20). I received this half-crown from Mr. Phillips.

GERD BOTTJER . I am a grocer and cheesemonger. On 11th Nov. the prisoner came for half a quartern of shilling butter, and paid me with a coun
terfeit 6d.â€”I told her it was bad, and. I broke it in her presenceâ€”I asked her how she dared to offer such a coin to me, I was certain she knew it was badâ€”she said she was not aware it was bad, and complained a great deal about my breaking the sixpenceâ€”she interrupted me in my business, and I told her to leave and get away as quickly as possible, or I should give her in chargeâ€”I sent for Mr. Saunderson; he came overâ€”I asked him if he knew anything about herâ€”he said, "That is the very person that passed the coun
terfeit crown to me"â€”I would not be certain whether she said anything, but some one said, "How can he say it is the same person because she had a mug in her hand?"â€”Wood, the officer, came, and took her into custody.

Cross-examined. Q. She said she wondered at your impudence in accusing her of anything of the kind? A. Yesâ€”I had heard that Mr. Saunders had taken a crown-piece, and when he came, I took hold of her armâ€”he said she was the person.
MR. BODKIN. Q. When you broke the sixpence, what did you do? A. I gave her the pieces backâ€”she was not given into custody in the shop, she went outside.

HENRY WOOD (police-sergeant, K 23). I took the prisoner into custody outside of Mr. Bottjer's shopâ€”I asked her what she had done with the six
penceâ€”she said she had flung it awayâ€”I produce this crown, which I received from Mr. Saunders.
Cross-examined. Q. Was she searched? A. Yes; and a good sixpence and three farthings were found on her.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These two crown-pieces are counterfeitâ€”this half-crown is counterfeit also.
JANE BLACK . I am a widow, and live in High-street, Whitechapel. The

prisoner lived with me four or five weeksâ€”her health was very hadâ€”if I had known she had been in a bad state of healthâ€”I would not have taken herâ€”she did needlework for meâ€”she went, out while she was with me; she was out on Friday the 10th Nov., and on the Saturday when she was takenâ€”I could not tell whether she was out on the 2nd or 4th of Nov.â€”she was able to go outâ€”Mr. Saunderson's, the Black Horse, is a long way from my house.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 30.â€”
Confined One Year .

22.
JOHN TOBIN was indicted
for a like offence.

JOHANNA M'CAULIFFE . I live at the Crown and Seven Stars, in Rosemary-lane. On 3rd Nov. the prisoner came for a cup of coffee, and offered me a shillingâ€”I told him I had only got ninepence, and he drank two more cups of coffeeâ€”I then gave him the ninepenceâ€”I took the shilling to a public-house and called for a quartern of rumâ€”they told me it was a bad shillingâ€”I put it into my pocket and kept it till I met the police-sergeant, and gave it himâ€”I am sure I had no other shilling.
JOHN M'DONNOUGH . I keep the Windmill, in Rosemary-lane. On 3rd Nov. M'Callie came, she offered me a shillingâ€”I am sure I gave her the same shilling back.
PATRICK MADDEN (police-sergeant, H 20). I received this shilling from M'Callie.

MARGARET LAGAROWICH . My husband is at sea, my mother lives at Wap
ping. On 6th Nov. the prisoner came and called for a cup of coffee and an eggâ€”it came to twopence-halfpennyâ€”he gave me a bad sixpenceâ€”I cut it with a knifeâ€”I called a policeman and gave him the sixpenceâ€”he took the prisoner into custody.

FREDERICK MARSHALL (policeman, H 179). I took the prisoner and received this sixpenceâ€”the prisoner refused to let me search him, and be made his escapeâ€”I followed him and caught him in Dock-street, about a hundred yards offâ€”I took him to the station.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . The shilling and sixpence are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 23.â€”
Confined One Year .

23.
MARY ANN MARRS was indicted
for a like offence.
MESSRS. BODKIN and DAWSON conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN STEVENS . I keep a general-shop in Boswell-court. On 7th Nov. the prisoner came for a quarter of a pound of sugar, which came to 1 3/4 d.â€”she laid down a half-crown on the counter, and I gave her changeâ€”she left the shopâ€”in about ten minutes I looked at the half-crown; it was badâ€”no person had been in my shop in the intervalâ€”I put the half-crown apart from other moneyâ€”in a few days I got information and gave it to Dyer at the police-court.
Prisoner. I never was in his shop; I do not know where it is. Witness. I am quite sure she is the personâ€”I have not the slightest doubt of it.
JAMES DYER (police-sergeant, E 2). I produce this half-crown.

ELIZABETH ANN BRETT . My mother keeps a shop in New North-street, Red Lion-square. On 10th Nov. the prisoner came there for a half-quartern loafâ€”she had come about five minutes previous for change for a shillingâ€”she gave me a good shilling and I gave her two good sixpencesâ€”that was between six and seven o'clockâ€”she then came for the loaf and gave me a half-crownâ€”I examined it; it was badâ€”I gave it to my motherâ€”the prisoner offered to go and get it changedâ€”my mother would not allow her to do that,
but kept her in the shopâ€”my mother asked her where she livedâ€”she refused to tellâ€”an officer was sent for, and he took her into custodyâ€”I gave the half-crown to the officer.
THOMAS HINDS (policeman, E 83). I took the prisoner and received this half-crown.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These are both counterfeit.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in Mr. Stevens' shop.

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined Six Months.

24.
THOMAS WADE was indicted
for a like offence.

EMILY LANGDALE . My mother keeps a shop near Piccadilly. On 16th Nov. a person came there and asked for a biscuitâ€”to the best of my recol
lection it was the prisonerâ€”I served himâ€”he put down a sixpence on the counterâ€”I put it amongst the halfpence in the tillâ€”there was no other six
pence where I put itâ€”my mother afterwards came and discovered it was a bad one.

MARY ANN LANGDALE . I remember the prisoner coming for a biscuit, on 16th Nov.â€”I am positive he is the personâ€”my daughter served him, and he paid her a sixpenceâ€”soon afterwards I had occasion to go to the tillâ€”I ob
served the sixpence with the halfpence; it was the only sixpence thereâ€”it was apart from all other silverâ€”I found it was badâ€”I wrapped it in paper and put it at the back of the tillâ€”in less than an hour the prisoner came again for a biscuit and some cheeseâ€”he gave me a half-crownâ€”I examined it and took it in my handâ€”I opened the till, and said, "I don't think I can give you change"â€”I recollected him to be the person who came in with the sixpenceâ€”I knew him when he was looking in at the windowâ€”I walked round the counter with the half-crown in. my hand, and when I got very near him 1 said, "I don't think this is good"â€”he said, "Yes it is; if you don't like it I will give you halfpence"â€”I said, "This is the second time you have been here to-night passing bad money"â€”he tried to leave the shopâ€”I pre
vented him by holding his coatâ€”he got out and gave a sudden jerkâ€”the piece of his coat that I had hold of, came off, and he ran awayâ€”he was brought back in about five minutes by Wright the officerâ€”I gave Wright the two pieces of bad money.

JAMES WRIGHT (policeman, A 312). I took the prisonerâ€”I have the half-crown and the sixpenceâ€”the prisoner was running in Well-streetâ€”there was a piece off the breast of his coatâ€”he stated that he had not been in any shop at all.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These are both counterfeit.
Prisoner's Defence. I know no more about the sixpence than a man that never saw it.

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined One Year .

25.
THOMAS FEENEY was indicted
for a like offence.

ANN EVANS . My husband keeps a shop in Gray's-inn-lane. On 20th Nov. the prisoner came, about ten o'clock in the evening, for half an ounce of tobaccoâ€”it came to 1 1/2 d.â€”he paid me a half-crown, which I put into the till; I had no other thereâ€”before I put it in I had shown it to my husband.â€”he did not perceive that it was bad, nor did Iâ€”I gave the prisoner changeâ€”the half-crown remained in the till till the Wednesday morning, when I took it out, and gave it to my husband to pay awayâ€”he came back and gave me the half-crown, and 1 nailed it to the counterâ€”it remained there till the Thursday, when the policeman took it offâ€”on the Thursday

afternoon the prisoner came for a quarter of in ounce of tobacco; he gave me a sixpenceâ€”I looked at it, and told him I thought it was badâ€”he said if it was bad he did not know it; and he said a lady gave it him for carrying. 1 parcel to the omnibusâ€”I gave the sixpence to my little boy, who carried it to his fatherâ€”he came back with a sixpence, and gave it meâ€”the prisoner said it I would let him go, he would make it upâ€”I pointed to the half-crown on the counter, and told him he had passed thatâ€”I sent for the officer, and give him the half-crown and sixpenceâ€”I knew the prisoner was the man that passed the half-crown directly he came into the shopâ€”I would not let my husband serve him; I served him myself, because I remembered him.

Prisoner. I was not in her shop on the Monday; I did not give the half
crown. Witness. I am sure he is the manâ€”he did not disown it when I showed it him on the counter.

JOHN EDWARD EVANS . I was in my parlour on the Mondayâ€”I could not say that the prisoner was the man that came into my shop. On the Wednesday morning I received a half-crown from my wife; it was not takenâ€”I brought it back, and gave it to my wifeâ€”it was nailed to the counterâ€”it was the same I had taken of her.
ROBERT EVANS . I got a sixpence from my mother; I gave it her back againâ€”I am sure it was the same; I had not lost sight of it.
BENJAMIN SWANSON (policeman, G 172). I took the prisoner on 23rd Nov.â€”I received this half-crown and sixpence.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These are both counterfeit.

Prisoners Defence. The first time I went into the shop was on the Thursday; I gave her a sixpence for half an ounce of tobacco; I had just taken it for carrying a parcel for a lady; I was not into the shop on the Monday; I had not a halfpenny till the Wednesday.

GUILTY . Aged 45.â€”
Confined One Year .

26.
WILLIAM BARTER was indicted
for a like offence; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

27.
JOHN RAYCRAFT, alias John North
, stealing 34lbs. weight of lead, value 5s.; the goods of
James Collins, having been before convicted.

JAMES COLLINS . I am a builder, and have some premises in King-street, Camden-townâ€”I had some lead thereâ€”I missed someâ€”this which is pro
duced is itâ€”I have compared itâ€”it is mine.

JAMES MELVIN . On 15th Oct., at half-past six o'clock in the morning, I was on the top of one of the prosecutor's buildingsâ€”I saw the prisoner removing this leadâ€”I called to him and said, "I have caught you, have I?"â€”he was about fifty yards from the building, carrying this lead before him.
Prisoner. He said, "That is the lead I saw on the top;" I said, "There it is," throwing it on one side; it was not off the premises; the other boy employed me to take it.

THOMAS CAMPION (policeman, A 358). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at Clerkenwell, by the name of John Northâ€”(read, "Convicted January, 1817, confined three months")â€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16.â€”
Confined One Year .

28.
WILLIAM CREMAR
, feloniously receiving 18 gallons of beer and 1 cask, value 14s.; also 18 gallons of beer and I cask, value 14s.; the goods of Sir
Henry Meux and another; (see vol. xxviii. page 765;) to which he pleaded

GUILTY .â€”Recommended to marcy by the Prosecutor.â€”
Confined One Year .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”The Lord Mayor; Lord Chief Justice DENMAN; Mr. Ald. GIBBS; Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq., and the Third Jury.

div1.p:
29.
HENRY MEWS
, feloniously forging and uttering a request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud "
William Holmer; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 59.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

30.
FREDERICK LINTOT and
BENJAMIN LINTOT
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles John Rigby and another, with intent to steal; to which

FREDERICK LINTOT pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

WILLIAM THOMAS BLAKE . I am shopman to Messrs. Rigby and Co., of 80, Gracechurch-street, brush-makers. We have a warehouse in Bull's Head-passage, in which brushes and articles of that kind are keptâ€”it is over a butcher's shop, occupied by Charles Lintot, the prisoners' brotherâ€”having missed brushes on several occasions, on 14th Nov. I and the officer Davis placed ourselves to watch the premises on a shelf about six feet above a hole is the boards, where we suspected an entrance had been made from the butcher's shopâ€”the board was down, so that for anybody to get in they must slide or lift it upâ€”about half-past ten o'clock I heard a noise in that direction, and noticed a part of the flooring being raisedâ€”I did not see anybody get through the hole; it was too darkâ€”Iâ€”heard a footstep go up stairsâ€”I then spoke to Davis, and got down from the shelf, and went to the holeâ€”Davis turned his light on, and I saw Benjamin Lintot with his head just above the holeâ€”Davis tried to seize him, but he dropped down, and Davis fell in trying to catch himâ€”he got up again, and followed him.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had you any means of distinctly seeing who it was at the hole? A. Noâ€”it was quite dark till Davis turned on his lightâ€”I then saw Benjamin Lintot distinctlyâ€”I had a full view of him, and have no doubt he is the person.
CHARLES JOHN RIGBY . I am in partnership with my brother. I came into the butcher's shop when I was-informed of this, and found Frederick Lintot in the custody of an officer.

Cross-examined. Q. Were either of them in your service? A. Frederick was for about four yearsâ€”I discharged him for coining late in the morningâ€”I have heard that his father was once in a large way of business.

JOHN DAVIS (City-policeman, 551). I was watching with Blakeâ€”I turned my light on a head that came up the holeâ€”it was Benjamin Lintotâ€”I got on the ladder to secure himâ€”he got down, and I got down after himâ€”the ladder moved, and I fellâ€”I went after him, and secured himâ€”he made no remarkâ€”I gave him to another man, returned, and found Frederickâ€”I afterwards searched Benjamin's premises, and found these brushesâ€”(pro
duced).
MR. RIGBY re-examined. I cannot swear to the brushesâ€”they are such as were in my warehouse.
JOSEPH PINDAR . I made these brushes for the prosecutor.

BENJAMIN LINTOTâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 32.â€”
Transported for Seven Years. (There was another indictment against the prisoners.)

31.
JONAS HAYNES was indicted
for a robbery, with violence, on
Catherine Bissett, and stealing a bag, I handkerchief, I purse, and 1 glove, value 5s.; 1 half-crown, 1 sixpence, and an order for the payment of 50l.; her property.

CATHERINE BISSETT . I am single, and live at 11, Gloucester-terrace, Kensington-gate. On the afternoon of 3rd Nov., at ten minutes before one o'clock, I was coming through Kensington-gardens, along the flower-walk, which is the most public walk in the gardens, between Mount-gate and Kensington, abutting on the park-railingsâ€”I had a reticule tied very tightly round my left wrist, containing a 50l. and a 10l. check, a half-crown, a sixpence, and a small bill of my poulterer'sâ€”there was a small alcove in the gardens, which I had passed some yardsâ€”I had not seen any one in it but a woman, whose appearance I did not likeâ€”I did not hear any footstep after passing the alcove, but I felt a tremendous blow on the right shoulder, which knocked me flat on the ground, and when I was down I saw a man, who I most solemnly declare before God, is the prisoner, stoop over meâ€”I held the reticule very tight, but after a struggle the string broke, and he got it off my wristâ€”as it was turned topsey turvey one of the checks dropped outâ€”he dropped a black glove of his own, which the park-keeper picked upâ€”I am now suffering so much from the effects of the violence, that it is with the greatest pain I give my evidenceâ€”my arm was bruised.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTONE. Q. You saw no person till you were knocked down? A. Noâ€”the blow was not sufficient to stun meâ€”I was not frightened because I have great presence of mindâ€”I was very much agitated at the thoughts of losing my moneyâ€”I did not feel the blow at all though it knocked me downâ€”I will be just to the prisoner; he did not hurt me after I was down, he only struggled to get the bagâ€”if he had wished to kill me, he might have done it in a momentâ€”the string broke in a very short timeâ€”I gave immediate information to the park-keeperâ€”I heard the prisoner was in custody when the policeman came in the evening; he asked if I was the lady that had been robbedâ€”Mr. Herries, the bankers' clerk, said they had the man in custody, and when I went to the police-office the prisoner was thereâ€”that was between two and three o'clock the next day.

MOSES BENJAMIN . I am foreman to Mr. Myers, clothier, of Wigmore-street. On Friday, 3rd Nov., about two o'clock, the prisoner came there to purchase a suit of clothesâ€”they came to 6l. I thinkâ€”he produced a 50l. check to pay for themâ€”I asked him where he got itâ€”he said his mistress had given it him in part payment for his wages, and he had to receive a certain portion, he intended to get the cheque changed, and to return the otherâ€”I was not satisfied, and called Mr. Myers, and gave him the chequeâ€”he took a cab down to St. James's, to learn something about the chequeâ€”I kept the prisoner there during that timeâ€”he was then given into custodyâ€”I noticed that he had only one glove, that was a dark oneâ€”on the following evening I found this purse under our show-board.

JAMES HANDLEY (policeman, D 199). I took the prisoner into custody at Mr. Myers' shopâ€”I asked him where he got the check fromâ€”he said he should not answer me any questionsâ€”he had only one gloveâ€”that was found in his pocketâ€”this is itâ€”the other glove was given me by the park-keeperâ€”the two correspondâ€”I also produce the purse.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he afterwards say he had picked up the check in the gardens? A. In the park.
JAMES MEEK . I am gate-keeper at Kensington-gardensâ€”I picked up the glove that has been produced, and a string of the reticule on the flower-walk.

CATHERINE BISSKTT
re-examined. This is my checkâ€”the purse is also mine, and is my sister's making.

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
Transported for Fifteen Years.
Before Lord Chief Justice Denman.

32.
THOMAS HUNT was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly utter
ing a forged 5l. Bank of England note, with intent to defraud the
Governor and Company of the Bank of England.

JOHN HITCHES . In Oct. last, I was barman at Mr. Potter's, the White Horse, High-street, Shoreditch. I usually go by the name of Georgeâ€”I had known the prisoner by sight, for about three months before 25th Oct. lastâ€”I have seen him at our house several timesâ€”on 25th Oct., I noticed him leaning against the counter there at nearly three o'clockâ€”he was in one of the boxes with which the bar is fitted upâ€”there was a man with him in the same boxâ€”they were there when I came down from dinner, and about five minutes after that the prisoner spoke to me, and said, "George I want you, I have something to show you"â€”he said that gentlyâ€”I asked him what it was, and he said it was a noteâ€”I did not see anything in his hand at the timeâ€”I asked him what it was about, if he could not read itâ€”he said it was a 5l.-note, and if I would come outside he would show it meâ€”I said, "I could not come out I had my business to attend to"â€”he then spoke to the man with him, and I afterwards explained to Mr. Potter who was in the bar what had happenedâ€”I then spoke to the prisoner again, and I asked him to give me the note, and I would take it into the yard and look at itâ€”he gave me three notes, and said, "There is three of them"â€”I took them into the yard to look at them, and called Mr. Potterâ€”I gave them into his hands, and he took the numbers of themâ€”I called them out to him one at a timeâ€”he then gave them back to me, and I put them into my pocketâ€”I returned to to the bar againâ€”the prisoner was there, and the man with himâ€”I asked the prisoner what he wanted for the notesâ€”he said I could have the three for 12l. or one for 4l.â€”I asked him where he got themâ€”the man was with him at the time, and they both answered at one time, and said, "I found them opposite Bishopsgate Church"â€”I told the prisoner that I did not want them:â€”the other man went out directly afterâ€”I asked the prisoner where he was gone to, and he said he was just gone outsideâ€”he came in again in about five minutesâ€”he went out again in two or three minutesâ€”I asked the pri
soner where he was gone, and he said he was gone to get some dinner at the cook-shopâ€”I said, "Is he not come back yet?"â€”he said, "No, I will go and fetch him if you like"â€”I said he had better not go, perhaps he would be back againâ€”I said, "I wished him to come back again before I gave him the notes"â€”the notes were quite new, clean, and folded up when the prisoner handed them to meâ€”they were much cleaner then they are nowâ€”(looking at them)â€”about ten minutes after the other man went out the second time, the policeman Taylor came in, and asked me in the prisoner's presence, if I was the young man that bad had any notes offered meâ€”I said, "Yes"â€”I had the three notes in my possession at the timeâ€”Taylor asked the prisoner if he was the man that bad offered the notesâ€”he said, "Yes," and he took him into custody, and we all three went to the stationâ€”on our way there we met police-sergeant Eves, to whom I gave the notesâ€”they had not been out of my sight since the prisoner gave them me.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What sort of a man was the man hat was with the prisoner? A. A short dark Jewish looking manâ€”the pri
soner

remained ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after he had gone awayâ€”he went out and in twiceâ€”I cannot say how long it was after that man came into the house that the policeman cameâ€”he had been there perhaps a quarter of an hour, twenty minutes, or it might be half an hour after I came down stairsâ€”I only knew the prisoner by sightâ€”I did not know his nameâ€”I do not know that his mother, or any relation nursed Mrs. Potterâ€”he has been at the house several timesâ€”I looked at them both when I asked where they got the notes, and both said they picked them upâ€”I never saw the prisoner write.

JAMES POTTER . I keep the White Horse, Shoreditch. On 25th Oct., about three o'clock in the afternoon, I observed the prisoner standing close to the counter, leaning over, as though he wanted to speak to some oneâ€”there was one man behind him, and another drinking a glass of ale at the sideâ€”thinking they were waiting to be served, I directed Ritches to serve themâ€”he said that they had been servedâ€”he came to me shortly after, and I asked what the man wanted, and he said he had some notes that he wanted to show himâ€”the prisoner could not hear thatâ€”Ritches came to me with a newspaper in his hand that the men should not think that he came to speak to me about the notesâ€”I directed him to get the notes to take the numbers, and see if they were correctâ€”he got them and showed them to me in the yard; they were perfectly newâ€”I took the numbers and dates of themâ€”these three produced are themâ€”I am in the habit of taking a great many notes, and I knew that these were not genuine by the paperâ€”in consequence of that I told Ritches to hold conversation with him privately, and not pay any attention to other customers till I went for a con
stableâ€”I told him to keep the notesâ€”I then went into the street, and observed five other persons going in and out into the bos adjoining where the prisoner was, and two or three others going into the other box, and listening over the partition to hear what passed between Ritches and the prisonerâ€”they appeared to watch to see what we determined to doâ€”I was waiting for a constable I had sent forâ€”Taylor came, and I communicated the circum
stances to him, and pointed out the other persons to him, but he did not seem to take so much interest in the matter as I considered he would have doneâ€”I afterwards directed him to take the prisoner into custodyâ€”the other man came out of the door as I was speaking to Taylor.

HENRY TAYLOR (policeman, H 91). On 25th Oct. last I went to the White Horseâ€”I went into a private box, and asked Ritches, in the prisoner's hearing, if he bad had any notes offered to himâ€”he said, "Yes," and pointed out the prisoner as the man that offered themâ€”the prisoner said he found them opposite Bishopsgate Church, and not knowing what they were, he came to George the barman, to ask what they were as he could not read or writeâ€”it had been wet that morning, but at that time it was very clean and dry.

JAMES EVES (police-sergeant, H 14). On 25th Oct. I met Taylor in Shoreditch with the prisoner in custodyâ€”Ritches was walking behind, and handed me three notesâ€”I took them to the Bauk, and delivered them to Mr. Higmanâ€”Mr. Pearson, a clerk at the Bank afterwards returned them to me stampedâ€”I kept them in my possession till I took them to the police-courtâ€”they were then taken possession of by Mr. Freemanâ€”I asked the prisoner his addressâ€”he gave it, "Thomas Hunt, at Mr. Dixon's, across the ruins, Crabtree-row, Hackney-road"â€”I asked him where he got the notesâ€”he said he found them opposite Bishopsgate Church, and a man who had the appear
ance of a Jew saw him pick them up, and wanted themâ€”he did not let the man have them, but they went to the White Horse and had a pint of beer.
WILLIAM HIGMAN . I am a clerk, in the Bank of England. On 25th Oct. I received three 5l.-notes from Evesâ€”I gave them to Mr. Savage, the inspector.
JOSEPH SAVAGE . I am a clerk in the Bank of England. On 25th Oct. I received three 5l.-notes from Mr. Higmanâ€”I gave them to Mr. Pearson, another clerk.

MR. PEARSON. I am a clerk in the Bank of England. On 25th Oct. I received three 5l.-notes from Mr. Savageâ€”I indorsed them with my name and the dateâ€”these are them (produced)â€”I immediately went and got the stamp "forged," and returned them to Eves.

JOSHUA FREEMAN . I am inspector of notes at the Bank of England. I have seen and examined these notes; they are forgeries; they are not all from the same plateâ€”there is no water-markâ€”there is an attempt to give it by pressure.
Cross-examined. Q. Are they very well done? A. Very fairlyâ€”an ignorant person, not skilful in notes, might be deceived by them.

GEORGE TEAKLE (policeman, H 8). I went, four, five, or six times, to the residence of a person named Dixon, 9, Greengate-gardens, Hackney-road; it is opposite Crabtree-row, Hackney-road, across the ruinsâ€”I never saw the prisoner thereâ€”I know a person named George Hunt; I subpoened him as a witnessâ€”he was here this morning; I missed him about three minutes after I saw him hereâ€”I have since been after him to his house, and to every house in the neighbourhood, and have not been able to find him.

COURT to JOHN RITCHES. Q. Did the prisoner at any time tell you he could not read or write, and want you to explain the notes to him? A. No, he did not apply to me for any information on that subjectâ€”he said nothing about having found them until I asked him.

(The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate teas read by consent as follows:â€”"I am a weaver by trade, sir; I have not followed it up for eight years, come Christmas; it was so bad I could not get a living by it. I am a labouring man, sir, and now work on the Quay, in Thames-street, by the water-side. Coming home from my labour, opposite Bishopsgate Church, sir, I picks up these papers, sir, folded up. A Jew comes up to me, sir, immediately, and says, 'What have you got there?' I says, 'I don't know, being no scholar.' He says, 'Let me look.' I unfolds them, and lets him look. He says, 'Where are you going?' I says, 'To Mr. Cotter's, and there I shall hear what they are.'I goes in, he follows me, and calls for a pint of porter. He says, 'Drink.' I says, 'No, you are a stranger to me.' I says, 'George, will you look at these for me, being no scholar?' He says, 'They are three 5l.-notes;' he says, 'What do you want for them?' The Jew says, 'Ask him 12l.; however, he took them. I sees no more of him; George, I mean. While the prosecutor was gone with them the Jew says, 'I am going to my dinner, a door or two off, at the cook's-shop.'I waited there nearly three-quarters of an hour from the time I first went in. He never came back again no more. I still staid there till Mr. Potter and the policeman came in, and I have no more to say.")

GUILTY . Aged 32.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

33.
JOHN ATKINS, alias William Granger
, uttering counterfeit coin having been before convicted.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant-solicitor to the Mint. I pro
duce
a copy of the record of the conviction of John Atkins, at tin's Court, in Dec. Session, 1839â€”I have examined it with the original, in Mr. Clark's office; it is a true copyâ€”(read.)
WILLIAM WILSHIRE (policeman, K 249). I was present at the prisoner's trialâ€”he is the same manâ€”he pleaded guilty, and had six months.

GEORGE BAKER . I am a cheesemonger, at King David-street, Shad-well. On 18th Oct. I came home, and found there had been a bad shilling passed at my shopâ€”on the 19th the prisoner came and asked for 3d.-worth of bacon, and paid me with a bad shillingâ€”I observed it was of the same stamp as that which had been passed the day previousâ€”I said nothing about it, but gave him the changeâ€”I marked the shilling, and put it into my cash-box, with a piece of paper, separate from any other coinâ€”he came again on the 21st, between five and six o'clockâ€”he took up a piece of meat, and put it into my scale, and gave me another bad shilling of the same stamp as the two othersâ€”I could not give him in charge, as I was busy in my businessâ€”I said, "It is a bad shilling"â€”he said, "Is it?"â€”I said, "You know that it is," and he took up the shilling and went awayâ€”on Monday, the 23rd, he came again, and another person with himâ€”he took up some meat, the same as he had done before; it came to 3 1/2 d.â€”he tendered me half-a-crownâ€”I observed it was badâ€”I pulled out the till, and said, "I have no silver here, I must go to my other counter; but instead of that I slipped round to himâ€”the other one went awayâ€”the prisoner said, "Do not you like my half-crown?"â€”I said, "No, nor you either"â€”he got awayâ€”I pursued him for 300 yards, till I got him into a dark cornerâ€”he turned sharp round, to hit at me, but he fell right into my arms, and I seized him by the throat, and took him to the stationâ€”I delivered the half-crown and the 2s. to the sergeant.

GEORGE HOGSTON (policeman, K 205). Baker gave the prisoner into my custody at the stationâ€”he said he knew of the half-crown, but he knew nothing of the 2s.â€”while the half-crown and 2s. were lying at the station, before the charge was taken, he made a grab at the 2s.â€”the sergeant caught hold of one hand, Mr. Baker of the other, and I caught him by the throatâ€”I did not know at the time whether he had got them or not, but he had notâ€”these are them, and the half-crown also (produced.)
MR. POWELL re-examined. The 2s. and half-crown are all counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 50.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

34.
FREDERICK HERBERT
, feloniously forging and uttering an order for payment of 6l., with intent to defraud
John Leadbeater: also an order for payment of 14l., with intent to defraud
John Simpson: also an order for payment of 1l. 5s., with intent to defraud
John Coffin; to all of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 35.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

35.
THOMAS JOHNSON and
MARY ANN EKE
, for a robbery on
Allen Hembrow, and stealing 1 watch, value 2l. 18s., his goods.

ALLEN HEMBROW . I live at Devenport-mews, Bayswater, and am a groom out of a situation. About eight in the evening of 30th Oct. I was with a friend in Westminster, and met a young woman called Emma; I do not know her other nameâ€”I went with her to No. 1, Duck-lane, Westminster, and had some gin and beer with her and Ekeâ€”while there I missed a handkerchief out of my coat-pocket, but I did not take any particular notice of

thatâ€”Eke went out of the room three or four times while I was thereâ€”after she came in the last time the prisoner Johnson and a boy came inâ€”Eke asked me in Johnson's presence to stand some drinkâ€”there was no light in the room at that timeâ€”there had been a candle, but it was outâ€”there was no fireâ€”I told my friend I had no more money, and asked him to go out and fetch some drinkâ€”he wentâ€”the prisoners remained in the roomâ€”Eke came and caught hold of my left arm and felt meâ€”I thought she was after my watch, and I broke my guard and put the watch into my right hand coat-pocket, keeping it in my handâ€”she said to Johnson, "Tom, the watch is in his coat-pocket"â€”I immediately took it out and put it into my right trowsers-pocketâ€”Johnson came up and tore my pocketâ€”he got hold of my handâ€”I bit Eke's fingers as she had got hold of my left armâ€”Johnson bit my thumb and made me leave go of my watch, and got it away after twisting me about the roomâ€”the seals were broken off, and fell on the floorâ€”he escaped with the watchâ€”Eke pulled me back on the bed and held me there till the man escapedâ€”she then escaped herselfâ€”I locked the door till the policeman came, and called, "Police!" and "Murder!"â€”when the policeman came I saw him pick up the seals close against the door and the guard at the other end of the roomâ€”I was soberâ€”I know Johnson to be the man.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENJDERGAST. Q. During the greater part of the time, as I understand, you were in the dark? A. We were, nearly all the timeâ€”I went to the house about eight o'clock, and this happened about half-past elevenâ€”I did not see Johnson again till the following Thursdayâ€”he left his hat in the roomâ€”it was knocked off in the scuffleâ€”I afterwards saw it on. Johnson's headâ€”it did not come over his eyes or appear too large for himâ€”I had never seen him before the night of the robbery.

MR. PAYNE. Q. How long was he in the room altogether with you? A. About ten minutesâ€”I recognised him again immediately I saw him on the Thursdayâ€”there was no light in the room while he was in it; but a light shone in at the window full on his face, and I can swear to him.

Eke. Q. You said the man that did the robbery had whiskers? A. No I did notâ€”I did not send you out for aleâ€”you were on the bed with meâ€”I lighted the candle three or four times, and as fast as I lighted it you blew it outâ€”I bit your finger while you held my armâ€”I did not pinch it in your trying to get in at the doorâ€”I was never in the house beforeâ€”my friend has been thereâ€”I have seen you once or twice before at the Queen's Head.

WILLIAM KNEEBONE TRIBBLECOCK . I am a carpenter, and live in Edward-street, Dorset-square. I was with Hembrow on the evening of 30th Oct., about eight o'clock, and met a female called Emma, who lives with Ekeâ€”I went with her to 1, Duck-lane, and there saw Ekeâ€”we remained there till nearly elevenâ€”a knock cameâ€”to the door while I was in the room, and a man and a boy came inâ€”they remained about two or three minutesâ€”I then went out for some aleâ€”I had not been gone two or three minutes when I heard my friend hallooing "Murder!" and "Police!"â€”I got a policeman and went with him back to the house in about five minutes after I had left itâ€”the man and boy were then goneâ€”we found Eke thereâ€”I could not recog
nise the features of the man that was in the roomâ€”it was in the darkâ€”I know that Hembrow had his watch when he went into the house.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you knew this girl's friend very well? A. Not longâ€”I had seen her several times before, and my friend knew her by seeing her at Paddingtonâ€”I saw the hat foundâ€”I did not see it put on John
sonâ€”I thought the man that was in the room was taller than Johnsonâ€”I do not believe Johnson is the man.
Eke. Q. You have known me a long time, and have come to see me ever since I left service? Witness. I have know you a good while, and never knew anything against your honesty before.

RICHARD COUSINS (policeman, B 30). About eleven o'clock on the night of 30th Oct., I was in Peter-street, and heard cries of "Police!" and "Murder!"â€”I went to 1, Duck-lane and met Eke at the doorâ€”she said, "I think you are wanted up-stairs"â€”I said, "You had better accompany me, as it is in your own room"â€”we went upâ€”the door was fastenedâ€”I knocked, and on my saying "Police," it was opened, and the prosecutor was insideâ€”when he saw Eke he said, "I shall give her in charge for stealing my watch"â€”she said, "D----you, you have bit my finger, and that is quite sufficient"â€”I found a key, seal, this little strap, and a foreign piece, close to the door, and this guard near the windowâ€”the carpets were turned upside down and the poker lying in the middle of the room.

MARK LOOME (police-sergeant, B 11). From information I received, I went in search of Johnson on Thursday, 2nd Nov., and found him at the White Horse, Orchard-street, Westminster, with ten or twelve others, several of whom I knewâ€”I called him out of the tap-room, and told him he was charged, with a female, with stealing a watch from 1, Duck-laneâ€”he said he knew nothing about it, it was dâ€”d hard to suffer for other peopleâ€”I think he said he had not been to the house where the robbery was committed since Sundayâ€”I had seen him beforeâ€”he is called Tomâ€”I have never seen him with whiskersâ€”another man has been apprehended sinceâ€”both the prisoners said that was the personâ€”I believe his name is Tom, but as soon as the pro
secutor saw him he said he was not the manâ€”he had very small whiskersâ€”I am not aware that he lived in the house; Johnson's brother did.

ALLEN HEMBROW
re-examined. I have seen the other man that has been taken upâ€”it was not him that robbed meâ€”it was Johnson.

Eke's Defence. At the time the policeman met me I had come from the back parlour, hearing some one run down stairs; the policeman said, "What is the matter, Poll?" I said, "You are wanted up stairs;" I went up with him, and the prosecutor said to me, "I know you have sent the men up to rob me;" I know the man that had the watch, he lived in the next room to me; I was not in the room at the time the robbery was committed; it was all done in a minute; Johnson was never in my room; a person came to me at the House of Detention, and said that the man who lived in the next room to me had the watch; I wanted it to be returned; I have known the prosecutor since I left service; he says he was never in the house before, but I have a witness to prove he has repeatedly visited me on a Sun
day evening, and that I was in the parlour when the robbery happened.

CHARLES MOODY . I have not seen Hembrow at the house, but I have seen Tribblecock there several timesâ€”the prosecutor described to me the man that had robbed him as having sandy whiskers, and said that he lived up stairs, and he had drunk with him on another occasion in the roomâ€”I do not keep the house nowâ€”I gave it up on account of this occurrenceâ€”only two unfortunate women lived there.
MRS. TATE. Eke did not come into my parlour on the night of the robbery, to my knowledge.

EKEâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 20.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

JOHNSONâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

36.
ELIZABETH ROGERS,
ISABELLA JENNINGS , and
JOHN JENNINGS
, stealing 1 coffce-pot, 1 tea-pot, 24 forks, 2 soup-ladles, and other articles, value 150l., the goods of
Cranstoun George Ridout, the master of Rogers, in his dwelling-house.

CRANSTOUN GEORGE RIDOUT , Esq. I have been in the army, but have retired, and live at 11, Wimpole-street, Marylebone; Rogers was my housemaid. On 29th Aug. I left town, leaving her alone in charge of the houseâ€”my wife and family had left on the 9thâ€”the day before I left, I gave Rogers directions what to do in my absence, and wrote it down, and read it over to herâ€”on. 23rd Oct. I received information, came to town at eleven o'clock at night, and found Rogers alone in the houseâ€”I went up to my bed-room, and found a closet on the landing, where plate, linen, and valuables were kept, wide open, and the ground covered with things which had been taken out of itâ€”I had left it locked, and also my wardrobe and drawersâ€”I found them openâ€”Sergeant Harris came to the house with me, and I missed a silver tea-pot, coffee-pot, twenty-four silver forks, a quantity of linen, and a great many other things, amounting to nearly 200l.â€”I do not know the Jennings'sâ€”I never gave them leave to come to the houseâ€”Rogers had a married sister, and I said, "I will allow you to see your sister, Mrs. Osborne"â€”this is my plate (produced), and this is my daughter's box; it was in her room up stairs, and is broken open.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long had Rogers been in your service? A. Since 27th July, 1847â€”I left her in charge of the house that year, from Aug. to Oct., and left the plate in the closetâ€”I understand Jennings is her sister.

JOHN STICKLEY . I am page to Mr. Ridout. On 26th May last I went to the plate-closet with Rogersâ€”a tea-pot and other things were taken out, which would enable her to know there was plate thereâ€”the family left town on Aug. 9thâ€”the day before that, Mrs. Ridout packed the plate upâ€”Rogers came down, and said, "Mistress is up stairs, packing away the plate; I suppose she is going away to-morrow"â€”my master remained till the 29thâ€”I went away with him, leaving Rogers in the houseâ€”she slept at the top of the house, above the plate-closet.

LOUIS FEZER . I am butler to Mr. Chalon, of 10, Wimpole-street, next door to Mr. Ridout's. On 22nd Sept. I saw a cab at his door, about half-past nine o'clock at nightâ€”I saw two or three bundles put into it by the two female prisonersâ€”Rogers put the lastinâ€”there was a young man there whom I did not knowâ€”I have seen John Jennings go in and out of the house several timesâ€”the two women went away in the cab, and the man outsideâ€”in about half an hour I heard the door open.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you near enough to see the bundles? A. Yesâ€”it appeared like linenâ€”I had seen Isabella Jennings go in many times, but never with any bundles.

CHARLES RUTTERFORD . I am a carpenter, of East-street, Manchester-square. The two Jennings's lodged with meâ€”Rogers took the lodging for themâ€”she came on 22nd with another person and a child, and boxes and bundlesâ€”I helped to carry them up stairsâ€”one was heavyâ€”they appeared to be clothes or linen.

Cross-examined. Q. Was Jennings far advanced in the family-way? A. I did not see her at first; she was afterwardsâ€”on the Sunday after, she was confinedâ€”they were taken at my houseâ€”they sent for their thingsâ€”I saw that part of them were baby linen and female apparel.

CHARLES CROSBY . I am assistant to Miss Fleming, pawnbroker, of Farring
don-street. I produce four table-forks, four dessert-forks, six dessert-spoons,
our ten-spoons, a pair of sugar-tongs, and four ladles, pledged on 22nd Sept., or 9l., by Isabella Jennings, in the name of Ann Smith, for Amelia Green.
Isabella Jennings. Q. Was I in the family-way? A. I did not see; you had a cloak onâ€”I have no doubt of you.

JOSEPH AVANT . I am manager to Mr. Grey, a pawnbroker, of Fleet-street. I produce two gravy and four table-spoons, pledged on 22nd Sept., about seven o'clock in the evening, in the name of Amelia Greenwood, 24, Hackney-road, for 5l., by a respectable female, named Elizabeth Smith, not either of the prisoners.

CHARLES OSBORNE . I am married to Rosrers's sister. On 24th Oct. Jennings came to me, and asked me to lend him a great-coat and a pair of bootsâ€”he said he would bring them back in an hour or an hour and a halfâ€”I lent him themâ€”it was after Mrs. Jennings was in custodyâ€”he said he was afraid the pawnbroker would identify his wife; that he was the person who had stolen the plate, at two different times, and this was a part of the plate he had given his wife to pledge, part to another party, and the other part he had taken away and buriedâ€”I asked where he buried itâ€”he said he would not tell me, unless he was taken into custody, and then he would tell me, to pay for Counselâ€”he went away with my coat and boots, and did not come back, as I gave information, and he was takenâ€”I saw him at the station, and asked him what he had done with the plate he had buriedâ€”he said his brother Ben had got it; he had not seen anything of him sinceâ€”I asked where he wasâ€”he said he thought he was at Windsorâ€”I asked what he had done with the money from the plate he had first stolenâ€”he said he had thrown it down the water-closetâ€”the water-closetâ€”was searched, but no money foundâ€”he said a flash girl had pawned the other part of the property.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he say anything about Rogers? A. That she did not know anything of the robbery, that she was out when his wife let him in, and he concealed himself in the houseâ€”Rogers and Jennings, and my wife, are sistersâ€”it was my wife who Mr. Ridout had no objection to coming to the houseâ€”she went, but was not able to stay, as she had her shop to attend to.

THOMAS HILL (policeman, D 80). On Monday morning, 2nd Oct., I was on duty near Mr. Ridout's about twenty minutes past seven o'clockâ€”Rogers came to me, and said she had been up to see what time it was, and found two doors open, and she fancied some one was in the houseâ€”I went with her, searched, but found nobodyâ€”I found one shutter of the dining-room open, and the place in a confused stateâ€”the cheffionier-drawers were open, the drawing-room was rather confused, and a drawer was open thereâ€”I asked the prisoner if she missed anythingâ€”she said she did notâ€”I went into the back-room, and found it rather confusedâ€”I found a cupboard on the next floor broken open, and the plate-basket and a box standing outside with nothing in itâ€”I asked Rogers if she knew whether there was any plate in itâ€”she said she did notâ€”I went into a bed-room on the same floor, and found the ward
robe-drawers openâ€”on the next floor a box was standing open on a table, with the lock attached to the lidâ€”I said, "It is a very bad job"â€”Rogers made no answerâ€”I went with her into the parlour, and found a cupboard openâ€”the housekeeper's room-door was shut, but it had been broken openâ€”I took hold of the lock of the wine-cellar, and it came off in my handâ€”the door was closedâ€”I got through the dining-room window, which was open, and went across the loads through a door which led into a stable in Harley
mewsâ€”the door was on the latchâ€”a piece was broken off another door between the stable and the leadsâ€”it appeared to have been done some timeâ€”

I found a piece of iron between the two doorsâ€”I fetched Sergeant Mark
wick, returned, and Rogers was still thereâ€”she did not complain to me of missing anything.

JAMES HANDLE (policeman, D 199). On Sunday night, 1st Oct., about eight o'clock, I went on duty in Wimpole-streetâ€”I went into Harley-mewsâ€”the stable-doors of Wimpole-street are thereâ€”I tried Mr. Ridout's stable-doorâ€”it was fastâ€”I always make a mark when stables are to let, and I marked this and the next oneâ€”that enabled me to tell whether it was opened or notâ€”I saw it every ten minutes during the night, and tried itâ€”the last time was at five minutes past four, when I removed my markâ€”it was fast thenâ€”in the morning, between eleven and twelve, I went to the house, and saw Rogersâ€”I asked her how long it was since she was over the whole of the houseâ€”she said, "Four or five days"â€”I said, "That is strange"â€”I asked if she had the key of the stablesâ€”she said she had, and Mr. Puttick also had one, and he had told her to leave the stable-door openâ€”I believe he is the house-agentâ€”I said, "The stable-door was fast during the night, and when I went off my beat in the morning"â€”I do not think she made any answerâ€”we went into the dining-roomâ€”I asked when she was in that roomâ€”she said when she went over the houseâ€”I said I had seen her standing at the door with femalesâ€”she said it was her sisterâ€”I asked her two or three times if there was any plate missingâ€”she said she did not knowâ€”I asked if she knew if there was any in the houseâ€”she said she did not know.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she say her sister had come there, as she was afraid of being in the house alone? A. I will not swear she did not.

THOMAS LINSCOTT . I manage Miss Fleming's business, at Farringdon-street. I recollect these spoons and forks being brought by Isabella Jen
ningsâ€”I have no doubt of her.
Jennings. Q. Did you think I was in the family-way? A. Noâ€”you had a cloak on.

JOSEPH PRICE (policeman, D 240). On 2nd Oct. I was left in charge of 11, Wimpole-street, from nine o'clock in the morning till between five and sixâ€”in a closet where they said the plate was, I found a silver cream-jugâ€”I asked Rogers if she knew if the plate was left at homeâ€”she said she did notâ€”I asked if she had had any one in the houseâ€”she said only her sister, named Jennings, who lived in East-streetâ€”I said, "Was her husband here?"â€”she said, "No, he has been to the door, but has not been inside."
Cross-examined. Q. Have you got the written directions? A. Yesâ€”(produced)â€”I found them in a box, which Rogers said was hers.

THOMAS HARRISSON (police-sergeant, D 14). I went to the house with Super-intendent Hughes, and asked Rogers who she had had in the house with herâ€”she said no one but her sisterâ€”I asked if her sister was married or singleâ€”she said, "Married"â€”I asked what her husband wasâ€”she said a servant out of place, that he had been at the door, but had never been in, that her sister lived at 24, East-streetâ€”I went there, and saw Mrs. Jennings and another personâ€”while I was there Jennings came homeâ€”I said, "I suppose you have heard what has occurred at your sister's master's"â€”he said, "I have heard something about it"â€”I said, "Have you any objection to go to Mr. Ridout's?"â€”â€”he said, "No"â€”I asked Mrs. Jennings what she brought there on Friday nightâ€”she said only her own clothes and some baby-linenâ€”I found several bundles of women's and children's linenâ€”I took Jennings to the houseâ€”Mr. Ridout and Rogers were thereâ€”I took Rogers and Jennings to the stationâ€”I found two iron skewers in the kitchenâ€”one was bent, which attracted my attentionâ€”I fitted them to some marks on this box of Miss Ridout's, and to

the plate-closet doorâ€”they would make such marksâ€”on 4th Oct. I went to Jennings's placeâ€”he was not at homeâ€”I went next morning, and he came while I was thereâ€”he said he had been at his father's, at Walthamstow.
MR. RIDOUT re-examined. These things are all mineâ€”these two table-cloths are very remarkableâ€”they cost eight guineas eachâ€”this box is my daughter's.

(Henry Stonor, Esq., barrister, 4, New Boswell-court, deposed to Rogers's good character, and Jane Williams to that of Rogers and Isabella Jennings.) ROGERSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 26: ISABELLA JENNINGSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 30.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Jury, be
lieving them to be influenced by John Jennings in the commis
sion. of the act.

JOHN JENNINGSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 23.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Sir CHAPMAN, MARSHALL, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Fifth Jury.

div1.p:
37.
JOHN BURROWS
, stealing 6 engraved plates, value 19l.; the goods of
Henry Titford, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 12.â€”
Confined Ten Days, Solitary, and
Whipped.

38.
WILLIAM MORRELL was indicted
for breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Freemantle, and stealing 1 coat, 2 pairs of trowsers, and other articles, value 10l., his goods; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . * Aged 18.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

39.
MARIA BORREMAN
, stealing 192 yards of ribbon, and other articles, value 20l., the goods of
Edward Wason Freestone, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

40.
THOMAS JACKSON,
ANN KELLY , and
GEORGE MASON
, stealing 120 yards of calico, value 25s., the goods of
William Satterley Baw
don and another; to which

MASON pleaded
GUILTY . â€ Aged 23.â€”
Transported for Seven Years ,
