JOHN NORBURN . I am assistant to William Satterly Bawdon. On 25th Oct. I missed a quantity of calico from outside the doorâ€”this is it (produced)â€”it is my master's.
JAMES BROOKS . I am fourteen years oldâ€”I saw the prisonersâ€”Mason had the calico, walking towards the Birdcageâ€”I pulled it from under his armâ€”the others had loft then.
Cross-examined by Mr. Horry. Q. Was not Kelley some distance behind? A. About three yards.

----GLASGON. I saw Kelley and Mason in Birdcage-walk two or three turnings, from Mr. Bawdon'sâ€”Mason had a piece of calico under each armâ€”Mason dropped one piece, Kelley picked it up and gave it himâ€”Jackson was not there then.
EDWARD SMITH (policeman, N 193). I was in York-street, Hackney-road,

and saw Mason in a milkman's chargeâ€”I took himâ€”he was very violentâ€”Jackson came up, caught hold of me, and tried to rescue himâ€”after a great deal of difficulty, with the assistance of other constables, we took them both.
Jackson. I did not try to rescue him? Witness. You pulled him away, and kicked me several times.
Jackson's Defence. The policeman knew I had been convicted before, and said he would take me, as he knew me, and knew me to be a relation of Mason, but I am not.

JACKSON and KELLYâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

41.
HENRY MORITZ GOLDSCHMIDT
, feloniously forging and utter
ing an order for the payment of 21l. 105., with intent to defraud Frederick Grafton. The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

42.
MATTHEW RIELLY
, feloniously breaking and entering the counting-honse of
Frederick Good Wadham, and stealing 1 clock, 1 pair trowsers, and other articles, value 6l. 19s.; his property: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . *â€ Aged 26.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

43.
THOMAS CARNEY
, stealing 64lbs. weight of pork, value 30s.; the goods of
Richard Tarrant Broome, his master.

RICHARD TARRANT BROOME . I am a meat-salesman, of Newgate-streetâ€”the prisoner was occasionally employed by me. On 18th Nov. I ought to have received eight pigs from Mr. Whistler, of Thetford, and the prisoner told me they had comeâ€”I missed one in the afternoonâ€”they were peculiarly dressedâ€”they always have their fore feet cut offâ€”I received other pigs that morning, but none dressed that wayâ€”on the next Tuesday I recognized one of them at Mr. Duckworth's, in Newgate-market.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Is Mr. Whistler here? A. Noâ€”he would not know the pigâ€”I saw five or six of the pigs that Cameâ€”the prisoner calls everything over to me, and I book itâ€”I have booked eight, and only found sevenâ€”they were outside in the street in hampers, tied downâ€”some time after they arrived, the prisoner cut the basket open to get them outâ€”I only paid Mr. Whistler for seven, not knowing the weight of the missing one.

CHARLES HART . I am Mr. Broom's foreman. On 18th Nov., about eight o'clock in the moving, I received two hampers from Mr. Whistler, with four pigs in eachâ€”I ordered the prisoner to cut the string and take them outâ€”he did soâ€”they had the fore feet cut offâ€”the prisoner asked to go out about eight, and was gone four or five minutes.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not that a common thing for him to do? A. Occasionallyâ€”I did not see him goâ€”he did not go directlyâ€”there were a great many persons in Newgate-streetâ€”it was just getting lightâ€”there were three other men employedâ€”I sold all the pigs that came that morningâ€”I did not sell these eight.

GEORGE WELLS . I am scale-man to Mr. Duckworth, of Newgate-street. On 18th Nov. the prisoner came with a pig, and said, "George, will you book a pig in the name of Steel?"â€”I did soâ€”it had the fore feet offâ€”I asked him where Mr. Steel livedâ€”he said, "Holloway, Highgate, or somewhere there"â€”he afterwards came back and asked for the porterageâ€”the clerk paid him 2d.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever hear anything against him before?
A. Noâ€”I have known him many yearsâ€”I saw no pigs that day dressed like this.
JOHN CRAYDON . I am a general dealer, in Tothill-street, Westminster. I have known the prisoner some time, and know his writingâ€”this note is his writing.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it exactly his writing? A. There may be a little differenceâ€”the prisoner has embezzled 20l. worth of property of mine, ten or eleven weeks agoâ€”there is a great dispute between usâ€”(note readâ€”"Nov. 18, 1848. Sir, please let bearer have the account of the pig sent on Saturday.")
WILLIAM CHARLES NORMAN . I am a dairyman, of Vauxhall-walk. I know the prisoner, and can swear to his writingâ€”I have no doubt this note is his.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen him write? A. Scores of times?
(The prisoner received a good character).

GUILTY . Aged 25.â€”
Confined Six Months.

44.
MARY ANN HART and
ELIZABETH HARRIS
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d., 4 sovereigns, and 8 5l. notes; the property of
Thomas Browett, from his person.

THOMAS BROWETT . I am a solicitorâ€”I was stopping at the George Inn, Aldermanbury. On the night of 14th Nov. I was going home, about ten minutes past one o'clockâ€”I turned up a court, the prisoners came one on each side of me, and threw their arms round me, left me in an instant, and I missed my purse from my right waistcoat-pocketâ€”the prisoners were only five yards offâ€”I laid hold of them, and charged them with itâ€”they said I had dropped itâ€”a policeman cameâ€”I laid hold of the shawl of one of themâ€”the purse fell on the ground, and the money fell outâ€”it contained three 5l. notes, two checks, and 4l. 10s.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were you sober? A. Perfectlyâ€”they were not with me half a minuteâ€”I never said I did not know whether I dropped it myselfâ€”I did not feel the purse goâ€”before the policeman came I offered them a guinea to restore itâ€”I proposed no settlement after I saw the policeman.
JOHN MYERS (City-policeman, 158). I saw Bowett holding the prisonersâ€”I laid hold of Hart, turned her shawl up, lifted up her arm, and the purse fell from under it.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure it did not fall from bis pocket? A. Quite.

HARTâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”HARRISâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined Four Months.

45.
GEORGE JONES
, stealing 1 bag, value 6d., 7 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, 3 shillings, 1 5l.-note, and an order for payment of 5l. 16s., 7d.; the property of
James Reynolds, from his person.

JAMES REYNOLDS . I come from Readingâ€”on 9th Nov. I employed the prisoner to row me from Blackfriars to Westminster-bridge and backâ€”I drank with himâ€”he followed me to Farringdon-street, and I gave him a glass of ginâ€”I had about 20l. in my left-hand coat-pocketâ€”I kept my hand on itâ€”it went while I was drinking the gin, and the prisoner ran awayâ€”he was taken next dayâ€”I am sure of him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was the house full? A. There was no one thereâ€”I did not go back to the house or complain there of having been robbedâ€”I ran to stop the checkâ€”I had drunk very littleâ€”I offered to pay

the fare, but the young man with him would not accept of it as I had treated themâ€”then the prisoner came and asked me for it, and I gave him some more drinkâ€”the street was full of people when I followed him outâ€”his brother who rowed the boat with him gave me his address writtenâ€”I gave it to the policeman.
HENRY JOSEPH KING (Thames-policeman). I took the prisoner at Wapping.
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. Many yearsâ€”I never knew anything against his characterâ€”this paper enabled me to find him out.

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined Six Months.

46.
JAMES HOWES
, stealing 2l. yards of lace, and 3 dozen of tufts, value 10s. 6d.; the goods of the
Great Western Railway Company, bis masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 30.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

47.
JEREMIAH BUCK
, stealing 1 ream of paper, value 16s.; the goods of
Charles James Jeffries; and
JOHN HUDDERT
, feloniously receiving the same.

CHARLES JAMES JEFFRIES . I am a music publisher. On 4th Nov. Buck, who was porter to my printer, came to my houseâ€”I watched himâ€”he went out with two reams of music paper on his shoulderâ€”I crossed over to the railing in Sobo-squareâ€”he looked back to my shop several timesâ€”he turned down an archwayâ€”I went on to his masters and waited till he cameâ€”I opened the door to himâ€”he had only one ream of paperâ€”I said, "What have you done with the other ream?"â€”he said he had dropped it in the mud and would go back and find itâ€”I said, "No, it is not likely; you will come in and tell me what you have done with it"â€”he said,â€”"Pray have mercy on me?"â€”I said, "Tell me what you have done with it?"â€”he hesitated a good while, and at last agreed to take me to where he left itâ€”he took me to a grocer's shop in Crown-street, kept by Huddertâ€”I said to Huddert, "Do you know this man?"â€”he said, "Yes; I have bought a small quantity of paper of him"â€”I said, "Where is it?"â€”he said, "I have not paid for it"â€”he threw it down, and said, "There it is"â€”I called a policeman, and the prisoners were taken to the stationâ€”we came back to the house and found a quantity of paper which I believe to be mineâ€”it has been made up into bagsâ€”it is music paper, not grocer's paperâ€”I was a good deal excited.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You were in a very great passion? A. Noâ€”I know this ream by the Government stamp on itâ€”this other paper I believe to be mineâ€”it is made on purpose for musicâ€”I never saw it used for any other purposeâ€”this portrait of Jenny Lind I swear to (pointing to it) it was hanging up in Huddert's shop-parlourâ€”an artist, named Taft, went by my desire to the Opera to take it for meâ€”I have sold thousands of themâ€”I cannot swear that this was not sold.
JOSEPH BARK (policeman, F 124). I went to Huddert's shop with Mr. Jeffriesâ€”I found these paper bagsâ€”on the way to the station he said, "The b----y b----r for getting me into such a mess as this."

Buck's Defence. I had not the means of living, and was compelled to ob
tain two reams instead of one which I was sent for; I asked for permission to leave it at Mr. Huddert's for a little time; I had not determined what to do with it.

MARY ANN SCOTT . I am a widow, and live at 32, Crown-street On 4th Nov. I was in Huddert's shopâ€”a man came in with two pieces of paperâ€”he threw one by the side of the canisterâ€”he said, "Let me leave this

here for a few moments"â€”there was a little child who was likely to tumble over it, and I threw it between a canister and a millâ€”I do not know Hud-dart, but I saw an account of this in the newspaper, and came forward.

JOSEPH CLARK . I am a grocer, of Broadway, Westminster. I have know Hud
dart about two yearsâ€”he was in my employ as shopman about twelve monthsâ€”he conducted himself in the most satisfactory manner, and left me to set up in businessâ€”this is the same sort of paper as we use in our businessâ€”I have a quantity of itâ€”he has bought paper of meâ€”this other sort we use for some purposesâ€”we give 27s. per cwt. for paper for bagsâ€”I had a very excellent character with him.

BUCKâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 48.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.â€”
Confined Three Months.

HUDDERTâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

48.
WILLIAM CLEAVER was indicted
for unlawfully uttering coun
terfeit coin.

JOSHUA BURTON . I live in Great Turnstile. On 16th Nov., the prisoner came and asked for a pieâ€”it came to 1d.â€”he gave me a shillingâ€”I gave him changeâ€”he went awayâ€”I found the shilling was bad, marked it, and kept it apart from other coinâ€”on 20th Nov. the prisoner came for another articleâ€”he paid me a shilling, I saw it was bad, and said, "How many more are you going to bring me of this kind"â€”he said he did not know it was badâ€”I gave him into custodyâ€”I gave the policeman the two shillings.
ALFRED BARRS (police-sergeant, F 19). I took the prisoner, and have the two shillingsâ€”he gave me a false address.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mintâ€”these shillings are both counterfeit.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined One Month

49.
THOMAS FOWKE was indicted
for unlawfully breaking open a desk in the counting-house of
George Ratcliffe, with intent to steal; to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
To appear for Judgment when called upon.

50.
SAMUEL BROADLEY,
THOMAS YARMOUTH , and
WILLIAM SKINNER,
stealing 6 gallons of wine, 36 bottles, and 1 basket, value 6l. 7s.; the goods of
Daniel Harts; to which

*BROADLEY pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 23.

*YARMOUTH pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 21.

GEORGE BEAZELY . I packed up three dozen of sherry, on 17th Nov., and put them into this hamper in the cartâ€”they belonged to Mr. David Hart, and were in his cartâ€”I swear to the hamper, and the direction on itâ€”I sent it by our carman.

JOHN DAVIS (City-policeman, 551). I saw the three prisoners in East-cheap, about six o'clock in the evening, on 17th Nov.â€”Yarmouth was trying one of the errand cartsâ€”I followed the prisoners about an hour and a halfâ€”they went to the Blackwall Railway, Fenchurch-streetâ€”Broadley and Yarmouth took a hamper and carried it awayâ€”Skinner was there, about ten yards from them with a basket on his headâ€”he could see themâ€”I am confident he was aware of what was going onâ€”he was merely out to look if the man in uniform was comingâ€”I followed the two prisoners to Fenchurch-buildings.

Cross-examined by Mr. Prendergast. Q. Did they not call out to Skinner, and did he not refuse to pay any attention to them? A. Broadley gave a halloo for Skinner to join them; he did not, he had not an opportu
nityâ€”he came in the direction where they wereâ€”I swear he was watching themâ€”I was secreted under a doorwayâ€”Broadley called, Hoy, Hoy! which is a signal among thievesâ€”I said before the Magistrate that Broadley called out to Skinner to join them, but he did notâ€”I do not know that I said that Skinner walked towards themâ€”Skinner told me he had just been to Bil
lingsgate.

SKINNERâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

51.
JOSEPH MORRIS
, stealing 1 watch, value 2l. 15s.; the goods of
Thomas Bolton, from his person.

THOMAS BOLTON . I live at 51, Strand, and am a doctor's boy. On 2nd Nov., about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, a woman accosted me in Bedford-placeâ€”she walked with me till we came to Russell-square, where she stopped, and we got talking togetherâ€”I missed my watch, and caught hold of herâ€”the prisoner whom I saw seven or eight yards off came behind herâ€”I saw her hand my watch to himâ€”I let go the woman and took hold of the prisonerâ€”he gave me a blow in the face, knocked me from him, and ran away to the corner of Montague-place, where he stoppedâ€”I came up to him, and charged him with having my watchâ€”he denied itâ€”a gentleman requested him if he were innocent to be searchedâ€”he said be would notâ€”he was taken into custodyâ€”he resisted when he was stopped.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How long were you with this female? A. About five minutesâ€”I was soberâ€”the prisoner was standing still when I came up to himâ€”it was all the work of a momentâ€”there was another person with him in the square.
ROBERT DAINES . I met the prisoner running down Bedford-placeâ€”I caught himâ€”he bit me on both armsâ€”I had a long struggle with himâ€”I got him down, and kept him till the officer came.
CHARLES JORDAN (policeman, E 165). I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 25.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

52.
CHARLES COPELAND
, stealing 4 spoons, and 1 pair of sugar tongs; value 35s.; the goods of
Henry Savage; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)

53.
MARY CLARK
, stealing 1 pair of clogs, value 14d.; the goods of
Andrew Wake; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Two Months ,

54.
RICHARD ATKINS
, stealing 1 brooch, value 4s.; and 4 shillings, and 10 pence, the property of
Charlotte Augusta Morgan; to which she pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Four Months.

55.
ELIZA HAINES
, stealing 1 half-crown, the moneys of
Francis Robinson, from the person of
Catherine Robinson; having been before convicted.

CATHERINE ROBINSON . I live with my father and mother. On 28th Oct. I was going to take a half-crownâ€”the prisoner came and asked me what I had gotâ€”I said a half-crownâ€”she told me to give it herâ€”I gave it her,
she wrapped it up in a bit of paperâ€”she gave it me three times, and took it three timesâ€”the third time she gave me the paper without it.
MRS. ROBINSON. I sent my child with the half-crownâ€”she came back crying, and had not got itâ€”it was my husband's, Francis Robinson.
ROBERT PIKE (policeman). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted Sept., 1847, confined ten days solitaryâ€”she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 14.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE COLTMAN; Sir PETER LAURIE, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. GIBBS; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq., and the Fourth Jury.

div1.p:
56.
PETER BYRNE
, embezzling the sums of 3 shillings and 9 shillings, which he had received on account of
Henry "William Thurling, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.â€”Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined Fourteen Days.

57.
ANN LONDON
, stealing 9 spoons, and other articles, value 13l.; the goods of
John Cooke, her master: also, I time-piece, value 30s.; the goods of
Thomas Tully; having been before convicted; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

58.
SARAH DARLING
, stealing a gold snap, a pair of cuffs, 3 handkerchiefs, 1 1/4 yards of lace, value 5s.; and 2 4d.-pieces; the property of 2
George Allen, her master.

ANN ALLEN . I am the wife of George Allen, who keeps a coffee-shop in New Church-street, Portman-marketâ€”the prisoner was in my service about nine days. On 12th Nov., between eleven and twelve o'clock, I gave my daughter my keys to go to my drawers for a handkerchiefâ€”half an hour afterwards I missed my keys, but could not find themâ€”I asked the prisoner if she knew anything about themâ€”she said she did notâ€”between two and three in the afternoon the prisoner pointed out the keys to me, on a hot plate, in the yardâ€”I then went to my drawers, and missed some shillings, two 4d.-pieces, a pair of cuffs, some lace, and a gold-claspâ€”I then went down to the prisoner, and asked her about itâ€”she at first denied having been to the drawersâ€”she afterwards said now I had found her out she would cut her throat, so help her God!â€”I afterwards went up to her room, and requested her to open a little box thereâ€”she did so, and I found part of the missing property in itâ€”she said it was mine, and gave me part of the silver she had takenâ€”she said she took it out of the drawerâ€”my gold-snap was among the thingsâ€”these are them (produced)â€”she said she was very sorry for what she had done.
ANN ELIZABETH ALLEN . My mother sent me to her drawers with her keysâ€”after I had been there I laid them on the parlour-tableâ€”I did not go to the same drawer these things were in.
RICHARD COMPTON (policeman, D 87). I took the prisoner into custodyâ€”these articles were given me by the prosecutrix.
Prisoner. I am very sorry for what 1 have done.

GUILTY . Aged 16.â€”Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined One Mouth .

59.
JOHN HUGHES and
WILLIAM DAVIS
, robbery on
James Horton, and stealing 2 blankets and 3 yards of linen bedtick, value 14s. 9d.; the goods of
Samuel Horton; to which

HUGHES pleaded
GUILTY . â€ Aged 19.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

JAMES HORTON . I live at Belgrave-cottage, Whittaker-street, with my father, Samuel Horton. On the evening of the 16th Nov. I was going along Cadogan-place; I saw the two prisonersâ€”I am sure they are the personsâ€”I had never seen them beforeâ€”they came up to meâ€”Hughes snatched a brown-paper parcel out of my arm, and ranâ€”he said nothingâ€”I pursued him, and Davis knocked me down with his fist against the railingâ€”I got up again, and began to run after Hughes, and found him caught by Tillerâ€”this is the bundle that I was carrying (produced)â€”it is my father's property.

JAMES HUNTER TUCK . I am a florist, in Cadogan-place. On this night, about half-past six o'clock, I heard a cry of "Stop thief!" and saw Hughes running with a brown-paper parcel under his arm, calling "Stop thief!"â€”I followed, and asked him which way the thief was goneâ€”he said, "On forward"â€”I saw Hughes run into the policeman's armsâ€”he threw the bundle down at his feet, and said he had never seen it.

EDWARD TILLER (policeman, B 55). I was on duty in Cadogan-place on the 16thâ€”I heard "Stop thief!" cried, and saw Hughes some distance before he got up to me, with a parcel under his left arm, and when I stopped him he dropped it.
HENRY HILL (policeman, B 176). In consequence of information, I apprehended Davis on the following morning, and took him to the stationâ€”I fetched Hortonâ€”he picked him out, and identified him.

Davis. Directly he came into the station-house he said to the boy, "Don't you think that is the one?" pointing to me, and the boy said, "I think it is."Witness. Horton looked at Davis first, and said, "I think this is him"â€”he then looked at two others, and said, "Yes, I know it is him by bis face"â€”I had a description of himâ€”three of them and a female came down to the station to inquire for Hughes, and I brought them all into the station into a private room, and then fetched Horton, and told him to go in and see if either of them were the party.

DAVISâ€”
GUILTY . â€ Aged 24.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.
Before Mr. Justice Coltman.

60.
JOHN DONOVAN
, feloniously killing and slaying
Christopher Broderick: he was also charged, on the Coroners' Inquisition, with the like offence.

CHARLES SEXTON . I am a driller, at Poplar. On Monday, 26th June, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I and my wife were in the Poplar-road, coming from Limehouseâ€”I saw the deceased coming down the East India-road, which is between Poplar and Limehouseâ€”he was coming towards me on the pathâ€”he was intoxicatedâ€”the prisoner Came from towards the Cape of Good Hope, which is close at hand, and knocked the deceased's hat off with his handâ€”the deceased had a bit of green in his hatâ€”he did not attempt to pick up his hat, but made a kick at the prisonerâ€”I cannot say whether he did kick him or not, but the prisoner seemed to fall on his handsâ€”he got up, and struck the deceased with his fistâ€”I cannot say exactly whether he hit him on the forehead, but the deceased fell right down at my feet, on the flagsâ€”he seemed to fall on his sideâ€”the prisoner ran awayâ€”I picked up the deceased, and saw a wound in the right side of his forehead

â€”he was insensibleâ€”the wound was on the same side as that on which he fellâ€”his shoulder came in contact with the ground first, and the side of his head then came in contact with the ground; he then turned on his back, as if insensibleâ€”I helped to take him to the doctor'sâ€”he was taken to the hospital, as he was so intoxicated we could not find out who he belonged toâ€”I recognized his dead body at the hospital, about three weeks afterwards.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you been acquainted with him before? A. No; I recognized his body more by the wound on his head than anything elseâ€”the hair was shaved off, and he looked as black as a coalâ€”I can almost swear the prisoner is the man that did itâ€”I did take a person named Mahoney for the partyâ€”I had known the prisoner for a few months; he was in the same employment as I wasâ€”I did not give Mahoney into custodyâ€”I said he was the man, but directly the policeman took him I said, "That is not Donovan"â€”it was dark at the time I fixed upon him.

MARY ANN SEXTON . I am the wife of last witness. On Monday evening, 26th June, I was with him in the Poplar-roadâ€”I saw a man walking in the road, whom I did not know before, and I saw the prisoner towards the East India-road; I had seen him before, but did not know much of himâ€”I saw him meet the deceased, and knock his hat offâ€”the deceased turned round, and made a kick at himâ€”I cannot say that he hit himâ€”the prisoner fell, got up again, made a blow at the deceased, hit him in the face across the fore
head, and he fell directly on his right shoulder, on the flag pavementâ€”my husband went to him, and lifted him upâ€”he was lying on his shoulder and sideâ€”his forehead was bleeding very much, and he was insensibleâ€”I had not heard a word said before the prisoner knocked his hat offâ€”the deceased was taken to the hospitalâ€”I saw him at the hospital, dead, three weeks afterâ€”I then recognized him as the same man.

Cross-examined. Q, Is the road paved in the middle, and the outer part not? A. I cannot sayâ€”he fell on the footwayâ€”I did not see the prisoner's hat off at allâ€”he fell on his hands immediately the deceased kicked him, just as if the man had tripped him up, and when he got up the deceased was standing, fronting him.

ROBERT WESTFIELD (policeman, K 329). On Monday evening, 26th June, I was on duty in the Commercial-road, and saw the deceasedâ€”he fell on the ground, on his sideâ€”I did not see what caused that fallâ€”I was on the opposite side of the way, and cannot say whether he fell on his right or left sideâ€”I saw the prisoner and another young man go down a court close byâ€”I pursued him, in consequence of what the Sextons said, but did not overtake himâ€”I saw enough of him to know that he was the prisonerâ€”I helped to take the deceased to the doctor's, and afterwards took him to the London Hospital in a cartâ€”I saw him after he was deadâ€”that was the Same person.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you receive Mahoney into custody? A. Yesâ€”Sexton pointed him outâ€”it was between ten and eleven o'clock at night, but within a minute Sexton said he was not the man.

JAMES HAMS (police-sergeant K 21). Last Sunday night the prisoner gave himself into my custody at the house of a gentleman named Hallâ€”he had sent for meâ€”he said he was very sorry for what had occurred, it was a very unfortunate affair, and he wished to take his trial for itâ€”I spoke first, and said, "I understand you are going to give yourself up, Donovan?"â€”I do not think I said for whatâ€”when we got to the station, I said, "Donovan, you know what you arc charged with, I suppose? I will read the warrant to you"â€”I did soâ€”ho then said, "I did not strike him, I merely pushed him with my open hand; he came squaring up to me, and he fell; some people

who were by lifted him up, and then I saw the blood coming from his fore
head; some people among the crowd said, 'Run, Jack! run!' I did not wish to go, but they pushed me down the court"â€”that was all.

MARY ANN SEXTON
re-examined. Some man said, "Run, Jack! "â€”I do not know who it was.

PETER GOWLAND . I am house-surgeon at the London Hospital. The deceased was brought there on the evening of 26th Juneâ€”I attended himâ€”he had a contused wound about an inch, above the left eyebrowâ€”it had bledâ€”it was about half an inch in length, and penetrated to the boneâ€”it was a most common wound, such as we see every day, not serious at allâ€”he remained in the hospital, and went on very well, until the 6th of Julyâ€”erysi
pelas then extended from the wound, and he got worse; the brain became affected, and he diedâ€”erysipelas is a common consequeuce of a blow on the headâ€”it certainly was in consequence of this wound, and of that he diedâ€”he was very drunk when he came inâ€”I heard that he had been in the habit of drinking a great dealâ€”I did not know him beforeâ€”a fist would not have pro
duced such a wound; there would have been contusion all round, and a dif
ferent wound altogether.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe that people who are of intemperate habits are much more liable to have erysipelas come on from a wound than others? A. Yes.

COURT, Q. Did you hear the witnesses describe the way in which the man came to the ground? A. Yesâ€”whether that fall could cause this wound, would depend on how much of the force of the fall was taken off by the shoulder coming to the ground first; if the whole weight of the body was received on the shoulder first, then the mere fact of the head coming to the ground would not have produced the wound, but if the fall was not much broken the corner of a flag-stone might have produced it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY of an Assault . Aged 18.â€”
Confined One Month .

61.
EDWARD CULLIFORD
, feloniously forging and uttering an acceptance to a bill of exchange for the payment of 23l., with intent to defraud
William Martin Swinford.

WILLIAM MARTIN SWINFORD . I am a lithographic printer, of 276, Strand. The prisoner has worked for me some yearsâ€”in March last he brought me this bill for 23l., dated 13th Marchâ€”he asked me if I would give him 20l. for it, as it was a settlement of an account between him and Mr. Paul Bedfordâ€”I gave it himâ€”the bill purports to be endorsed by Mr. Charles Manbyâ€”he said he had been to the theatre, and got Mr. Charles Manby to indorse it for himâ€”I cannot say whose writing the acceptance or endorsement isâ€”I received this letter by post in June (produced)â€”it is the prisoner's writing.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Is this letter in his usual style of writing? A. He writes in various mannersâ€”I have no doubt about the signature being hisâ€”I should say it is all hisâ€”I have known him fourteen or fifteen yearsâ€”I have done business with him about nine yearsâ€”he is a person of ability in his businessâ€”he has not been doing so well of late as he wasâ€”he was in the habit of calling at my officeâ€”I do not know the state of his circumstancesâ€”he is a lithographic writerâ€”I think I have discounted six or seven bills for him in two yearsâ€”two of them purported to be the same as this, and the same amountâ€”they were paidâ€”I think I had one bill of him for 30l.; that was paidâ€”all except these two have been paid.
PAUL JOHN BEDFORD . The acceptance of this bill is not my writingâ€”I never gave the prisoner any authority to write it.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Ever since he was a boy; we were schoolfellowsâ€”he is a well-conducted, hard-working, industrious manâ€”I have always entertained the highest opinion of his characterâ€”he could not have imagined that I would have authorised him to accept this billâ€”I never allowed him to use my acceptance unless I did it myselfâ€”I gave him no authority on this occasionâ€”I knew he was in diffi
culty at the timeâ€”if he had asked me to lend him my acceptance I should not have refused himâ€”I should think from his previous conduct and character, that he would have acted right and honestly to me.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. When did you first hear of this bill. A. Somewhere about two months ago; considerably after June.
CHARLES MANBY . I am a civil engineer, and live at 25, Great George-street. Westminster. The indorsement of this bill is not my writingâ€”I never gave the prisoner any authority to write it.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you known him any time? A. Three or four years; I employed himâ€”I never knew anything of his private characterâ€”I have heard him spoken well ofâ€”he has never had my authority to use my name under any circumstancesâ€”he had done lithographic work for me, for three or four years, for the Institution of Civil Engineersâ€”he has never received bills or acceptances from meâ€”he has always been paid by the Institution checkâ€”there has never been any dispute as to the amount of money until these forgeries were discovered; till I was called on, and made inquiries into it, and then examined the accountâ€”there is no money due to him by the Society nowâ€”there is a balance standing, but he has not finished the work, which must be done by other handsâ€”if he had finished it, there would have been 37l. due to himâ€”he could finish it in three weeks.

WILLIAM POCOCK (policeman, F 14). I took the prisoner into custody at his residence, Charlton-street, Somers-townâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he made no answer. (Letter readâ€”"2nd June, 1848. Gravesend. Sir,â€”Under the painful circumstances in which I am placed, and being about to quit the country, I have considered it my duty to write to you, and to state that the bills you hold are fictitious; at the same time, I beg to assure you it is my full intention to strive, by every means in my power, to earn enough to enable me to remit you the amount of them as early as it is possible for me so to do.")
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

62.
EDWARD CULLIFORD was again indicted for
forging and utter
ing a bill of exchange for 30l., with intent to defraud
William Martin Swinford. Mr. ROBINSON conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM MARTIN' SWINFORD . The prisoner brought me this bill for 30l. in May, and said he had been to Mr. Man by, and got him to give it to himâ€”he asked me to give him 29l. for itâ€”I said I would give him 28l. 10s., and gave him a check for the moneyâ€”I received this letter on 3rd June, and believe it to be the prisoner's writing.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. This bill would become due before the other? A. Yesâ€”I paid it into my bankers'â€”it was returned as unpaidâ€”at times the prisoner has paid me the money for bills, and at times they have been paid by the acceptorsâ€”I do not think he has ever paid the money into my bankers'; ho may have done soâ€”if he has, it would have been all rightâ€”he knew that it was the London and Westminster Bank (Holborn Branch)â€”I
learned that this was a forgery two or three days after it became dueâ€”it was notedâ€”I have never received the money.
CHARLES MANBY . The signature to this bill is not mineâ€”I never gave the prisoner authority to accept itâ€”I never gave him a bill; I always paid him by check.

Cross-examined. Q. Was he a good workman? A. Yes; but neglected it so much that I was obliged to employ some one elseâ€”there was 130l. owing to him at the time of Cockburns' failure; it may have been 200l.â€”he has got it all except 37l., for which the work has not been completedâ€”he borrowed 100l. from Mr. Webster, and I guaranteed the repaymentâ€”the failure did not delay the payments, he was paid at the next meeting of the Councilâ€”he could only be paid by the signature of three in Councilâ€”I do not think they met from May till the beginning of July.

GUILTY . Aged 24.â€”Strongly recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

63.
JOHN M'DONALD
, feloniously assaulting
Enoch Thomas, and cutting and wounding him on the head, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

ENOCH THOMAS . I deal in household furniture, at Crown-court, Golden-squareâ€”I have known the prisoner two or three monthsâ€”I supplied him with some furniture, for which he was paying me at 5s. a weekâ€”he is a porter at the Western Literary Institution. On Thursday, 2nd Nov., he called on me before half-past twelve o'clock in the day, and proposed that we should go out togetherâ€”we went to a public-house, and had two quarterns of ginâ€”I drank one small glass; he drank the remainder with some waterâ€”we went to two or three shopsâ€”he made purchases at eachâ€”he said he would pay me 5s. then, instead of between three and four, which was his usual timeâ€”we drank a quartern of rumâ€”I drank about one-third of it, and he the remainder in water againâ€”we then went towards Leicester-squareâ€”he was not sober, but was far from drunkâ€”he walked very wellâ€”he asked if I would be answerable to a loan society for him for 4l., and if I would he would give me 10s. for the accommodation, and pay me 16s. more off my bill, which Mould be giving me one out of fourâ€”I declinedâ€”he bit his lips, and appeared confused, and said, "You certainly might do that, for it is a small amount"â€”I said, "I will do it on no terms whatever," and he was not to ask me such a question againâ€”when we got to his house he went down stairsâ€”I followed a few yards behind himâ€”he was at the kitchen door before I got to the bottom, he stooped down, as I suppose, to put the basket out of his hand at the kitchen door, but he turned round and struck me over the left temple with an instrument between two and three feet longâ€”it was a similar instrument to this (produced)â€”it struck me on the left templeâ€”I have the mark nowâ€”it staggered me at least two yards, but did not strike me to the groundâ€”I recovered myself, and grappled with him by the hips, to try to throw him back on the mat by the kitchen door, but my strength failed me, and he threw me off, lifted his arm again, and the blow fell on my left shoulderâ€”it broke my collar-bone, and I fell down and lost my sensesâ€”he did not say one word before he attacked me in this wayâ€”I became insensibleâ€”after some time I partly came to myself, and in about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes I contrived to get homeâ€”I then fell on the bed and faintedâ€”my head and clothes were covered with bloodâ€”I was afterwards seen by Mr. Harding, a surgeon.
Prisoner. I asked him to be security for me two months ago, and he

refused, and I never asked him afterwards; he was stupidly drunk; he followed me into Mr. Bolton's in Leicester-square; he fell from the top of the stairs to the bottom. Witness. I was never in Mr. Bolton's placeâ€”I did not fall down the stairsâ€”he has asked me for loans on several occasions.

JOHN MURRELL (policeman, A 305). I was called to the Literary Insti
tution in Leicester-square on the afternoon of 2nd Nov., and took the pri
soner into custodyâ€”his hands and coat were very bloodyâ€”I asked him how his hands came to be in that stateâ€”he said in all probability he might have a little scratch on themâ€”I made him wash them, and did not find any scratchâ€”he was not tipsy, but had been drinkingâ€”he answered my ques
tions rationallyâ€”I afterwards went back to the Institution, and found a quantity of blood at the bottom of the stairs, within two or three feet of the last step, and some splashed on the wallâ€”I found this iron bar bent as it is now, but no blood on itâ€”it appeared very black, as if it had been recently in the fireâ€”I also produce a cap stained with blood, which I found at the prosecutor's house.

WILLIAM HARDING . I am a surgeon. I saw the prosecutor on the day this happenedâ€”he was in bedâ€”his head and face were bloody, and on washing it I found a cut over the left eye, and a very considerable bruise and swelling, showing that he had received a severe blowâ€”the skin was dividedâ€”it might have been inflicted with such an instrument as thisâ€”I examined his shoulder next morning, and found a fracture of the collar-bone, which I think was very likely to have been the consequence of a blow with the same instrumentâ€”he is still suffering from the effects of the injuryâ€”he is pretty nearly well now.

Prisoner. Q. Was the wound from a blow or a fall? A. I could not tellâ€”it might have been occasioned by a fallâ€”I think that the fracture of the collar-bone was not from a fallâ€”it was broken near the shoulder joint, and a fracture in that situation is generally considered to be occasioned by direct force appliedâ€”a fracture from a fall generally takes place in the centre of the boneâ€”I would not say it was impossible.
MR. BODKIN *. Q. Could you form any judgment as to whether both those injuries would be the result of one fall? A. I think they could not.

JOHN MURRELL
re-examined. I was present when the prisoner was under examination before Mr. Hardwickâ€”I heard him make a statement which was taken downâ€”I know Mr. Hardwick's writingâ€”this is itâ€”(readâ€”The pri
soner says, "I am not aware that I struck Mr. Thomas; I do not recollect his coming to my place at all; he said he would come in the evening to take some tea, for me to let him into the lecture-room; we had been drinking all the afternoon, and I was quite insensible; the piece of iron I had for the pur
pose of forcing the lock back, and Mr. Thomas knows it; he oiled it for me last Thursday week.")

Prisoner's Defence. We had been drinking; when we came to Mr. Bol
ton's, in Leicester-square, he forced me in to get a quartern of rum, and then went home; I went up stairs for some article that I wanted, and as I went down, to the best of my recollection, I heard him falling, but being insen
sible I was not aware of it; I must have gone to lift him up and got a stain on my hand and coat; that is all I know till the clerk of the office rang the bell at four o'clock, and at five Thomas came with the policeman and took me; he begged me off before the Magistrate; I am innocent; I never had any ill feeling towards him; why did not he make a complaint to the clerk in the office, who met him as he was going out of the hall from my apartments full of blood.

GUILTY of an Assault . Aged 31.â€”
Confined Six Months.

64.
MARTIN WILLIAMS and
WILLIAM FREDERICK WILLIAMS were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Bowie, and stealing therein 2 coats, 2 pairs of trowsers, I waistcoat, I shawl, I table-cloth, and 1 handkerchief, value 5l., his property: 2nd Count, feloniously receiving the same.

JOHN BOWIE . I live at 12, Swan-yard, Shoreditch. The prisoners lived next door to meâ€”on Saturday night, 11th Nov., about a quarter-past ten o'clock, I ascertained that all was right and went to bedâ€”I got up next morning between six and seven; went into the sitting-room and found the drawers pulled out and some of them put on chairsâ€”one of the windows was a little Tipâ€”it was down the night before, to the best of my knowledgeâ€”I searched the drawers and missed two coats, two pairs of trowsers, a waistcoat, a shawl, a handkerchief, and a table-clothâ€”I then went down stairs and found the outer door unlocked and the key lying down inside on the floorâ€”my wife had locked that door the night beforeâ€”I did not hear her lock itâ€”I gave infor
mation to the police about five minutes afterâ€”I saw Martin Williams on Sunday evening, 12thâ€”I told him I bad been robbed, and (old him the articles that had been stolen from meâ€”he said it was a very great pity; I might hear of them by and byâ€”he came to me next day and told me he wanted to speak to me in the public-houseâ€”I went with him, and he said that he had all my things and I should have them in the eveningâ€”he said his son had robbed me, and had robbed him several times beforeâ€”I went and got a policeman; went back, and asked Martin Williams to go home with me and show me the thingsâ€”he went home and said be could not find themâ€”we then came down and went to a bed-room down stairs, which the old gentleman said was his roomâ€”I saw the policeman turn up the bed there and find two coats, two pairs of trowsers, and a shawl; and a table-cover was in a drawer in the roomâ€”these are them (produced).

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When did you lose your pro
perty? A. I did not miss it till Saturday morningâ€”I saw Martin Williams on Sunday evening, and that was the first intimation I got of itâ€”he told me his son had robbed me and he had robbed him several times before and wanted him punishedâ€”the son was taken the same nightâ€”a silk handker
chief, some beads of my wife's, and several things are still missingâ€”Martin Williams is a very honest fellow, as far as I knowâ€”he has a little boy four or five years oldâ€”he said that little boy pointed out the bundle to him, that he wanted his son to return it, and he had refused, and on that he came and told me.

JOHN JOHNS (policeman, H. 76.) On 12th Nov., in consequence of a communication made to me by last witness, I went into a public-house and saw Martin Williams thereâ€”I heard him say he did not know whether the clothes were in his house or notâ€”I told him I would take him there, and we wentâ€”he said, "I know nothing about it, but I will go to my house and see if they are there"â€”on the way to the house he told me to keep all as quiet as I could, not to let anybody know of itâ€”I went with him to the garret of the bouse, but found nothingâ€”he then went into the back bed-room on the first floor and I followed himâ€”there was a box there, and he took a key out of his pocket and tried to unlock it, but the key would not fitâ€”I searched the room, turned up the bed, and there found, between the bed and mattress, two coats, two pairs of trowsers, a shawl, and a satin waistcoat; and in a drawer I found a table-clothâ€”Martin Williams said nothing thenâ€”I asked him before I found them if he knew anything about them, and he said, no, he knew

nothing at all about themâ€”at the station he said he did not like to rob his neigh
bour; he believed it was his son did it; he had robbed him before, and he would be likely to be at home at two o'clock in the morning.
Cross-examined. Q. Had he been drinking? A. Yes, very freelyâ€”he was very near drunk.

ALFRED HENRY GRANT (policeman, G 62). On Monday evening, 13th Nov. about a quarter to nine o'clock, the prosecutor came to me, and I went in search of the younger prisoner, and found him at a beer-shop in Holywell-lane, Shoreditchâ€”I told him I came about the bundle of clothesâ€”he said, "Oh, I can give a good account of how I came by it"â€”he said, as he was going home on the Saturday night with a friend of his, he saw a man standing outside the prosecutor's door, and another man came to him to look out of the door, and asked if it was all right; he said, "Yes," and came out; the man came out with a bundle, and, on seeing him, he threw down the bundle, and ran away; he then took up the bundle, and took it in-doors, and put it into the copper; that his father found it in the morning, and told him to take it into Bowie's; he told him he would not, why did not he take it in?

William Frederick Williams. I did not say so; we bad no copper. Witness. Those were the words he usedâ€”I know Mr. Hammill's writingâ€”this is his signature to these depositionsâ€”(read)â€”"The said William Frederick Williams saith as follows, 'I had a young man with me on Saturday night, who saw me pick up the bundle and throw it into the shop, I can tell you where he works; his name is George Gamble; he works at Mr. Breton's, Christopher-court, Bunhill-row; I am innocent of the charge'"â€”I was present when that statement was madeâ€”I am not aware that any inquiry has been made after the person he speaks of.

William Frederick Williams's Defence. I own I put the things under the bed; I put them there that my father should not take them back; I thought he might get into disgrace; the thought came over me that I would take them in myself afterwards; I went out, and when I returned, in about a quarter of an hour, the things were gone. MARTIN WILLIAMSâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

WILLIAM FREDERICK WILLIAMSâ€”
GUILTY of Stealing only .â€”Aged 18.â€”
Confined Four Months .

65.
WILLIAM NORTH
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwell
ing-house of
Abraham Corbet, and stealing therein 33 pairs of boots, and 24 pairs of shoes, value 10l. 18s.; the goods of the said
Abraham Corbet and another.â€”2nd Count, feloniously receiving the same; having been before convicted.

ABRAHAM CORBET . I live at 13, Adams-row, Hampstead-road, and am a shoemaker, in partnership with another. On Sunday morning, 21st Oct., I locked the shop door, and went to bod, at one o'clock, leaving a quantity of boots, which had been hanging outside, on the floorâ€”I was disturbed about two o'clock by a sudden noiseâ€”as I thought some one had burst the door open, I got upâ€”I did not go down stairsâ€”not hearing anything more, I went to bed againâ€”about a quarter of an hour afterwards I was called up by a policeman, went down, and found the shop door lying in the shop, broken off the hinges, and part of the door-post also, and the bolt and lock both brokenâ€”I then sent for one of my men, Alfred Princeâ€”I went to bed again, after making up the door, and left my man sitting at the door till eight o'clock next morningâ€”I then examined my stock, and missed twelve pairs of Wellington boots fourteen pairs of bluehers, one pair of nailed boots, twenty-four pairs of children's shoes, and six pairs of children's bootsâ€”they were safe
when I went to bedâ€”I did not count them, but I know what I had in my shopâ€”I have seen some of them sinceâ€”the nailed boots I know, but the others I cannot swear to.

ANN COYNE . I am the wife of Michael Coyne, of 11, Fitzroy-row, New-road. The prisoner was a lodger of mineâ€”on Sunday morning, 21st Oct., I saw him, between eleven and twelve o'clock, at my own door, with a pair of girl's boots, which he said would fit my little girlâ€”I said I had no girl of my own, but my lodger, Connell, hadâ€”I took them to fit the girl, but they would not fit her, and I returned them to the prisonerâ€”he brought another pair of boots, which he said would fit my boyâ€”he said he would let me have them for 3s.â€”I had no mere than half-a-crown, which I gave himâ€”my boy wore themâ€”on the following Monday a man named Cooper came to me, and asked me for the boots, and I gave them to him, and he gave them to a policeman, who was in the passageâ€”I saw the policeman with the girl's boots; I know they were the sameâ€”when I returned them I took them into Cooper's roomâ€”he took some salt, put it on the bottom, rubbed them very hard, and stained the leatherâ€”when I saw them again they were so stainedâ€”there was a number on them; I think it was "3," but am not quite certainâ€”these produced are the same, and these are the boy's boots (looking at them).

GEORGE LUCK (policeman, S 345). On Monday morning, 23rd Oct, about three o'clock, a man named William Cooper came to me, and gave me some informationâ€”the prisoner was already in custody for creating a dis
turbanceâ€”I went with Cooper to 11, Fitzroy-row, and he there gave me this pair of girl's boots (produced)â€”I did not see where he got them fromâ€”he gave them me in the passage, against the front doorâ€”I afterwards found a pair of nailed bootsâ€”Cooper and Mrs. Coyne were in the house at the timeâ€”Corbet's house is in St. Pancras' parish.

ALFRED PRINCE . I live at 26, Henry-street, Hampstead-road, and work for Mr. Corbet. On the Saturday night, or Sunday morning, I was fetched by a policeman to my master's premisesâ€”I remained, and took care of them, till eight o'clock, Sunday morningâ€”I then examined the stock, and missed twelve pairs of Wellington boots, and fourteen pairs of bluchersâ€”they were all safe on the Saturday nightâ€”I had seen them at nearly one o'clockâ€”this pair of girl's boots are Mr. Corbet's propertyâ€”these initials, "H. P.," on the bottom, is a private mark which I made myselfâ€”this other pair are not in a saleable condition, and were never sold out of my master's shopâ€”we never sold a pair without punching them for the lacesâ€”I cannot say when I had seen this particular pair beforeâ€”this other pair are boy's nailed bootsâ€”we only received four pairs of these on the Saturday, at mid-day, and they were lost on the Sunday, I had not sold a pairâ€”they then had no holes, and were not in a saleable stateâ€”they have since been pierced with a kind of small awl, or something of that sort, not in a proper way.

ABRAHAM CORBET
re-examined. These girl's boots are oursâ€”I know them by the appearance and the workâ€”I only keep one man that makes these, and there is a private mark on themâ€”I swear to their being our propertyâ€”Fitzroy-square is about three minutes' walk from our shop.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the robbery; Cooper gave me these two pairs of boots on the Sunday morning, to take down to sell to the landlady.
THOMAS WILSON (policeman, S 271). I produce a certificateâ€”(readâ€”William Webb, convicted Feb., 1847, and confined three months)â€”the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 24.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

66.
WILLIAM HURREN and
THOMAS CARTER were indicted for
a robbery, with violence, on
Robert Taylor, and stealing 1 breast-pin, value 14s.; his property.

ROBERT TAYLOR . I live in Bishopsgate-street. Some time before the 12th Nov. I was barman at the King's Arms, it is sometimes called the Cat, in Beech-streetâ€”I have seen the prisoners there frequentlyâ€”I was there on Sunday night, 12th Nov., in the wholesale-departmentâ€”the prisoners were then in the retail-department, which is separate from the wholesaleâ€”whilst there Carter used a blackguard expression to me, and they said how they would serve me if they could get at meâ€”he attempted to get at me, but could notâ€”after a short time I went outâ€”the prisoners followed me out togetherâ€”I hud got about half-a-dozen yards, and then Carter struck me a severe blow on the jaw and knocked me downâ€”Hurren was close to himâ€”Carter made a grab at my scarf, in which I had a pinâ€”I saw it safe immediately before coming out of the houseâ€”he then ran awayâ€”the scarf was partly pulled out of my waistcoatâ€”immediately I got up I missed my pinâ€”I immediately ran round the corner, called "Police!" and the prisoners were taken into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What time was it? A. About twelve o'clock, or a quarter-pastâ€”I had not got a black eye; I had not been quar
relling with a baker about an hour before, and the landlord did not send a man to try to pacify meâ€”I was barman at the Cat about a week, and left about three weeks beforeâ€”there might have been some ill-feeling between me and Carter about his having passed some bad moneyâ€”I did not call him a smasher; the only remark I made was, that when taking his money I had been told by my employer to look at what money I took, and when I did so he said, "What are you looking at so particularly?" and I said, "I am obliged to look at what I take particularly"â€”he tried to get to me, but was prevented by the landlord coming inâ€”he appeared to be very violentâ€”he appeared soberâ€”I waited for half or three-quarters of an hour to avoid himâ€”he still waited for meâ€”I have not found my pin.

GEORGE GREEN . I am a music-seller, of 27, Featherstone-street, St. Luke's. On Sunday night, 12th Nov., about a quarter-past twelve o'clock, I was passing the Cat, and saw Carter strike Taylor a blow which knocked him downâ€”he came against me, and then fellâ€”I heard Carter say, "I have been waiting for you," and I heard Hurren say to Carter, "Hook it, " and they both went away togetherâ€”they walked for a few yards, increasing gradually to a run.

Cross-examined.Q. Hook it means cut your stick, or "run," does it not? A. I imagine soâ€”that was said as the man was calling "Police!"â€”the louder he cried, the faster they ranâ€”Hurren did not interfere in the scuffle.

FREDERICK JACQUES . I am a pastry-cook, at Beech-street, Barbican. On Sunday night, 12th Nov., about twelve o'clock or a quarter-past, I was in the bar of the King's Arms, and saw the prisoners in companyâ€”I tried to shun their companyâ€”Carter asked me if I knew the prosecutor when he lived at Mr. Gamble'sâ€”I said I had no recollection of himâ€”he said that on one occasion, when he lived there, he had called him a smasher, or something of that sort, for which he would break his headâ€”the prosecutor was then in a separate place from the prisonersâ€”about five minutes after the prosecutor came out, and the prisoners followed directlyâ€”Carter knocked him downâ€”I expected a disturbanceâ€”lfurren said to Carter, "Come on, you bâ€”â€”; they are after you'â€”they ran awayâ€”Hurren was close by when the blow was struckâ€”they walked till they got opposite the next house, and then they ran
down the street at the back of my shopâ€”I went another way, met them, and they were takenâ€”I did not hear either of them say anything about the pin.

Cross-examined. Q. You expected a scuffle? A. Yes; from what Cairter said, I knew he meant to pitch into him when he came outâ€”there were a good many people in the public-houseâ€”Carter said this before them allâ€”after the scuffle, Hurren said to Carter, "Dâ€”your eyes, hook it; they are after you"â€”Hurren did not interfere in the scuffle at all, only when Taylor called "Police!" he said, "Hook it."
COURT. Q. He used both those expressions? A. Yesâ€”when he said, "Hook it," Taylor was gone round Whitecross-street for a policemanâ€”I have heard hook it explained as "walking or running away."
(The prisoners received good characters.)

HURRENâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

CARTERâ€”
GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 21.â€”
Confined One Month .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”SIR PETER LAUUIE, Knt., Aid.; SIR CHAPMAN-MARSHALL, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. GIBBS; Mr. RECORDER; and Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Sixth Jury.

div1.p:
67.
HENRY ALFRED FRANKLIN , was indicted
for embezzling 2s.; the moneys of
Henry Mellon, his master; to which be pleaded

GUILTY â€”Aged 17.â€”
Confined One Month .

68.
FRANCIS HATCH
, stealing 141bs. weight of metal, value 14s.; the goods of
John Shepard, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.â€”
Confined One Month .

69.
WILLIAM M'CARTHY
, stealing 1 chain, value 9s.; the goods of
Josiah St. John and another; also 1 pair of steps, value 15s.; the goods of
James Power; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24â€”
Transported for Seven Years

70.
JOHN BLOOMER WICKS was indicted
for embezzling 15l.; the moneys of
John Robert Harris, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Confined Three Month .

71.
WILLIAM PHILLIPS and
WILLIAM PHILLIPS , jun,
stealing 1 purse, value 1s., 8 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 3 groats; the property of
Thomas Farmery, from the person of
Thomasina Farmery.

THOMASINA FARMERY . I was in St. Paul's-churchyard on 28th Nov.â€”I had a purse in my pocket containing eight shillings and sixpence and three fourpenny-piecesâ€”my attention was called by an officer who showed me my purseâ€”I had not missed itâ€”this is it (produced).

MICHAEL HAYDON (City-policeman, 21). I saw the two prisonersâ€”the younger one walked by the side of the prosecutrixâ€”he put his hand in her pocketâ€”the elder one walked close behind himâ€”I got close to them, and the eldest prisoner said, "Have you got it?"â€”the younger one replied, "Yes"â€”they walked down a courtâ€”I followed them, and took the younger oneâ€”I took from his hand this purse, and with assistance I secured both the pri
soners.

WILLIAM PHILLIPS, Jun.â€”
GUILTY . * Aged 14.

WILLIAM PHILLIPSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 16.

72.
JANE BAILEY and
JAMES HORNETT
, stealing 1 desk, 2 knives, and 1 snuff-box, value 17l., and 5 5l.-Bank-notes; the property of
Eliza
beth Norcraft, in her dwelling-house.â€”2nd COUNT, feloniously receiving the same.

ELIZABETH NORCRAFT . I was formerly a houskeeper, I afterwards took a house, No. 22, York-street, in the parish of St. Marylebone. The prisoner Bailey was introduced to me by a lady who came to lodge in my house, and was employed by me on loth, 16th, and 17th of Aug. at needleworkâ€”she used to work in the front atticâ€”I had a writing-desk in that roomâ€”I last saw it safe on the loth Aug., when I dusted itâ€”I had in it two silver watches, two silver pen-knives, two pair of silver scissors, a valuable pearl snuff-box, a smelling-bottle, and various other things, and 37l. in moneyâ€”there were seven 5l.-notes which I hid received from Major Angeloâ€”Bailey had com
plained of the state of her health several times on the 16th and 17thâ€”she said she had the toothacheâ€”on the 16th she said she had the mumpsâ€”on the evening of the 16th I said it was dark, we could not see to workâ€”she said she could, and I went down, and left her in the room aloneâ€”she came down in about ten minutesâ€”she then went upstairs with a candle, to fetch her clothes, and said she would come again at seven o'clock in the morningâ€”she came down, and her candle was outâ€”she put it down in an agitated way, and ran upstairs very quickly, and shut the door after herâ€”I did not see the bundle that she brought downâ€”she was in the darkâ€”I had no suspicion of her, but she went out in great hasteâ€”I missed my desk on Thursday the 17thâ€”she had been to work that dayâ€”I had before told her that if I lost that desk I was ruined, for everything I possessed was in it, and on the Tuesday she asked me if I had paid my rent and taxesâ€”I said, "No; I had been so ill, and it had been so wet I had not gone out."

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE.Q. Are you quite sure as to the day on which you lost this desk? A. I am sure it was taken on the 16thâ€”I missed it on the 17th, between seven and eight in the eveningâ€”she had been gone about a quarter of an hourâ€”I have not charged any one but her with steal
ing itâ€”I had a carpenter there at work on the Saturday, and on Monday the 14thâ€”on the Tuesday he was not thereâ€”I took the desk up on Monday night the 14th, when I went to bedâ€”it never was up there before thatâ€”I took the carpenter up on suspicion.

COURT. Q. Did he work there after the Monday? A. He came on the Wednesday and I took him up into the roomâ€”I never recollect seeing the desk after the lothâ€”on the 16th I did not notice itâ€”the carpenter went up on the 16th, but I went up with himâ€”I staid till he had put a castor on the bed, and he and I went down togetherâ€”I left Bailey in the roomâ€”I did not notice the deskâ€”it stood on the left-hand side of a pair of drawers that was between the two windows.

MR. WILDE. Q. Were you at home during the whole of the 15th and 16th? A. Yes; I never left my house at allâ€”there were other persons there, but they went no further than the parlour-doorâ€”as far as I know they did not go upstairsâ€”I saw a man in the house on the Tuesday with a post-office orderâ€”I dusted my desk that day, between eleven and twelve o'clockâ€”the man came about fourâ€”I saw him in the passageâ€”I was in the passage, and then in my little roomâ€”I can see the passage from my little roomâ€”Bailey was strongly recommended to me, and I recommended her to my friendsâ€”I should have got her a situationâ€”on the Monday morning the carpenter put a little bit of brass into the key-hole of the deskâ€”he put it in with a bit of glue.
COURT. Q. Had he any basket, such as carpenters have, large enough to

put the desk in? A. He had a basket, but not very bigâ€”there was nothing in it but a few nails and his hammer, and so onâ€”I do not think it was large enough to have covered my deskâ€”the carpenter is not hereâ€”he was clearedâ€”Mr. Broughton saw nothing against himâ€”I told him he was never in the room aloneâ€”Mr. Broughton said, why did I suspect himâ€”I said I did notâ€”that was in the morning, when Bailey was liberated because I had not suffi
cient evidence to retain herâ€”after that was over I came out, and my friends said, "It is the carpenter"â€”I said, "Perhaps it would be as well for him to have a hearing"â€”we went in, and Mr. Broughton said, "Have you anything more against him?"â€”I said, "No."

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. At the time Bailey was discharged, had you disco
vered that the notes had been changed by Hornett? A. No.

JAMES NIXON . I keep the house, 24, Francis-street, Tottenham-court-road. Bailey came to lodge there on the 2nd of Augustâ€”she had a little back room, for which she was to pay 4s. 6d. a weekâ€”I asked her for a depositsâ€”she said she had not got one: she was a poor servant girl out of place, and she wanted a cheap roomâ€”I know Hornett by seeing him come to the house to see Baileyâ€”Hornett made application to me with respect to my coffee-shop, which he wished to takeâ€”he wished to know what I would let him have it forâ€”he said he expected some money from his uncle, and he would consult with bis brotherâ€”his brother and he came about it, but I did not let him have itâ€”this was about the 8th of Augustâ€”on the 11th or 12th I applied to Bailey for rentâ€”she said she had no money then, but she would pay me the two weeks togetherâ€”on the 18th she gave me half a sovereign and I gave her a shillingâ€”there was 9s. for two weeks' rentâ€”on the morning of the 19th she bought a pair of boots of meâ€”I think she paid me 4s. 6d. for themâ€”I saw at that time that she had gold and silver to the amount of between 3l. and 4l:â€”Hornett used to come to see her occasionallyâ€”I saw him there about four days before Bailey paid meâ€”he had been there between the 11th or 12th and the time I was paid.
Cross-examined by MR. CLAKKSON. Q. Was it not three weeks before the 17th of August that Bailey came to you? A. No, two weeksâ€”it was on the 15th her rent was due, and on the 18th she paid me.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Are you certain it was on the 18th she paid you the rent? A. Yesâ€”on this memorandum (looking at one) it says, "August the 8th, received one week, 4s. 6d., the 15th, received one week, 4s. 6d."â€”that is when the rent was dueâ€”that is my way of putting it downâ€”I received it on the 18th.

CHRISTOPHER RIPLET . My mother and myself live at No. 8, Cbapel-street, Tottenham-court-roadâ€”Hornett lodged thereâ€”Bailey took the lodging for him some time in June, at 3s. a weekâ€”she said it was for her brotherâ€”I applied to him about three weeks before the 17th of August for three weeks' rentâ€”he told me to make out his bill, he would speak to his sister, and I should be paidâ€”I made him out a bill of 9s. for three weeks' rent, and he paid it me about a fortnight before he leftâ€”he left on 17th Augustâ€”I very frequently saw Bailey at Homett'sâ€”she came to my house on the night of 16th August, between eight and nine o'clockâ€”she had a paper parcel similar to a letter wrapped in paperâ€”she asked for Jamesâ€”I said he was gone to the theatreâ€”she appeared very much excited, and said she must see him very particularly; she had a letter from his uncle, who was very ill indeed, and she must see him that nightâ€”she asked me to send my lad to the theatre to fetch him outâ€”I said I could not think of such a thing; it was very fullâ€”she was rather troublesome, and I said, "If you must see him you had better take a candle and go up in his room and wait for him"â€”the shop is rather

small, and I sent her up to be out of the wayâ€”she went up stairsâ€”she came down two or three times afterwards to know if he was come in, and he was notâ€”I went to bed about half-past eleven o'clock, leaving her in the roomâ€”in the morning Hornett called me up between six and seven o'clockâ€”he said, "Ripley, I wish you would get up and get me a cup of coffee; I must go into the country, and I want to pay you"â€”I got it for himâ€”Bailey breakfasted with himâ€”I cannot say whether she came from out of the house, or whether she came down stairsâ€”she had a parcel with her as large as a gownâ€”it seemed to be something soft, and was in brown paperâ€”I made out Hor-nett's billâ€”it came to 16s.â€”he gave me a new 5l. note to pay itâ€”I had not change for it, and I gave it him backâ€”my boy, William Leech, came down in about half an hour, and I saw that Mr. Dobree, the pawnbroker, was opening his shopâ€”I said to Hornett, "I can get change for you now, Sir"â€”he gave the note to Leech, and he went and got it changedâ€”Hornett then paid me my 16s.â€”he said he was going to the Eastern Counties Railway, and he went away in a cabâ€”Bailey had gone away first with the parcel.

JAMES NIXON
re-examined. Bailey went out daily for a few hoursâ€”I do not know whether she went to workâ€”she went out at various times, and came home generally very late in the evening.
WILLIAM LEECH . On the morning of 17th Aug. I took a note from Mr. Hornett to get change at Mr. Dobree'sâ€”Mr. Bliss gave me the change, and he wrote on the noteâ€”I took the change to my master's.
HENRY ROBERT BAYFIELD . I am a clerk in the Bank of England. I produce two 5l.-notes which were paid in thereâ€”they are Nos. 15075 and 15076.

WILLIAM THOMAS BLISS . I am in the employ of Mr. Dobree, the pawnbroker. I have no recollection of Leech coming, but on the back of this note, No. 15076, here is, in my writing, 17, 1848â€”that indicates that I changed it on 17th Aug.

SAMUEL LOWE . I am a tailor, in Barbican. Hornett came to my shop to buy a pair of trowsersâ€”I cannot tell the date, but it was on the Monday morning before 24th Aug.â€”I think it was about the 20th or 21stâ€”he paid for there with a new 5l. noteâ€”this is it, No. 15075â€”I wrote on it the name which he gave me. "Smith, 10, Bedford-row, Cambridge"â€”he said he was lodging in Whitccross-strert tor a short time, but his residence was at Cambridge.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. When did you pay the note away? A. On the 24thâ€”I had not seen Hornett before, to my knowledgeâ€”he came about eight o'clock in the morningâ€”I saw him again about a fortnight afterwardsâ€”I am sure he did not say "Cambridgeâ€”heath"â€”he said "Cambridge," because I asked him if he knew a Mr. Watson, whe had been a neighbour of mine, and who had got a shop there, and he said he knew the shopâ€”to the best-of my belief Hornett is the manâ€”I know we are all liable to mistakesâ€”I have not any doubt that he is the man.

MAJOR RICHARD ANGLLO . I have lodged at Mrs. Norcroft's since June, 1847â€”in May last 1 received from Glyn's fifty 5l.-notes, numbered consecutively from No. 15051 to 15100â€”I spent them as I required themâ€”I did not take the numbers regularly till I came to 15073â€”I had spent the numbers before 13073 before Juneâ€”I paid Mrs. Norcroft ten, the notes from No. 15075 to 15085.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You have a memorandum here?. A. Yesâ€”I made this on Thursday night, 17th Aug., when Mrs. Norcroft spoke of her lossâ€”I made it from my pocket-book, which I have hereâ€”here are the numbers of the notes I give her.

ELIZABETH NORCERAFAT re-examined. I saw Horne't at my house on Tues
day,

15th Aug.â€”he was in my passageâ€”he called to see Bailey, as I under
stood, with a Post-office order.

WILLAM MOSES . I am a potman, in York-street, next door to Mrs. Norcraft. I saw Hornett at the corner of the mews, with his hands on the post, in the after part of the dayâ€”he was looking up to the top of the houseâ€”after he had been looking a little time, a female looked out of the attic windowâ€”it was Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday, I am not certain whichâ€”I think I heard of the robbery on Friday; it was in that weekâ€”I did not know which house Hornett was looking at, till I saw the female look out at 22â€”that female resembled the female prisonerâ€”Hornett left where he was standing, went to the door, and placed his hand to the bellâ€”I was not close enough to hear whether he pulled itâ€”I was on the opposite side of the streetâ€”I cannot tell whether he pulled it or notâ€”he stood back against the partition-board, as if he did not want to be seenâ€”I did not stop to see whether he went in, as I was on my business.
Bailey. I had worked four days in her kitchen.

ELIZABETH NORCRAFT
re-examined. She did, but not on that occasionâ€”she told me in the morning that she expected a Post-office orderâ€”I did not hear what Hornett said to her in the passageâ€”she Said it was too late.
(George Walsh Hallam, Esq., a Magistrate of Hertfordshire, in whose service the prisoners had lived, gave them a good character.)

BAILEY
GUILTY
of stealing. Aged 29

HORNETT
GUILTY
of receiving. Aged 24

73.
ALEXANDER FULLERTON was indicted
for embezzling 2l. 4s. 9d.; the moneys of
Charles Miller, his master.
CHARLES MILLER . I am a coal-merchantâ€”the prisoner was in my employ.
MR. PRENDBRGAST. Q. Was there not a written agreement? A. Yesâ€”it is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

(The prisoner was also charged with
stealing a ton of coals, upon which MR. BALLANTINE offered no evidence.)

74.
ISABELLA HAWKINS
, feloniously receiving 900 yards of ribbon, 14 yards of silk, and other articles, value 24l. 12s. 5d.; the goods of
Edward Wason Freestone, knowing them to have been stolen. (See page 24.)

EDWARD WASON FREESTONE . I am a bonnet-manufacturer, of High-street, Shoreditch. Maria Borreman was my servant. On 24th Oct. I spoke to her, and her box was searched by a constable, and these ribbons and cap-fronts found in it, and a piece of paper which had covered a draper's parcel, with the prisoner's address on itâ€”I gave the girl in charge, and went to the prisoner's house, 5, Trafalgar-road, Dalston, between ten and eleven o'clock in the dayâ€”she came to the doorâ€”I said, "Is your name Hawkins?"â€”she said, "Yes; I believe you are after Maria"â€”I said, "My name is Freestone; I believe you are the aunt of Maria, who lives with me"â€”she said, "No; I am a distant relation"â€”I said, "She has been robbing me, and I believe you have some boxes here belonging to her"â€”she said she had one that was in the front kitchenâ€”she was very much agitatedâ€”I said I did not wish to injure her, and told her to compose herselfâ€”I went into the kitchenâ€”the box was lockedâ€”the policeman opened it with a key taken from Borremanâ€”we found

in it some towels, with my mark, and a roll of ribbonâ€”I said, "Is this all?"â€”she said, 'Yes"â€”I said, "Are you positive?"â€”she-said, "Yes"â€”I said, "I am satisfied to the contrary; I have two letters, which prove you have two silk dresses here belonging to Maria," and insisted on searching the houseâ€”she said we had no rightâ€”I told the officer to proceedâ€”she said, "There is ano
ther box at the top of the stairs, on the landing," she took me there and showed it meâ€”the policeman unlocked it with one of the keys, and found upwards of 900 yards of ribbon, some straw trimming, a small portion of lace, and some silk cordâ€”some of the ribbon is worth 8d. a yard, but taking it at 4d. it is worth 15l.â€”it is new, and cut off in lengths of three or four yards each, from pieces which I have brought hereâ€”here are also a dozen rolls of ribbon, some with thirty-six yards, and some lessâ€”this parcel was found behind the door of the children's room, at the bottom of a basket of dirty clothesâ€”it contained a handkerchief, a pair of stockings, (from which the mark had been tried to be erased,) and some ribbons and flowersâ€”there were two bonnets on the bedâ€”I said, "That is one of our ribbons"â€”we had bonnets trimmed with it, and if they do not sell, we take the ribbon offâ€”she said, "Maria gave me that, and said one of the young ladies at your house gave it her"â€”that is nt ver done, it would be put on a lower-priced bonnetâ€”in a cupboard in the front sitting-room I found a black silk dress, worth 36s. or 38sâ€”I had silk like itâ€”my servant slept in the house, and had no occasion to have a trunk at the prisoner'sâ€”three or four other boxes, locked, were pointed out as belonging to herâ€”I found in them some books, (one of which I identify,) some plaid silk for a dress, some new stockings and bootsâ€”there was nothing which was not under lock and key, but the ribbon on the bonnet and the parcel behind the doorâ€”the value of the things I identify is from 20l. to 30l., independent of those in the three or four boxes.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is not the prisoner's husband a most respectable man, working for a Mr. Devaux, a merchant? A. Yesâ€”the boxes were left there till the eveningâ€”the prisoner claimed none of the things in the boxesâ€”she did not show me the silk dress, I found itâ€”she said Maria always kept her boxes locked, and when she came home she always went to them aloneâ€”she said, "I was not aware she had such things here"â€”she may have said, "I am taken by surprise"â€”between five and six the same evening, after leaving the police court, I went with Holland and Holmes to the houseâ€”she afforded us every facility to examine itâ€”she held up a cambric handkerchief to me, with my wife's name on it, and said I had dropped it in the morning when I went awayâ€”we searched, and found a few trivial thingsâ€”a great many things in the boxes did not belong to me, but these were new things, some very expensiveâ€”Borreman did not dress expensivelyâ€”I found the boxes as I had left them in the morningâ€”I found a few pieces of ribbon in some small cigar-boxesâ€”she said the girl had brought the parcel there a fortnight before, and she did not know what was in itâ€”one box was larger than an ordinary servant's box.

WILLIAM HOLLAND (policeman, N 146). I took the prisoner, and told her the chargeâ€”she said, "That girl has brought me into all this trouble; the boxes were always locked; she always kept the keys"â€”I saw this handker
chief in Mr. Freestone's handsâ€”he called my attention to the private mark on itâ€”the prisoner said, "The policeman left that in the morning"â€”I searched the house, and found four boxes and some bundlesâ€”the prisoner gave me every facilitvâ€”she claimed none of the propertymixed with Borre
man'sâ€”her husband is a highly respectable gentleman, and lived in the house.
NOT GUILTY .

75.
ROBERT CHALK
, stealing 48 knives, 48 forks, and other articles, value 7l.; the goods of
Marian Bailey and others.

JOB SMITH (policeman, G 44). I went with Turpin, on 27th Oct., to 53, Baldwin-street, City-road, and took the prisoner thereâ€”I searched the room in his presence, and found some duplicates in a box, in a pocket-book (produced).
HENRY TURPIN (policeman). I was with Smithâ€”I produce some knives and forks which I got at the Bell.
ELIZABETH GREY . I am bar-maid at the Bell, in Basinghall-street, kept by Mr. Robinson. On 17th Aug. the prisoner brought these knives and forks (produced)â€”Mrs. Robinson bought them.
Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. What did she give for them? A. 3s. 6d. for sixâ€”he said, "They belong to Miss Bailey, at our house," and she was obliged to part with them, as she was unfortunate.
ALFRED DABBS . I am a pawnbroker. I produce a counterpane, pawned on 8th April, by a manâ€”this duplicate produced by Smith is the one I gave.

THOMAS NEALE . I am assistant to Mr. Grant, a pawnbroker, of London-wall. I produce a book, pawned on 18th Aprilâ€”the duplicate I have corre
sponds with this one produced.
JAMES SWAINE . I am assistant to Miss Reeve, of Redcross-street. I produce a counterpane, pawned on 3rd Aprilâ€”this is the counterpart of the duplicate I kept.

MARIAN BAILEY . I am single, and live with my brother and sister, at 29, Gresham-street. The prisoner was porter thereâ€”I missed a great number of articles, and charged himâ€”he owned it, and said he would bring them all backâ€”I said he had sold the knives and forksâ€”he said he had notâ€”I said he had, at the Bellâ€”I never authorized him to sell anythingâ€”these knives and forks and snuff-box are oursâ€”the counterpanes are worth 1l. each.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the house? A. Officesâ€”the prisoner used to keep them, and his wife to clean them, and lived rent freeâ€”I and my sister do so nowâ€”my father and mother are dead, and the things are our joint propertyâ€”I never gave the prisoner or his wife things to pawn for meâ€”I have pawned things myself while the prisoner was thereâ€”his wife never went with meâ€”she went once with my sisterâ€”I did not miss the knives till Aug., and the other things afterwardsâ€”my father left a willâ€”I do not know whether it was provedâ€”I did not agree with the prisoner to pay me for these thingsâ€”he said he would bring them back, and make it all right, but he set us at defiance, and I gave him in charge a month afterwardsâ€”I did not miss the snuff-box till the policeman produced irâ€”we have not found one quarter of the thingsâ€”I missed one shilling out of my tea-caddy.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY .

76.
ROBERT CHALK was again indicted
for stealing 1 book, value 5l.; the goods of
Marian Bailey and others.
JOB SMITH (policeman). I found a duplicate relating to this book at the prisoner's lodging, in a box at the side of the bedâ€”his wife was in bed.
