THOMAS NEAVE . I am a pawnbrokerâ€”I produce a book, pawned on 18th April, by a man in the name of John Chalkâ€”the young man who took it in has leftâ€”I was present.
MARIAN BAILEY . This book belongs to me, my brother, and sisterâ€”here are my father's initials at the bottom of each plateâ€”I never authorized any one to pawn it.

GUILTY . Aged 27.â€”
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. JUSTICE COLTMAN; Sir PETER LAURIE, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. MOON; Mr. Ald. SALOMONS; Mr. COMMOS SERJEANT; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq., and the First Jury.

div1.p:
77.
JAMES MAYHEW was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged request for the delivery of Nibs, weight of tobacco, with intent to defraud
Robert Allen; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 29.â€”
Confined One Year .

78.
WILLIAM DAY
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Samuel Reed, and stealing 1 coat, and 1 pair of gloves, value 6s.; the goods of
James Charles Webb; I seal, 1d.; the goods of
Thomas Cut
ler; and 1 hand vice, I seal, I cornelian, 2 rings, and 1 ear-drop, 6s.; the goods of the said
Samuel Reed; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

79.
ARTHUR HARVEY
, stealing 2 bags, and 52lbs. weight of sugar. value 19s. 3d.; the goods or"
David Pinnett, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Six Months.

80.
CHARLES PINE
, stealing 3 pairs of shoes, value 10s.; the goods of
Pierre Surand, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Four Months.

81.
JOHN SULLIVAN,
GEORGE POWELL , and
GEORGE TUR
NER
, stealing 2 jackets, and other articles, value 3l.; the goods of
William Henman; and 1 waistcoat, and 1 pair of trowsers, 15s.; the goods of
Thomas Nowlan, in a vessel; having been before convicted; to which

SULLIVAN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.

POWELL pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.

TURNER pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.

82.
GEORGE JOHNSON
, stealing 1 shilling, and 2 sixpences, the moneys of
Maria Getliffe, his mistress; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 15.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

83.
CAROLINE ROBERTS
, stealing 2 spoons, value 17s.; the goods of
Nathan Wetherall, her master; also unlawfully obtaining 1 loaf, and other articles by false pretences; to both which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

84.
MARSHALL KINNAIRD
, stealing 2lbs. 14oz. weight of tea, value 17s. 3d.; the goods of
Thomas Christie, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 30.â€”
Confined Four Months.

85.
JOHN TRUMP was indicted
for embezzling 1s. 10d., and 1s. 10d.: the moneys of
Thomas Thurlby, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

86.
JAMES HARRIS
, robbery on
Mauricio Oribe, and stealing 1 watch, value 50l., his property; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

87.
WILLIAM BEDFORD,
stealing 2 picture-frames, value 5s.; the goods of
Ernest Benson, his master.

p.hi: The property belonging to Ernest Benson and another, the prisoner was

div1.p: ACQUITTED .
Before Mr. Justice Coltman.

88.
BENJAMIN NORTH was indicted
for carnally knowing and abusing
Mary Ann North, aged eight years.

GUILTY of an Assault. â€”
Confined Twelve Months,

89.
HENRY LAWFORD , and
RICHARD KNIGHT
, feloniously as
saulting
John Weatherley, with intent to rob him.

JOHN WEATHERLEY . I am a confectioner. On the night of 14th Nov., about half-past twelve o'clock, I was going through Holloway, near the brewery on the right hand pathâ€”I had a brown paper parcel under my arm, containing a pair of bootsâ€”I met the prisoners walking together towards meâ€”they parted to make way for me to pass between them, and as I did so Lawford attempted to strike meâ€”I parried the blow, and Knight struck me on the head with his fist, and knocked my hat offâ€”I got away from them and began shouting out for the policeâ€”they advanced towards me and followed meâ€”I kept retreating from them, baching out, and they were menacing, and attempted to pick up stonesâ€”Lawford said they would soon stop my noiseâ€”I continued calling police, and retreated some little distanceâ€”Lawford left Knight, and attempted to make liis escape up a turning which was no thorough-fjreâ€”by that time I had got to Highbury gates, and got the assistance of the policeâ€”I lost sight of Lawford, and followed Knight till I got to the lower roadâ€”I did not lose sight of him till the policeman caught himâ€”Lawford came up at the time Knight was being taken, as if he was a perfect strangerâ€”I recognized him, and gave him in charge alsoâ€”I am quite convinced he is the personâ€”the transaction took place under a gas lamp, and it was a moonlight nightâ€”I had plenty of opportunity of seeing himâ€”not a word was said by me or them before they attempted to strike meâ€”Lawford was slightly intoxicated, but far from being insensible.
Knight. I was two yards past him when his hat was knocked off. Witness. No he was notâ€”it was Knight knocked my hat off.

HENRY HALE . On the night of 14th Nov., about half-past twelve o'clock, I was following the prosecutor about fifty yards from himâ€”I heard a cry of "Police!" listened, and in the course of a few minutes heard cries of "Stop thief!" and saw Lawford part from Knightâ€”I gave chase with the prosecutor after Knight, and came up with him at Highbury Chapel, and saw him takenâ€”I saw Lawford come upâ€”they are the same two persons that I had seen with the prosecutor.

WILLIAM PEARSON (policeman, N 390). On 14th Nov. I saw Knight near Highbury, running, and the prosecutor after himâ€”I took him into custodyâ€”Lawford come up, and I took him alsoâ€”the prosecutor charged them with an assault with intent to rob himâ€”Knight said he had done nothingâ€”Lawford said nothing.
Lawford'a Defence. I was at work at the York Railway, and the foreman
gave us a supper that night at the Plough, Ilornsey-lane; "have bad a little too much to drink; tliere was no attempt to rob the prosecutor.
Knight's Defence. If I had not been intoxicated I should not have offered to do such a thing; I did not touch his hat.
(The prisoners received good characters.)
LAWFORDâ€”Aged 23.
KNIGHTâ€”Aged 22.

GUILTY of an Assault.
Confined Six Weeks .

90.
ELIZABETH WHITE
, robbery on
William Houston, and stealing 1 watch, 1 breast-pin, and 1 scarf, value 25l., 3 sovereigns, and 13 shillings; his property.

WILLIAM HOUSTON . I am a builder at 18, Praed-street, Paddington. On Sunday night, 29th Oct., I was going along Albany-street, and met the pri
sonerâ€”I had seen her beforeâ€”she said she knew me, and asked me to accom
pany her to her place, and I went with her to 8, Fitzroy-row, I thinkâ€”I went in with her, and she desired two females who were in the room to go and get something to drinkâ€”they were gone about five minutes, and brought what I understood to be rumâ€”she gave me a glass of itâ€”I had had two or three small glasses of gin-and-water before, not more than that, but was not tipsyâ€”I almost immediately became insensibleâ€”on recovering, about seven o'clock in the morning, I missed my watch, a scarf, a silk guard-chain and gold clasp to it, three sovereigns and thirteen shillingsâ€”I am quite sure I had them before I went into the houseâ€”I gave information to the police.

COURT. Q. Did the prisoner have any of the rum? A. I do not knowâ€”I did not see herâ€”I do not know whether the other women had anyâ€”while I was drinking it theywent out of the roomâ€”I was sitting in a chair when I drank the rum, and I was sitting in the same place when I awoke in the morningâ€”it appeared to me to be rum by the tasteâ€”I did not observe any bad taste as if anything was mixed with it.

GEORGE COOPER (policeman, S 276). On 5th Nov., in consequence of information, I went to apprehend the prisoner at 7, Fitzroy-row, I found herâ€”I searched the room and found five duplicates, one of which refers to a scarfâ€”at the police-court the next day she said she found it in the New-road.

ALFRED ROBERT WOOD . I conduct my mother's business, a pawnbroker at 65, High-street, St. Giles'sâ€”on 31st Oct. I took this scarf (produced) in pledge in the name of Ann White, 5, Drury-lane, and gave a duplicate for itâ€”this produced is itâ€”it was a woman that pledged itâ€”I do not know whe
ther it was the prisoner or not.

WILLIAM HOUSTON
re-examined. This is my scarf, and the one I wore that night.
Prisoner. I have nothing to say.

GUILTY of Stealing the Scarf from the Person. â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

91.
EDWARD JONES and
WILLIAM COTTERELL
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Stephen Warwick with intent to steal.

STEPHEN WARWICK . I live at 1, Northampton-square, in the parish of St. James's, Clerkenwell. On Sunday morning, 19th Nov., about twenty nmiutes past twelve o'clock, I was called up by a police-officer, and found the front kitchen shutter broken open and the sash off, a pane of glass broken, the sash-fastening pulled back, and the sash thrown upâ€”I had seen it fast at half-past elevenâ€”I always go round the house and examine the doors and windows, having been robbed before.

SARAH EXALL . I am servant to Mr. Warwickâ€”I was in the kitchen that night at eleven o'clockâ€”I had previously put the shutters to at five o'clock, and put the bar up between six and sevenâ€”the window was then fastenedâ€”on Sunday morning the window was broken, and the bottom hinge offâ€”I had slept through the disturbanceâ€”the window had not been opened during the day.

JAMES COBBETT (policeman, A 410). On Sunday morning, 19th Nov., about ten minutes past twelve o'clock, I was on duty in Northampton-square, and saw the two prisoners come up Ashby-street, from St. John-street-roadâ€”they stayed a minute or two and then got over the prosecutor's railing, and went down the steps into the areaâ€”they did not see meâ€”I was standing under a tree in the centre of the square, under the enclosureâ€”I stood there about ten minutesâ€”I heard a pane of glass break and the scrooping of shutters, a curious noise as though any one was wrenching them openâ€”I then went across the road, looked over the railing, and saw Cotterell go from the window into the coal-house under the pavementâ€”I said, "Who is there?" three times, and got no answerâ€”I then called another constable, went over the railing down the area, and saw both the prisoners standing in a corner of the coal-houseâ€”I asked Cotterell what he wanted there, and he said he had dropped his hat into the areaâ€”I asked Jones what he wanted thereâ€”he said he dropped his knifeâ€”they said they heard me coming, were frightened, and got into the coal-house out of the wayâ€”I examined the window and found it and the shutter broken.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. The outside shutter do you mean? A. The shutters are insideâ€”a square of glass was broken opposite the fasten
ing, so that any one could pull the fastening backâ€”the fastening was pulled back and the bottom sash thrown upâ€”the inside shutter was forced in about two inches from the bottom and the screws forcedâ€”no person could get in in. the state the shutters were then inâ€”I went into the kitchen, after calling Mr. Warwickâ€”there was a wooden bar across the shutters then still up.

BENJAMIN PHILLIPS (policeman, D 58). I was with Cobbettâ€”he left me outsideâ€”I saw Cotterell in the areaâ€”I knocked at the door, and Mr. Warwick let me inâ€”while knocking I saw Jones come out of the coal vault, the door of which was standing openâ€”there was no fastening to itâ€”I after
wards went in there and found this dark lantern and a jemmy (produced.)

JAMES COBBETT
re-examined. The pane of glass was not wholly taken out, only the bottom part of itâ€”there was room enough for a person's hand to be put in to unfasten the windowâ€”it might be done with a chisel or other instrumentâ€”you could put your thumb and two or three fingers throughâ€”the fracture was close to the fastening.

(MR. PARRY submitted that a sufficient entry was not proved to sustain the charge, no part of the person of the prisoners having been proved to be intro
duced. The COURT left it to the Jury to say whether the hand was or was not introduced to undo the fastening.)

JONESâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 19.

COTTERELLâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 18.

92.
GEORGE JARVIS
, stealing 12lbs. weight of horse-hair, and two leather linings of carriages, value 2l.; the goods of
Frederick John Woodford and another; having been before convicted.
FREDERICK JOHN WOODFORD . I live at 1, Hertford-cottages, Kingsland, in the-parish of St. John, Hackneyâ€”I have a yard attached to my house,

where I keep flys. On the night of 5th Nov. there wns one fly there of mine, and one belonging to John Steven Clements, standing at liveryâ€”I have no doubt they were sale when I shut up at eleven o'clockâ€”I did not look inside themâ€”next morning I saw Morrell, who had the leather lining of the flyâ€”in consequence of what he said, I went into the yard and found the squab of the two flys torn out altogether, and the horse-hair with itâ€”they were worth about 35s.â€”the leather that Morrell showed me matched exactly.

WILLIAM MORRELL . (policeman, N 135). On Monday morning, 6th Nov., about half-past six o'clock, I met the prisoner with a lanje bundle of horse-hair under his armâ€”I asked him where he got itâ€”he said he found it in a fieldâ€”I saw part of the back lining of a carriage sticking out of his pocket, and asked him where he got it fromâ€”he said he had brought it from home, it was the lining he had torn out of his mother's old cloakâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”I afterwards went back, and, thrown over a garden wall, close to where I found the prisoner, I found the remaining portion of the liningâ€”I afterwards went with the lining to Mr. Woodford's, and it matched with the carriages in his yardâ€”it made up all that was wanting.
Prisoner's Defence. I found it hid under some turf in a field.
(The prisoner received a g'ood character.)
CALEB SWORDS (policeman). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's convictionâ€”(read, "Convicted, Sept. 1846, confined six months")â€”I was presentâ€”the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 14.â€”Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

93.
JAMES LEVITT
, stealing 1 jacket, value 1s., the goods of
Joseph Monkhouse; and 1 jacket, 1s., of
Alexander Sandford, in a vessel in a port, &c.

JOSEPH MONKHOUSE . I am an apprentice on board the Elizabeth Archerâ€”the prisoner came on board there last Tuesday, and asked if I had any old clothes for saleâ€”I said, "No"â€”there was a pair of old shoes in the fore
castle; he asked if he might have them; I said, "Yes"â€”I came out of the forecastle, shut the door, and went to my dinner, leaving a jacket on the pig-houseâ€”when I came back I found a policeman had him in custody, and the jacket was goneâ€”I afterwards saw it at the police-station.

Prisoner. I asked you if I might have the old jacket and the old shoes. Witness. Xo, he only asked me for the shoesâ€”at the station he asked me to look over it, and he would treat me well the next day.

WILLIAM FISHER (policeman, H 100). On Tuesday last, 28th Nov., I saw the prisoner on the Spirit-quay, London-docks, coming from where the Elizabeth Archer was lyingâ€”I asked him what lie had gotâ€”he said two old jackets and a pair of shoes that the apprentice had given himâ€”he said the apprentices were on boardâ€”he went and showed me the ship, and then he said they were gone away to dinnerâ€”I took him to the station, left the jackets there, and brought him on boardâ€”when the apprentice came on board I asked him if he bad given the prisoner the jacketâ€”he said, "No."
Prisoner's Defence. The young man gave me the jackets and the old shoes.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Five Months.

94.
JAMES BROOKS
, stealing 8 feet of wooden board, value 1s. 4d., the goods of
Charles Archer, his master.
CHARLES ARCHER . I live at North-place, Chelseaâ€”the prisoner was in my employment about three years as a sawyerâ€”this piece of deal was shown

me by my brother, the prisoner, Rose, and my nephew; they all brought it togetherâ€”I know it to be mineâ€”I was looking over the first-quality tier of wood a fortnight previous, and saw this particular piece among itâ€”I took such notice of it as to be able to know it againâ€”I was quite certain, as soon as I saw it, that it was my property.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. I believe the prisoner has borne the highest character? A. Yesâ€”the Magistrate admitted him to bailâ€”as soon as he was spoken to about the board, he said that on the Saturday Mr. Moth had given him a board to saw to put a cut inâ€”he did not tell me he had brought that board and left it in my place on the Saturday evening, and after he had received his money, it being dark, he took this board, thinking it was hisâ€”if he had told me that, I should not have taken any stepsâ€”he did not say a word till after he was out on bailâ€”I saw Mr. Moth on Mondayâ€”he saw the board at the stationâ€”he said he had given him a board, but he did not believe that to be the boardâ€”he had had it in the place about a twelvemonth, and it was much more soiledâ€”he did not say, in my presence, that it was extremely like it; but looking more closely at it, he did not think it was itâ€”the prisoner was paid, I should think, on Saturday about six o'clockâ€”I do not think it was as late as sevenâ€”I did not search for Mr. Moth's board on my premisesâ€”I had no idea there was any board thereâ€”I am aware that the prisoner did some work previously for Mr. Moth, to cut boards in twoâ€”he did not use my toolsâ€”he never cut anything on my pre
misesâ€”I believe he cut them at Mr. Todd's.

COURT. Q. What passed between you and the prisoner on the Monday morning? A. I stated to the prisoner that that was my propertyâ€”he said he had received a board from a Mr. Moth, a greengrocer in the New-road, to put a cut inâ€”my brother, the two other parties, and the prisoner went down to Mr. Mothâ€”all four returned with the board in their possessionâ€”one of them, I do not recollect which, said that when Mr. Moth saw the board, he said he had given him a board on the Saturday evening something like the one in their possessionâ€”he could not swear to it, but believed it was not the oneâ€”the prisoner still persisted in his innocence, saying that he hoped he should not move from the place if that was not the board he had received from Mr. Mothâ€”I told him I had no other stepâ€”to take to prove who were the guilty parties without taking him and the greengrocer before a Magistrateâ€”I was confident that one of them had robbed me of that boardâ€”during the three years the prisoner was with me he conducted himself in a very praiseworthy manner.

MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Were there a number of boards of all sizes and de
scriptions lying about your premises where he stated he placed the board? A. Yesâ€”it has never occurred to me that a mistake might be made.

WILLIAM TAUNTON . I am pot-boy at the Enterprize, in June-street, Chelsea. On Saturday evening, 4th Nov., the prisoner came to my master's about seven in the eveningâ€”he told me he had taken a board into the back-garden, and asked me to take care of it till Mondayâ€”he said it was a job he had got, and it came to fourpenceâ€”his partner Rose came in about five minutes to twelve that night, gave me some directions, and on Monday morning I delivered it up to the prisoner and his partnerâ€”Mr. Arthur's brother and nephew were with themâ€”Rose is a sawyer in Mr. Arthur's employ.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen Rose here to day? A. Yesâ€”the prosecutor's nephew was with the prisoner when he came on the Saturday even
nig, and had a pot of porter.
CHARLES ARTHUR . I met the prisoner about seven o'clock in the evening

in a new road cut through a brick-field at the top of North-street, Chelseaâ€”he had a board with himâ€”his partner Rose was with meâ€”I said, "Have you got a job of carpentering?"â€”he replied he had not, he had got a board to cut which came to fourpenceâ€”we all three went to the public-house together, with the board, I do not exactly know who carried it, and it was then put in a back place somewhereâ€”we had a pot of beer, and I went back to Mr. Arthur's to settle for my week's workâ€”I left them at a shop in North-street, and did not see them again that nightâ€”I had suspicions that the board was my uncle's, but did not make any remark about itâ€”I did not know itâ€”there is a mark on it, but I did not see it at the timeâ€”I gave a slight information to my uncle's foreman, his brother, George Arthur, on the Saturday evening, but told him to inquire of my uncle whether he had sold it or notâ€”I and he went and looked at it on the Monday, and he claimed it as his brother's.

Cross-exaviined. Q. Were you at work at your uncle's that day? A. Yesâ€”the prisoner did not put the board down in the tap-room, we stood at the barâ€”he made some remark to his partner that he was going to bring the board up to his house, but instead of that he would leave it there till the Monday morningâ€”I have heard that the prisoner was some time ago about to be pro
moted to the office of foreman at my uncle'sâ€”another uncle of mine filled that place; the uncle that went with me about the boardâ€”my uncle's place is full of boards of various sizesâ€”I did not search for Mr. Moth's board; I believe my uncle didâ€”Mr. Moth did not, when he first looked at the board, say it was the board he had given himâ€”he said it was a dirtier board than thatâ€”it was getting towards evening when I saw the prisoner carrying the boardâ€”I do not know whether it was light; it was about seven o'clock.
WILLIAM KING (policeman, B 198). I produce the boardâ€”he told me he did not steal the board, he had had it from a man to cut.

CHARLES ARTHUR
re-examined. This is my boardâ€”I know it by a knot in it, which I noticed because I thought it had no business to be among the first qualityâ€”it was a 12-foot board, but a piece has been cut off.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you mention to any one that your brother could identify the board, but you could not? A. No; but as soon as I saw it I identified it.
Jury. We think it was a mistake.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Sir PETER LAURIE, Knt., Ald.; MR. RECORDER; Mr. Ald. MOON; Mr. Ald. SALOMONS; Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Fifth Jury.

div1.p:
95.
JOHN BROWN and
JAMES HOARE,
stealing 93lbs. weight of lead, value 12s.; the goods of the C
ommissioners for Paving, Lighting, and Cleaning the Regent's Park; having been before convicted; to which

BROWN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 20.

HOARE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined One Year .

96.
CHARLES YARWOOD
. stealing 1 umbrella, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Edward Augustus Hewitt; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

97.
ANN BERTINI
, stealing 1 chair, value 2s. 4d.; the goods of
William Brett: also, 2 iron weights, and 5 brass knobs, 2s. 6d.; the goods of
William Houlahan; having been before convicted; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 32.â€”
Confined Three Months.

98.
MARIA CARLOTA ALVEZ CABRAL and
MARIA ROSA
, stealing 3 towels, and other articles, value 5s. 3d.; the goods of
Hester Pitman.

HESTER PITMAN . I am a widow, and keep a lodging-house, in Finsbury-square. The prisoners came to lodge there in Aprilâ€”Cabral was represented to me as a Baroness; she was married in Mayâ€”Rosa acted as her servantâ€”each of them had a bed-roomâ€”they boarded with me, and used the rooms of the house as well as other boardersâ€”they had access to the dining and. drawing-roomsâ€”Rosa's bed-room was opposite to her mistress'sâ€”having missed many articles, I spoke to Sergeant Brannan, and he came to my house on 2nd Nov.â€”he went up with me to Rosa's bed-roomâ€”some towels, and other things, were found there, between the mattress and bedâ€”some of them were sewn up in an old apron belonging to Rosaâ€”some soap and other things were found there, which Brannan took possession ofâ€”I speak Spanish, which is understood by both the prisonersâ€”I spoke to Rosa in Spanish, and told her they were my thingsâ€”she said they were for her useâ€”I said all that she had for her use was the linen on her bed and one chamber-towelâ€”she did not make any other replyâ€”I then went to her mistress's room, being, called by the officerâ€”it was between nine and ten o'clock in the morningâ€”she was up, but her husband was notâ€”we had to wait till he got upâ€”we then got admission, and found her concealing a silver brooch, which had been lost in Aug. last, under her shawlâ€”there were two towels round her waist, under her clothes, and two pieces of soap under her arms, under her dressâ€”the towels were cleanâ€”they had not been supplied for her use; I do not know where they were taken fromâ€”I had the giving out of her linen myselfâ€”she and her husband had each of them twice a week a clean towelâ€”there were other clean towels in the room for their useâ€”there were some men's shirts foundâ€”I have missed other property, which I have not yet tracedâ€”she did not say anything about whose these things wereâ€”the value of what I found in her room, including the brooch, was about 2l.

COURT. Q. Has she ever shown any symptom of insanity? A. Noâ€”I have not traced the sale or pawning of any articleâ€”the watch and guard
chain have not been foundâ€”the soap found was two pieces of common mottled soap, and a piece of scented soap.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. They boarded at your table? A. She never dined at my table, but her husband didâ€”they boarded in my houseâ€”they might pay altogether about a guinea a dayâ€”the towels were all marked with my name, in the same way as those I was giving out to the lodgersâ€”my daughter gave them things out by my desire, but not more than I orderedâ€”some of the things in Rosa's room were dirtyâ€”some of them were wrapped up in a newspaperâ€”she had not as much of this common mottled soap as she liked; when she asked me for a piece she had itâ€”she used to wash some of her mistress's clothes and her own, some were put outâ€”the shirts have been in my possession fifteen yearsâ€”there is no mark on them, but I know them, having seen them a great many timesâ€”neither of the pri
soners speak a word of English.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant G, 20). I went to the prosecutor's on 2nd Nov., between nine and ten o'clockâ€”I went up stairs'â€”I told the inter
preter,

who was with me, to make the servant sensible who I was, and what I came forâ€”I went into her bed-room, and found between the bed and the mattress a newspaper, with two clean towels in it, which Mrs. Pitman claimedâ€”I also found these other articles there, which I threw out on the landing for her inspectionâ€”here are stockings, pieces of linen, shirts, and a pair of drawers, they were between the bed and the mattress, and some pieces of soapâ€”part of the things were sewn up in an apron, which I placed on the landing, and Mrs. Pitman claimed themâ€”Rosa endeavoured to snatch the bang from me, which was sewn at both endsâ€”when I was on the landing I saw Cabral in her bed-roomâ€”I noticed her put something down her bosom, and two towels and three pieces of soap were found there by Mrs. Pitmanâ€”I saw two towels found in the wardrobe in the room occupied by her and her husbandâ€”the wardrobe was not locked.

FRANCISCO GAVARETTE . I was residing in Mrs. Pitman's house at the time this affair occurredâ€”I went up when the officer came thereâ€”I told Rosa that the officer came to search herâ€”she said she had no objectionâ€”I addressed the prisoners in Spanish, which they understandâ€”they answered me in Por
tugueseâ€”Rosa said some of the things were her's.
Cross-examined. Q. She did not claim the shirts? A. She said one shirt was her brothers and one was her master's, but the master said it was not.

HESTER PITMAN
re-examined. These articles are all mine.
Cross-examined. Q. They had a little while before given you notice of their intention to go away as soon as there was a ship going to Portugal? A. Yes.

COURT. Q. Was she married in May to a Portuguese gentleman? A. Yesâ€”he has never been charged with any of these thingsâ€”he was in the roomâ€”he was very angry with her when the brooch and other things were taken from herâ€”J do not know that they had quarrelledâ€”I had no know
ledge that she was lightheadedâ€”before she was married there was a consul
tation with five physicians to ascertain whether'she was in her senses or not, and they gave thuir sentence that she was in her sensesâ€”her future husband called them inâ€”I do not know that it had been reported that she had been out of her mind, and that was the reason these five persons were called inâ€”I have heard her say that she was confined a great many years; not on ac
count of her being out of her mind, I believe she gave herself voluntarily up to go into a convent, she was kept out of her property.
NOT GUILTY .

99.
MARIA CARLOTA ALVEZ CABRAL was again indicted
for stealing 1 brooch, value 20s.; the property of
Hester Pitman.
JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant, G 20). I saw the prisoner fold this piece of paper round somethingâ€”I took it from her hand and found in it this silver brooch.

HESTER PITMAN . This brooch is mineâ€”I missed it in August last from the mantel-piece in the back parlourâ€”the prisoner went in and out of that roomâ€”I made inquiries in the house, and a thorough search was madeâ€”it was not foundâ€”I spoke to the prisonerâ€”she did not make any answer about it, nor her servantâ€”I told her that the brooch was lost, and Rosa heard me speak of itâ€”search was made immediatelyâ€”I never heard any tidings of it till the officer cameâ€”Cabral had seen it in my child's bosom many times.
Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Whose is it? A. Mineâ€”my child

is under ageâ€”she is fifteenâ€”she is no thereâ€”I had never worn the broochâ€”when I saw it last it was in my back parlour, on the chimney-pieceâ€”it was a gift to my daughter by her eldest sisterâ€”my daughter was inti
mate with the prisonerâ€”the prisoner had ornaments of her own, she never lent any to my daughterâ€”the prisoner paid me, and after she had been before the Magistrate she came back to my house and lived there, and her husband lives there now.
FRANCISCO GAVVARETTE . I was present when the things were taken from the prisonerâ€”when she came down she said her servant had found the brooch down stairs and iiad given it to her.
NOT GUILTY .

100.
MARIA CARLOTA ALVEZ CARBAL and
MARIA ROSA were again indicted for
stealing 1 watch, value 23l., and 1 guard-chain, 4l.; the property of
Hester Pitman; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

101.
SUSANNAH COOK and
THOMAS MAIERS were indicted for
stealing 23 paintings, value 20l., and 9 painting-frames, 50s.; the property of
Richard Gale, the master of Cook; and
JOSEPH ROWLAND
for felo
niously receiving the same: Maiers having been before convicted.

RICHARD GALE . I live at 47, High Holborn, and am a picture-dealerâ€”it is my dwelling-houseâ€”I have a gallery at the back of my shop up one pair of stairsâ€”I keep some of my pictures in that galleryâ€”I have also a small back room up another flight of stairs, in which I keep other picturesâ€”I was not at all aware that I had been robbed of any pictures till the 16th Oct.â€”I kept pictures in that room and gallery which were not immediately wanted, and I had not been up there for nine or ten weeks before I discovered my lossâ€”Cook had been in my service for about four months, I had a good character with her, and believed her to be honestâ€”I trusted her with the key of a door which led from the shop to that galleryâ€”she had that key before we were up in the morningâ€”on 16th Oct. I missed pictures from the gallery, and the room, and on the 17th Oct., I was in St. Mary-Axe, and saw a pic
ture of a huntsman blowing a trumpet, in Rowland's shop windowâ€”I knew it was mineâ€”I went in, made inquiries, and waited till Rowland came inâ€”I said, "I have been robbed to a considerable extent, 50l. or 60l., if you will act straightforward, and provided you tell me the truth, and will give me every facility to find the person you bought them of, and will not let any person know of the robbery, that I may find my property, you shall not be a loser"â€”I further said, "My motive in making this proposition is, that I may apprehend the thief, and if I discover more of my property elsewhere I may claim it," but he mentioned the robbery directly to other people, he broke the promise directlyâ€”he said he had purchased the pictures of a person who gave the name of Falk, who was introduced to him by a Jew that he knew very well, and from whom he had often purchased picturesâ€”I wrote down an address which he gave meâ€”I found two more of my pictures in his windowâ€”I then asked permission to look round his shopâ€”I found as many more pictures as made up fifteen or sixteenâ€”these are them (produced)â€”here is one, which is a cattle picture by Listerâ€”he is a well-known artist, whopaints inferior pictures at moderate pricesâ€”I had seen Rowland on the subject of this picture at my placeâ€”he offered me a sovereign for it, and said he would give me a sovereign a piece for as many as I had of that artistâ€”that was at my own place five or six months agoâ€”after my conversation with Rowland

I told him I should put it into the hands of the police. and I told him to let the pictures remain where they were till I came back with the officerâ€”I went awaysâ€”I left four on five of the pictures in the frames in which they had been taken from my house and where I returned in two hours, or two hours and a haft, with the policeman. I said to Rowland, "Where are the pictures that I saw here this morning, they have been removed out of the shop, the frams are here, but the pictures are gone?â€”he asked me to repeat the promise I had made in the morning, in presence of the policemanâ€”I did soâ€”he then said, "Now I will produce the pictures"â€”he went to the hack premises, and produced the fifteen or sixteen pictures that I had seen in the morningâ€”three or four smaller pictures had been taken out of their framesâ€”"The Huntsman" was notâ€”the policeman told him the pictures must be restored to their framesâ€”he did not restore the person of whom he had purchased the picturesâ€”he said of a young man about five feet eight or tune inches high, with a light complexion, and a moustacheâ€”he said he had given the name of Falk, that he was related to Mr. Falk of Oxford-streetâ€”he was then cautioned to keep the pictures, and I and the officer leftâ€”before I left I found about half a dozen more pictures, as many as made up twenty-twoâ€”on Monday morning, 23rd Oct. Maiers was taken into custody, and on the same day I gave Cook into custodyâ€”on the day after Rowland had been given into custody, I found at his place three other picturesâ€”that would make twenty-fiveâ€”I found no others that I could swear toâ€”just as I had found the other three pictures, Rowland came homeâ€”he had been admitted to bailâ€”he produced the duplicates of nine paintings which had been stolen from meâ€”I saw them at the pawnbroker's, at the police-court, and they are now hereâ€”in answer to a question, he said he had no duplicatesâ€”he then said, "I recollect I have some"â€”he produced the duplicates, and said, "I bought them of a man, but I had forgotten the cir
cumstance"â€”I had told him that Maiers was in custodyâ€”the duplicates I found in his possession produced the pictures I had lostâ€”I have lost altoge
ther 110, or 120, worth 120l. or 130l.â€”they had nearly emptied the room, and the gallery beside.

Croos-rxammetl by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You have some very good painting? A. I have none very valuableâ€”forty or fifty pictures were foundâ€”some of them I had put awayâ€”I thought they had been seen too longâ€”tins picture to the man blowing the trumpet is by George Haynesâ€”this cattle Lister's. he paints a are it many of these pictures, but I never saw two alikeâ€”he has painted for me for several yearsâ€”I never knew him to paint two alikeâ€”Rowland said he would give me a sovereign for thisâ€”I gave two for itâ€”I did not show him any otheiâ€”the same artist has done pictures for the Art-Union for twenty or thirty guineasâ€”they are the prizes in the Art-Unionâ€”I have known it to be the case, that pictures which I get painted for 25s. go there for 25l.â€”I should say I have 500 picturesâ€”Rowland has a great manyâ€”I should say there were 100 in his shop, and perhaps 150 kept down stairs in a place which had the appearance of a workshopâ€”I do not think I can pick out the nine pictures which I found, after I found the first fifteen or sixteenâ€”some of them were small, and might have escaped his attentionâ€”I have seen him at picture salesâ€”he buys a great manyâ€”he had not bid for the huntsmanâ€”in two or three transactions which I had with him he paid me for What he boughtâ€”he brought twenty-two pictures to Bow-street himselfâ€”the policeman told him to bring them, and he didâ€”the cattle scene was one.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you see the clerk take down what Rowland

said? A. Yesâ€”the Magistrate put his name to itâ€”this is itâ€”this other is the statement made by Maiersâ€”(readâ€”"The prisoner Maiers says as fol
lows:â€”Let the girl be discharged, it was not her; if I am to suffer, let me do it."

Maiers. Q. Did you ever see me at your place? A. Only onceâ€”I heard the bell ring as I was coming down stairs in the morning, about a quarter before eight o'clock, and I saw you speak to Cookâ€”I did not see her give you anythingâ€”you ire the person who was there.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What took place? A. The bell rung, and Cook passed me and spoke to himâ€”they were'evidently acquaintancesâ€”he then saw me, and he said, "Does Mr. somebody (mentioning some name) live here?"â€”she said, "No," and shut the door in his face, though they had been conversing as friends just before.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Have you a porter? A. An occa
sional porterâ€”he comes to open the shop about half-past eight o'clock in the morningâ€”that is the usual hour.

COURT.Q. What was to prevent the porter gaining access to this gallery and back-room? A. The person must have gone through the shop and through the door which leads to the passageâ€”the porter always opened the shop at half-past eightâ€”the middle door was always locked at niuht, and Cook had the key in the morningâ€”the porter had no access till she let him in at half-past eight.
Maiers. Q. Did you sell any pictures a short time before we were in custody? A. Yes; not on the Friday beforeâ€”I sold some frames.
COURT. Q. Did you ever sell any to Maiers? A. No; certainly not.

SAMUEL ROLFE. I am in the employ of Mr. Bunday, a portmanteau-maker, in Holborn. I have seen Maiers at Mr. Gale's shop-door twenty or thirty timesâ€”I have seen him speak to Cook before eight o'clock, in the middle of the day and in the evening, when she came out for beerâ€”I have seen him speak to her once or twice a weekâ€”one morning, about three weeks before he was taken into custody, I saw him walk up and down close by the door two or three times, and when he got an opportunity he spoke to some one at Mr. Gale's doorâ€”it was then about half-past seven or a quarter to eight o'clockâ€”I could not see who it was he was speaking toâ€”I was side
ways, and the person was inside the doorâ€”after he had spoken to the person, he left the door, with two paintings, one in each handâ€”that was prior to the shop being opened.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. What day was this? A. I did not keep it in my headâ€”I have seen him so oftenâ€”the shop opens generally about half-past eight o'clockâ€”it is never opened before, unless the porter has to go somewhere elseâ€”I do not think I have seen it above once or twice in a twelvemonthâ€”it was not eight when I saw Maiers at the door.
Maiers. Q. How did I carry the pictures? A. In your hands, exposedâ€”I did not see you with any other pictures.

JOSEPH GRAY . I live at 46, High Holborn, and am shopman to Mr. Brown, a bookseller. I have repeatedly seen Maiers hanging about Mr. Gale's shop before it was openedâ€”I saw him for about four or five weeks before he was takenâ€”when I have seen him go there, he has had nothing with himâ€”I saw him on two distinct occasions go into Mr. Gale's house when the door was partly open, and come out with a picture in each handâ€”I met him once in Holborn, he had nothing with him, but there was a lad behind with a pictureâ€”I looked into his face, and he looked at me.
EDWARD FAULCONER . I live in Pemberton-row, Gough-squareâ€”Maiers

lodged at my mother's up to the time of his being takenâ€”he was in the habit of coming home with pictures. between seven and eight o'clock in the morningâ€”he was not lodging at our place when he was takenâ€”he left on a Monday, and on the Thursday before he. had brought pictures home in the morning.
COURT. Q. Did you notice the pictures he brought home? A. Some of themâ€”this is oneâ€”this is another, and this is another which he had (looking at those produced).
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. He his had this one a long time? A. Yes; lour or five weeks.
Cioss-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you go to sell some? A. Yesâ€”I do not know how manywere-sold, but he told me he was to receive 17l. for them.

FREDERICK FOX . I am shopman to a pawnbroker, of 13, Old-street. I produce ten paintings, five of them were pawned on 2nd Oct, by Maiers, for 25s., four on 9th Oct., for 30s., and one on 12th Oct., for 30s., all by Maiers.

RICHARD GALE
re-examined. Two of these were found at Rowland'sâ€”these ten pictures are part to what I lost.

JOHN COCK (policeman.) I found this duplicate of the large pictures for 30s. in. Maiers' box, at his lodgingsâ€”these other two duplicates, which refer to these nine pictures, I received from Rowland.

FREDERICK FOX
re-examnwd. These duplicates, found at Rowland's, are for these nine pictures, on which 2l. 15s.â€”was lent.

Maiers. I did not pawn this large picture; a man pawned it, and I went into the shop and bought the duplicate of him. Witness. I am sure you are the person who pawned this oneâ€”I saw you on every occasion.

WILLIAM SMITH (policeman, E 30). I was taken by Mr. Gale to Row
land'sâ€”I have heard Mr. Gale's evidenceâ€”it is correctâ€”I took Cook into custody on 23rd Oct., at Mr. Gale'sâ€”I found this letter in her box.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Was Cook there when you found it? A. Yesâ€”the box was in her bed-roomâ€”she pointed it out as hers, and gave me the key to open it.

JAMES JACOBS . I am a translator of languages, and live in Somerset-street. I have known Maiers about four yearsâ€”I know his writingâ€”I believe this letter to be his writingâ€”I would not swear to it. (This letter being read, addressed Cook as "My dearest and only-beloved Susannah," and alluded to his desire to possess a keepsake in remembrance of her.)

JAMES COLEBY. I am porter to Mr. Gale. I never opened the door to Maiers any morning between seven and eight o'clockâ€”I have seen him a number of times at Mr. Gale's door when I have been going to shut up in an eveningâ€”he came for the servant.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. What time did you open? A. At half-past eight o'clock, never above two or three minutes beforeâ€”I have been there about eight, and was let in b) Cookâ€”I then left, and went away, and trie door was shut after me.
COURT. Q. What was the earliest time you have been employed to remove goods? A. Never before eight o'clock.

ABRAHAM MYERS . I have known Rowland about twelve years. I have a picture by Sherlock, which I bought of Rowland for a sovereign, six or seven weeks agoâ€”this is itâ€”it is a picture I could buy at James's for about 25s.â€”Sherlock paints them for about 15s.â€”I have bought them for the value of the canvass.
Cross-examined by MR BALLANTINE. Q. You buy them to sell? A. Yes;

I stood at Garraway's coffee-house for thirty yearsâ€”I am not a dealer in great pictures; I buy them to get a livingâ€”I get 4s. or 5s. by a pictureâ€”I know Maiers; I bought three pictures of himâ€”pictures of this sort are awked a boutâ€”I would sell tlm one for 25s.

RICHARD GALE
re-examined. These pictures were taken from my gallery, and wwre afterwards brought to the police-court by Rowlandâ€”this picture of "The Irishman" was not brought at all; I found it on the top of a cupboard in Rowland's houseâ€”it is a picture by Flint, and is not so valuable to me as to some othersâ€”it had the name on the back, but it has been rubbed off.

COURT. Q. Has it occurred to you to be possible that under the pre
tence of courting Cook, Maiers has been shown the gallery, and that he had taken an opportunity of taking the pictures unknown to her? A. I conceive it impossible, as he must have passed through a room where she was employed, and up two flights of stairs, to get to the galleryâ€”it might have been done with one picture, but not with all.
JOHN COX (police-sergeant, C 12). I produce a certificate of Maiers's former conviction at this Courtâ€”(readâ€”Convicted July, 1847, and confined six months)â€”he is the person.
(Cook received a good character.)

COOKâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.â€”
Confined One Year . MAIERSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Trans
ported for Fourteen Years.
ROWLANDâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

102.
JOSEPH ROWLAND was again indicted
for feloniously receiving 3 paintings; the property of
Richard Galeâ€”( No evidence was offered.)
NOT GUILTY .

103.
HENRY BRAMALL, alias Beaumont
, was indicted
for bigamy.

GEORGE SOWRAY . I am a clerk in the Registrar-general's Office. I pro
duce the book of licenses for marriagesâ€”here is a license for Princes-street Chapel, Devonport, in the district of Stoke Damarel, in the county of Devonshireâ€”it is an Independent Chapelâ€”it is dated 18th Aug., 1837â€”there is nothing to alter the registration of that place.

JOSEPH ELMS . I am superintendent-registrar of marriages at Stoke Damarel, Devonshire. I produce a book from the registry, which contains the register of Princes-street Chapel, in East Stoke Damarel district, on the 18th Aug., 1837â€”I also produce the register of marriage thereâ€”on the 28th Aug., 1839, Henry Edward Bramall and Rebecca Coath, of full age, bachelor and spinster, were married according to the rites of the Scotch Church, by Alexander Fletcher, minister pro tern.
JOHN DIAMOND . I live at Swansea. On 18th Aug., 1839, I was at Devonportâ€”I was present at the marriage of the prisoner to Miss Coathâ€”I signed the registerâ€”I saw her alive about two years since.

REV. ALEXANDER FLETCHER . In Aug., 1839, I was officiating as minister in Princes-street Chapel, Devonportâ€”on the 18th Aug. the prisoner was married by me to Rebecca Coathâ€”I performed the ceremonyâ€”this is my sig
nature to the registerâ€”they applied to me through Mr. Diamond, an acquaintance of his, and maintaining a respectable character.
WILLIAM MIDLAND . I am a drug agent, and reside in London. I know Rebecca Coathâ€”I saw her on Wednesday weekâ€”she is residing with her friends at Liskeard, in Cornwall.

GEORGE HARCOURT STUBBING . I am clerk to the City Solicitorâ€”I pro
duce

a copy of an entry from the register of marriages in the parish Church of Barnstapleâ€”I examined it word by word at the parish Churchâ€”it is a true copyâ€”(readâ€”"March 25, 1843, Henry Beaumont, surgeon, residing at Barn
staple, was mirried to Elizabeth Tinley, by me,â€”HENRY LUXMORE, Vicar."

JAMES COPELAND . I am a draper, and live at Barnstapleâ€”I was living there in March 1843â€”I was present on the 25th March 1843, when the pri
soner was married in the name of Henry Beaumont, to Elizabeth Tinleyâ€”I signed the book.

ELIZABETH TINLEY I was married to the prisoner in March 1843, in the name of Beaumontâ€”he lived with me about three months before he went to seaâ€”he has been to sea and back ever since I knew himâ€”he finally left me twelve months last Mayâ€”I was then living in Charles-place, Hoxtonâ€”when I married him I had so much a year to keep me, and furniture, and plate, and clothes.â€”he told me he was going to Americaâ€”he engaged a ship tor, himself and meâ€”my clothes were sent on boardâ€”he went and took them ana left me, taking all my money and clothes.

GUILTY . Aged 29.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

There were two other indictments against the prisoner for
marrying
Han
nah Amelia Bland , and
Emily Georgina Rose ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY â€”
Transported for Seven Years more .

104.
CHARLES HEATH was indicted
for stealing 1 copper boiler, value 12s.; the property of
Samuel Richard Arnott,: having been before convicted.

CHRISTIAN RANDALL . I left some work I was engaged in at No. 52, Noel street, Islington, on 14th Nov., between four and five o'clock in the eveningâ€”there was a copper in the brick-work in the back kitchenâ€”in the morning it was gone.

THOMAS PARKIN CUFF (policeman, N. 230.) I heard a noise in the empty house, No. 52, Noel-street, on the night of the 14th Nov. about eight o'clockâ€”I saw the front door of the house was openâ€”I ran to it and saw the figure of a man go towards, the stairsâ€”I heard some one in the back kitchen at the rear of the houseâ€”I went down stairs, took a match out of my pocket, got a light, and saw the prisoner get out of the window to the yardâ€”I went out at the front doorâ€”I sent to the station for a bull's-eyeâ€”I at last took the prisoner out of a water-closet at No. 11, Montague-placeâ€”I had had such an observation of his person as to say he is the same man I saw in the kitchenâ€”this copper was behind the front door of the house, I had heard a noise in the house.

Cross-pxammed by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were you not outside the house? A. Yes; I went to the doorâ€”if I had waited I do not know whether they would have brought the copper outâ€”I drove them back to the back-premisesâ€”it was a small lucifer match that I lightedâ€”I could see the prisoner by thatâ€”he got through the windowâ€”I cannot say whether he turned and looked at meâ€”I should say it might be a dozen yards from the house in Noel-street when I found the prisonerâ€”I found his hat in the garden adjoining the gar
den of the house where the copper wasâ€”I ound the prisoner in five or ten minutesâ€”he stid, "Don't illuse me."
JURY. Q. Was the hat one that would fit the prisoner? A. Yes; he denied it being his that night, but in the morning he said, "I mar as well own it," and he took and kept it.
SAMUEL RICHARD ARNOTT The house 52, Noel-street is mineâ€”this copper is mineâ€”it is worth 12s. or 15s.
WILLIAM RENDER (policeman N 252.) I produce a certificate of the
prisoner's former convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted June 1848, and confined three monthsâ€”the prisoner is the person.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
Confined One Year .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. MOON; Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq., and the Third Jury.

div1.p:
105.
FRANCES BARRETT
, stealing a pawnbroker's ticket, value 1d.: the property of
Frances Lee.

FRANCES LEE . I am single, and live at St. Bartholomew's-terrace, Bethnal-green. The prisoner used to come to see meâ€”on 30th Oct. I sent my sister, Mary Ann Lee, to pawn a gownâ€”she brought the ticket, and I put it in a tea-caddyâ€”the prisoner remained there from four till eight o'clockâ€”on the next Saturday I missed the ticket, and have not seen it since.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Is your sister much like you? A. No; my hair is light and hers darkâ€”the prisoner lives at Wapping; the pawnbroker's is in the Mile-end-road, about half a mile from thereâ€”her sister-in-law does not live a quarter of a mile from the pawnbroker'sâ€”I was there on Thursday, between three and four in the afternoonâ€”the prisoner was there washingâ€”I went with the prisoner to the pawnbroker's on Friday the 10thâ€”I did not ask the pawnbroker's young man whether she was the personâ€”I did not speak to him.

MARY ANN LEE . I am sister of the last witness, and live with my father and mother. On 13th Oct. I pawned a gown for my sister at Mr. Ashbridge's, in the Mile-end-road, and took her the money and ticketâ€”I put the ticket in the tea-caddyâ€”the prisoner was there.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you before the Magistrate when the pawnbroker was examined? A. Yes; I heard him say that my sister pawned itâ€”he afterwards said he had made a mistake.

HENRY LEE . I am an iron plate-workerâ€”the last witnesses are my daughtersâ€”on 2nd Nov., about twenty minutes to seven o'clock, I met the prisoner in the Cambridge-road with something under her arm, going in a direction from Ashbridge's, the pawnbroker's, to her own home.

JOHN WILLIAM PETO . I am assistant to Mr. Ashbridge, pawnbroker, of the Mile-end-road. On 30th Oct. Mary Ann Lee pawned a gown with meâ€”I gave her a ticketâ€”the duplicate is hereâ€”on 2nd Nov. the prisoner brought the duplicate and redeemed itâ€”I did not know her beforeâ€”I am sure of her.

Cross-examined. Q. Has Mr. Ashbridge a very large business? A. Not very; he has three assistantsâ€”I advanced the moneyâ€”I swore before the Magistrate that Frances Lee pawned the gownâ€”the Magistrate called my attention to it, and I corrected myself and said I had made a mistake in con
sequence of the likeness between the two sistersâ€”I was not positive which sister pawned itâ€”I did not give the gown to the person who brought the ticket, but I stood byâ€”the young man who gave it was before the Magistrate, but he did not recollect the circumstance, and I was broughtâ€”Frances Lee iskuii me if the prisoner was the person who brought the ticket, and I said it "asâ€”I do not recollect the time it Mas broughtâ€”I cannot say whether it was
daylightâ€”it was between twelve and seven o'clockâ€”I understand the prisoner has witnesses to account for where she was all day,
GEORGE MULLETT (policeman). I took the prisonerâ€”I took her to the pawnbroker's with other femalesâ€”Peto identified herâ€”I told her the chargeâ€”she said, "I know nothing about it."
NOT GUILTY .

106.
FRANCES BARRETT , was again indicted
for stealing 1 gown, value 8s.; the goods of
Frances Lee; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

107.
CHARLES HUTCHINSON and
FREDERICK FIELD
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; the goods of
John William Foster: Field having been before convicted.

ANN CASE . On 2nd Nov., between twelve and one at noon, I was at my bed-room window, which looks into Mr. Foster's garden, and saw Hutchinson get over the wall, walk half-way down the garden, take a handkerchief which was hanging up to dry, and give it to Field, who was stooping down at the wallâ€”they both ran across a fieldâ€”I went down and got close behind them, and heard Hutchinson say, "I wonder what the lady would give us if we told her who stole the handkerchief"â€”Field put it into his breast-pocketâ€”I followed them into the Ball's-pond-roadâ€”they turned up a court and ranâ€”I called, "Stop thief!"â€”they were stopped and taken to the stationâ€”I have not seen the handkerchief since.
GEORGE LANGDON (policeman, N 265). I searched the prisoners at the Kingsland station, but iound nothingâ€”Ilutchinson said the parties that took it in away.

RACHAEL FOSTER . On 2nd Nov. I had a handkerchief hanging out to dryâ€”I missed it between twelve and oneâ€”it was my husband's, John Wil
liam Foster.
Field's Defence. I saw two boys take it and give it to another boy.

WILLIAM MONAGAS (policeman). I produce a certificate of Field's con
victionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted July, 1848, confined three months)â€”I was presentâ€”he is the person.

HUTCHINSONâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 17.â€”
Confined Six Months.

FIELDâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

108.
JOSEPH SLATE ,
GEORGE TAYLOR , and
HENRY SUTMIRE
, stealing, 58 yards of Orleans cloth, value 2l. 10s.; the goods of
William East White.

WILLIAM HENRY WHITE . I live with my father, William East White, a draper, in the Kingsland-road. On 16th Nov., about half-past two, I re
ceived information, ran into the road, and saw the prisoners running away togetherâ€”Slate and Sutmire had two pieces of cloth eachâ€”I pursued them into Albion-square, and lost sight of them just as they turned the cornerâ€”I turned and saw them again, caught them, and gave them all in custodyâ€”there were four at first.
GEORGE KNIGHT WHITE . I am one of the prosecutor's sons. I ran with my brother and picked up these two pieces of cloth, which I had seen safe two hours before.
ROSINA ANN TYLER . I live near Mr. White. I was at my window, and saw the prisoners come from his shopâ€”one of them had something under his apronâ€”I told Miss White.
ROBERT FORD (policeman). Mr. White gave Slate and Taylor into my
chargeâ€”Sutmire was brought to the station in five or ten minutes with these pieces of cloth.

WILLIAM THORNELL (policeman). I produce a certificate of Taylor's con
victionâ€”(readâ€”Confined one month and whipped)â€”he is the person.

SLATEâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 17.â€”
Confined Six Months.

TAYLORâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 16.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

SUTMIREâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 16.â€”
Confined Six Months.

109.
ELIZABETH WILLIAMS and
LYDIA LEE
, stealing 5 yards of fringe, value 2s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Clarke, from the person of
Mary Watkins.

MARY WATKIVS . I am in the service of Mrs. Clarke. On 21st Nov., at half-past ten in the day, I was in a lane at Kensington with a parcel contain
ing a visite trimmed with fur, and some fringe by the side of itâ€”I met the prisoners in the laneâ€”Williams asked me if I would have my fortune toldâ€”I made no reply, but was going on, when Lee snatched at my parcelâ€”the paper gave way, and she took the fringeâ€”two young men at the top of the lane turned and lookedâ€”she threw it down and ran offâ€”the constable ran after them.
Lee. I picked it up, said, "Here is your fringe," shook the dirt off it, and gave it you, and you said, "Thank you?" Witness. It is not true.
ELIZABETH CLARKE . I am single. Watkins is my servantâ€”I sent her with a parcel containing a visite and some fringeâ€”it belonged to Mrs. A'Becket, a customer.

HENRY COLLIER (policeman). I took the prisoners at the Admiral Kep
pell.

WILLIAMSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 15.

LEEâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 15.

110.
GEORGE WILSON was indicted
for embezzlement.

ROBERT CLARKE . I am a licensed-victualler, of Pimlico. The prisoner was my potman six or seven weeksâ€”he absconded on the 28thâ€”four shil
lings were due to himâ€”it was his duty to receive money and settle for it on Saturday eveningsâ€”he did not settle before he left for any money for that weekâ€”he paid me no money received from Mr. Jones.
WILLIAM JONES . I live at Denham-road, Chelsea, and dealt with Mr. Clarke for beerâ€”the prisoner brought itâ€”the last money I paid him for Mr. Clarke was 7s. 2d.â€”I usually paid on Saturday night.
Prisoner. Q. Did I give you any bill? A. No; I dealt with Mr. Clarke, not with you.
JOHN SMITH (policeman). I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I sold the beer on commission; I was not able to make up what I had received; I intended to pay Mr. Clarke as soon as I could.

GUILTY . Aged 27.â€”
Confined Four Months.

111.
JAMES LALLEY
, stealing 6 calf-skins, value 1l. 10s.; the goods of
Joseph Barber.

JOHN WILLIAMS (Thames-policeman, 4). On 10th Nov., between six and seven in the evening, I stopped the prisoner on Tower-hill with this bag on his shoulderâ€”I asked what he had in itâ€”he said, "That is my business"â€”I found it contained some hidesâ€”I asked where he was going with themâ€”he said, "Home"â€”I said, "Where do you live?"â€”he said, "That is my busi
ness"â€”I took him in chargeâ€”he threw me on my back and made his escapeâ€”the scavenger stopped him, and I got him againâ€”he said, "You could not
blame me for getting away"â€”I took him to the station, and found six calves hides and a tally in the bundle.

JOHN CHADBURN . I am foreman at I Brewer's-quay. I missed six bundles of calf-skins from a gateway thereâ€”I had landed them on 28th Oct.â€”there was this tally with them; I swear to itâ€”the prisoner had been employed on the quay, but not latelyâ€”I had seen him there several days, and ordered him awayâ€”I believe this to be one of the bundles of skinsâ€”they were in the care of Joseph Barber.
Prisoner. Q. What did you order me to leave the quay for? A. Because I suspected you of stealing cheese.

GUILTY . Aged 40.â€”
Confined Six Months.

112.
ELLEN LEVERETT
, stealing 11 sovereigns and 2 half-sovereigns; the moneys of
Patrick Sullivan, in his dwelling-house.

PATRICK SULLIVAN . I am a labourer, of 1, Rosemary-lane. On Saturday night, 3rd Nov., I was with Birch in the Prince Albert public-house, Tower-hillâ€”as I went home, within twenty-five yards of my house, the prisoner, who is my daughter, came to meâ€”she is about thirty-eight years oldâ€”her husband is a cab manâ€”she got into the house with me in spite of me, as I was taking the key out of the doorâ€”I could not get her outâ€”I was ill, and threw off my coat and waistcoat to go to bedâ€”I had eleven sovereigns and two half-sovereigns in my waistcoatâ€”I counted it then, folded the waistcoat up carefully, put it down, turned round, and saw her with it under her armâ€”she threw it downâ€”I went to it, and found nothing in the pocketâ€”I called to my son, and sent him after herâ€”she left her pattens and umbrella behindâ€”she had followed me out of the public-houseâ€”I had given her and others some drink, and then walked out at one door, and she at the other.
Prisoner. Q. Did not I ask you to lend me a trifle? A. I gave you 2s. a few days before, and that was the third time in a fortnightâ€”I was sober.
WILLIAM HEARN BIRCH . I am an artist, of 13, Cooper's-row, Tower-hill. I was at the Prince Albert, and saw Sullivan put his money awayâ€”I walked part of the way home with himâ€”he was quite sober.

JOHN SULLIVAN . My father told me somethingâ€”I went after the prisoner next morning, and found her sitting on the bed in Portpool-lane, where she livesâ€”I asked her where the money was which she had taken from her fatherâ€”she said she wished she had moreâ€”I asked her to send part backâ€”she said she took noneâ€”I gave her in charge.

Prisoner. Q. How long were you in the house before you fetched the policeman? A. Half an hour or three quartersâ€”you sent me three times for ginâ€”you gave me a shilling the first time, and two fourpenny-pieces afterwards

ARCHIBALD JEFFERY (policeman G, 88). I was called to the prisoner's house, and found her drunkâ€”I told her the chargeâ€”she said she had received 2s. from her father, as he supposed, but one was a sovereign, and she did not tell him his mistake, because she was deserving of itâ€”I took her in charge.

GUILTY . Aged 38.â€”Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined Eight Months.

113.
EDWARD ACKERMAN
, stealing 1 weighing-machine, value 18s.; the goods of
Alfred Shepherd and others; having been before convicted.

JAMES FINCH . I am errand-boy to Alfred Shepherd and others, of Crane-court, fleet-street. About six weeks ago the prisoner came to the shop, and said he came for the scales for Mr. Caudle, our scale-maker; that they were to be cleaned, and we should have them presentlyâ€”I saw them given to him
â€”he took them awayâ€”I went to a public-house with the policeman, and found the prisoner.

WILLIAM TAVERNER . I am warehouseman to Messrs. Shepherd. Finch called meâ€”the prisoner was thereâ€”he said he came for the scales from Mr. Caudle, to adjust and cleanâ€”he took them away, and never returned.

GEORGE CAUDLK . I am a scale-maker, and contract with Messrs. Shepherd to keep the scales in orderâ€”if anything wants repairing they are brought homeâ€”I never sent the prisoner for themâ€”I do not know him.
JOHN LOIN (policeman). I took the prisoner.
WALTER HENRY BROWN . I produce a certificateâ€”(readâ€”Convicted Sept., 1847; confined three months)â€”I was presentâ€”the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

114.
JOHN M'NEIL was indicted
for bigamy.

HENRY WILLIAMS . I am a sergeant of the 25th Foot, quartered at Chat
ham. I have known the prisoner upwards of nine years, and was present at his marriage, in the beginning of Aug., 1839, to my niece, Emma Phillipsâ€”she is alive, and is hereâ€”I do not know how long they lived together; I went to India.
ROBERT BURN (policeman, C 125). I have a copy of the register of marriages at St. Pancrasâ€”I examined it with the register-bookâ€”(read).

ELIZABETH MARY BONNETT . I live in Greek-street, Soho. I became acquainted with the prisoner; and on 13th Nov. last married him, at St. George's, Bloomsburyâ€”he said he was singleâ€”I went away with him to a public-house, and afterwards went to my aunt'sâ€”I heard something, went hack to the public-house, and gave him into custody.

Prisoner. Q. How is it that you gave me your wrong name? A. I gave "Phillips" firstâ€”you had known me by that name three or four monthsâ€”I have known you altogether since the beginning of last Aug.â€”I told you when you intended to publish the banns that my name was Bonnettâ€”I told you of my uncle's improper conduct towards me, that was not why I claimed your protectionâ€”you told me your wife had committed adultery, and attempted suicide by throwing herself off Westminster-bridgeâ€”I went to the station, and saw her, and you told me it was a woman in keeping.
Prisoner's Defence. My first wife committed adultery, and we parted by mutual consent; I thought I was free; there must have been some plot in it, as I was taken before the marriage was consummated.

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
Confined Eight Months.

115.
DANIEL GUY was indicted
for stealing 1 scarf, value 30s.; the goods of
Thomas Davis; having been before convicted.

THOMAS DAVIS . I am a gardener, of Princes-street, Portman-square. On 8th Nov. I laid my scarf on the counter, and went into the parlour, at the back of the shopâ€”in about an hour and a half I heard a cry, went into the shop, and missed itâ€”I have not seen it since.

SARAH PIPER . I am a servant. I saw Mr. Davis's scarf on the counter, about seven o'clock in the eveningâ€”I was in the parlour, and saw the pri
soner come into the shopâ€”I did not know him beforeâ€”he went on his hands and knees, took the scarf, and ran awayâ€”I went out, but did not see himâ€”I described him to the police, and picked him out of seven or eight others on the Friday afterwards.
JAMES CLARK (policeman, D 268). I received information, and saw the prisoner and several others in Portman-market. I took Piper there, and told

her to look at a lot of eight or ten, and see if she could see the man who stole the scartâ€”she picked out the prisonerâ€”I took himâ€”he said he knew nothing about. it; that I made the girl swear false.
CHARLES BENNETT (policeman). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction (readâ€”Convicted June, 1847; and confined three months)â€”I was presentâ€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 17.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

116.
WILLIAM STEERS
, stealing 2 pickaxes, value 5s. the goods of
Jonas Gregson and others, his masters.

JAMES BRANNAN (policeman, N 9). On 31st Oct., about eight o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner and another person in White Lion-street, Pentonville, at the door of a marine-store shopâ€”he was speaking to the other person, who went away, and the prisoner went into the shopâ€”I went away, came back in about two minutes, and met him coming out of the shop with these two pick
axes, without handles, under his armâ€”he said he had been working at a sewer, at Holloway, and gave a false name and address.

WILLIAM ROWBOTTOM . I am in the employ of Jonas and George Gregson, contractors for the Birmingham Junction Railwayâ€”the prisoner was in their employ, as a labourer, at a shed at Ball's-pondâ€”he had to stop after the other men were gone, to trim lampsâ€”he had nothing to do with the pickaxesâ€”these pickaxes produced belong to Messrs. Gregsonâ€”there is "O" on them in white paint, which has been tried to be rubbed outâ€”they have a peculiar eyeâ€”we had seventy-two, and missed threeâ€”they were ordered specially; I never saw such anywhere else.
Prisoner. You said, before the Magistrate, you had sold half a dozen. Witness. Yes; but they remained at our place.

JOHN INGHAM . I am watchman to Messrs. Gregson. On 31st Oct. I went on duty at six o'clock, and saw the prisoner and another trimming the lamps at the shedâ€”the pickaxes were kept thereâ€”they left at half-past six, and did not come back.

WILLIAM GREGSON . I am the time-keeper. On Tuesday evening, a little past five o'clock, I went to the prisoner in the yard, and found him trimming the lampsâ€”it is my duty to look after the servantsâ€”I went a little way with him, and parted with him about half-past sixâ€”I saw nothing bulky about him.
Prisoner's Defence. The sub-contractor told me I might have a couple of picks if I liked, as he owed me for three days' work.

WILLIAM ROWBOTTOM
re-examined. The sub-contractor could not get at them without coming to me; the prisoner could.

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Three Months.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq. and the First Jury.

div1.p:
117.
MARGARET LYNCH,
ANN BRIANT , and
CAROLINE ARCHER
, stealing 3 half-crowns, 6 shillings, and 3 sixpences, the moneys of
Errington Robson, from his person; Briant having been before convicted.

ERRINGTON ROBSON . I am a mason, at Limehouse. On 4th November, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I was going along Shadwellâ€”the three prisoners came up to me, one shoved her hand into me breeches pocketâ€”I
got hold of itâ€”the other two rushed on me, and pushed me down backwardsâ€”they ran off, taking 15s. out of my pocketâ€”I gave informationâ€”I was not sober, but knew what was going on.
JAMES DODD . I live with my mother, at Palmer-Street, Shadwell. I was

the prisoners and anotherâ€”I knew them by sightâ€”I followed them into Palmer-streetâ€”they went up to Robsonâ€”Lynch put her hand into his pocket and took out some moneyâ€”the other two knocked him downâ€”I saw them passing something to one another, which looked like moneyâ€”Lynch said, "Let go my hand; I have not got it all"â€”I followed them, and pointed them out to the constable.

JAMES CLARKE . I live with my father, in Palmer-street. I was playing in the street, and saw the prisoners and anotherâ€”I knew Lynch well by sightâ€”she put her hand into Robson's pocket, and took out some moneyâ€”the other two rushed on him, and pushed him downâ€”one of them laid hold of Lynch's hand, and she cried out, "Leave go my hand; I have not got it all"â€”I saw something pass between them.
JEREMIAH FORD (policeman, K 317.) I received information, and took the prisonersâ€”the fourth person could not be identified, and was dischargedâ€”Lynch escaped, and was taken again.
WILLIAM CHARLES POTTER (policeman). I produce a certificate of Briant's conviction (readâ€”Convicted Oct. 1846; and confined Six Months)â€”I was presentâ€”she is the person

LYNCHâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.
BRIANTâ€”
GUILTY . * Aged 24.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.
ARCHERâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

118.
RICHARD CALVERT
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 5s.; the goods of
Lewis Jacobs; having been before convicted.

LEWIS JACOBS . I am a clothes dealer. On 8th Nov. I gave Ann Mad
don a pair of boots to cleanâ€”this boot (produced) is one of them.

ANN MADDON . I am in Mr. Jacobs' service; he gave me the boots to cleanâ€”I put them on a step, turned round, and missed themâ€”I saw the prisoner and another iooking in ac the windowâ€”I called "Stop thief!" and they ran.

JOSEPH MADDON . I am no relation of the last witnessâ€”I was on Saffron-hill, heard a cry of, "Stop thief!" and saw the prisoner running, and he dropped somethingâ€”I picked up this bootâ€”I am sure he dropped it.

ALEXANDER TURNER (policeman, G 56). I saw the prisoner running in Saffron-hill, with a pair of boots in his handâ€”I followed himâ€”he was stoppedâ€”I asked him where the boots wereâ€”he said he did not know anything about them; it was not him that took them.

WILLIAM WALLIS . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former con
viction (readâ€”Convicted Sept. 1847; and confined three months)â€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

119.
SAMUEL JAMES HAYLAND
, stealing 2 boxes, 12 spoons, 8 forks, and other articles, value 2l.; the goods of
Eliza Carter.

ELIZA CARTER . I am single. On 16th June I went in an omnibus to King's-cross. I left four boxes at the toll-house thereâ€”I employed the prisoner as a porterâ€”he took two with me to my lodgingsâ€”I sent him back. for the other two, and never saw him again or the boxes.
JOHN KEEN . I was at the toll-house, and Miss Carter left her boxes there, returned, and employed the prisonerâ€”I saw her go away with him with two boxesâ€”he came back and took the other two away.

JEREMIAH LOCKABY (policeman, S 180). I went in search of the prisoner, and found him on 10th Nov.â€”I asked him about the boxesâ€”he said he knew nothing about themâ€”I asked if he lived near King's-crossâ€”he said he had

not been there for several yearsâ€”in goin along he said, "I will tell you all about it: I did carry the boxes. I took them to the house, the lady gave me 1s., and I went to act change"â€”I used to see him before 16th June, but he absconded after that.
Prisoner's Defence. I took the boxes, and believe I left them at the same house as I left the first at.

GUILTY . Aged. 25.â€”
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; MR. JISTICE COLTMAN; Mr. Ald. THOMPSON; Sir PETER LAURIE, Knt., Ald.; Sir CHAPMAN MARSHALL, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. MOON; Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Eduard Bullock, Esq., and the Second Jury.

div1.p:
120.
WILLIAM BARRYMORE,
stealing 1 coat, 1 waistcoat, 1 pair of trowsers, and 1 pair of boots, value 4l. 10s.; the goods of
Robert William Elliott: also 1 coat and other articles, 4l. 10s.; the goods of
John Wilkinson: also 1 coat and other articles, 9l. 10s.; the goods of
John Newby Howe, in his dwelling-house: to all which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 45.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

121.
GEORGE TURNER, alias
Peter Hutchinson ,
unlawfully obtaining 1s. of
George Jevers, by false pretences; also 1s. from
John Saunders, and 1s. from
John Kelly to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

122.
WILLIAM NYE and
GEORGE WILLIAM NYE
, stealing 1 half-crown, 3 shillings, 1 sixpence, 4 pence, and 2 halfpence; the moneys of
Charles Moore, the master of
William Nye: to which they both pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

123.
HENRY FOSTER
, stealing 4lbs., weight of beef, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert Finch to which he pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Four Months.
Before Mr. Justice Coltman.

124.
EMMA SAINT MART was indicted
for stealing 2 rings, value 40l.: the goods of
Sir John Hare, Knt.

SIR JOHN HARE , Knt. I reside in the Royal Crescent, Bath. I was formerly a merchant at Bristolâ€”I know the prisonerâ€”I first became ac
quainted with her in the early part of 1846â€”she was then Miss Todhunterâ€”she resided with her mother, who is married to Count Gabrouski, a Poleâ€”I saw them at the house of mutual friends once or twiceâ€”I was in Paris in Jan., 1847, saw them there, and renewed my acquaintance with themâ€”I left Paris on 6th Jan (reffering to his diary)â€”the prisoner and her mother came to the same hotel I was staying atâ€”I gave my rooms up to them, and they staid there a short timeâ€”I went back to Paris on 30th Marchâ€”I found them packing up, just on the point of leavingâ€”the) left the day afterwards

â€”I left Paris soon afterâ€”I merely went to Paris to pay my accountsâ€”I made a stay of some days at Boulogne, and then came to Londonâ€”I received a note from them in London, requesting me to call on them; and I did so, at their lodgings in St. John's Woodâ€”I found them there, and the prisoner's present husband, the Baron St. Mart, alsoâ€”I learnt from them that she was about to be married to himâ€”they stated that they were to be mar
ried in two or three days, and they invited me to dine with them; which I didâ€”they stated that they expected papers from France, and the marriage was to be deferred till they arrived, which would be in about ten daysâ€”they invited me to dine with them three or four times, and to go to a party with them, and as they said they had nothing to doâ€”I invited them in return to spend a few days with me at my house at Bathâ€”they accepted the invita
tion, and arrived there on Saturday, 24th April, the Countess Gabrouski, Miss Todhunter, and the Baron St. Martâ€”they remained till the following Thursday, 30th Aprilâ€”on Monday, 26th, I dined at home with these three personsâ€”there was no one else there that dayâ€”after dinner I had occasion to write one or two short letters, which I did at my portable desk, with the intention of posting them on the way to an evening party to which we were invitedâ€”they were all sitting close to me in the dining-roomâ€”I took this casket, containing a diamond ring, out of the deskâ€”it was one of these two caskets (producing two)â€”they were both lying on the top of the desk, in the open partâ€”I opened the one containing the diamond ring, and placed it on my fingerâ€”is was a large diamond, with small diamonds round it, what is called a cluster-ring, I wore it when I went to any respectable partyâ€”Miss Todhunter (that was the young lady's name at the time) requested me to let her look at it, and I took it off, handed it to her, and she placed it on her fingerâ€”she then said, "What have you in the other casket?"â€”I took it upâ€”it contained an emerald ringâ€”it was an emerald in the centre, surrounded by small diamondsâ€”it was so remarkably small, that I could not get it over the small joint of my little fingerâ€”I handed it to herâ€”she held it in her hand, and remarked what a very small finger Lady Hare must have hadâ€”I had mentioned that these were my wife's ringsâ€”I am a widowerâ€”one ring was on her finger, and one in her hand, and she said, "I will keep these things"â€”I then requested her to return them, saying that I set a very high value on themâ€”she said, "No, I will keep them"â€”I said, "You must not keep them, for they were my wife's rings, and you must give them up," and I used every effort I possibly could to obtain them from herâ€”I requested her to give them to me repeatedly, and she repeatedly refused, and said she would keep themâ€”she did not assign any reason whateverâ€”I was anxious to save the post, and took the letters to the Post-office, and after that went to the partyâ€”the Baron went with meâ€”I returned from the party between eleven and twelve, I should thinkâ€”I do not think I saw the prisoner that nightâ€”I think they were gone to bed; I am not certain about thatâ€”I did not during their stay, till the Thursday, renew my application about the rings: it never occurred to meâ€”I was exceedingly busy on the Tuesday in going to market, and providing things that were requiredâ€”I had a large dinner-party that dayâ€”on the Wednesday Mr. and Mrs. Pennington came down, and of course I did all I could to make them welcome, and got another dinner for them, and we went to the assembly in the eveningâ€”on the Thursday the whole party leftâ€”I was too much engaged from the Monday to the Thursday to speak about the ringsâ€”I was going to market, and providing different things to make them comfortable, and never thought of the rings till they had left the houseâ€”I was invited to the wedding, which was to take place on the Saturdayâ€”I
