left Bath on the Friday (30th April) for that purposeâ€”I called on them at their house, in Thayer-street, on my arrival in London, about fourâ€”they were at dnnerâ€”I was invited to partake of it, and sat downâ€”during the dinner some one came in, and the prisoner was called away to go up stairs, and as she was going from the room, I got up from the table and said, "Bring me down my rings"â€”I said that in a low tone of voiceâ€”she made no answer, but went up stairs, for about five minutesâ€”when she came down, she came up to me and said, "What did you say when I left the room?"â€”I said, "Bring down my rings," repeating the same words,â€”she then said, "I have not got your ring's"â€”I then appealed to the Countess, and I said her daughter had my rings, and I had requested her to bring them downâ€”a scuffle, at least high words, ensued, and I left the houseâ€”I went next morn
ing to a relation of mine, Mr. Charles Fleay. and he accompanied me back to the houseâ€”J went in with him, introduced him, and then I went outsideâ€”I went to him the same night, but did not see himâ€”I am not certain whether I went back to the house that nightâ€”he accompanied me on the Saturday morningâ€”that was the morning of the prisoner's marriageâ€”I remained in the street after introducing himâ€”he came out and joined me after some time, and made a communication to meâ€”I called at the house myself, between eight and nine in the evening, accompanied by Sir Alexander Downey and Mr. Mackinnon, of the Lie of Skyeâ€”I think I saw the Countess, the Baroness, and the Baronâ€”I demanded the rings again, and said I had brought friends with me to demand themâ€”they said they had not got my ringsâ€”I believe the Countess spoke, but I am not certainâ€”they all denied having them, in factâ€”I saw the prisoner while I was there, but whether she was in the room when I first went in, I am not quite certainâ€”the Baron came towards me to force me out of the room, when my friends interferedâ€”I did not get the ringsâ€”I then went to the police-office, in Marylebone-lane, but there was no Magistrate thereâ€”I called at the house on the Monday, and learnt that they had left England on the Sundayâ€”they were partially married on the Saturday, and the marriage was completed in the Catholic Chapel on the Sundayâ€”I am not quite certain how long I remained in England, but I was in Boulogne on 26th July following, and saw the prisoner there with her husbandâ€”whilst there a communication was made to me by the Prefect of the Department on this subjectâ€”I had frequently before that been speaking of the loss of my ringsâ€”I remained some time at Boulogne, going backwards and forwards to Paris occasionallyâ€”I did not hear a word of my rings till I received this letter from Police-Sergeant Hockaday, on 6th Nov. in the present yearâ€”I was then in Bathâ€”I had never heard of such a person as Hockaday before I received the letterâ€”I sent a description in answer to that communication, and followed it up by immediately coming to Londonâ€”I arrived there the same day I received the letter, the 6thâ€”I went to the station-houe, from where the letter was directed, saw Hockaday, and put into his hands a description of the ringsâ€”in consequence of what Hockaday told me, I took steps to have the prisoner taken into custodyâ€”I was with the officer when she was arrestedâ€”on being told what she wns taken for, the Countess (her mother) said, "That man (meaning me) is mad, and that is his keeper"â€”the officer was in plain clothesâ€”the prisoner implored me very much to let her goâ€”she en
treated, and said, "Oh, Sir John, pray let me off! pray let me off! pray for
give rre '" and supplicationsâ€”a gentleman came up and was interfering, when I said, "If you interfere with justice, I shall give you in charge"â€”the prisoner was Ukjn to the station, and alter three examinations was com
mited for trialâ€”I should sayâ€”40/. is the very smallest value of the ringsâ€”I
had never had any conversation with the prisoner about those rings, or any others, till the afternoon when I produced them from the casket.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKBURN. Q. When did you retire from busi
ness? A. About eight or ten years agoâ€”I became acquainted with the Countess and her daughter in 1846â€”it may have-been in 1845â€”I believe it wasâ€”the Countess was then living at her house, 11, Bentinck-terraceâ€”I once went to a pic nic with herâ€”I do not think I visited her on any other occa
sionâ€”I believe I dined there onceâ€”I am not quite sureâ€”this is a diary of 1847 (handing it to Mr. Cockburn)â€”I think it was Mrs. Col. Fitch that intro
duced me to the Countessâ€”I do not think that I saw them again after the pic nic until I met them abroadâ€”most likely I called on her after I was introducedâ€”I do not recollect that I did, but I should as a matter of courseâ€”in 1846, I met them in Bolongue, where I was staying at the timeâ€”I went there in Dec., 1845â€”there were a good many other persons there at the timeâ€”I was there for the same reason as many others: little railway mishapsâ€”I was there, and at Paris for nearly two years, frequently coming to England, I came openlyâ€”I never had the least hesitation in coming to Englandâ€”I saw the Countess and her daughter at Boulonge, and renewed the intimacy thereâ€”I saw very little of them thereâ€”I went to Paris, and met them there at the boarding-houseâ€”that was in Dec. 1846â€”they gave me their address; I did not ask for it, they volunteered it, and I called on them next dayâ€”I dined at the same boarding-house frequentlyâ€”five times at leastâ€”I think not moreâ€”I swear I did not dine there twenty times, or a dozenâ€”I think five or six times was the mostâ€”it was a public table, where ladies and gentlemen dinedâ€”it was not the boarding-house I was stopping atâ€”I was at the Hotel Mauriceâ€”there is a table d'hote there, but it is the fashion in Paris not to dine at your own hotelâ€”gentlemen frequently go about to boarding-houses to dineâ€”when I rode out in my carriage they asked me to allow them to make a call or two, and 1 took them out once or twice while I was at the boarding-houseâ€”I lent them my carriage once or twiceâ€”I did not imagine that a par
ticular sort of wine would be good for the young lady's complaintâ€”I was recommended to take a particular wineâ€”it was so good that most likely I recommended it to all my friendsâ€”I think it is most likely I sent the prisoner some of itâ€”I could not sit at a table, and not ask a lady to take wineâ€”I did not get some wine from my wine-mercbant, and send it to herâ€”she requested to know where I got the wine, and the lady who got it for me procured some for the prisoner likewise, and she paid for itâ€”it did not occur to me that the apartments were too close, and not good for the young lady's healthâ€”the Countess said she was almost dead from suffocationâ€”she was sleeping in a back room, and begged I would ask Mr. Saunders whether there was room in the hotel I was stopping atâ€”I applied to Mr. Saundersâ€”he could not accommodate them exactly as they wished, and as my month was up in two or three days, I gave my apartments up to them, and I went and lived in the upper part of the house, not in the atticâ€”it was a very large houseâ€”I left Paris on 6th Jan., and returned about two months afterwardsâ€”I called on themâ€”they were then packing up to leave, and having a dispute witb the landlordâ€”they were going the next day provided the landlord would allow, themâ€”they did leave the next dayâ€”I did not express any regret whatever at their being about to leave Paris so immediately; I swear thatâ€”not even as a matter of common-place civilityâ€”I do not think I was even so polite as thatâ€”I was told at the same time that the lady was going to be marriedâ€”they left next day for Bolongue I supposeâ€”I saw one of them on

board the ship next day at Bolongueâ€”I am not certain whether I saw both or notâ€”I cannot say: it was a matter of so little importanceâ€”they left Paris the day after I arrivedâ€”I see by my diary that was 30th March, and they left on the morning of 31stâ€”I left aain the next day, or the same night, I am not quite certain whichâ€”it is vury likely I travelled through the night, I cannot recollect, I was so frequently going backwards and forwards between Paris and Bolongueâ€”it was my custom to see every steamer offâ€”it is the fashion at Bolongueâ€”I am in the habit of following the fashionâ€”I went on that occasion, and saw one of the ladies on boardâ€”they did not express surprise at seeing me, after leaving me at Paris the night beforeâ€”they could notâ€”I was on shore, and they on boardâ€”I do not know that they said they were surprised, and I said I came to say-good by to themâ€”I know a gentleman named Owen; I do not remember calling on him that morningâ€”I do not recollect that I told him I had just been to see two ladies off by the steamerâ€”Owen never said, "What! is that the young lady you have been so sweet upon?"â€”he never said anything of the sort; I swear thatâ€”I left Bolongue on Saturday, 10th April, for Folkestoneâ€”my visit to Paris was very shortâ€”I went because my coachman had requested I would come to pay for the keep of the horsesâ€”I had sent him money previously, and he made use of it for his own purposes, considering it as wages, and I thought next time I would go to pay my bills myselfâ€”there was the coachmaker to pay, and the coach
man's lodging, the keep of the horses, and various little thingsâ€”I think the coachmaker's bill was about 1, 600 francsâ€”I did not think it safe to intrust the payment of that to an agentâ€”when I was at Paris the Countess gave a ball at our houseâ€”I sent in part of the refreshmentsâ€”I asked my friends, and she asked hersâ€”it was on 3rd Jan.â€”I did not pay half the expensesâ€”I dare say I paid as little as I could: I paid some of itâ€”I sent in a dozen of wine now and thenâ€”the very same sort of wine that I was in the habit of drinking, and I sent in a few things from the confectioner's besides; tarts, or something of that sortâ€”I came to London on 10th Aprilâ€”I went to Bath on 13th, and came back to London on 15th to go to Court, to the Drawing-roomâ€”I called on the ladies on 18th, at St. John's Woodâ€”they afterwards removed to Thayer-streetâ€”I dined with them on 21st, and met Mr. and Mrs. Penning
ton there, who invited me to their ball on the following dayâ€”I wentâ€”it is very likely I may have danced a quadrilleâ€”I am frequently in the habit of dancingâ€”I am about sixty years of ageâ€”it is not sixty-fiveâ€”I believe between sixty-one and sixty-twoâ€”it is not sixty-fourâ€”I swear I am not. sixty-fourâ€”I will say I am sixty-four for the sake of saying somethingâ€”the Countess said that Mr. Pennington had business to do at Bath, to sign some. papers which were to be sent off, and I then invited them down to my houseâ€”the Countess, her daughter, and the Baron St. Mart came down on Saturday, 24thâ€”I cannot tell what time they arrivedâ€”they slept there that nightâ€”the next morning the party, most likely, assembled at breakfastâ€”the young lady was generally lateâ€”it is always my custom at my house to wait till all the party are assembledâ€”I did not distinguish the place which the young lady was to occupy at the table in any particular modeâ€”I cannot say that I never make a bit of poetry, or sometimes give a young ladyaboquetâ€”I do not recollect placing a copy of verses in the prisoner's plateâ€”I may have placed a boquet there; I do not remember itâ€”I am not particularly in the habit of paying attention to young ladioâ€”I hope to be always civil to all ladiesâ€”if a young lady stopped at my house* I may have put vi-rses into her plate two or three timesâ€”I do not recollect anything about itâ€”I think it is most likely I put (lowers into her

plateâ€”I have no doubt I didâ€”I did not do so every morning she stayed thereâ€”I never recollect placing verses thereâ€”it is very likely 1 used to call her "Missey"â€”I do not recollect that I addressed her as "Missey" in these poetical effusionsâ€”I do not recollect anything about the versesâ€”I do some
times make a few verses, but not particularly addressed to young ladiesâ€”on the 26th I dined at home with the Countess, Baroness, and Baronâ€”I suppose we dined about half-past six, that is the usual hourâ€”I was going to a party that evening in Pulteney-streetâ€”I proposed to the ladies to go with me, but they declined because they had not evening dresses with themâ€”the Baron went with meâ€”he was with me when I posted the lettersâ€”I did not go any
where else that eveningâ€”the room in which this conversation about the rings took place is about fifteen feet by eighteen or twentyâ€”we were all sitting at the same tableâ€”my portable desk was on an adjoining table, under the win
dowâ€”I got up from the table to write my lettersâ€”the rings were in two sepa
rate caskets in my deskâ€”I very seldom wore the diamond ringâ€”I generally wore the emerald ring which I have on nowâ€”I only wore the diamond ring on very special occasionsâ€”this was a very large party that I was going to, and I should have worn it thereâ€”I took it out of the casket for the purpose of putting it onâ€”I did not call the Baroness's attention to it and say, "Look here Missey, here is a very pretty diamond"â€”she said, "What a beautiful diamond you have on"â€”it was very large and very brilliant, and of the very finest description, and the diamonds round it were also of the finest descriptionâ€”the diamonds round the emerald ring were also of the finest waterâ€”she asked me to let her look at the ring, and I did soâ€”I think it is possible I had worn the ring in her presence beforeâ€”I had it with me at Parisâ€”I should say I did not wear it at Mr. Pennington's ballâ€”I had it with me in Londonâ€”I have, no doubt, danced with the prisoner; not many times; not whenever I had the opportunityâ€”I do not know that I ever danced with her more than once or twiceâ€”I have been with her on occasions when I could have danced with her more than once or twiceâ€”there were balls at the boarding-house at Paris, and I occasionally danced with her thereâ€”I have been with her when dancing took place, and have not danced with herâ€”that was at the boarding-houseâ€”I was there I suppose two or three times when dancing took placeâ€”the Baron St. Mart was present on 26th April when this took place about the rings; I have no doubt he saw themâ€”I do not recollect seeing the prisoner place them in his handâ€”I do not recollect seeing her show them to her motherâ€”there was a general conversationâ€”I was engaged finishing and sealing my letters, and during that time they may have shown them to each otherâ€”I cannot recollect the mother saying, "Yes, they are very pretty"â€”I was busy with my lettersâ€”they were very short lettersâ€”I dare say they were of consequence, or I should not have been so anxious to finish themâ€”I do not recollect hearing the mother say, "They are very pretty, take them away," nor her handing them to the Baronâ€”I distinctly recollect the Baron did not give them to me, and they were never given me afterwardsâ€”there was a general conversation while I was engaged about my letters, and I had not the least doubt that they all looked at themâ€”I should suppose, after I gave her the rings to look at, I was engaged about my letters about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, or it might be half an hourâ€”these entries in the diary were made within a few days, within my recollection, not the same dayâ€”I generally made them at the end of the weekâ€”nothing has been added sinceâ€”the words "rings stolen" have been written since, merely to refresh my memoryâ€”that being the actual time they were stolen it is written in very

large characters: and about four days after you will see, "Opened my porta
ble desk"â€”I wrote "Rings stolen" at the end of the week, when I opened my portable deskâ€”I opened my desk on Friday, 30thâ€”I made this entry either on the Friday or soon afterâ€”it may have been a day or two afterâ€”I have stated before that I made up my diary once a weekâ€”I did not write the whole u! the cntras under the head of Friday, 30th, at the same timeâ€”it is impos
sible for me to say which of tlie two entries I made firstâ€”if you will give me the book I will show youâ€”this was made firit (looking at the diary)â€”"To London to demand my ring's"â€”I made the otiiera few thus afterwards, when I found I could not rjctihe rings backâ€”this entry, "Opened my portable desk," was merely to refresh my memory; to recollect that I opened my port
able desk and missed my ringsâ€”I then immediately came to London and demanded my ringsâ€”it was on opening the desk on Friday that I missed themâ€”it was that which led me to come to Londonâ€”it never occurred to me, from the Monday to the Friday, to make any application for the ringsâ€”I was so much engaged on the Tuesday and Wednesday in providing for my friendsâ€”I did my maiketing on that occasion myselfâ€”I went to the market-place twice that day to get the best that Bath could affordâ€”I went to buy my own fishâ€”I did not order it the night beforeâ€”it is possible I might have called on my way to the party, and said I should want fish to-morrowâ€”we dined on the Tuesday about half-past sixâ€”I was engaged the whole day in mar
keting, and going down to the Catholic chapel with the Baroness and Countess, to see if they could get married in Eath, as they were very anxious to get married on the following dav, to o offâ€”that took a long time, because we had to go from place to place, we could not get the informationâ€”that did not put the loss of the rings into my headâ€”I think Mr. and Mrs. Pennington came about the middle of the day on Wednesday, and they were with me till about the middie of Thursdayâ€”I cannot recollect what train they went byâ€”they had lunch with me before theywentâ€”you may call that dinner if you chooseâ€”I am not certain whether it was dinner at four or five.

Q. What was there to engross your attention that day, and prevent your asking about the rings? A. I had a great deal to do that day of a private nature, writing lettersâ€”that took me a great deal of the dayâ€”I used my portable desk, and opened itâ€”I opened it before the Fridayâ€”there is no entry of that in my diaryâ€”I opened it to write letters every dayâ€”I opened it on the Friday to write lettersâ€”I had done so on the Thursday also, but it never occurred to me till they left the house that they had stolen the ringsâ€”these entries, "Opened my portable desk," and "Rings stolen," were not written on the same dayâ€”it is not the same inkâ€”"Rings stolen" is written in darker inkâ€”"Opened my portable desk" is not in the same inkâ€”I have not the least doubt I wrote them both at the same timeâ€”I opened the desk every day between Monday and Friday, but it never occurred to me that the rings were goneâ€”I did not sec the caskets, they were under a square cover in the top of the desk, not where I kept my papers.

Q. What led you to go to it on the Friday? A. It occurred to me the moment they had kit the house that I had nit ijot my nriis backâ€”I then recollected the circumstances of the Monday cunmcr. and her savins she would keep the rinysâ€”that lid not come into my head beforeâ€”she said that openly, in the picsericc of the others, loud enough for me to hear it, and I suppose loud enough for the others to hear itâ€”I have not the least doubt of thatâ€”the liaron, I suppose, heard herâ€”the Baron said, before he left, that he had sent her some trinket, I do not know what it was, and begged I would

pay for it if it came after he leftâ€”it is very likely that I told the Baron that the jeweller had charged 6. for doing something to his ring, and that I took the 6d. of himâ€”I do not recollect it, but I may have done soâ€”I think it is very likely the servant might have come in and said, "Here is a ring," or "some trinket," and charged 6d., and I might have taken the 6d.â€”that did not bring my rings to my mindâ€”I came up to their house on the Friday, and got there at their-dinner hourâ€”I sat down at the tableâ€”there was something set before me, but I do not think I ate itâ€”I was waiting for an opportunity to speak to the prisonerâ€”some one came in, and she was called to go up stairsâ€”there was not a word said about the rings before thatâ€”it is very possible there was a conversation at the dinner-table about the marriage license, I do not recollect itâ€”I do not recollect the Countess saying, "I hope your license is all right with regard to the spelling of the names; there was a mistake of about mine, and we had to wait at the Church while it was sent to Doctors' Commons to be altered"â€”I do not recollect one syllable about itâ€”I was thinking of my rings at the time, waiting for an opportunity to ask her in the most delicate way for themâ€”I did not follow her out of the room into the passageâ€”I got up from the table, went to the door, and said, "Bring down my rings"â€”she might have been just in the passage at the time, but the door was openâ€”I swear I did not follow her into the passage, and shut the door behind herâ€”she went up stairs, and when she came down she said, "What did you say to me?"â€”I said, "Bring down my rings"â€”she did not ask whether I wanted to see her wedding-ringâ€”after I made this remark, she called to her mother, and told her I was saying something she did not comprehend the meaning ofâ€”I appealed to the mother, and, as I said before, there were high words, and I left the roomâ€”I do not know that she called to her mother, and said, "Mamma, Sir John Hare is saying something to me about his rings which I do not understand"â€”the mother did not come out into the passageâ€”we were at the tableâ€”I did not say, "You had better not speak so loud, or the Baron will hear"â€”I did not hear the mother say, "I do not care whether the Baron hears, or all the world; you shall not make such a charge against my daughter"â€”I believe she said I was madâ€”at that I leftâ€”I think I then called on some friends, to relate it to themâ€”I cannot recollect what friends they wereâ€”I was back
wards and forwards at the house all the eveningâ€”I expected that they were going off, and I took care to watch that they did not goâ€”I was there, back
wards and forwards, several times in the eveningâ€”I did not keep the house in sight the whole eveningâ€”I might have stopped there two or three hoursâ€”I went out of the house about five o'clockâ€”it is very likely I staid till seven: I think I didâ€”Mr. Pennington came out to see meâ€”I sent a message, requesting he should come to meet me at my solicitor'sâ€”I think I delivered the message myself at the doorâ€”I walked about with Mr. Penningtonâ€”he accompanied me to look for a friendâ€”I was somewhere about the street, in the neighbourhood, till he came, going frequently to see who went in and came out of the houseâ€”I siw the Countess and the Baron come out and go into a cabâ€”I followed the cab a considerable distance, to see where they were goingâ€”I saw them go towards the Circus and Oxford-street, and then lost sight of themâ€”they drove faster than I could walkâ€”I had not an opportunity of taking the number of the cab, I was not near enoughâ€”I do not recollect that I saw them come backâ€”it is possible I may have gone back again to the houseâ€”I was exceedingly anxiousâ€”I believe I did go back, I will not swear itâ€”Mr. Pennington came to me about ten the same eveningâ€”I did not stop

at the house all the eveningâ€”I went to various placesâ€”I cannot exactly say where, most likily I went to the Clubâ€”to the best of my belief, I went in my Club that evening. after ten o'clockâ€”I am not certain whether I went beforeâ€”think I saw Mr. Pennington first in the passage, in Thayer-streetâ€”I was standing at the door and about thereâ€”I am not quite certain whether he came out and found me in the streetâ€”he went to a public-house with meâ€”I went out then to see for a friend living close byâ€”he was not at home, and I went backâ€”Mr. Penninfgton was still there, and went to Berkley-street with me, to see for a friend of mineâ€”I stayed with Mr. Pennington perhaps three quarters of an hourâ€”I went back to the house as far as the door, and walked up and down perhaps for half an hour afterwardsâ€”I watched till about tenâ€”I had not then he en to the Clubâ€”I went to the house next morning, the wedding morning;, with Mr. Fleayâ€”I walked in and said, "That is the Countess"â€”I just introduced Mr. Fleavâ€”I do not suppose I introduced him with the ceremony of "I beg leave to introduce Mr. Fleay to the Countess Gabrouski," and vice versaâ€”I bolted into the room and said, "That's the Countess," and walked out againâ€”Mr. Fleay afterwards came out to meâ€”he brought out 13s. 8d.â€”he said she had paid him for some little accounts she had left unpaid at Bath, for when she left Bath she said she had just money enough to pay her expenses to London, and begged I would pay some little amountâ€”I gave the account to Mr. Fleay, and requested him to receive itâ€”she requested me, as she had no money in her pocket, to give the servants 5s., and that was down among other itemsâ€”I think my servants said they had paid 1s. 6d. for. flies, and that was added to itâ€”it was after breakfast that I went with Mr. Fleay, I suppose eleven or twelve o'clockâ€”it may have been as early as nine,â€”I went again about eight in the evening, with Mr. Mackinnon and Sir Alexander Downeyâ€”I was round in the neighbourhood two or three times in the course of the dayâ€”I watched the house: not the whole of the day, nor yet the greater part; I was there once or twiceâ€”I stayed perhaps ten minutes or a quarter of an hour; I swear not more than thatâ€”I went to watch, I thought they were going oft'â€”I went again that night, about eight or nineâ€”I called on Sir Alexander Downey and Mr. Mackinnon, who were dining together, and after they had finished their dinner I wentâ€”it must have been about nineâ€”I will not swear it was not as late as tenâ€”I should decidedly say it was not as late as half-past tenâ€”I know nothing about Mr. Pennington coming down from his bed-roomâ€”I believe the Baroness went up stairs, called Mr. Pennington down, and asked his protectionâ€”I do not I know that the Countess had left on the Saturday afternoonâ€”I will not swear that I saw her that nightâ€”I know nothing at all about her leavingâ€”I said I saw the party thereâ€”I saw the Baronessâ€”I called in so many different times that I really do not recollect whether I saw the Countess or notâ€”I dare say we knocked pretty loudly at the doorâ€”I believe I saw the prisoner that eveningâ€”I did not call out several times, "You shall not be a Baroness! you shall not be a Baroness!"â€”I never used such wordsâ€”the Baron wanted to put me outâ€”alter the Saturday night, I aw no more of them till I saw them at Bolongue in Julyâ€”I was summoned before the police there, on the complaint of the Baronâ€”I think it is very likely I may have walked up and down their house in Bolongue, as I was told they were at an hotel close by meâ€”I did not make any signs at them, or at other persons: I swear thaiâ€”I wanted them to set meâ€”I made no signâ€”no complaint was made that I had made a sign indicative of breaking open a deskâ€”I made no such signâ€”they did not complain that I made signs and insulting gesturesâ€”where
ever

I saw them I generally looked at them and followed them when I met them, just to have a look at themâ€”I had not seen quite enough of the ladyâ€”I did not follow them for the purpose of insultâ€”I had a right to look at any one, and especially at the person who had stolen my ringsâ€”I did it for the purpose of seeing themâ€”they might have taken it for an insult if they thought properâ€”I did it for my own gratificationâ€”I walked up and down that they might see me, to call to their recollection that they had stolen my ringsâ€”I cannot call it an insult to tell a person that they had stolen my pro
pertyâ€”I next saw them at Ascot races, in Juneâ€”my carriage stood about four from theirsâ€”I may have seen them once in the Park, nowhere elseâ€”I never thought of taking steps to apprehend them till I received the letter from Hockadayâ€”the police-court that I went to on 1st May is in Marylebone-laneâ€”it may be a police-stationâ€”I saw a police-sergeant there, and asked if there was any Magistrate there, and he said no Magistrate would be there till Monday morning.

Q. Did not Mr. Pennington press you if you had any charge to make against the Baroness, to prefer it in a formal way? A. Mr. Pennington wanted me to set a value on the rings, and wanted me to compound a felonyâ€”he said something to the effect that I had made a scandalous imputa
tion upon the lady, and if she took his advice, she would institute legal pro
ceedings against me, but not in those wordsâ€”he requested me to put a value on the rings, and then he said, "Well as you have made this accusation, had you not better go to law with them?" or something of that sortâ€”he may have said the very words you put, but I do not recollect exactlyâ€”he did say soâ€”he said if I had been robbed, I ought to make a formal charge against themâ€”after having taken Mr. Fleay and other friends, and used everry effort to get back my rings, I went to the police-officeâ€”I did not wish to be too much in a hurry in going to the police-officeâ€”I wanted to get back my rings by fair means firstâ€”I did it in a most gentlemanly wayâ€”I think it was a gentlemanly proceeding, after waiting all day, to go at ten at nightâ€”I gave them every opportunity of returning the ringsâ€”I was so disgusted with Mr. Pennington that I can scarcely tell you what he saidâ€”he asked me to compound a felony, and I thought the sooner I was out of his way the betterâ€”I took him to my solicitorâ€”I was not going to have anything to do with him without my solicitorâ€”I was exceedingly cautiousâ€”I have not furnished Eliza Russell with any money; I swear thatâ€”she has not applied to me for a farthingâ€”she did not send her sister to me at the Police-court and say she must have moneyâ€”I have not promised her anyâ€”I swear I have not expended a shilling in any way whatever to any individual, nor promised an)-â€”no money has been supplied to her, to my knowledgeâ€”the letter from Hockaday was the first intimation I had about Eliza Russellâ€”I never saw her before I came up in company with the policemanâ€”I might have seen her at the houseâ€”she says she recollects seeing me when I dined there, but I should not recollect a girl coming in to waitâ€”I do not mean to say that she has represented to me that she saw me the day I dined at the Countess'sâ€”she says she has seen me at the Countess's, but not on any par
ticular occasionâ€”I did not say this moment that she had seen me the day I dined thereâ€”you asked me that questionâ€”she says she has seen me at the houses; he did not say when.

Q. Did you not see her when you were there at ten o'clock on the evening of 1st May?. A. I saw two servants there, one that opened the door, and another, but never looked in their faces, or knew who they wereâ€”I do not

recollect whether I saw one with a bonnet on, in the act of going outâ€”the servant was not in the room when I spoke about the ringsâ€”the discussion did not take place in the passage; it was up stairs in the drawing-roomâ€”I suppose the servant showed me upâ€”I went upâ€”I saw the Baron and Baroness there, and the door was openâ€”the Baroness left the room; I do not know what forâ€”when Mr. Pennington came in there was a scuffleâ€”the Baron held up his fist, and threatened to knock me down, for making such a charge against his wifeâ€”I claimed my rins againâ€”a great deal of noise took placeâ€”one of my friends that I took came from the Isle of Skye, and the other from Frankfortâ€”I did not represent one of them as my lawyer, nor did one of them represent himself as suchâ€”I do not know that he didâ€”he might have done soâ€”I did not see the Countess and Baron and Baroness in any public places after their return to England, except Ascot and the Parkâ€”when I took her into custody she begged to be let offâ€”she entreated me to let her offâ€”she said that at the police-officeâ€”she might have said it when I apprehended herâ€”I believe she didâ€”I believe she asserted strongly and strenuously that she was innocent, at the same time she implored me to let her offâ€”she did not, that I know of, make any observation about not taking her to the police-courtâ€”I did not observe that she was in the family-wayâ€”she stated to me in the police-office that that was the case, and begged me to let her offâ€”I had not the least idea of it till thenâ€”she might have stated then that she was innocent, but not in my hearingâ€”the policeman told me so.

JURY. Q. Did you make any application about these rings to your family, or mention to your family before you left Bath the errand you were coming upon after the rings? A. No, I never mentioned the circumstance, because I was so certain that I had only to come up to London to ask for them, and they would be restored to meâ€”I had not mentioned it to any oneâ€”I had no intention of prosecuting when I left Bath; I thought I should get them withoutâ€”until I was attempted to be turned out of the house by the Baron I did not go to any police-station, or make any complaint about itâ€”I tried all the fair means. I possibly could, by going repeatedly, and taking friends, up to Saturday evening, to endeavour to get my rings.

MR. COCKBURN. Q. When the discussion took place between you and the Countess and the Baroness on the Friday afternoon, did you not say that you were sure the Baroness had not got your rings for any improper purpose? A. No; I did not say anything of the sort.

ELIZA RUSSELL. In Feb. 1846, I heard of a situation through a person named Warren, in consequence of which I called at the house of the Countess Gabrowski, 11, Bentinck-terrace, Regent's-park, and was there engaged as housemaidâ€”I stayed in the service till 30th Nov.â€”at that time the Countess disposed of her house to a lady and gentleman named Swan, and I continued in the same house in the service of Mr. Swanâ€”while I resided with the Countess I became acquainted with Miss Todhunterâ€”she remained Miss Todhunter till the Countess left that houseâ€”I stayed with Mr. Swan six months, and left on 30th Nov., 1847â€”during the time I was there, Miss Todhunter called once while she was single, with the Baron, to show him the family pictures, and she called again on the Friday before she was marriedâ€”I saw herâ€”there was another servant in the house at the time named Pottsâ€”Miss Todhunter came in a cab on the Fridayâ€”she told me she wanted me to go somewhere with her, as she wanted to make some moneyâ€”I went and asked Mrs. Swan, but she told me she could not let me goâ€”I told Miss Todhunter that, and she

asked me to come to the wedding on the next dayâ€”I applied to my mistress for permission, and she said she would spare me, but she must ask Mr. Swan first, and she eventually gave me leaveâ€”I did not, during the whole of the Fri
day, leave the houseâ€”I went the next day to Thayer-street, and arrived there about eight o'clock in the morningâ€”I assisted in dressing Miss Todhunter, and getting the breakfast readyâ€”the breakfast did not take place much before one o'clockâ€”after the wedding and breakfast were over, I should think about three, the Countess left the houseâ€”the prisoner asked me what time I was expected homeâ€”I said I must be home by half-past fourâ€”she said that was ratber early, and she could not spare me till after that time, as she wanted me to go somewhere and make her some moneyâ€”this conversation took place in the back drawing-room in the afternoon, soon after the Countess was goneâ€”between three and five o'clock the prisoner gave me two ringsâ€”that was either in the back inner bed-room or in the back drawing-roomâ€”they were wrapped up in silver-paperâ€”she told me I was to take them to Mr. Boyce, Lisson-grove-North, and to ask 10l. on them, and I was to have a 5l.-note and five sovereigns, and she gave me money to pay for a cab and for the ticket, as I was not to break into the 10l., and when I came back she said she had written a letter and she wanted to send the 5l.-note abroadâ€”I went in a cab to Boyce's, the pawnbrokers, pledged the rings, and received a 5l.-note and five sovereignsâ€”I went back to the prisoner, gave her the money and the ticketâ€”she tore the ticket up and put the 5l.-note inside the letter, sealed it up, and I took it to the Post-office leading out of Oxford-streetâ€”she gave me tenpence to pay the postage of itâ€”I paid a bill that afternoon to a dress
maker in Blenheim-street, I think the first turning out of Bond-streetâ€”that was after I had been to the pawnbroker'sâ€”I suppose I paid it with that moneyâ€”she desired me to pay it with the money I had got from the pawn
broker'sâ€”I think the bill was 3l. 17s.â€”I brought back the bill to the prisoner, and it was ten o'clock before I left the house to return to my mas
ter'sâ€”I recollect before I left two or three gentlemen coming to the house, and I heard a confusion when I was up stairs in the bed-roomâ€”the Baroness (the prisoner) came up to me and told me to put on my things and rush home, as it was getting lateâ€”I think the gentlemen that had come were in the house at the timeâ€”I said to the prisoner, "What a noise there was," and she said, "Oh, it is a little fuss," or somethingâ€”I left and went homeâ€”Mrs. Swan was dissatisfied at my coming so late, and on the Monday alter she gave me warning, and I left at the end of a monthâ€”I then went down to my mother, who resided at Ross, in Herefordshireâ€”she was very ill at the time; I re
mained there till 12th Nov., 1847â€”I then got a situation in Baker-street, Portman-square, with a Mrs. Potterâ€”Mrs. Swan gave me a character on that occasionâ€”I stayed there seven months and left in Juneâ€”I went to Bentinck-terrace to see the Baroness, as I heard she was in townâ€”she was only on a visit thereâ€”she was living at Bolongue, but came over to spend a few weeks with her mother, who lived in Bentinck-terraceâ€”she had not got a lodging in St. John's-wood thenâ€”the Baroness gave me a very nice dressâ€”in conse
quence of what was said I went again to live with the Countessâ€”the Baroness and her husband were not in England then; they had been gone a day or twoâ€”I went on 26th Juneâ€”in the following Aug. the prisoner came over again to England by herself, and took a lodging in St. John's-woodâ€”she used to visit her mother at Bentinck-terraceâ€”I mostly accompanied her home of an eveningâ€”one evening I had been to see my little niece that was coming up by the Great Western Railway, and when I came back the cook said the Baron
ess had been crying, and when I went up stairs I found she had been cryingâ€”

she did not stay long, but I went home with her, ami as we were going along she said, "Mamma has been scolding me about a 10l.-note, Eliza; and thinks I have taken it," and she said, "And for God's sake, Eliza, never say any
thing about those two rings I gave you"â€”I had pledged two table-spoons of her mother's, and she said, "Never say a word about those spoons I gave you to pledge"â€”she said, "For God's sake do not say anything about the rings and spoons"â€”she gave me the spoons in Oct. 1846, before she was marriedâ€”I pawned them at Mr. Boyce'sâ€”I have left the Countess's service five weeks to-dayâ€”I left in consequence of an unpleasant affair that I was accused of, but I was quite innocentâ€”some one got into the house, broke open the Countess's jewel-box, and took away the trinketsâ€”the police were sent forâ€”they examined the premisesâ€”I was charged with it, given into custody, and was in custody from the Tuesday till Saturdayâ€”I was not given into custody, but I was ordered not to go to the door or to answer anybodyâ€”on the Satur
day the Countess said she had nothing to allege against me, therefore I was to go, but wished to know where I was goingâ€”I gave her my address, and then leftâ€”a week afterwards I received my wages from the Countessâ€”the prisoner was then in Englandâ€”on the Monday and Tuesday after I left, I went to the Baroness, at Bentinck-terrace, and as I was coming from there in Park-road, I met a gentleman named Hardinge, who had been in the habit of visiting the familyâ€”that is him (looking at a gentleman in Court)â€”I had some conversation with him, and in consequence of what passed, I went the same day, Tuesday, to Mr. Boyce's, the pawnbroker'sâ€”on the following day I communicated to a policeman what I knew about the pawning of these ringsâ€”that was the "Wednesday or Thursday, I will not be positive whichâ€”it was in last monthâ€”up to the time I had this conversation with Mr. Hardinge, I had no notion whatever that the rings I pawned were Sir John Hare'sâ€”one ring was a large diamond set in with smaller ones, and the other an eme
rald, what I call a green stone, set in with small diamonds.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKBURN. Q. I understand you that you left the Countess in Nov., 1845? A. I did not leave the house; I remained with Mrs. Swanâ€”I ceased to be in the Countess's serviceâ€”Mr. and Mrs. Swan took the house furnished for twelve monthsâ€”I then went to my mother's, on account of her health, for no other reasonâ€”there was nothing peculiar in the state of my own health at the timeâ€”I was not in the family-wayâ€”on my oath, I did not, in the month of Dec. in that year, or there-abouts, have a childâ€”I know a person of the name of Snaith, a tailor, at 38, Great North-street, Lisson-groveâ€”his wife was not the nurse who attended me in my confinementâ€”I was with my mother up to the first week in Nov.â€”I then came to London, and went to Mrs. Den's, 35, North-streetâ€”I stayed there till I got the situationâ€”on my oath, I was not confined thereâ€”I was not confined at all at or about that timeâ€”I have never been brought to bed of a child, not at any time; I swear thatâ€”I have not miscarried (the witness here hesitated, and then teas silent)â€”I went into Mrs. Potter's service on 30th Nov.â€”I did not say that the father of the child, if it bad been born alive, was a relation of Mrs. Swan'sâ€”I did not say Mr. Fowler was the father of itâ€”Mrs. Swan did not know I was in the family-way when I went away, I swear that, nor afterwardsâ€”I left Mrs. Swan's in the first week in June, and went straight to Herefordshireâ€”I stayed at Mrs. Potter's till the next June, and then went back to the Countess'sâ€”the Baroness called on me on 30th April at Mrs. Swan'sâ€”the Baron did not come with herâ€”Mary Potts, the cook, opened the door to herâ€”I saw the Baroness in the cab at the doorâ€”Potts was not by; she went to Mrs. Swan, and asked

leave for me to go with the Baronessâ€”I took the answer to the Baronessâ€”I think I have stated before to-day that the Baroness said she wanted me to make a little money for herâ€”I have said so at other times than before the Magi
strateâ€”I first stated it to the solicitor a few days agoâ€”that was the first time I; mentioned itâ€”that is since I was before the Magistrateâ€”it was last Tuesday week I was before the Magistrateâ€”I may have been at the Baroness's on the Saturday morning, when Mr. Fleay came, but I do Dot know, I was busy up stairsâ€”they went to Church, came home, and had the wedding breakfast about one o'clockâ€”after that a gentleman named Duplex, a medical gentle
man, calledâ€”Mr. and Mrs. Pennington were thereâ€”Mrs. Pennington was poorlyâ€”Mr. Duplex was in the habit of attending the Countessâ€”I do not remember that he wrote a prescription for Mrs. Penningtonâ€”I do not remember going to a chemist's to get it made up; I may have done soâ€”the Countess left about three o'clockâ€”Mr. Duplex remained till thenâ€”it might have been half-past threeâ€”it was not part of the arrangements, to my know
ledge, that she was to leave London-bridge by the half-past five trainâ€”I mean to say she left as early as threeâ€”I believe Mr. Duplex saw her to her carriage, but I do not know whether he had returned or notâ€”Mr. Alfred Todhunter, the Countess's son, was there likewiseâ€”he might have gone away with his mother to see her off by the trainâ€”I did see her leave, through the drawing-room window, but I did not see who accompanied herâ€”I was not in the passage when she leftâ€”it was a few minutes after she left that this took place betweeen me and the Baroness about getting money on the ringsâ€”I think it was in the back drawing-room; it was either there or in the back bed-roomâ€”I believe it was in the back drawing-roomâ€”that room opens with folding-doors into the front; they were open thenâ€”I do not know that there was a fire in the front-roomâ€”it was very warm that day.â€”they sat in the front-roomâ€”I do not know what time they dinedâ€”I swear there was not dinner at half-past five, and I did not assist at itâ€”I had nothing after the wedding breakfastâ€”I swear the breakfast did not take place as early as half-past eleven, for she was not married until before twelveâ€”she was married at Marylebone Churchâ€”Mr. and Mrs. Pennington breakfasted with them, and remained there the whole dayâ€”they slept in the house that nightâ€”they were not in the front drawing-room the whole afternoonâ€”Mrs. Pennington had occasion to go to bed in the afternoonâ€”she may have come down before the Countess left, but she went to bed again; that I swearâ€”she did not come down to take leave of the Countess, and then remain down the whole afternoonâ€”there was no dinner that day that I know ofâ€”I did not wait at itâ€”I did not go out and fetch a bottle of wine for the Baronâ€”I ordered some wine in the morning in New Bond-street for the wedding, but none after thatâ€”they had tea that eveningâ€”I did not wait on them, the servant of the house didâ€”I should not like to be positive whether Mrs. Pen
nington was at the tea-tableâ€”it was immediately after the Countess left that I was sent by the Baroness about these ringsâ€”I did not mention to any one that she gave me money to pay for the cab and the ticket till I mentioned it to the policemanâ€”that was on the Wednesday or Thursday after I left the Countess's serviceâ€”I swear that I told that to the policemanâ€”I have not told it to any one else unless I said it at the police-court.

Q. Did the Baroness tell you in what name you were to pawn these rings? A. Yes, in the name of Mary or Ann Turner, 15, Gloucester-placeâ€”I pawned them in that nameâ€”the pawnbroker asked me the name in which they were to be pawned, and I told him Mary or Ann Turner, 15, Gloucester-placeâ€”I am quite sure of thatâ€”I did not pledge those rings the day before,

Fridayâ€”I never saw them till I saw them on the Saturdayâ€”I saw the rings as I was going alongâ€”I received a duplicate from the pawnbrokerâ€”there was only one duplicateâ€”both the rings were included in one ticketâ€”I did not notice the duplicate after he gave it to meâ€”I saw it, but did not see what was on it; that I swearâ€”I brought it back, and gave it to the Baroness in her bed-room, or the back drawing-roomâ€”I should not like to be positive which; I cannot tellâ€”I may have said before to-day that this conversation took place in the bed-roomâ€”I believe the gentlemen were in the house that night when I leftâ€”I had a good way to go homeâ€”Mrs. Swan discharged me for my not being punctual to timeâ€”she had wished me to return at half-past four, and I did not get home till half-past tenâ€”I am sure it was as early as thatâ€”I was up stairs in the Baroness's bed-room when the confusion was going on, and the gentlemen were in the houseâ€”the Baroness came up, and wished me to put on my thingsâ€”she said she should like me to come in the morningâ€”I have not said to any one before to-day that the Countess told me it was only a bit of fuss, and to reach home as quick as I couldâ€”I believe I mentioned it at Maryleboneâ€”I do not recollect mentioning it to any oneâ€”Mrs. Swan gave me warning on the Mondayâ€”I left at the end of. the month, and went to my mother'sâ€”I returned from my mother's in Nov. and went to Mrs. Potter's on 30th Nov.

Q. How were you maintained during the period you were absent from service? A. I had money given to me when I came from home by my father and motherâ€”no one else supplied roe with money, except my sisterâ€”I left Mrs. Potter for the purpose of going to the Countessâ€”I gave the warningâ€”I did not mention to any one that the Baroness asked me not to say a word about the rings till I told Sergeant Hockadayâ€”I told him on the Wed
nesday or Thursday, after I was told they were Sir John Hare's ringsâ€”that was after I had been charged with breaking open the jewel-caseâ€”the day that; took place the Countess dined at the Baroness'sâ€”I was left alone in the house with Mrs. Humphreys, a lady who was on a visit to the Countessâ€”next morning the Countess said she did not see her jewel-case on her drawers as usualâ€”I did not say, "Good God, my Lady, surely it is not lost!"â€”I went immediately to look for itâ€”Mrs. Humphreys was dressing, and I told her I was looking about for the Countess's jewel-case, which I could not see anywhereâ€”it was found upon the cook's bed, where she used to sleepâ€”she had left on the Mondayâ€”the Countess dined out on the Tuesday, and the jewels were missed on the Wednesday.

Q. Did you suggest that it might have been the cook? A. I could not say who it wasâ€”I said it was very strange it was goneâ€”I mentioned the cook's name in this way, that she had come the night before after her things and took away a bundleâ€”she came the night before as the jewel-case was missing in the morningâ€”she came the evening the Countess dined at the Baroness'sâ€”that may have been on the Tuesdayâ€”the bed on which it was found was no one's bed but the cook'sâ€”I slept in the room underâ€”they searched my boxesâ€”they did not find a handkerchief of the Countess's in itâ€”she did not charge me with stealing a handkerchiefâ€”I do not know that Hockaday said, independent of the jewel-case, that the Countess would be justi
fied in giving me into custodyâ€”if he did say so, it was not in my hearingâ€”there were two towels in my box, one marked in my name, and one not marked at allâ€”they were mine, and the Countess said one was hersâ€”I swear she did nut claim a handkerchiefâ€”she said there was some paper marked with her initials and coronetâ€”I do not know whether it had a coronet on itâ€”I did not notice itâ€”it was the night I left the houseâ€”the Countess sent for

Mr. Miller, to search the premisesâ€”there was a pane of glass broken in one of the windowsâ€”the police cameâ€”one policeman came before Sergeant Hockadayâ€”I forget his nameâ€”I do not know that he stated that the house had not been broken from without but from withinâ€”they said I must either have done it, or else knew some one that had done itâ€”I never let any man into the houseâ€”I did let a person named Graves into the house, quite two years and a half ago, when I was left in the house, when the family went abroadâ€”I showed him over the house; that is allâ€”I never spoke to him sinceâ€”I mentioned at that time that I had spent the day somewhere with a person named Applegate, at his lodging, at Poplarâ€”he is a single manâ€”it may be two months ago that I spent the day at his lodgingâ€”he is no relation of mineâ€”I did not spend the day with himâ€”I did not leave my place till five o'clock, and did not get there till sevenâ€”I was not alone with himâ€”I was in company with two more; a young man and a young womanâ€”Applegate saw me homeâ€”that was about half-past eleven.

Q. I believe the house was shut up and Applegate hoisted you over the wall, and you had to scramble back again, as you could not get in? A. I did not get back over the wallâ€”I unlocked the doorâ€”I decline to answer where I passed that night, I was kept in the house from Tuesday till Satur
dayâ€”I do not know whether that was by the recommendation of the policeâ€”I was not told by any one not to go out till I was told by the Countess on the Saturday eveningâ€”I was not ordered either to stay or leaveâ€”I was not to go to the door or out of the house, and on Saturday evening I was ordered to leaveâ€”during the time I was ordered not to go to the door I saw the Baroness frequentlyâ€”she was backwards and forwards at her mother'sâ€”she did not tell me that I must know something about the robbery, and that if I did not confess it I should be sent to Newgateâ€”they said I must know some
thing about itâ€”the Baroness told me she was sorry, and urged me to tell all I knew of itâ€”she did not tell me that if I did not I should be punished, because I told her I was quite innocentâ€”if Hockaday told the Countess on the day I was discharged that she would be justified in giving me in custody, it was not in my presenceâ€”the Countess did not, in my presence, say that she did not wish to do that, but that she should be justified in discharging meâ€”the Baroness was not there when I was discharged, only a servant and the Countess herselfâ€”the Baroness was there in the course of the dayâ€”when I was discharged I went to Miss Warren's, in Marshall-streetâ€”I did not stay the night thereâ€”I went to a friend's house at Maida-hill, the father and mother of Eliza, who used to live with me in Baker-streetâ€”I stayed there till 1 got the situation I am now in, with a lady in Devonshire-street, Portland-placeâ€”I called at Mrs. Hedges', in North-street, for some linen she had of mineâ€”I do not know Selina Lawsâ€”I went to Ellen's, the laundressâ€”I do not know her other nameâ€”that was a few days after I was discharged from the Countess's serviceâ€”I believe I had then seen Mr. Hardingeâ€”I saw him a few days after I left the Countessâ€”I did not tell Mrs. Hedges that I should get 40l. from Sir John Hare if I could convict the Baronessâ€”I never men
tioned Sir John Hare's nameâ€”I did not tell her I had got a claw on the Ba
roness, and that if I got her transported Sir John would give me 40l., or that I should get 40l.â€”I mentioned nothing to Mrs. Hedges excepting about my leaving the service as I didâ€”she said she thought I had been very illusedâ€”I did not say I had been very iilusedâ€”I mentioned the way I left the house, and that the Countess would not pay me my wagesâ€”Sir John Hare did not get me the situation I am now inâ€”I never saw a penny of his moneyâ€”I did not send to him for anyâ€”I swear I did not send my sister to him for money

the last time I was at the police courtâ€”I never sent any one to him fcrr moneyâ€”I first communicated with Serjeant Ilockaday about this business on the Wednesday or Thursdayâ€”I went in search of him to the station in Salisbury-streetâ€”I had seen Mr. Hardinge when I lived in the Countess's service in 1846â€”I first went into the Countess's service in Feb. 1846", and remained there till she went away in Nov.â€”in the course of that time I saw Mr. Har
dinge several timesâ€”he was visiting there with his wifeâ€”I believe I accosted him when I met him on the Tuesdayâ€”I first told Hockaday that it was in consequence of seeing Mr. Ilnrdinge that I was induced to make this state
mentâ€”I did not make any charge against Hockadayâ€”I never said he had made some proposal to me of an improper character.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you ever said a single syllable either to Mrs. Hedges the washerwoman, or anybody else about any money to be got as the result of this prosecution? A. Never to any oneâ€”I have not received a farthing, or any promise of money of any description from any oneâ€”when the Countess discharged me I went to Miss Warren's, at whose house I had been staying at the time I first went into the Countess's serviceâ€”that gen
tleman (pointing to the Solicitor for the Prosecution) is the only person to whom I made any communication about this matter after I went before the Magis
trateâ€”he examined me on the subject-matter of this caaeâ€”I stated all I knew to him, and he took it down in writingâ€”the first policeman who came to the Countess's house, did not say that it had been broken from withinâ€”there was some writing-paper found in my box, which I had bought myselfâ€”I do not know whether there was a coronet stamped at the cornerâ€”I never saw any papers in the Countess's possession that had anything but the sta
tioner's mark on itâ€”the note-paper found in my box was my ownâ€”I did not take it away with meâ€”the Countess took it away from me; there was a good bitâ€”I should think about half a quireâ€”the Baroness told me to pawn the rings in the name of Mary, or Ann Turnerâ€”she told me at that time that the rings had been pledged beforeâ€”I knew nothing of Hockaday till he came and examined the Countess' premisesâ€”Applegate has not been keeping my com
panyâ€”I knew himâ€”I was with him about three timesâ€”I returned home that night at half-past eleven o'clockâ€”that was quite two months agoâ€”the Countess did not know I had been out that night, and she did not in the morningâ€”I came in at seven in the morning, and the servant who let me in did not mention it.
JURY. Q. Did you receive the two rings in the back drawing-room, or bed-room? A. I cannot tell.

MARY POTTS . I am now in the service of Mrs. Punch, of Cavendish-road, St. John's Wood. On 28th March, 184", I went to live with Mrs. Swan, 11, Bcntinck-terraceâ€”Eliza Russell was living there as housemaidâ€”I remember hearing of the prisoner's marriage on 1st Mayâ€”the day before that she came to Mrs. Swan's to see Russellâ€”I opened the door to her, and spoke to her firstâ€”she saw Russellâ€”I am positive Russell did not leave the house that dayâ€”my mistress gave her permission to go to the Baroness's on the Saturdayâ€”she came home that night at half-past ten o'clockâ€”my mistress was very anjjry, and she was discharged on the Monday.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKBURN. Q. When were you examined before the Magistrate? A. I think it was at the first hearingâ€”Eliza went and spoke to Mrs. Swan when the Baroness crimeâ€”I went into the kitchen.

CHARLES FLEAY . I am first cousin to Sir John Hare, and carry on busi
ness as an estate agent, at Paddington. On Saturday morning, 1st May, about ten o'clock, I went in company with, Sir John Hare to 17, Thayer-strect

â€”I went into the front drawing-room, and saw the Countessâ€”I afterwards saw the Baronessâ€”Sir John presented me to the Countessâ€”he said, "Mr. Fleay, a friend of mine," and then left meâ€”I made a communication to the Countess; the Baroness came in shortly afterwards, and I said in her presence I had called by the request of Sir John Hare to demand two rings which had passed from Sir John's hands to the Baroness'sâ€”I believe I did not mention any timeâ€”it was understood to be at Bathâ€”the Countess had explained itâ€”the Baroness said she had not got them, they were returned to Sir Johnâ€”I returned to Sir John, and told him what had passed.
Cross-examined by MR. COCKBURN. Q. Was it then that you delivered the little account of 13s. 8d.? A. Yes; I got the money and took it to Sir John.

THOMAS HORTON HARDINGE . I reside in Park-lane. I occasionally visited the Countess at Bentinck-terraceâ€”I have frequently seen Eliza Rus
sell thereâ€”I met her a few weeks ago, as near as I can recollect; it was at the Countess's doorâ€”it was quite accidentalâ€”I had some conversation with herâ€”I made a communication to her on the subject of Sir John Hare's rings. Cross-examined by Me. Cockburn. Q. Did you stop her for that pur
pose? A. No, I stopped her to inquire how the Countess wasâ€”she gave a look of recognition as I came upâ€”I was walking rather briskly, but she did not address me as she has statedâ€”I first said to her, "How is the Countess?"â€”that lead to further conversation; it was not a minute's conversationâ€”I knew Sir John Hare at my table, and at his own alsoâ€”I did not attend before the Magistrateâ€”I was first called on to come forward in this matter very unexpectedly indeed, yesterdayâ€”Sir John himself came to me.

MR. BODKIN. Q. How long was it before you met Russell that you had seen Sir John Hare? A. Not for many monthsâ€”I should say, in justice to myself, as it might be inferred that I held an unnecessary communication with the girl, that I made only one remark, and that was drawn from me.

SAMUEL HOCKADAY (police-sergeant, S 15). On Wednesday, 25th Oct., I was called to the Countess's house, in Bentinck-terraceâ€”I went from the station in consequence of information; a complaint was made of a robbery having been committed thereâ€”I saw the inspector, from him I learnt that the jewels had been lostâ€”the house was being searched, and I joined in the searchâ€”suspicion was directed towards the witness, Russellâ€”I cannot say whether it was arranged that she should stay in the house till the matter was further investigated; I was no party to thatâ€”I examined the premisesâ€”I found a small portion of a pane of glass in the parapet-window had been forced out with some blunt instrument; a triangular piece, just enough to admit three or four fingers, near the catchâ€”that would enable a person to get inâ€”on the following day I found there was an empty house seven doors offâ€”the glass in the area door there had been broken near to the lockâ€”I went through that door through the house, and found an iron bar had been wrenched off from the parapet window, and marks of sooty feet and hands on the wall and floor of the houseâ€”I could not trace the marks along the parapet to the Countess's house, because there had been a heavy fall of rain, but I got from that empty house to the window in question myselfâ€”I was at the house when Russell was discharged on Saturday evening, 28th Oct.â€”I was called in on Wednesday, 25thâ€”I had been employed the whole of that time making inquiriesâ€”I communicated to the Countess daily the result of those inquiriesâ€”the prisoner was in the house when Russell was dischargedâ€”I cannot say whether she did or did not hear what took placeâ€”on the following Tues
day a communication was made to me by Tomlin, S 250, about the pawning

of some ringsâ€”I saw Eliza Russell on that clay, but she made no communi
cationâ€”she came to the station about a duplicate which I held of hersâ€”on Thursday she made a communication to me; in consequence of that I sent Tom
lin to Mr. Boyce, the pawnbrokerâ€”in consequence of Tomlin's report I wrote to Sir John Hare, and received an answer from him at the stationâ€”this is it (produced)â€”he brought it himself to me at the Salisbury-street stationâ€”he accompanied me to Boyce's shop, and we saw a person named Bestâ€”Mr. Boyce was not thereâ€”the following day we went to his private house and saw himâ€”I met Russell in North Bank when Sir John Hare was with meâ€”she made in communication which Sir John wrote downâ€”after he had written it he read it over to herâ€”we then went to the Marylebone police-court, and Sir John applied to the Court with reference to the caseâ€”we then proceeded toward the residence of the Countess, and as we were going we met the Baron, the Baroness, the Countess, and a gentleman whose name I do not know, walking in front of Portland-terraceâ€”I arrested the Baroness, and told her that Sir John Hare charged her with felony, and told her it was relative to two diamond rings some time sinceâ€”I do liot recollect the exact words I usedâ€”the Baroness protested her innocence, and said the matter had been investigated beforeâ€”Sir John Hare was with meâ€”there was an appeal to his feelings, but I do not remember the wordsâ€”I was addressing the gentleman who was with the party, and do not know the words that passedâ€”we pro
ceeded to the stationâ€”she still protested her innocence, but the charge was takenâ€”I believe there was an appeal to Sir John from the Countess and also from the Baroness, but I do not recollect in what termsâ€”Sir John persisted in the charge.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When the Baroness protested her innocence was Sir John Hare close to you? A. Quite close; he must have heard itâ€”I believe the Baroness was searched at the station by the female searcherâ€”that was not at the express direction of Sir John Hareâ€”it is our rule to search every one charged with felonyâ€”it is a rule we do not I deviate fromâ€”I was at each examination at the police-courtâ€”Sir John Hare J was examined first on the first occasion; then Russell, and then Francis Bestâ€”Mary Potts was only called on the last examinationâ€”there were three exami
nations altogether.

FRANCIS BEST . I am assistant to Mr. Boyce, pawnbroker, at Paddingtonâ€”I remember on 1st May, 1847, taking two rings in pledgeâ€”I have seen Eliza Russellâ€”I cannot positively say that she is the person I took them in of; I believe she isâ€”I advanced 10/. on themâ€”I do not recollect in what money that wasâ€”the rings have been soldâ€”one was a cluster diamond ring and the other an emerald, a green stone set round with diamondsâ€”I cannot say whether one was smaller than the otherâ€”the cluster diamond ring has been broken up after they were sold at the pawnbroker's sale at the expiration of the twelve months for which we are bound to keep themâ€”Mr. Boyce pur
chased them for 16l. at the public auction at Debenham and Storr's, in Kingâ€”I street, Covent-gardenâ€”that was on 15th August lastâ€”the rings had been previously pledged at our shop; I believe by the same person as pledged them on this last occasion, and that was Russell according to my beliefâ€”I have no doubt at all on the subjectâ€”the previous pawning was on 30th April, Fridayâ€”I do not know who took them outâ€”I cannot say whether I delivered them outâ€”I did not fill up the first ticket, I did the secondâ€”I cannot say when the diamond ring was broken upâ€”Mr. Boyce told me it was broken upâ€”I have not seen itâ€”I did not sell the otherâ€”it was not sold at Paddingtonâ€”Mr. Boyce told me it was soldâ€”Eliza Russell called at our shop before the

police cameâ€”I think it must have been on the Tuesday before the Baroness was takenâ€”she had not, to my knowledge, ever pawned anything with us beforeâ€”I think the rings must have been pledged in the afternoon of the Saturdayâ€”I cannot say the hour, it was in the after part of the day.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKBURN. Q. Have you the entry here? A. Yes; and the duplicatesâ€”I made the last one out myselfâ€”it is my impres
sion that the same person pledged them on both occasionsâ€”I was present on both occasionsâ€”Loft is the name of the man in the shop who made out the first duplicate; he is in Courtâ€”he consulted me as to what he should advance on the rings, and so my attention was called to the transactionâ€”I saw the person that came with the ringsâ€”they were pawned in the name of Mary Wilson, 12, Gower-street, on both occasionsâ€”the person who brought them, and asked 10l. on themâ€”the question is generally put by the pawn
broker, "How much do you want?"â€”I must have put the question as to the name, it is the usual course of business so to do, and I make a cor
responding entry in the bookâ€”there can be no mistake about the nameâ€”an emerald set in diamonds is a common form of ring; the cluster is still more common, it is the common form of a diamond ring, especially an old
fashioned oneâ€”the diamonds in the cluster ring were rather darkishâ€”my impression was that they were not of the first waterâ€”the appearance of the ring rather led me to think lightly of itâ€”I do not remember that there was any particular brilliancy about the diamonds round the emerald ringâ€”according to the best of my opinion, they were not so good as those in the cluster ringâ€”they were of an inferior description certainlyâ€”when Eliza Russell came to me the other day, she asked me for a fresh duplicate.

MR. CLARKSOK. Q. Are you any judge of diamonds? A. I have not had so much experience as some in the tradeâ€”we generally like to be on the right side in valuing articlesâ€”I was not present at the sale of the ringsâ€”of course we anticipated they would fetch 10l., or we should not have lent it on themâ€”I do not know what the one was sold forâ€”when I received the rings on the Saturday, I directly knew them to be the same that had been redeemed on the Friday nightâ€”I did not make out the ticket of the previous pledgingâ€”I positively swear I did not take the name and address from the previous ticket.

GEORGE JOHN BOYCE . I am a pawnbrokerâ€”I have a shop at Paddington, and another in Theobald's-roadâ€”I remember some inquiry about these ringsâ€”I was present at Debenham's and Storr's when they were sold, and bought them for 16l.â€”I broke the cluster ring up, and I was very doubtful whether the other was an emerald; and having inferior brilliants round it I sold it as a common ring, either in a lot or separately, I do not recollect whichâ€”I think I took them in my pocket from the sale, and broke one up after a few days, or it might be a weekâ€”I broke it up with my handsâ€”I have sold part of the stones, and some I have by me now; I have the centre one still, I have not got it hereâ€”I told the Magistrate I had the stones nowâ€”I sold the emerald ring in the same state in which I bought itâ€”I sold it from my house in Theobald's-roadâ€”it is not at all usual to sell them in the same place they are pawned atâ€”I cannot give you the slightestâ€”notion toâ€”whom I sold it, nor the priceâ€”it might have been sold in a lot.

ROBERT EDWARDS BROUGHTON, ESQ . I presided at the Marylebone police-court on the occasion of the examination of the prisoner on this chargeâ€”after the evidence was concluded, the prisoner was called upon, in the terms of the Statute, to know if she had anything to say or wished to sayâ€”she made a statement, which was taken down in writing by the clerkâ€”when the deposi
tions

were read over, that statement was read over alsoâ€”this is the statement (looking at the deposition)â€”it is signed by meâ€”(readâ€”the prisoner says, "Sir John Hare offered me marriage at Bath, at his house, and said he was a richer man than my husbandâ€”Sir John took a little box from a desk and said, 'Look here, Emma, and took them and put them on my finger, and I showed them to my mother, and my mother gave them to me again, and I gave them to the Baron, and he gave them to Sir John, and I never saw them againâ€”I know nothing of the rings spoken of by the pawnbrokerâ€”Sir John came up: to town; he said something about rings, and I said, 'You do not mean that you want to see my wedding-ring'â€”after that he said he wanted his rings.")
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. Moon and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Sixth Jury.

div1.p:
125.
ROBERT BORLEY
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Hall, and stealing 1 cake, value 1s.; and 1 tin, 3d.; his property: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.â€”
Confined Three Months.

126.
JOHN WEBB
, stealing 6 feet of wood, called veneer, value 6s.; the goods of
William Stannard, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 15.â€”
Confined Two Months.

127.
GEORGE ARNOLD
, stealing 2 lbs. weight of rope, value 1s.; the goods of
Christopher Male, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.â€”'
Confined Two Months.

128.
ELIZABETH NADAULD
, stealing 6 yards of printed cotton, and other articles, value 1l.; the goods of
John Samuel King, her master; to, which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Confined Three Months.

129.
SARAH MITCHELL
, stealing 1 watch-case, value 2s.; the goods of
James Griffith, her master: to which she pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Judgment Respited.

130.
CATHARINE DOUGLAS
, stealing 25 yards of alpaca, and other, articles, value 2l. 5s. 6d.; the goods of
William Skinner, the younger, her master: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Judgment Respited.

131.
JAMES MERRY
, stealing 100 lbs. weight of silk, value 75l.; the goods of
Joseph Baxendale and others.
GILBERT M'MURDO, ESQ . I am surgeon to this gaol. I have attended the prisonerâ€”he is in a state in which he does not know right from wrong.
NOT GUILTY, being Insane .

132.
EDWARD HIGGINS GREEN
, unlawfully obtaining 2 bills of exchange by false pretences.
(MR. CLARKSON offered no evidence.)
NOT GUILTY .

133.
THOMAS CHURCHER
, stealing 22 lbs. weight of chocolate, value 10s.; the goods of
Henry Taylor and another, his masters.
GLORGE TEAKLE (police-sergeant, H 8). The prisoner told me where his lodgings wereâ€”I went there, and found these packets of chocolate, weighing 22 lbs.

GEORGE BARTLETT . I am foreman to Henry and John Taylor. The pri
soner told me he had taken this chocolate, and had it at homeâ€”it is my master's.
Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. How long has he been there? A. About three yearsâ€”seventy or eighty persons are employed there.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 35.â€”
Confined Four Months.

134.
GEORGE BOLTON and
JAMES BOLTON
, stealing 300lbs. weight of lead, value 20l.; the goods of John Kelk.â€”2nd COUNT, for felo
niously receiving the same.

WILLIAM MURPHY (police-sergeant, V 40). On Friday evening, 17th Nov., I saw Wharton and Hewson, and went next day to the residence of the two prisoners in Kew-road, Richmondâ€”in the front shop I saw George Boltonâ€”I asked if he had bought any lead from any one latelyâ€”he said, "No"â€”I said, "Are you quite sure of that"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Have you got any lead on the premises"â€”he said, "No"â€”I then read a search-warrant to him, and proceeded to search the premises with the assistance of two other officersâ€”Roberts called my attention to a lot of bricks in the yard, under which were these seventy-one pieces of leadâ€”fifty-eight pieces are new weighing about 350lbs.â€”the old weighs 55lbs.â€”I searched in the bed-room, and found two lockers containing brass taps, a dozen rasps, and other thingsâ€”George Bolton gave me the keysâ€”I saw a cart standing close to the heap of bricks which had "George Bolton" on it, with some lead in it in a bagâ€”I brought away the books.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. I believe you were examined several times before the Magistrate? A. Yesâ€”he thought there was not suffi
cient evidenceâ€”I brought more almost immediatelyâ€”James was not at the pre
misesâ€”I was obliged to call the assistance of other men, two or three hun
dred persons got round the doorâ€”there was a small sack over the bricksâ€”George gave me the key of his boxes, and conducted me all over his premisesâ€”there was no disinclination on his partâ€”he was not in custody when we began to search, but we should not have let him go away.

MR. WILDE. Q, Were you present when this piece of lead was found? A. Yesâ€”George Bolton said to Mr. Beadon, "Don't mark that, that did not come from your place; I had that from another place," or words tantamount to thatâ€”I did not recollect that on my first examination.

JESSE ROBERTS (policeman, V 96), I went to the prisoner's premises on 18th Nov. with the other officerâ€”George said to a man who was at work, "Go and fetch my brother"â€”previous to that, I pulled the sack of the bricks, and saw the leadâ€”I was present when this piece was markedâ€”George said,. "Don't mark that, I had it from another place."

Cross-examined. Q. How far was the lead from the house? A. Just in the rear of it, in the yardâ€”there are several sheds there, occupied I believe by different personsâ€”it is entered by a gateâ€”it was always understood to be George Bolton's yardâ€”I believe he was in the house when I found this leadâ€”he came into the yard when the other officer spoke to him about it.

GEORGE WOODS (policeman, V 209). I followed the other officers to George Bolton'sâ€”the search-warrant was read, and we went into the back premises. to searchâ€”when George and I were near the top of the yard Roberts called

out, "Here it is"â€”George said to me, "Oh they have found it"â€”we went back to that part of the yard, and saw Roberts pulling out the leadâ€”a cart was standing near with "George Bolton" on itâ€”George said to a man that worked in the shop, "Go and fetch my brother"â€”when he came he said to him, "They have found it"â€”James Bolton replied, "What have I to do with it; I have nothing to do with it"â€”I searched the cart, and found some leadâ€”we then went into the house, and opened a bureau with a key which George gave, and found these booksâ€”both prisoners got hold of them, and swore we should not have them.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it an open yard? A. It is enclosed by gatesâ€”persons who have premises up the yard have keysâ€”I can only find two per
sons who have access to it.

THOMAS BEADON . I am superintendent of the works at Kennar-hallâ€”this lead is the property of Mr. John Kelkâ€”we missed property from about 1st or 2nd Nov.â€”none of this would have been removed by Mr. Kelk's permis
sion or mine.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there a Mr. Mole who has something to do with it? A. There is a man of that name working there as a journeyman under meâ€”he is nothing superior to another working manâ€”I have the supreme command over this leadâ€”the keys are delivered to meâ€”I can identify this piece of leadâ€”it fits another piece which I have brought hereâ€”they have been sawn, not cutâ€”an immense quantity of lead is cast of this shape and formâ€”I missed a great deal before any one was apprehendedâ€”I had been on the watch from the beginning of Nov.

RICHARD SWABY . I am a carman, and occupy some sheds near the prisoner's houseâ€”George Bolton had the occupation of the corner where the bricks and lead wereâ€”I have seen him taking lead from thereâ€”I believe I never saw James there.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean you have seen George loading anything from there? A. I have seen him taking lead from that corner several times, but it is a long time ago since I saw him take the lastâ€”the yard is let to dif
ferent personsâ€”I have sheds thereâ€”other persons have access to it.

JOHN HEWSON (a prisoner). I am a labourerâ€”I was employed in Nov. at Kennar-hallâ€”I never took any lead belonging to Mr. Kelkâ€”I can swear to this one piece of leadâ€”it was made in the plumber's shop at Kennar-hall, on the Wednesday before the Friday on which we were takenâ€”I know Bolton's premisesâ€”I went there with some others with some lead three weeks ago last Mondayâ€”a strange man weighed the lead, and took us into the parlourâ€”George Bolton put the money on the tableâ€”I never went at any other time.

Cross-examined. Q. You have come out of Newgate? A. Yes; I was charged with stealing leadâ€”some was found on meâ€”I never stole itâ€”I was working at a job with Whartonâ€”he opened a box in his bed-room, took out the lead, and asked me to accompany him to Richmond with itâ€”I did. not know where it came fromâ€”I not 9d. for my shareâ€”I thought that rather queer.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

GEORGE BOLTONâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 32.â€”
Confined One Year .

JAMES BOLTONâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

135.
JOHN HEWSON and
THOMAS WHARTON
, stealing 27lbs. weight of lead, value 10s.; the goods of
John Kelk: to which

WHARTON pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Six Months.

HEWSONâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

136.
LEWIS JOSEPHS and
MICHAEL MYERS
, stealing 1 coat, and 1 horse rug, value 2l. 10s.; the goods of
William Graham; and 1 coat, 2l. 10s.; the goods of
John Froggatt.

EMILY CHARSLEY . On 8th Nov.
