I was in Mr. William Graham's service; between six and seven o'clock that evening I heard a knock at the doorâ€”I went, and saw Josephsâ€”he said he had brought a pot of pickled fish which. had been orderedâ€”I went up stairs and inquired; it had not been orderedâ€”I came down and told himâ€”I was away about two minutesâ€”after he was gone, a coat and rug which hung on the balustrades was goneâ€”no one else had been in the house.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. Do you keep a lamp in the hall? A. No, you can see the hall from the kitchenâ€”I saw them safe when I went up stairsâ€”I did not miss them till somebody else calledâ€”some of them were my master'sâ€”I had no light in my handâ€”the light in. the kitchen lights the hall sufficient to see everythingâ€”Josephs had a frock coat on.

RICHARD LAWLEY . About half-past six o'clock, on 8th Nov. I was in Red Lion-courtâ€”Mr. Graham's is opposite that courtâ€”I saw Josephs in the blacksmith's shop in the middle of the courtâ€”he had nothing with himâ€”Myers came, and brought him a coat from the prosecutor's houseâ€”Myers then went back again, and I saw him go into Mr. Graham's, take another coat, and give it to another boyâ€”I gave information.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. When did you see Josephs again? A. When he was in custodyâ€”the policeman called me up, and said, "Is this the boy?"â€”I said it wasâ€”I am a cooper, and work with my fatherâ€”it was rather dark when I saw Josephsâ€”I had seen Myers two or three times before.
NOT GUILTY .

137.
LEWIS JOSEPHS was again indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 2l. 10s.; the goods of
Silvester Lewis Samuel.

MARY DAVIS . On 30th Oct. I was in the service of Mr. Silvester Lewis Samuel. Between ten and eleven o'clock that night the prisoner came, and said he had brought the bloaters which the gentleman and lady had ordered, and he was sorry he could not bring them beforeâ€”I went to the top of the kitchen stairsâ€”I returned, and he was very much confusedâ€”he took them, and retreated back, and went awayâ€”I then missed a coat from the passage.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. When did you next see him? A. The policeman called on me on the Saturday week following, between two and three o'clock in the morningâ€”I went to the station, and saw the prisonerâ€”he was in our house a minute or twoâ€”I was not out of the hallâ€”we have gas thereâ€”he had a frock-coat onâ€”I did not express any doubt about his personâ€”this coat was not hanging upâ€”it was folded up, and was a large bulkâ€”he had nothing in his hand when he brought the bloatersâ€”I had the coat in my hand ten minutes beforeâ€”several coats, umbrellas, and other things, were in the hallâ€”I may have made mistakesâ€”I am not mistaken about the prisoner's personâ€”I missed this coat in about four minutes afterwardsâ€”during that time I was in the kitchenâ€”our door fastens with a spring lock.

GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Six Months.

338.
JAMES WELLS was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOSEPH DOBSON . I am a grocer. The prisoner was in my serviceâ€”on 18th Nov. I watched him, and saw him put his hand into his waistcoat pocketâ€”I went into the shop to speak to him, but returned, and saw him take half-a-crown from a customerâ€”he gave the changeâ€”I then saw the half-crowu in

his handâ€”he did not put it into the tillâ€”I went towards him, and he dropped it behind himâ€”he said, "It is only a weight, Sir; I will pick it up"â€”I said, "Come away from the counter"â€”I looked down, and found the half-crown.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Who was in the shop? A. A good many customersâ€”there were two persons to serve besides the prisonerâ€”it was a little after eleven o'clock at nightâ€”I did not look into the tillâ€”I saw him throw the hall-crown on the counter, and go to the till to get changeâ€”I do not know what the customer boughtâ€”the prisoner was with me about eighteen months.
JAMES GAIR (policeman A 447). I took the prisonerâ€”he said, "Master, I am very sorry; I know I have done wrong; I hope you will forgive me this time."
Cross-examined. Q. That was after some almonds were taken from his pocket? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

139.
JAMES WELLS was again indicted
for stealing 3oz. weight of almonds, value 3d.; and 1 half-crown; the property of
Joseph Dobson, his master.

JOSEPH DOBSON . The prisoner was in my employâ€”I saw him put his hand to his left-hand waistcoat pocket, when 1 thought he should be putting money into the tillâ€”I afterwards saw his trowsers thickly coated with sugar, where he had a sort of bag in place of the right-hand pocketâ€”I found in it some almonds, and in his right-hand waistcoat pocket a half-crownâ€”I could not swear that he got the half-crown from the tillâ€”it was his business to put all money into the tillâ€”I then charged him with it, and then found the bag with the almondsâ€”it is not hereâ€”he said before the Magistrate he bad left it at the House of Detentionâ€”it was sent for, and could not be foundâ€”there was from three ounces to a quarter of a pound of almonds in it, worth from 3d. to 4d.â€”they were such as I had in my stockâ€”they are twin-almonds, flat on one sideâ€”I do not allow the men to put any into their pocketsâ€”if I saw them eating any I should not say anything.

JAMES GAIR (policeman, A 447). I took the prisonerâ€”he said he was sorry for itâ€”he admitted he had done wrong, and he hoped his master would for give himâ€”his pocket was very greasy, as if it had been carrying sugarâ€”these are the almonds.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY of Stealing the Almonds. Aged 33.â€”
Confined Four Months.

140.
EDWARD SURGURY
, stealing 1 shilling; the moneys of
John Walker, his master.

JOHN WALKER . The prisoner was my pot-boyâ€”I missed money from my till, and marked some money, and showed it to the policemanâ€”I put 1l., in shillings, sixpences, and fourpenny-pieces, into the till when 1 left the bar to go to dinnerâ€”whin I returned, I took out all the marked money that was left, and put it into a bit of paperâ€”several puces were gone, which had reduced it to about 15s.â€”at night I put it in againâ€”it went on so for two or three days, and when I had no more marked money to put in I sent for the police
manâ€”he searched the prisoner's box, and found 1l. 17s., and one was this marked shilling.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. You asked him for the key of his box, he gave it you, and you found the shilling? A. Yesâ€”he had been in my employ about nine monthsâ€”there are three persons in my bar to take money besides meâ€”I had not marked any money for six months before thisâ€”I think it was on 18th Nov. I began to put marked money into the till,
and I made this charge on the 29thâ€”I put that same marked money into the till a great many timesâ€”I had been to his box three timesâ€”I had a key of it.

JAMES NEVILLE (policeman, G 152). I saw the money after it was markedâ€”this is one of the shillingsâ€”the prisoner asked me what I thought would be done with himâ€”I said I could not answer that question.
NOT GUILTY .

141.
EBENEZER JONES
, stealing 1 watch, value 20l., the goods of
Mary Ann Bale; and 2 brooches and 1 handkerchief, 3l. 4s., the goods of
Ann Harman; in the dwelling-house of
William Leddelow; also 3 coats and other articles, 15l., the goods of
John Marshall, in his dwelling-house: to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

142.
WILLIAM JONES
, stealing 1 quadrant, value 2l. 10s., and 1 waistcoat, 10s.; the goods of
John Malcolm Scott; having been before convicted.

JOHN MALCOLM SCOTT . I am a mariner. I got acquainted with the prisoner about 7th Nov.â€”I went to a public-house and talked and drank with himâ€”he was going to put me on board a shipâ€”I gave him a quadrant and waistcoatâ€”he told me he had a shipâ€”he went away with my quadrantâ€”this is it (produced).

WILLIAM CHARLES POTTER (policeman, K 212). I took the prisonerâ€”I asked him where the quadrant wasâ€”he said he knew notâ€”I found it at the Whit by coffee-shopâ€”his wife brought it there in Scott's presence, and left it there, when the prisoner was remandedâ€”this is itâ€”the waistcoat has not been found.
Prisoner. I told you I had the quadrant, and put it on the seat in the public-house. Witness. No, you said you knew nothing of it; you believed the other man stole it.
Prisoner's Defence. I knew nothing of it from the time I put it on the seat of the public-house.
CHARLES PILCHER (policeman, K 190). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted May, 1847, confined one year)â€”he is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Tears.

143.
ELIZA CLARKE
, stealing 1 pair of trowsers, value 5s.; the goods of
William Seeley: having been before convicted.

WILLIAM JONES HUNT . I keep a shop in Tottenham-court-road. On 24th Nov. I was at the door, and saw the prisoner take a pair of trowsers from a chair outside the doorâ€”I followed and took herâ€”she dropped the trowsersâ€”these are themâ€”they are my employer's, William Seeley's.
EDWARD TANNER (policeman, E 56). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted Sept., 1847, confined three months)â€”she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
Confined One Year .

144.
JOHANNAH HIRD and
CATHARINE DILLON
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 5s. 6d.; the goods of
William Kendall the younger: Hird having been before convicted; to which

HIRD pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

WILLIAM RENDALL . I am a picture-dealer, of Tonbridge-street. On 16th Nov. my son was bringing some boots from the makers and lost themâ€”he is seven years oldâ€”he knows right from wrongâ€”I believe these are them.
FRANCIS CLEMENTS . I made these boots for Mr. Rendallâ€”I gave them to the little boy on 16th Nov.

WILLIAM RENDALL the younger. On 16th Nov. I was coming along with some books which I got from Mr. Clementsâ€”I saw Dillon and Hirdâ€”Dillon took hold of my pinafore while Hird took the bootsâ€”Dillon told me to go round the corner to get somethingâ€”I went, and then I saw some little girls, who said the prisoner had run awayâ€”I had seen Dillon before, and knew her.

DILLONâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 17.â€”
Confined Ten Days.

145.
JAMES HATHAWAY
, stealing 1 pewter pot, value 1s. 3d.; the goods to
John Frederick Renninson: having been before convicted.
JOHN FREDERICK RENNINSON . I am a licenced victualler, at Paddington, On 20th Nov. I stopped the prisoner with this pot in the tap-room.
Prisoner. I was not out of the house; I was going to get some water. Witness. No, he was going towards the streetâ€”it was under his smock-frockâ€”he said he had nothing upon him.
THOMAS JENKINS (policeman, D) 217). I produce a certificate of the, prisoner's convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted March, 1847, confined four months)â€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
Confined One Year .

146.
CHARLES BROWN
, stealing 42lbs. weight of lead, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Parker, fixed to a building; and
JESSE JONES
felo
niously receiving the same.

THOMAS LOCKERBY (policeman, S 180). On Saturday night, 18th Nov., I saw Brown in Southampton-street, carrying somethingâ€”I followed him, and saw him put it over some railings into an area at the end of Jones's houseâ€”there are several boards placed right across the areaâ€”there is no window, but a door in the basement into the areaâ€”it can be seen by day-lightâ€”it is generally kept shutâ€”I lifted up what Brown had placed on the boards, and found it was leadâ€”Brown had then gone into Churchway, which is the front way to Jones's houseâ€”I concealed myself for a few minutes, and Brown came out of the front door into Churchway, took the lead, and pnt it through the railings cm to another board a little lower down the areaâ€”I took hold of him, and asked what he had got, he said, "Nothing particular, only a parcel I brought for Mr. Jones; wait a minute, Mr. Jones will be here for it"â€”at that instant Jones opened the little door and came into the areaâ€”the lead was about as high as his breastâ€”he took hold of one end of itâ€”I caught the other end and said, "Stop. I will take that"â€”Brown said, "That is your property, is it not, Mr. Jones?"â€”Jones looked up and saw me; he knew meâ€”he had seen me before, and he said, "No," I think, I will not be positiveâ€”I took Brown and the lead to the stationâ€”I came back to Jones's shop and said to him, "Well, what about this lead?"â€”he said, "Well, I had not it"â€”I said, "I shall take you into custody for receiving the lead, knowing it was stolen"â€”he said, "It was never in my shop"â€”I said, "No, but on your premises, and in your possession"â€”he said, "You never saw me pay for the lead"â€”I said, "No, I did not"â€”I found a half-crown and a shilling on Brownâ€”I asked him where he got that fromâ€”he said he had earned if at a penny or twopence a timeâ€”I said I thought it was money he had received for the leadâ€”he said, "No," and he had never taken anything to Jones's shop beforeâ€”at the Police-court Jones told me he had a good mind to cutâ€”he said, "I would have come back again on Monday morning; I thought you would come for me; you need not say I received the lead; I should not mind giving you a pound or two;" and then his wife said, in his presence, "I will give you 3l. "â€”this was in the Police-court passageâ€”I took tins lead to a place belonging to Mr. Baker, in South

Crescent-mewsâ€”I compared it with the lead on the wall thereâ€”it matched exactlyâ€”I tried it on three or four placesâ€”there was a great quantity of lead stolen from thereâ€”I found this catch there.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. How long has Jones had that shop? A. About two yearsâ€”I did not search the place afterwardsâ€”I did not see pieces of board in the areaâ€”a little door opens into the areaâ€”he did not take anything out of the area.
THOMAS PARKER . I saw this lead fitted by Lockerby on my wallâ€”it fitted exactly.

Cross-examined. Q. Who are you tenant to? A. To Mr. Clevertonâ€”I am a cab proprietorâ€”I keep my horses thereâ€”I have one partnerâ€”I have lived in those premises nearly two yearsâ€”Mr. Graham is not partner in those premisesâ€”he has nothing to do with my stable at allâ€”he keeps his horse in his own stableâ€”the cabs do not belong to him.

WILLIAM JOHN BROWN (policeman, S 67). I was in, the passage of the police-court when the prisoners were thereâ€”I heard Jones say to Lockerby, "I had a great mind to cut it on Saturday night; I thought you would come for me, as it was such a long time to lie in the cell till Monday"â€”he said to me, "I should not mind spending 2l. or 3l. with such a man as you or Lock
erby, and have nothing more to do with the case"â€”he said he knew nothing of Brown before.
Brown's Defence. The lead was given me in Seymour-streetâ€”the greater part of the money I had was given me by my father.

WILLIAM ELLIOTT . I live in Sidmouth-street, Gray's-inn-roadâ€”I have known Jones for the last four or five yearsâ€”I was in his shop on that Saturday evening between six and seven o'clockâ€”Brown-came inâ€”he had nothing with himâ€”he asked Jones if he would buy a piece of leadâ€”Jones said, "No"â€”Brown went out of the shopâ€”after he was gone a man came in and said, "What do you want for two pieces of board outsideâ€”he went outsideâ€”the boards came to 7d.â€”the man gave Jones 1s.â€”he gave the child the shilling to get changeâ€”I did not see the policeman take Brown.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you see Jones go in the area? A. No; he went out with the other man to look at these boardsâ€”I did not see Jones and the officer talking togetherâ€”Jones came back to the shopâ€”he did not tell me that an officer had been asking him whether some lead belonged to him, or had been taking some from the areaâ€”the boards were over the area outsideâ€”there were two pieces on the stage or platformâ€”I have worked for Jones for the last eight monthsâ€”Brown had been gone about three minutes before the man came into the shopâ€”I remained in the shop about five minutes after the man was goneâ€”the shop door is towards Church way.

BROWNâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Confined Three Months.

JONESâ€”
GUILTY .â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. MOON, and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq. and the Fourth Jury.

div1.p:
147.
JAMES DRISCOLL and
ELLEN DRISCOLL
, unlawfully assaulting
James Armstrong and
John Bulling, police-constables, in the execution of their duty.
NOT GUILTY .

148.
DENNIS M'CARTHY and
THOMAS SEED
, stealing 28lbs. of leaden pipe, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Edmund Cobbett.

p.hi: The pipe being the property of Edmund Cobbett and another, the prisoners, were

div1.p: ACQUITTED .

149.
JAMES KING and
JOHN JONES
, stealing 1 looking-glass and frame, value 1l.; the goods of
Henry Colvin.

HARRIET COLVIN . I am wife of Henry Colvin, who keeps the Brass-found
ers' Arms, Whitechapel. The prisoners were in the skittle-ground on 3rd Nov., playingâ€”I had a glass in the parlour safe at about a quarter-past nineâ€”my husband came in at a quarter past ten, and it was goneâ€”the prisoners had left about a quarter of an hour beforeâ€”I just saw their shoulders as they wentâ€”the bar is very highâ€”a person could have taken it and gone away without my seeing, but not unless they laid on their hands and kneesâ€”King returned for his jacket which he had left in the corner of the barâ€”a woman came into the house; I served herâ€”she did not go to the skittle-ground or anywhere elseâ€”the prisoners came to the skittle-ground next evening and were taken.

HENRY BRECHT . I am the son of the last witness, and live in the house. Just before the glass was missed I saw both of the prisonersâ€”Jones hustled me by the handkerchief in the skittle-groundâ€”I did not see King thenâ€”I saw him go out of the skittle-groundâ€”Jones left about a quarter of an hour afterwardsâ€”I saw him go through the house and out at the doorâ€”I saw the jacket on the corner of the barâ€”the glass was missed about three-quarters of an hour after they were goneâ€”I did not see any one leave the house during that timeâ€”persons might have left without my seeing them.
THOMAS KELLY (policeman, H 2). I took the prisoners in the house, I told them the chargeâ€”they said they were innocent
ELEANOR BRECHT . I am the daughter of Mrs. Colvin. Two women, one of whom they said was King's mother, brought a glass back to the houseâ€”it was not the glass we had lost or like it.
NOT GUILTY .

150.
FRANCIS PEAKE
, unlawfully assaulting
Jane Elizabeth Rebecca Peake, with intent, &c.
(The prosccutrix did not appear.)
NOT GUILTY .

151.
EDWARD MARTIN
, unlawfully obtaining 2 sovereigns, of Eliza
beth
Mary Gregory, by false pretences.

ELIZABETH MARY GREGORY . I am the wife of Daniel Gregory, a labourer, of Barking. I thought myself entitled to the Golden Fleece public-house, and put myself in communication with the prisoner, about Good Friday lastâ€”he said he was a writer in the law, and could procure the pro
perty for meâ€”on 25th April I gave him 2l. for these copies of wills, which he said he had obtained at Doctors' Commons that morning (produced)â€”he said I was entitled to the property, which appears by these willsâ€”he sent me upwards of fifty letters, one contained this receipt, which he said would enable me to receive 14l., which he would send me by a post-office orderâ€”(the letter requested the witness to send the prisoner 1l., as he had expended money on her business)â€”he said he got the receipt from Butler and Son, and that it would enable me to get 14l.â€”upon that I gave him 10s.

Prisoner. Q. How many post-office orders did you send me? A. So many that I cannot say, and I have given money to Mr. Cooper, a friend of yours, by your directionsâ€”he said he would forward it to you.
RICHARD MOSS (policeman). I took the prisoner.

WILLIAM HENRY MARLOW SIDNEY . I am a solicitor, of Hatton-garden. I have searched at Doctors' Commons for the wills of Lady and Arthur Hubbard, but could find no such namesâ€”these documents are not copies of wills which would be sent from Doctors' Commonsâ€”they are on paper, bearing the seal of, and only used in, the Court of Chanceryâ€”I have inquired for the person mentioned in the receiptâ€”there is no such person there.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY .

152.
EDWARD MARTIN was again indicted
for a like offence.

ELIZABETH MARY GREGORY . The prisoner told me he had received a decree of the Lord Chancellor, in consequence of which I went to town about 16th Aug.â€”he said the decree was made, and he wanted to get it, and wanted, the money to pay for itâ€”I gave him 3l.â€”he produced this document (pro
duced), and said it was done privately, because the Lord Chancellor was ill, and that by that, and nothing else, I was to take possession of the property in a coach and four, with Mr. Hide, the Lord Chancellor's officerâ€”he said this was the Lord Chancellor's seal, and I must not break it.
BENJAMIN HEASMAN . I am a stationer, of Chancery-lane. I have had many decrees in my bandsâ€”this is not oneâ€”it is not the signature or seal of the Lord Chancellor.

GUILTY . Aged 32.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

153.
LAWRENCE NAGLE , was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Rosa Nathan, with intent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .

154.
ALFRED CUMMINS was indicted
for embezzlement.

ELIZABETH MOODY . I am cook to Mr. Hamilton, of Hampstead. On 31st Oct. I had a check for 8l., for money owing to meâ€”I went to the pri
soner's father's shop to get it changedâ€”the prisoner was in the shopâ€”he used to come for ordersâ€”I could not get change, and went outâ€”the prisoner followed me and said he would get it changed for meâ€”I gave it himâ€”he never brought me the changeâ€”I gave him in charge on 10th Nov.â€”this is the check (produced).
Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. He is a baker? A. Yesâ€”I did not look at the date of the check, or the banker's nameâ€”I know it, because I put my name on it.

JOHN AVAN . I keep the King of Bohemia, at Hampstead. On 31st Oct., the prisoner called and asked if I would change a check for Mr. Hamilton's cookâ€”I did soâ€”I change three or four a weekâ€”this is itâ€”I know it by the cook's name.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know her writing? A. Noâ€”I know Mr. Hamilton's, and I know it by the date, and by the crossing of Mr. Bland, who I paid it to, with three other checks of Mr. Hamilton's, one for 10l., one for 12l., and I forget the amount of the otherâ€”I believe the prisoner had some drink just as he went awayâ€”he complained of the tooth-ache, and said he must go to the doctor'sâ€”I have seen him many times.
FRANCIS LAWRENCE BLAND . I am collector to Barclay and Perkins' breweryâ€”I received this clnck for 8l. on Strachans, from Avan.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you a mark on it? A. Yesâ€”A van's name is in my writing, and the crossâ€”I took two others for 10l. and 12l.
JAMES ALLEN . I am a cashier at Strachan'sâ€”this check was paid in by Barclays'.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you know that? A. Because it is crossed
so, and I wrote Barclays' on it, and we are Captain Hamilton's bankers, and we only had one check that day for 8l.

JOHN STYMAX (policeman). I took the prisoner leaving the House of Correction, and asked if he knew anything about Captain Hamilton, or his robberyâ€”he said, "Then I suppose I shall get seven years transportation," or words to that effectâ€”I found 5l. 6s. 3 1/2 d. on him.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he mention any other case? A. He said, "Which case are you going to take me on."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY , recommended to mercy. Aged 24.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. RECORDER and Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Second Jury.

div1.p:
155.
THOMAS MOORE was indicted
for stealing 5 spoons, 5 forks, and 1 basket, value 10l.; the property of
Mary King, in her dwelling-house.

ISABELLA KING . I live with my mother, Mary King, at St. Maxk's-ter
race, New Brompton, in the parish of Kensington. On 7th Nov., about five o'clock in the afternoon, I missed a basket of plate from the parlour cupboardâ€”it was worth about 10l.â€”I saw a man with a top coat and light hair in the garden in front of the house about two o'clockâ€”he looked up at the house twiceâ€”I did not see that he had anythingâ€”the garden gate was openâ€”this is the basket and plate (produced)â€”they are my mother's.

JOSEPH BALCOMB (policeman, V 302). On 7th Nov., about five minutes to two o'clock, I saw the prisoner about 100 yards from Mrs. King's, with something under his armâ€”I asked what he had gotâ€”he said, "A basket, of plate"â€”I asked bow he came by itâ€”he said a man gave it himâ€”he made a desperate resistance, and a constable came to my assistanceâ€”this silk-hand
kerchief was over the basket, and four combs were in itâ€”he had a frock coat onâ€”this signature to this deposition is Mr. Broderip'sâ€”(readâ€”"The prisoner says, 'I had the basket given to me to carry to Battersea Pier; he said he would meet me there and reward me for my trouble; at the time I was taken I had not a frock coat but a Chesterfield, which is now in the cell."
Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. Did you see any one near? A. No.

BETSY LEWIS . I missed the plate, and told my mistress of itâ€”I had seen it safe about one o'clockâ€”I was washing in the back kitchen at twoâ€”a person could enter by the area door and go to where the plate wasâ€”it was on the same floor.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY â€”Recommended to mercy. Aged 22.â€”
Confined One Year .

156.
JOHN BENJAMIN SMEDLEY
, unlawfully obtaining money by false pretences.
(MR. PARNELL offered no evidence.)
NOT GUILTY .

157.
THOMAS DAVIS was indicted
for embezzlement; having been before convicted.

THOMAS DUNN . I am a rope-maker, of Stepney-square. On 16th Nov. the prisoner brought me some yarn which I had ordered of Mr. Tubbsâ€”paid him 12s.â€”I put his name on this bill (produced)â€”he made this mark to it.
FRANCIS TUBES . I am a sail-maker, of Store-lane, Ratcliffeâ€”I sent the
prisoner to Mr. Dunn with some yarnâ€”he has never accounted to me for the 12s.
THOMAS WALKING (policeman, K 310). I took the prisoner and told him the chargeâ€”he said, "It is no more than I expected."
JOSEPH PUDDIFORD (policeman K 276). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted Jan., 1848, and confined five days)â€”I was presentâ€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Two Months.

158.
AUGUSTUS SNEWING was indicted
for embezzlement.

NOAH CARTER . I am a butcher, in Queen's-terrace, St. Jobn's-wood. The prisoner was my apprentice for three yearsâ€”he carried out meat, and received money for itâ€”it was his duty to account to me dailyâ€”Mrs. Laing is a customerâ€”I make up her accounts weekly.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. I believe you are not anxious to press this case? A. Not at allâ€”this is the first time this sort of thing has occurredâ€”I think he was under particular circumstances at the timeâ€”my daughter sometimes receives money, and hands it to meâ€”she is not here.

COURT. Q. Is he still your apprentice? A. Yesâ€”I do not prosecute him in order to get rid of himâ€”I had 30l. premium with himâ€”his father will place him somewhere elseâ€”I have not been promised repayment of the money he has embezzled.

SARAH HEATH . I live with Mrs. Laing. On 16th Nov. I paid the pri
soner 3l. 9s. 1d.: 2l. 10s., and 14s. 3d. for his masterâ€”the book is not signed for the last week.
NOT GUILTY .

159.
ROBERT WARD
, stealing a carpen tenter's square, value 2s.; the goods of
William Ireland Thurgood, his master.

WILLIAM IRELAND THURGOOD . I live at 48, Brick-lane, St. Luke's. The prisoner has worked for me about twelve months, off and onâ€”I lost a square, which the prisoner used on my premisesâ€”I questioned him about it, and after some time he gave tip the duplicate of it, with several othersâ€”I have lost a quantity of tools since he has worked for me.
WILLIAM LOVELL . This square was pawned with me on 17th Nov. for 6d.â€”I cannot say by whomâ€”the prosecutor has the duplicate that was given for it.
Prisoner's Defence. I had no intention of defrauding him; I intended to redeem it.
NOT GUILTY .

160.
ROBERT WARD was again indicted
for stealing a saw, value 4s.; the goods of
William Ireland Thurgood, his master; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: PRESENTâ€”Mr. Ald. WILLIAM HUNTER; Mr. Ald. MOON; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq. and the Fifth Jury.

div1.p:
161.
THOMAS MITCHELL
, stealing 3lbs. weight of horse-hair, value 2s.; the goods of
Henry Mitchell and another.

GEORGE TEWSLEY (policeman, B 181). About half-past six on the evening of 22nd Nov. I was in Sloane-square, in plain clothes, and saw the prisoner coming up Simon-street with this pillow.-caseâ€”he went to a marine-store shopâ€”I went to the window, and saw him taking this horse-hair out of this pillow-case, and putting it into the scaleâ€”I went in and asked where he got that hairâ€”he said, "Out of some old chairs"â€”I asked where the chairs wereâ€”he said he broke them up a long while agoâ€”I said I would take him to the stationâ€”he said if that was the case, he could show me the old chairsâ€”he took me to Messrs. Mitchell and St. John's back warehouse, in Simon-streetâ€”there were no chairs there, but I found an old horse-hair mattress, which had several holes, and a quantity of horse-hair taken out.

CHARLES CHINN (policeman, A 255). I was with Tewsleyâ€”I saw the prisoner putting the horse-hair into the scaleâ€”he then took us to the back of the premises in Simon-streetâ€”I then took him to the front of the premises, and he acknowledged to Mr. Mitchell and Mr. St. John that it was the first time he had taken any, and he did it merely to get sixpenceâ€”I took him to the station.
Prisoner. I never mentioned about the first time; I said it was my own.

JOSIAH ST. JOHN . I am partner with Henry Mitchell, as upholsterers. I went to our warehouse and found the prisonerâ€”we had been robbed, and gave him leave to live there to protect the placeâ€”I found in the room adjoin
ing the room he slept in, a mattress of ours, which had been openedâ€”I took the prisoner to my shop in Cadogan-rowâ€”he said it was the first time, and he did it to get a sixpenceâ€”I cannot swear to this horse-hairâ€”it appeared the same sort as that in the mattress.
Prisoner. It was my own. Witness. I had seen the mattress about three weeks beforeâ€”it was cut at the side, but not cut in the middle then.

Prisoner's Defence. We never buy horse-hair mattresses, but we cut them in different places; that bit of horse-hair was my own; I cut the mattress open in his presence to prove that it was horse-hair.

GUILTY . Aged 60.â€”
Confined Three Months.

162.
ROBERT REZER HEINEMAN
, stealing 61 yards of velvet and 3 boxes, value 16l. 3s.; the goods of
John Frederick Frank and others.

JOHN FREDERICK FRANK . I have two partnersâ€”we are warehousemen and commission-agents, in Bow-lane. In July last the prisoner came with a person who he represented to be a merchantâ€”the prisoner was a strangerâ€”he said a party in Manchester, who was well known to us, had told him that we had certain goods which he wanted for some partyâ€”we showed him someâ€”he said he was a commission-agent, and he was buying for other partiesâ€”he first asked for gingham, and requested us to let him have a sampleâ€”he came next day, and brought back the sample, and began to bargain about the priceâ€”I told him we should only sell for cashâ€”he said he was buying for cash, and for other peopleâ€”he came very frequently to the warehouse after that, and amongst other samples, he obtained three samples of velvetsâ€”in the course of the times that he came, I repeatedly asked him to return the sam
ples of velvetsâ€”he made excusesâ€”at one time he said he forgot themâ€”he had brought in the first sample he had, and other samples, but not the velvetsâ€”he had them about 19th Aug.â€”the other goods had been looked out that he wanted to have; we had put them aside, we said we wanted the thing settled one way or the otherâ€”he said a bill was coming due on 18th Aug.,

and after that he promised to payâ€”after 18th Aug. he said he could not find room in a vessel where the goods were to be shipped, and asked us to wait a few days longerâ€”I gave him this list of the articles and prices, to show the party for whom he bought the goodsâ€”he had asked for it for that purposeâ€”that was the only reason I gave it himâ€”I never intended to give him any creditâ€”I told him so from the beginningâ€”it refers, amongst other things, to the goods of which I had furnished him samples, and to the velvets amongst the restâ€”he came again on 31st Aug., and asked for an invoice, or list of all the goods he had bargained for, to show to the party the amount of money that he was to be prepared with the next dayâ€”I furnished him with the invoice, amounting to 553l.â€”next day he called againâ€”he was conversing with me in the warehouse, and a gentleman came in from the countryâ€”he asked me, in the prisoner's presence, loud enough for him to hear, whether I knew himâ€”I said we only knew that he said he came from a party we knew in Manchesterâ€”the gentleman went on to say that he was a swindler, and several persons in Manchester had lost goods by himâ€”the prisoner passed by us and went out, I did not think he would run away all at once, but he slipped away, and said he would come in againâ€”I did not see him again till he was in custody, about six weeks afterwardsâ€”I have seen my velvet samples produced by the pawnbrokers.

Prisoner. Q. What numbers did I have, and what lengths? A. One piece was twenty-one yards and a half, another was twenty yards and three-quarters, about sixty yards in allâ€”you had at one time fifteen yards, that you brought backâ€”that was before 19th Aug.â€”you said where you lived, and after you were gone we sent there, and you did not live thereâ€”you bought only for cashâ€”I have not put on these bills "Net cash"â€”they were not intended as invoices, but merely to show the price of the goods.

COURT. Q. Did you inquire into bis character? A. We wrote to Man
chester, and the person said he did not know much of him, but he thought we should be safe in selling anything for cash.

JAMES KEELEY . I was with the policeman and another man when the prisoner was takenâ€”I went with them in a cab from the Islington station to Bow-Janeâ€”after the other person had left to go into his employer's, Mr. Frank's, I saw the prisoner fumbling about under the tail of his coatâ€”he took out a pocket-book, and took some duplicates out of the pocketâ€”he raised himself up, and put them under the cushionâ€”when the officer took the prisoner out, I lifted up the cushion, and there were the duplicatesâ€”the prisoner turned round, and said, "These are my property"â€”the officer told me to give them to him, and I did.
Prisoner. Q. Did I take them out of the pocket-book? A. Yesâ€”I sat opposite you; the officer sat at your sideâ€”his attention was drawn from you while you did this.

HENRY HEWITT (policeman, N 164). On 14th Nov. I took the prisoner in chargeâ€”he had this carpet bag with him, which I examinedâ€”these boots, and two or three things, were in itâ€”we came in a cab to Bow-laneâ€”after I got out, Mr. Keeley delivered to me these duplicatesâ€”there are sixteen of themâ€”the prisoner claimed themâ€”three of them apply to the velvets.

HENRY BILSON . I am assistant to Mr. Barker, a pawnbroker, of Hounds-ditch. I produce this piece of velvet, pawned on 19th Aug., by the prisoner, for 4l. 10s., in the name of John Bordie, Camomile-streetâ€”he said it was his own propertyâ€”this is the duplicate I gave him.
WILLIAM STOWE . I am assistant to Mr. Grant, a pawnbroker, of London-wall.
I produce a piece of velvet, pawned on 30th Aug., by the prisoner, for 4l.â€”this is the duplicate I gave himâ€”he gave his name, "William Baldy, 18, Ca omile-street."

ABRAHAM BODMAN . I am in the employ of Mr. Russell, a pawnbroker, of Shoreditch. I produce a piece of velvet, pawned by the prisoner, on 23rd Aug., for 4l. 4s., in the name of John Bordieâ€”this is the duplicate I gave.

SAMUEL KINGSWELL . I act as porter in the house of Messrs. Frank and Co. About three months ago I went with the prisoner with some samplesâ€”I went first to 5, Carpenter's-buildingsâ€”he went inside, and told me to remain outside; and when he came out he told me to follow him, which I did, to 94, London-wallâ€”he then told me to leave the parcel, and that would doâ€”I left it with himâ€”he knocked at the doorâ€”as I was coming back I met the prisoner in Moorgate-streetâ€”he asked me what I wantedâ€”I told him I was going back to my placeâ€”he said, "May be you want a penny," and he gave me one.
WILLIAM LAWRENCE . I keep the house, 94, London-wall. The prisoner did not live there in Aug., but there was a person he used to come to there.

JOHN FREDERICK FRANK
re-examined. These are the property of our firmâ€”these are the boxes in which we let him have these velvets as samples.

Prisoner's Defence. I can assure you I never robbed any person in my life; I have not stolen these goods, though he charges me with doing it; you will find this velvet is down in this bill; they sold me the goods in a proper way.

GUILTY . Aged 29.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months .
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

163.
ALEXANDER JOHN COCHRANE was indicted
for embezzling the sums of 21l. 2s. 9d., 15l. 6s. 2d., 15l., and 24l. 19s.; the moneys of
Joshua Dorset Joseph Mayhew, his master; also, for stealing 69l. 6s. 3d. of his said master: to all which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

164.
GEORGE LITTLE WOOD
, stealing 10 pieces of wood, called battens, value 1s. 4d.; the goods of
Thomas Brassey.
MESSRS. CLARKSON and WORSLEY conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN OZWIN KNOWLES . I am agent to Mr. Thomas Brassey, a contractor employed on the railroad near Feltham. I missed property of his at various times, from the 4th to the 9th Nov.â€”on the 9th I was passing the line near Feltham, and saw two men sawing a piece of timber, which I saw was Mr. Brassey'sâ€”I asked what they were sawingâ€”the prisoner came up, put his shoulder under a piece which they had been sawing, and carried it awayâ€”I; saw the initials had been cut out of itâ€”this is the piece which I prevented the men from sawingâ€”I went to Mr. Biggs, took him to the saw-pit, and then went for the policemanâ€”no sale of such materials as this had taken place by order of Mr. Brassey, to my knowledgeâ€”no one had any authority to take them away.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Is Mr. Brassey here? A. I have not seen himâ€”I have not ascertained from him whether he has sold these articlesâ€”I do not know that he sells woodâ€”there are no persons under him who have the sale of these thingsâ€”he does not often sell theseâ€”these are called battens in the tradeâ€”I cannot see the initials of the name on this pieceâ€”they may have been sawn off or cut offâ€”there are a cart load of other

pieces of wood hereâ€”this piece was found on the prisoner's premises, about 100 yards from the pitâ€”it has the initials "T. B." on itâ€”these other pieces were found thereâ€”I did not find themâ€”the initials have been cut outâ€”this piece has been used for a scaffolding-plank on the lineâ€”it would not be knocked to pieces when it was done with there, it would be taken to another bridgeâ€”if a piece were broken it would be sent to the yardâ€”I do not know what would become of it thenâ€”I never knew Mr. Brassey, or anybody belonging to him, sell anything.

NORTH BIGGS . I am one of the agents for Mr. Brassey, on the line from Staines to Windsor. On 9th Nov. Mr. Knowles took me to a saw-pitâ€”I saw this piece of timber on the pit, and two men were sawing itâ€”I looked all round itâ€”it is Mr. Brassey's propertyâ€”while Mr. Knowles was gone for a policeman I watched the pitâ€”a man told me somethingâ€”I went to a shed and saw a man who had been sawing the timber, putting some pieces of timber through a hole in the roof, and the other man who had been sawing the timber, and the prisoner, were outside in the yard, close to the shedâ€”I called to the young sawyer, and said they might keep on throwing out, for I was watching themâ€”I found these four pieces, and several more in the shedâ€”this one has the initials on it; they have been taken out of the othersâ€”I am quite positive that these are Mr. Brassey's.

GEORGE SAUNDERS (policeman, V 236). I was called by Mr. Knowles on 9th Nov.â€”I went to the pit, and saw this piece of woodâ€”I saw the prisoner at his houseâ€”I asked him who the piece of timber belonged to on the saw-pitâ€”he replied, "It belongs to me; have not they cut it?"â€”I asked him to come round to the back of the houseâ€”there were fifteen pieces of timber thereâ€”I asked him if he knew anything of themâ€”he said, "No"â€”I pointed to the hole in the shed, and said they came out of there I thoughtâ€”he said no, they never were on his premisesâ€”I asked him to come over to his shed, and then this piece, marked "T. B.," was found in my presenceâ€”he said he had bought some of Mr. Crawley.
Cross-examined. Q. Crawley was before the. Magistrate? A. Yes, he came voluntarilyâ€”the prisoner said there that he had them from Crawleyâ€”Crawley has run away.

THOMAS CATTANACH . I know this long piece of timberâ€”I saw it on the railway side a few days before it was taken out of the prisoner's possessionâ€”Crawley was employed to watch the gates of the Companyâ€”he was not in the employ of Mr. Brasseyâ€”on 10th Nov. I went to examine some cottages of the prisoner'sâ€”I saw some pieces of Mr. Brassey's wood that were built into the wallâ€”I considered I had no right to remove themâ€”the prisoner keeps a beer-shopâ€”he is a coal-merchant and a potato dealer, and several other thingsâ€”his yard is about two hundred yards from the lineâ€”he is building the cot
tages about thirty yards from the line.
ROBERT GORHAM M'INTYRE (police-sertjeant, V 27). I went to the prisoner's premises after he was remanded, and found twenty-eight pieces of timberâ€”some of them are here.
WILLIAM STEPHENS . I am accountant to Mr. Brassey. I keep an account of what he buys and sellsâ€”he has never disposed of these.

Cross-examined. Q. Are the accounts here? A. Noâ€”I know from the accounts and from the custom of the office if wood had been sold it would be in the accountâ€”if these had been sold I should have had directions from Mr. Brassey to sell themâ€”it is his custom to transact all matters of sale throgh meâ€”if he had sold these I should have known itâ€”he has never sold Wood within my knowledge.
NOT GUILTY .

165.
GEORGE LITTLEWOOD was again indicted
for stealing 4 pieces of plank, value 1s. 4d., and one iron bolt, 1d., the goods of
Thomas Brassey; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

166.
THOMAS WILLIAM KENWARD
, stealing, whilst employed in the
Post-office, a letter containing I sovereign and 1 sixpence, the moneys of the
Postmaster-General; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.

167.
CHARLES MOORE
, stealing 2 sixpences and 5 halfpence; the, moneys of
Thomas Peek: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Six Months. (
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

168.
WILLIAM GOODMAN and
MARY NORMAN were indicted for
unlawfuly uttering counterfeit coin.

MARY ANN GEAXLEY . I live at the Blue Boar, Stratford. About half-past five o'clock, on 21st Oct., the two prisoners called for a pint of beerâ€”Goodman paid me a shillingâ€”I gave him 10d. changeâ€”I recollected him be
fore, and kept the shilling in my handâ€”I showed it to my master, and from what he said I sent it back to Goodman by the pot-boyâ€”he brought me; back a 4d. piece, and I gave 2d. changeâ€”the prisoners staid some time, and then left with the shillingâ€”I and my master both looked at it, and said it was bad.

GEORGE TILLEY . I am pot-boy at the Blue Boar. Miss Geaxley gave me a shillingâ€”I took it to the prisoners and told them it was badâ€”Norman gave me a 4d.-pieceâ€”I took it to Miss Geaxley, and she gave me 2d. changeâ€”when the prisoners left, my master told me to watch themâ€”I. watched them about an hour walking together, and told the policeman to have an eye to themâ€”I lost sight of themâ€”this is the shilling I took back to the. prisoners.
Goodman. Q. How do you know it is the same? A. Because Miss Geaxley put it in the crack and bent itâ€”I did cot mark it.

JOSEPH COWLAND . I am a victualler, of Stratford. On 21st Oct. Good
man came to my house for a glass of ginâ€”he gave me a bad shillingâ€”I bent itâ€”from what I had heard I went to the door, and saw Norman outsideâ€”Goodman went out, and they joinedâ€”a policeman came, and I gave it to him I had kept it all the time in my hand.
Goodman. Q. When you said it was bad what did I say? A. You gave me a good one and left, without taking the change.

MARGARET SAIL . My husband is a butcher, at Stratford. On 21st Oct. Norman came to my house for some meatâ€”she gave me a shillingâ€”I said it was bad, bent it, and returned it to herâ€”she gave me another, and went away.
JOSHEPH BENTON (policeman, K 301). I watched the prisoners, and saw Goodman with a shilling in his hand, rubbing it upâ€”he went into the

George and had half-a-pint of beerâ€”I went and stood alongside of himâ€”he laid down this shilling, which was bentâ€”the bar-maid gave him change, and put it in the tillâ€”I directed her attention to it, and a bad shilling was taken out, which was bentâ€”this is itâ€”I then went to Mr. Cowland'sâ€”he gave me this bad shillingâ€”I then went after the prisoners, and took Goodmanâ€”he put something in his mouth and swallowed itâ€”I got hold of his throat, but I could not stop himâ€”I found on him 1 1/2 d., and on Norman 11 1/2 d. in copper, and 2s.

WILLIAM POTTON (police-sergeant, K 27). I took Normanâ€”I saw Good
man put something in his mouthâ€”I caught him by the collar and said he was swallowing somethingâ€”after the charge was read to him at the station he said, "I gave a shilling to the landlord in one public-house, and I gave him a good one and I ran away because I would not be locked up"â€”I said, "Then you left the good shilling?"â€”he said, "Yes."
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am inspector of coin to the Mintâ€”these shillings are both counterfeit and cast in the same mould.
Goodman's Defence. The shillings I took while I was out selling mats; this woman knows nothing of it; I met her and asked her to have a drop of something to drink.
Norman's Defence. The two shillings that I had in my hand I gave to the policeman; one of these must have been the one the woman says was bad.

GOODMANâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 26.

NORMANâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined One Year .

169.
HENRY LAMBERT
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Stent, and stealing 6 tobacco-pipes, value 12s.; his property.

WILLIAM STENT . I am a tobacconist, of High-street, Stratfordâ€”it is my dwelling-houseâ€”I went to bed about eleven o'clock on 21st Nov.â€”the house was then fastâ€”about two in the morning the shutters were down and a pane of glass broken, and half a dozen gutta percha pipes had been taken.

JAMES CLARK (policeman, K 199). I was on duty at Stratfordâ€”I saw the prisoner about one o'clock with two prostitutes and a bakerâ€”he asked me to give him a light, which I didâ€”he went on towards Stratfordâ€”at a quarter past two he came on my beat againâ€”I watched him to Mr. Stent's shop, saw him take the bar off the shutters, and take the shutters downâ€”he broke a pane of glass and took some pipesâ€”I went as near to him as I could, but he got awayâ€”I found these pipes just inside the window.
BENJAMIN FOWLE (policeman, K 93). I took the prisoner.
Prisoner. I asked the officer for a light, and then I went home and went to bed.

GUILTY . Aged 20.â€”
Confined One Year .

170.
JOHN SPENCE,
JAMES HARTLEY,
ROBERT SMITH , and
THOMAS WADE
, stealing 6 lbs. weight of bread, value 1s. 10d.; the goods of
William Vooght, to which

SPENCE pleaded
GUILTY .â€”Aged 22.

HARTLEY pleaded
GUILTY
â€”Aged 24.

SMITH pleaded
GUILTY .â€”Aged 19.
ELIZABETH ALLEN . On 26th Oct. the four prisoners rushed into Mr. William Vooglu's shop at West Ham, and stole three half quarterns of bread.
Wade. Another was with us? A. Yes.
WILLIAM STONEY (policeman). I followed the prisoners and took them.

WADEâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 18.â€”
Confined Four Days and
Whipped.

171.
ELLEN DALBY
, stealing 1 pair of shoes and 2 napkins, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
James Scutt. her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Judgment Respited.

172.
BENJAMIN TATE
, stealing 2 blankets 1 apron, and 6 razors value 33s.; the goods of
William Nicholls, his master.

WILLIAM NICHOLLS . I am a hair-dresser, and live at 23, Greenwich-marketâ€”the prisoner was in my service for more than a month. On Sunday, 22nd Oct., I went into Devonshire, leaving him in charge of my placeâ€”I returned on the Thursday week followingâ€”I found the place shut upâ€”I forced an entrance, and missed a pair of blankets, an apron, and some razorsâ€”I found that the prisoner had paid over to my sister the proceeds of the first week's takings, but no moreâ€”his wages were 16s. a weekâ€”I allowed him to deduct his wages from the takingsâ€”he had the blankets in use.

JOHN MEWS . I live in Greenwich-market. On 31st Oct. I gave the pri
soner two razors to setâ€”these produced are them.

JAMES PAGET . I am a hair-dresser. On 3rd Nov. the prisoner brought me three razors to sellâ€”he said I should have them at my own priceâ€”I gave him a shilling and a pot of porter for themâ€”they are worth 1s. or 18d. eachâ€”I also bought this apron of him for 6d. next morning.

WILLIAM NICHOLLS
re-examined. I do not know either of the razorsâ€”the apron corresponds with one I had, but there is no mark on it.

HENRY SNATCHELL . I live next door to Mr. Nicholls. On 2nd Nov. I saw the prisoner pass our shop with a large bundle under his arm, about the size of half-a-bushelâ€”it "was as large as two blankets would be or a man's clothesâ€”I cannot tell what it wasâ€”the outside was something white.

EDWARD SAMNS (policeman, B 182). I took the prisoner on 7th Nov. in North-street, Chelseaâ€”I asked him if he had not been working at the other side of Londonâ€”he said he hadâ€”I asked whereâ€”he said at Greenwichâ€”I told him I must take him into custodyâ€”he went to the station, and there the inspector told him the-chargeâ€”he said he owned to making off with the money, but as to the razors or blankets he knew nothing about themâ€”I made inquiries and got the razors and apron from Paget.

Prisoner's Defence. I had a little too much to drink; I was very ill; I left the shop and came up to London; I had Mews's razors in my pocket as he gave them to me, and being tipsy I certainly did sell them to Page for 1s. as for the other things I know nothing about them.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Lord Chief Justice Denman.

173.
WILLIAM HILL was indicted
for feloniously cutting and wounding
Sarah Hill on the hand, with intent to do her grievous bodily harm.
MESSRS. PAYNE and MLTCALFE conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH HILL . I am the prisoner's wife. On 18th Nov., about a quarter to eleven o'clock at night, I was standing at my mother's shop door talking to Mr. Hammond, who was outsideâ€”the prisoner came to the doorâ€”he was in the habit of coming and using very improper language towards me before the customersâ€”he passed me, went ir, and passed out again, making use of a very improper expression, and wint up the streetâ€”about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after, I was still at the door and looked up, and all of a sudden I saw him close to me with a knife in his hand, what they call a Spa
nish knifeâ€”this is it (produced)â€”he instantly stabbed me in the left sideâ€”

it cut a cape, which I have on, and caught against a stay-bone over my breastâ€”it did not enter my personâ€”he then took the knife and cut along my waistâ€”it only cut the outside of my dressâ€”I fell backwards on the floor with the first blow, and was on the floor when I received the secondâ€”one of the blows cut a small piece from my finger, and cut my handâ€”I think it was in warding off the first blowâ€”I could not scream or speakâ€”my mother was standing in the shop, but it was done so momentarily that she did not see he was in the shopâ€”a lad outside sung out "He has got a knife, be has got a knife"â€”I was struggling to keep him from meâ€”Mr. Hammond came and caught him by the back of the neck and held him till the policeman cameâ€”we have been married eleven yearsâ€”he has frequently threatened meâ€”about a month before this he came in and I said something to him about work, and he said, "Do not bother me; if you do I will cut your b----y heart out."

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You were not on good terms? A. Noâ€”we have lived separately through his selling the shop for 25l.â€”he said he had no home to take me to, and if my mother did not like to take me in he would bundle me out, and my goodsâ€”we separated simply because we had no place to go toâ€”not through quarrellingâ€”he has been in the habit for the last six months of coming to see me at my mother'sâ€”Mr. Hammond is a neighbourâ€”he had been standing there about twenty minutesâ€”I was talking to him, and my mother was servingâ€”my husband looked very evil at me when he passed me firstâ€”there were no words at all between us, before he struck meâ€”he had been drinking, but was not tipsyâ€”he knew what he was aboutâ€”he is a plumber by tradeâ€”this is not a knife he uses in his businessâ€”I never saw such a knife used by a plumberâ€”I never saw it till that nightâ€”he does not work at my mother'sâ€”there had been no words between me and my husband about Mr. Hammondâ€”my husband had repeatedly called me the worst names he could call any oneâ€”he did not at the time say, "That was in consequence of being rather too intimate with that man"â€”he would come to me and say, "Will you let me come back again," and I said noâ€”I was willing to work, but not to be an incumbrance on my mother, if he had ever such a humble home I would come, but I would not allow him to come to that houseâ€”my mother had sworn her life against him two years ago.
MR. PAYNE.Q. Had you given him any provocation at all at this time? A. No.

WILLIAM HAMMOND . I keep a public-house, in Powis-street, Woolwich. I was at Mrs. Hill's mother's shop on this night, about half-past ten o'clock, standing at the door talking to Mrs. Hillâ€”the prisoner came up, and used some expression towards her and leftâ€”about ten minutes after he returned witli a knife, and made three or four stabs at Mrs. Hillâ€”I was not going to in
terfere till some one said, "He has a knife," and Mrs. Hill said she was being stabbedâ€”I immediately seized him, the policeman came, and the knife was taken from himâ€”it was then open.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had you been there? A. About a quar
ter of an hourâ€”I was not there the morning beforeâ€”I might have been two mornings before thatâ€”I sometimes go once a week, and sometimes not once a monthâ€”I was smoking a cigar at the timeâ€”I was outside, just at the door, and Mrs. Hill was insideâ€”she did not say anything when her husband came up on either occasion till she cried out she was being stabbedâ€”she did not ask him anything about money or goodsâ€”I did not interfere at firstâ€”I thought that it was no matter that called for interference on my part, not knowing he had a knifeâ€”I have known Mrs. Hill about two years as living in the neighbourhoodâ€”I should say the prisoner had been drinkingâ€”he was not drunk

JAMES GOSLING ,. On 18th Nov. I was at the door of my father's shop, three doors from Hill'sâ€”I saw the prisoner come up with a knife in his hand, and saw him strike Mrs. Hill with it in the chestâ€”I instantly went to the shop, and saw Mr. Hammond trying to come outâ€”I said the prisoner had got a knife, and Mr. Hammond then seized him by the throatâ€”there were two blows givenâ€”Mrs. Hill was knocked down, and was on the floor when the second blow was struck.

EDWARD THOMAS HOPPER (policeman, R 316). I was standing near the shop, and saw the prisoner strike Mrs. Hillâ€”I heard her call out, "I am stab
bed"â€”I immediately crossed to her, and found Mr. Hammond had got hold of himâ€”there was a knife in his hand with blood on the bladeâ€”as we were going to the station, I said to the prisoner, "You are a foolish man"â€”he said, "I (do not care for I meant to stab the b----y b----h"â€”he had been drinking, but was not drunkâ€”he knew what he was aboutâ€”I observed a cut in the breast of Mrs. Hill's dress, and another a little lowerâ€”the point of the knife was broken.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 32.â€”
Confined Two Years
, and to
enter into his own recognizance in 100l., and find two sureties of 20l. each to keep the peace for two years more .
Before Edward Bullock, Esq.

174.
WILLIAM BRADLEY
, unlawfully obtaining 4 shillings and 6 pence, the moneys of
Thomas Sallis, by false pretences; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 45.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

175.
EDMUND ROACH,
JAMES M'CARTHY,
JOHN REGAN , and
THOMAS HYLAND were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which

M'CARTHY pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 42.â€”
Confined Two Years.

ELIZA PERRIAM . My husband keeps a beer-house at Lewisbam. On the 13th Oct. M'Carthy came, called for half-a-pint of beer, and paid me with a bad shillingâ€”I bit it double, and told him it was badâ€”he said what was he to do, he had no more moneyâ€”he took up the shilling, took it away, and went towards Leeâ€”I saw the other three prisoners on the other side of the roadâ€”they went in the same direction.

JANE BEALE . My master keeps the Highlander beer-shop, at Lee. On 13th Oct. Roach came for half-a-pint of beerâ€”he gave me a bad shillingâ€”I bent it, took it up stairs, and gave it my masterâ€”he came down and said to Roach, "Do you know what you gave my girl?"â€”he said, "No"â€”he told him it was a bad shilling, and he left the house.

GEORGE BOOKER . I am the master of Beale. On 13th Oct. she came and gave me a bad shillingâ€”I came down and asked Roach if he knew what he gave my girlâ€”he saifi, "No"â€”I said it was a bad shilling, and asked if he had got anything more about himâ€”he said, "No, so help him God, he had not"â€”I searched him, and found nothing on himâ€”I kept the shilling, and followed himâ€”he joined the other threeâ€”I followed them and called at the police-stationâ€”I saw Roach go into Mr. Morlcy's shopâ€”the other three waited outside till he came outâ€”I looked round for the officers to come onâ€”I went into the shop and received a shilling from Susannah Morleyâ€”I marked it and gave it to the officer.

SUSANNAH MORLEY . My father is a baker, at Lee. On 13th Oct. Roach came and had 1d. worth of breadâ€”he gave me a shillingâ€”I put it into the drawerâ€”there were two sixpences and a 4d.-piece there, but no shillingâ€”I took it out in about two minutes, and gave it to Mr. Booker.

CHARLES WATSON . I am a baker, of Lee. About half-past eleven in the morning of 13th Oct. M'Carthy came for a penny loafâ€”he gave me a shillingâ€”I said I thought it was badâ€”he said he had no more moneyâ€”I ultimately gave him change, and he went awayâ€”I put it into my pocket, where I had no silverâ€”the officer came in about an hourâ€”I gave him the same shilling.

GEORGE SOLE (police-sergeant, R 41). I was at the station when Mr. Booker cameâ€”I and Hunt went out, saw three of the prisoners together and one a little behindâ€”just as they came opposite me, Hyland gave something to M'Carthyâ€”I jumped over the hedge, and found in M'Carthy's band a counterfeit shillingâ€”I caught Regan, and found on him a penny loaf, two books, and some halfpenceâ€”I received these two shillings from Mr. Booker.

ROBERT HART (policeman, R 79), I took Hyland, and found on him 101 bad shillings, two 4d.-pieces, a sixpence, and 7d. in coppersâ€”1l. 1s. was in one pocket, and 1l. in each of these four paper packages, and a small package of dirtâ€”4l.-worth of these shillings are very bright, they had never been out of the packagesâ€”rubbing them with dirt would make them appear dull.
JAMES EAGLES (policeman, R 233). I took Roachâ€”I found on him 11d. in good moneyâ€”I received this shilling from Watson.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These four separate shillings are counterfeit, of the date of 1844 and 1845â€”here are forty counterfeits, of the same mould as those of 1844.
Hyland's Defence. I picked them up that morning in the road; I met these men, and gave them part of it.

ROACHâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 32.

REGANâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 61.

HYLANDâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 50.

176.
JANE ORD
, stealing 2 pillows and other articles, value 9s.; the goods of
Hannah Spencer; having been before convicted: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 48.â€”
Confined Four Months.

176.
JOHN LOOMES
, stealing 1 duplicate, value 1d.; and 1 watch, value 3l.; the goods of
James Christmas: to which he pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Six Months.

178.
JAMES MILLER
, stealing 634 lbs. weight of lead, value 4l.; the goods of Joseph Batteibee, fixed to a building: also, 294 lbs. weight of lead, value 2l.; the goods of
Joseph Batterbee, fixed to a building.
(No evidence was offered.)
NOT GUILTY .

179.
JANE GOLD,
stealing 1 shawl, value 6s. 9d.; the goods of
John Stone: to which she pleaded
GUILTY .

Aged 22.â€”
Confined Three Months.

180.
JOHN WILSON
, stealing 60 yards of calico, value 12s.; the goods of
John Stone; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 62.â€”
Confined Three Months.

181.
GEORGE BEARD
, stealing 1 pair of slippers and 12ozs. of leather value 4d.; the goods of
Thomas Antony Hand, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.â€”
Confined Three Months.

182.
CHARLES LIPSHAM and
THOMAS WORCESTER were in
deicted for
unlawfully conspiring to obtain money from
William Harris, by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .

183.
JAMES BISHOP
, stealing 2 boxes and 40 cigars value 12s.; the goods of
Benjamin Harrisson; having been before convicted.

BENJAMIN HARRISSOV I am a shell-fish dealer, and sell cigars and tobacco, at Wellington-terracc, Waterloo-road. These cigars were three feet inside, the window, which is openâ€”a policeman spoke to me, and I missed two boxes of cigars, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, on 3rd Nov.â€”this is one box (produced)â€”it lias my private mark on it.

SAMIEL HARRISS (police-sergeant, L 6). I was on duty, and saw two men going from I Harrisson's windowâ€”I told him, and then went after them to Waterloo-bridge, and saw the prisoner coming up the steps, with his hands behind himâ€”I asked what he had gotâ€”he said, "Nothing"â€”I found this, box of cigars in his left handâ€”he said he picked them up in the roadâ€”it was about twenty yards from the shop; and two or three minutes after I had spoken to Harrisson.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me near the shop? A. I believe you to be one of the two I saw thereâ€”your back was towards meâ€”you could have gone down the right hand steps and up the left.
Prisoners Defence. I found the box on the steps.
WIILIAM POTTN . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction at this Courtâ€”I was present at his trialâ€”he is the manâ€”(readâ€”Convicted June, 1845, and confined eight months).

GUILTY . ** Aged 20.â€”
Confined One Year .

184.
JOHN COLLINS,
DANIEL COLLINS,
JOHN CONOLLY , and
JOHN RAGAN
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d., and 18 sovereigns, the property of
James Little, from his person; Conolly having been before convicted.

JAMES LITTLE . I am a seaman, and was paid off at Sheerness on 7th Nov.â€”I received 27l. for about three years' serviceâ€”I arrived at London-bridge about two o'clock, on 8th Nov., by steam-boatâ€”I then had 19l. in gold and some silver in my pocket, in a green silk purse, with two bright steel rings on itâ€”Vallance rowed me over to Tooley-street, and two of my shipmatesâ€”he took my bag to the Roacbuck, and went with them to the railwayâ€”he returned, and we had a pot of beer and half a pint of rum between us in the tap-roomâ€”I left my bag of clothes at the bar, and left the Roebuckâ€”I had changed a sovereign at the bar to pay for the drink I had, and then had eighteen sovereigns leftâ€”I put the purse in my breast, between my two Ciurnsey shirtsâ€”I had engaged a bed at the Roebuckâ€”I was not there more than an nour and a halfâ€”I went out with Vallanccâ€”he wished me to go home with himâ€”we went to the Horse and Cart public-house, in Tooley-street, and had some more beerâ€”I walked with him to Parish-streetâ€”I parted with him in the street, and turned to go back to the Roebuckâ€”I went into a shop in Tooley street and boughtt some bread and meatâ€”John Collins and Conolly came upâ€”Conully said, "Old follow, you shall not be lost; my mother keeps

beds, and you shall come along with me, and shall have a good bed, and shall not bo lost; you shall not be astray"â€”I went with them into a public-house in Tooley-streetâ€”we had the bread and meat, and I gave them plenty of beer, and some gin afterwardsâ€”I was going awayâ€”Conolly said, "You shall not go yet, I (or we) will stand a pot of beer"â€”a pot of half-and-half was called torâ€”it was placed on the tableâ€”one of them said to me, "Get up, old fellow, and drink hearty before we go"â€”I got up and took a hearty draught from the potâ€”neither of them drank anyâ€”in a little time Conolly said, "Come, drink, and let us go"â€”I took hold of the pot a second time, and saw that the beer was not like what I had seen, it was somewhat like milk, but I took another draughtâ€”I called a cab, and we all drove home to go to Conolly's mother'sâ€”I felt my money safe in the cabâ€”I was driven to any place they thought properâ€”we got out of the cab, and I began to feel myself rather deadâ€”we stopped at the Anti-Gallican, went in, and had some more beerâ€”they helped me out of the cab, because I felt myself too far goneâ€”one of them sat on each side of me; and while we sat there drinking some beer, it overcame me altogether, and I went to sleepâ€”there was no one but those two drinking with meâ€”we had nothing but beer thereâ€”en the following morning I found myself lying in a nasty, dirty, wet alley, my clothes unbuttoned, my pockets turned, my purse and everything goneâ€”I had some loose money, as well as that in the purse, and a tobacco-box.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. What time did you get to the Roe
buck? A. Between four and five o'clock in the afternoonâ€”it was not much after six when I leftâ€”I was not very drunk while I was in the prisoners' companyâ€”I did not see the beer poured out which they told me to drink hearty ofâ€”it was brought in by some servant.

JURY. Q. Did either of the prisoners handle the pot before you drank? A. Noâ€”I do not know whether they had any opportunity of putting any
thing inâ€”I did not see either of them go out to order it.

NORAH ARNETT . I am an unfortunate girl, and live in Unicorn-square, Southwark. On the night of 8th Nov., about eight o'clock, I went into the Anti-Gallican, and saw the four prisoners, and several othersâ€”I saw-Little and Campbell sitting, drinking, in the same box with the prisonersâ€”they had a pot of half-and-half when I went inâ€”it was fullâ€”they had emptied oneâ€”they called for anotherâ€”Little pulled out a purse from inside his breast, and paid 6d.â€”he was a little the worse for liquorâ€”he retained the purse in his handâ€”I did not see him return it to his breastâ€”he took out some half-pence, and paid for the half-and-halfâ€”the prisoners all went out in a very few minutesâ€”I knew them all, using the houseâ€”Campbell and Little remained, finishing the half-and-halfâ€”there were some more young men in the place, but not in the same boxâ€”Little called some of them to have some of the half-and-halfâ€”he was then the worse for liquor.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not see the purse leave his hand? A. Noâ€”lie-. at with his side to meâ€”I am not mistaken in Conolly; I knew them all.

THOMAS VALLANCE . I am a waterman, of Pear-street, Horsleydown. On Sth Nov. I rowed Little from a steamboat at London-bridge over to the Tooley-street sideâ€”he inquired of me for a lodgingâ€”it was then a quarter-past two o'clockâ€”he had two petty-officers belonging to a man-of-war with himâ€”I took him to the railwayâ€”he waited at the foot of London-bridge, and I took him to the Roebuckâ€”he paid me for my job, and stood a drop of something to drinkâ€”I offered to take him home to teaâ€”we went down Today-street, to Belt's houie, and Lad two pots of half-and-half; then we

went to the King of Prussia; we had nothing thereâ€”lie declined to go home with me to tea, but said he would go back to where Ins bag wasâ€”I was to be there in the morning to take him to the railwayâ€”next morning I found him King at the Rucbuek, in a basket of cinders, almost deadâ€”he never awoke till lour o'clock in the after noonâ€”I could not beat any senses into himâ€”he had only got me, that was in his right pocket.

ARCHIBALD CAMPBELL . I lodged at earns lodging-house, Vine-yard, Tooley-street. On 8th Nov., between six and stun o'clock, I saw Daniel Collinsâ€”he came our to me of Events miss, and and, Come and have a drop of beer"â€”I said I did not mindâ€”we went to the Anti-Gallican, and saw Little, in a box in the tap-room, with Conolly on one side, and John Collins on the otherâ€”in a few minutes Daniel Collins went over to the box where Little was, sat down, and joined the restâ€”in a few minutes Ragan came inâ€”he stood a listle at the side of the box, about ten minutes, and then sat down in the same box with themâ€”Daniel Collins asked some of the parties in the room to drinkâ€”he did not ask meâ€”I did not drink with them, only when I went inâ€”I saw Arnett come inâ€”Little was every much intoxicatedâ€”Daniel Collins lifted a pot off the table where he satâ€”John Collins put his hand into Little's left-hand pocket, took it out, put it into his breast, pulled it out shut, and slid he had got the skinâ€”Ragan then said, "Come and have a drop of gin, boys"â€”the four prisoners walked out, and a man whom they call Conolly Collinsâ€”I was not in it, I only saw it doneâ€”I remained in the, tap-room a few minutesâ€”Little got up, felt himself all over, said, "My money is all gone!" and rapped on the tableâ€”I went out, and saw no moreâ€”on the Friday I saw Daniel Collins with a new jacket and a new pair of shoesâ€”I did not speak to him, he was not near me; but in the evening I asked him where he got themâ€”he said he pot a sovereign from his father, and vent and bought themâ€”I said, "You got something out of that lot that was one last night, I suppose?"â€”he denied itâ€”I sau him receive two half-crowns rom a woman that night.

Cross-examined. Q. What time did you go into the Anti-Gallican? A. Between six and seven o'clockâ€”I stayed about half an hourâ€”I afterwards went home and went to bedâ€”I came from home to the Anti-Gallicanâ€”I had only drunk one dropâ€”a pot was handed to me by a party in the room when I went inâ€”I am sure I did not go into this box at allâ€”I saw Arnett standing at the tableâ€”that table was opposite to meâ€”it goes right across the. room from the doorâ€”it was the same tableâ€”I sat opposite, and saw all about itâ€”she was a considerable distance from them all the time, and I was further off than she wasâ€”I saw Little pull some money out of his left pocket to pay for liquorâ€”I did not see him pull his purse outâ€”that might be half an hour before the prisoners leftâ€”it was before I saw John Collins put his hand into his pocketâ€”they left about a minute or so after thatâ€”Arnett did not go with them, she remained in the room when they went outâ€”there was no one left in the room but me and Littleâ€”Arnett went out after themâ€”I am a sailorâ€”it is three months since I was at seaâ€”I live close by the Anti-Gallican.

Conolly A man snatched 3d. out of your hand for a lark; you said, "If you do not give me that 3d. it will be the worse for you," and fetched in a policeman and had me taken. Witness. Nobody took any money from meâ€”I gave information about this job, and of course the policeman took youâ€”I did not offer to put 2d. to your 2d. for a pot of porterâ€”I was never in your company that eveningâ€”Arnett'sâ€”husband had nothing to do with me that evening.

ELIZABATH BUCKMASTER . My husband keeps the Roebuck in Tooley-streetâ€”I remember Little and Vallance comingâ€”they had drinkâ€”Little paid for it out of a green purse, rather bulky, which he kept in his breast pocketâ€”he changed a sovereignâ€”I did not see him leave.

JOSHUA GOLDEN (policrnian, M 87). On 8th Nov., between five and six o'clock, I was on duty in Tooley-street, and saw Vallance part with Little at the corner of Parish-streetâ€”Little went into a cheesemonger's shopâ€”John Collins was standing opposite watching himâ€”he saw me watching him, joined another man, and both went into the Anti-Gallicanâ€”I spoke to two of my sergeants, and while doing so saw Little leave the shopâ€”I heard of the rob
bery that eveningâ€”on the Friday night Campbell gave me information, and I took John Collins.

Cross-examined. Q. In what state was Little?A. He had been drinking but was quite conscious of what he was doingâ€”he walked quite erectâ€”he bought some meat in the shopâ€”the man who Collins joined was Ringrose, who is not in custodyâ€”other people were in the street, but I saw no one standing looking but Collins.

HENRY HUNT (policeman, M 82). On 12th Nov. I took Daniel Collins, in Tooley-streetâ€”I told him it was for being concerned with his brother, who was remandedâ€”he said what his brother had done was nothing to do with himâ€”in going to the station I said, "You have been buying some new clothes"â€”he said, "What new clothes?â€”I said, "A jacket and a pair of boots"â€”he said, "This jacket I have had three months, and can't a fellow afford to buy a pair of boots out of 1l. a week?"â€”it was not a new jacket, but different to what I had been in the habit of seeing him inâ€”he asked where his brother wasâ€”I said I believed he was at Horsemonger-laneâ€”he said, "I have not seen him this fortnight."

CATHERINE HOLT . I am the wife of William Holt, who keeps the Colonel Wardell, in Tooley-street. On 8th Nov., about twelve o'clock, as we were clearing the house Conolly came and got change of a sovereign from meâ€”about twenty minutes before that, I found a drunken sailor by my door quite insensibleâ€”two constables had himâ€”I took him into my house and gave him such lodgings as I couldâ€”it turned out to be Littleâ€”a policeman searched himâ€”I saw nothing found but a few papers and a piece of whipcordâ€”he went asleep on the formâ€”he went away in the morning before I was downâ€”he was so drunk I could make nothing of him.

JOHN WEBB . I keep a lodging-house in Pump-court, Vine-yard, opposite the Anti-Gallican. On 8th Nov., between ten and eleven o'clock at night, a sailor was brought to my place by John and Daniel Collinsâ€”his head was downâ€”I could not see his featuresâ€”he appeared very drunk, and I refused to take him inâ€”next day I went with Daniel Collins to buy a pair of shoesâ€”he paid 6s. 6d. for them, and bought a jacket for 4s. 6d.
John Collins. Q. Did not Campbell help to take the man away?A. Yes, he came with them and went away with themâ€”I said that before the Magistrate.

ARCHIBALD CAMPBELL
re-examined. I only went outside the door the same as Webb did himselfâ€”I was there when the party came inâ€”I live there.
MR. METCALFE to JOHN WEBB. Q. Did Campbell live in the house? A. Occasionallyâ€”Conolly lodged thereâ€”Campbell was away at the Anti-Gallican with them and came back with them.

GEORGE WALKER JUDGE (Thames police-inspector). I produce a certifi
cate
of Conolly's convictionâ€”I was present at his trialâ€”he is the person mentioned in itâ€”(readâ€”Convicted Nov. 1843, and confined one month).

JOHN COLLINSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 22.

DANIEL COLLINSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 19.

CONOLLYâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 23.

RAGANâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 23.

185.
JOHN NEAL was indicted
for stealing 3 shillings; the moneys of
Charles James, his master.

CHARLES JAMES . I am a cheesemonger, of Lower Marsh, Lambethâ€”the prisoner was my servant eleven daysâ€”I received information, and put four marked shillings of George III. into the till, and marked two of Victoria, 1844, and gave them to Hill to spend at my shop, and one of Victoria, 1846, to Mary Ann Mackie to get 1s. worth of halfpence at my shopâ€”I marked them in their presence, made a hole through the wall, and placed a constable behind, in view of the tillâ€”he told me somethingâ€”the prisoner was standing at the doorwayâ€”it was his duty to mind the outside when the foreman was having bis mealsâ€”I found three marked shillings in the till, and sixpence not markedâ€”I told the prisoner a gentleman in the parlour wanted to see himâ€”he went inâ€”Ro
mainc said, "You have been robbing your master's till"â€”he said, "No"â€”Ro
manic asked if he had any money about himâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”he asked where he got itâ€”he said his mother sent it him from the countryâ€”Romaine said, "Where do you keep your money?"â€”he said, "In my pocket"â€”Romaine said, "Have you any more?"â€”he said, "No"â€”Romaine said, "He has two pieces of silver in his left boot"â€”he turned 2s. out of one boot, and a marked; shilling out of the other bootâ€”I found another marked shilling with other silver in his pocketâ€”these are the three shillings I marked (produced.)

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Have you any partner? A. Noâ€”. I was only away fifteen or sixteen minutesâ€”I could not see into the shop when I came back I found three marked shillings in the till, and a bent 6d. not markedâ€”there was one marked shilling besideâ€”he was in the shop alone except the customersâ€”Romaine asked him if he had any more about himâ€”I swear thatâ€”he said, "Have you not got some money in your boot?"â€”the prisoner said, "No"â€”I believe I said that before the Magistrateâ€”I did. not find a half-sovereign in the till.
CHARLES HILL . I am a furniture-broker. On 22nd Sept. Mr. James gave me a Victoria shillingâ€”I paid it to the prisoner forâ€”1/2lb of butter.
Cross-examined. Q. What did it come to? A. Sixpenceâ€”he gave me sixpenny-worth of copper out of the till.

MARY ANN MACKIE . I am the wife of William Mackie, of William-street, Lower-marsh. I took a Victoria shilling to Mr. James's shop by his direc
tion, gave it to the prisoner, and got copper for it.

WILLIAM ROMAINE (policeman, L 38). I watched the prisoner through a hole in the wainscot, and saw him take his hand from the till twice, and put it to his bootâ€”I found 18d. in one boot, and three marked George III. shillings in the other, and 8s. in his waistcoat-pocket, one a Victoriaâ€”he said it was money he had had sent up from the country from his parents.

Cross-examined. Q. How did you conceal yourself? A. I went through the next houseâ€”I was in private clothesâ€”I asked the prisoner if he had any money about himâ€”he said yes, some of it was sent up from his parents in the countryâ€”I accused him of robbing his master's tillâ€”he denied itâ€”I told Mr. James, to convince him, I would show him where he had placed itâ€”he

sat down on a chairâ€”I took off his left boot, and found Isc?.â€”I searched him, and found the restâ€”there might have been half-a-dozen customers come inâ€”I could not hear what they said. (The prisoner received a good character.)
