GUILTY . Aged 25.â€”Recommended to mercyâ€”
Confined three Months.

186.
CATHERINE BOX
, stealing 1 pair of clogs, 1 miniature, and other articles, value 7s. 4d.; the goods of
William Creer, her master.

HENRIETTA CREER . I am the wife of William Creerâ€”the prisoner was our servantâ€”shortly after she came I missed a pair of clogsâ€”she was set to find themâ€”she said she could notâ€”she was to leave on Saturday, and I insisted on her box being searchedâ€”I found in it a pair of clogs, a pocket, two books, a picture, an apron, and a curtain, my husbands propertyâ€”at first she said she bought the clogs, but afterwards acknowledged they were mine, and she did not know how they had got into her box, unless it was with the clean clothes.

WILLIAM GUEST (policeman, L 62). I was present at the searchâ€”Mrs. Creer took the clogs out of the prisoner's box, and charged her with taking themâ€”she said, "No, they are mine; I bought them"â€”Mrs. Creer said, "You know perfectly well they are mine"â€”she said, "Yes, I do not know how they got in, without they got in with the clean linen"â€”Mrs. Creer took a pocket outâ€”she said she did not know how that came thereâ€”she opened the box herself, in my presenceâ€”it was lockedâ€”I searched two boxes, some things were found in each.
Prisoner's Defence. The books were lent me to read.
MARY SYMMONDS . I washed for Mr. Creerâ€”this pocket and curtain are hers.

GUILTY .â€”Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined Two Months.

187.
GEORGE LAWRENCE and
CAROLINE LAWRENCE,
stealing 32lbs. weight of steel, and other articles, value 15s.; the goods of
Thomas Charles Matt and another, the masters of
George Lawrence: and
GEORGE COOK
, for feloniously receiving the same; to which

GEORGE LAWRENCE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 46.â€”
Confined Two Months.

GEORGE WILD (policeman, M 94). On 27th Nov., about seven o'clock at night, I was on duty in Suffolk-street, Boroughâ€”the female prisoner passed me with this bar of steelâ€”her daughter was carrying this other barâ€”they each looked for some oneâ€”I followed themâ€”just before they got to South
wark-bridge-road, I saw Cook walking a little in advance of themâ€”he turned round, they walked up to him, and each gave him a bar of steelâ€”I went up, and said, "What does this mean?"â€”Cook said, "This steel this woman gave me to make her husband some tools; I have made tools before for her"â€”I called the woman back, and said, "Where did you get this?"â€”she said, "I brought it from my husband, he sent it to Cook to make tools, as he has done before"â€”I said, "What is your husband's name?"â€”she said, "Jones, he is a smith"â€”I said, "Where does he live?"â€”she said, "No. 5, Queen's-gardens, Crosbierow"â€”I put the steel into a shop, and took all three to the stationâ€”I went to 5, Queen's-gardens next morning, searched Lawrence's house, and found these pieces of iron (produced)â€”I searched Cook's premises, and found some similar bars of steel, and 2cwt. or 3cwt. of tools made of steelâ€”he is a tool-makerâ€”they are stamped, and some of them have "George Cook" on them.
Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Was the steel lying on the forge? A. Behind it, and the tools were in a box, apparently ready for useâ€”Mr.
Jnnes rents the shop and one forgeâ€”he has been there about three monthsâ€”Cook bears an honest tractor.

COURT. Q. Where was it the womin handad the steel A. Two hun
dred yards after they had passed the turning which leads to Cook's forgeâ€”they were going in the direction of his mother's houseâ€”he might have come from there to his forge, but I saw him giong in the same direction as them, in. front of themâ€”I did not see him come from the forge,â€”Cook made some objection to the woman giving the name of Jones, but I could not hear itâ€”I heard Cook say, "What can I say for you?"

THOMAS CHARLES MATT . I am a coach-builder, of Saul-street, Borough, and have one partner. I received a communication, made a search, and missed more than 3cwt. of steel of this, kind and shape, worth 6l.â€”these bars and shackles are oursâ€”I do not know the toolsâ€”George Lawrence was in our employ.
Cross-examined. Q. Was that steel made for you? A. Noâ€”I know it by the maker's private mark, and also by their being rusty on one side and clean on the other.

JAMES BURTON (policeman). On 27th Nov., at ten o'clock at night, I saw Lawrence on Holborn-hill, and said he must go back to Saul-street respecting the steelâ€”he said, "It is a bad job, it cannot be helped, I hope my wife and child are not locked up; I took the steel"â€”on the way to the station he said it was through distress.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not he say he saw Cook, and told him he had some stuff which would make tools? A. Something of the sort.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

CAROLINE LAWRENCE and COOKâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

188.
GEORGE COOK was again indicted
for feloniously receiving 70lbs. weight of steel; the goods of
Thomas Charles Matt and another, knowing it to be stolen.
THOMAS CHARLES MATT . I cannot identify this steel.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Lord Chief Justice Denman.

189.
GEORGE BARNARD, alias Page
, was indicted
for uttering coun
terfeit coin, after a previous conviction.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant-Solicitor to the Mint. I pro
duce a copy of the record of the conviction of George Barnard at Gloucester in Oct., 1846â€”this I have examined with the original record in the office of the Clerk of the Peace, and it is a true copy.
GEORGE HENRY MASON . I am Governor of Gloucester County Gaol. I was present at the trial of George Barnard in Oct., 1846â€”the prisoner is the personâ€”I know him well, and had him in my custody.

ELIZABETH ROBINSON . My father is a shoemaker. One Friday night in Sept., about nine o'clock, I was in the street, and the prisoner spoke to me and said, "Little girl, will you go for an errand for me?"â€”I said, "Yes sir"â€”he said, "You go to the public-house and get me sixpenny-worth of gin, and make haste"â€”he gave me half a sovereign, wrapped up in a piece of paperâ€”I tried it with my teeth, and it bentâ€”I went to the Pilgrim, asked for the gin, and offered the halfsovereign in paymentâ€”it was refusedâ€”they gave it me backâ€”I went to the place he had given it me at, and he was not thereâ€”I then went home, told my father, and gave it to him.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you know the prisoner

before? A. Noâ€”my father's house was two or three minutes' walk offâ€”the public-house he told me to go to was within sight, he pointed it out to meâ€”I did not see him again till the policeman had him in custodyâ€”I am quite sure he is the man.

JOHN ROBINSON . I am the father of the last witness. On Friday night, 29th Sept., she gave me a half-sovereignâ€”I gave it to the policemanâ€”I went out with her and looked about the place, and went to where she tendered it.

EMMA SMITH . I am bar-maid to my father, who keeps the Pilgrim, in Kennington-lane. On Friday, 29th Sept., the little girl came for sixpenny-worth of gin, and gave me a bad half-sovereign, which I returned herâ€”on 14th Oct. I saw the prisoner at our house with another manâ€”he asked for a pint of sixpenny ale, and threw down a bad half-sovereignâ€”I took it up, bent it, and told him it was a bad oneâ€”he said he had no more money, and the other man paid for the aleâ€”I returned the half-sovereign to the prisonerâ€”I had bitten it, and made an impression on itâ€”this is it (produced)â€”it was shown me next morning.
Cross-examined. Q. What makes you know that to be the one? A. From the mark I made on it on the edge.

FREDERICK LEDGER . I am pot-man at the Pilgrim. On Saturday, 14th Oct., in consequence of what Miss Smith told me, I went to the bar, saw the prisoner there, and another manâ€”as soon as I came into the bar they walked outâ€”I followed, and never lost sight of themâ€”the prisoner said if I followed them any further he would break my bâ€”y leg, and he struck me with a stick, and I had a wrestle with himâ€”I still followedâ€”he wanted me to have a glass of ale and leave himâ€”I would notâ€”he was very insultingâ€”he was taken in my presence.
BENJAMIN CURSLEY . On 14th Oct. I saw the prisoner and Ledger struggling togetherâ€”I picked up a half-sovereign in the direction they had gone, which I afterwards gave to Brosnahan.
TIMOTHY BROSNAHAN (policeman, L 164). I produce two counterfeit half-sovereigns, one I got from John Robinson, on 29th Sept., and the other from Cursley.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL
re-examined. These half-sovereigns are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 33.â€”
Transported for Ten Years.
Before Mr. Justice Coltman.

190.
EDWARD MULCAHAY
, feloniously cutting and wounding
George Thomas Wallington on his left side, with intent to murder him;â€”2nd Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

GEORGE THOMAS WALLINGTON . I am a labourer, at Moss's-alley, St. Sa
viour's. On the night of 13th Nov., about twelve o'clock, I was returning home along Bankside with my wife, her sister, Mrs. Dooling, and her husbandâ€”I passed the prisoner, who I know by sight, by working in the same neigh
bourhoodâ€”he was standing on the pavement, near Bailey and Pegg's iron
wharfâ€”I crossed the road to make water, and Dooling crossed alsoâ€”I left Dooling there and walked onâ€”I heard some words between him and the prisoner, but could not hear what they wereâ€”I called out to Dooling to follow me, which he instantly didâ€”I heard Dooling say to him that if he made use of such language as that to him again, for twopence he would fetch him a thump ov er the headâ€”the prisoner passed by Dooling and came up to me,

and said, "Westminster" that is a nickname I go by, "did you suppose I was going to do that man any harm?" said, "No, I do not suppose you was; I know he would not do you any harm, for he is too quiet a man; we are going home civil, do you do the same"â€”he then said, "Bâ€”y Westminster, I know yon, take that," and stuck a knife into meâ€”he left it sticking in my side, and attempted to run awayâ€”I stepped forward, caught hold of his collar, and held him till Dooling came upâ€”he was niven into custody to a policemanâ€”I took the knife out of my side and gave it to Doolingâ€”the wound was on the seventh ribâ€”it bled all the way to the stationâ€”the knife went through a white duck frock, a blue Guernsey frock, and my shirtâ€”Mr. Odglincr, the surgeon, has attended me ever sinceâ€”I have suffered greatly from the wound, and have not been able to earn a penny since.

Cross-examined by MR. KCNEVLY. Q. And so you thought you would get your expenses and make some money by this? A. No, I had no such thoughtâ€”I was out in the air the day after I got this wound, and have been out a little daily sinceâ€”I did not drink anything for the first fortnight, except a little spruce, and have only had a little beer this weekâ€”I had no quarrel with the prisoner that nightâ€”the assault was entirely unprovoked on my paitâ€”the woman who was with me was my wifeâ€”she is not a prostituteâ€”Doo
ling was not inclined to quarrel with the prisonerâ€”I never knew him quarrel gvith any oneâ€”I did not hear him say to the prisoner if he said another word he would knock him downâ€”I have been in several rows in my time, but not of my own makingâ€”I am not a fighting manâ€”I never belonged to the prize ringâ€”I went down to see a fight at Croydon some time agoâ€”I was not en
gaged in itâ€”we had hod five pots of beer on this night, between seven of usâ€”the prisoner did not appear drunkâ€”I did not give the prisoner a dreadful blow on the faceâ€”I did not hear the Magistrate ask the prisoner who gave it himâ€”I did not see any markâ€”the prisoner said lie had had a hit on the nose with something, but he did not say I gave it himâ€”I believe he has a mark on the nose, which he got in a row with his brother twelve months agoâ€”I swear neither I or Dooling lifted a hand to himâ€”my hands were in my pocket when he stabbed meâ€”Doolincr and I lodge in the same houseâ€”I have not said that all I wanted was to get my expenses, and I had no enmity to the prisonerâ€”I did tell the prisoner's friends it would be better for me to be at work instead of bciny laid up through his brutalityâ€”I did not say that all I wanted was to bind him down to keep the peace, and to have some re
muneration.

ARTHUR DOOLING . I was passing along Bankside on the night in question with the prosecutor and our wivesâ€”I saw the prisoner; I stayed behind, when Wallington went onâ€”the prisoner and I stood three or four yards from each otlier, making waterâ€”he used some disgusting language to me which is not fit to mention, and I said for twopence I would give him a thump on the headâ€”that was all that passedâ€”Wallington called out to me to come on, and not have any row with him, and I went onâ€”the prisoner followed and passed meâ€”lie went up to Wallington, made a blow at his right side, and said, "Bâ€”Westminster, I know you; take that!"â€”I was about ten yards offâ€”the pri
soner attempted to run awayâ€”Wallington caught himâ€”I went up and he gave me the knifeâ€”I took it to the station, and there saw it was bloody.

Crooss-examined. Q You and Wallington were very quiet that night, I suppose A. Yes, and soberâ€”we had only had a very small drop to drinkâ€”about six pots among seven of usâ€”I never had any words with the pri
soner beforeâ€”he did not speak to Wallington till he got up to himâ€”I did

not see Wallington strike the prisoner a dreadful blow on the noseâ€”I did not strike him, and I believe no one else didâ€”I saw a little bit of a scab on his nose before the Magistrate, as big as a pin's pointâ€”it was not a fresh woundâ€”the Magistrate asked him where he got his nose damagedâ€”he did not say that I or my friend did itâ€”I do not know what he saidâ€”I lodge in the same house as Wallington, in Lad's-court, Moss's-alleyâ€”the woman who was with me is not my wifeâ€”she is not Wellington's wife's sisterâ€”we have not talked about this matter at all sinceâ€”the prisoner was not very drunkâ€”he had had something to drink, but knew what he was about.

GEORGE THOMAS WALLINGTON
re-examined. There were three women with usâ€”my wife, her sister, and Dooling's wife.
MICHAEL SKABRIGHT (policejnan, M 41). I took the prisoner into custody, and produce the knifeâ€”there was blood on itâ€”I produce the things the prosecutor had on.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner was rather drunk, was he not? A. Ratherâ€”I saw no cut on his faceâ€”he never named it to meâ€”he did to the Magistrate, and said they had assaulted himâ€”it was a slight scarâ€”it was a fresh mark, not black, only the skin a little movedâ€”Wallington and Doo
ling were both sober.

GEORGE ODLING . I am a surgeon. I saw Wallington at the stationâ€”I found a wound on his left side on the seventh rib, not quite an inch longâ€”it might have penetrated the ribâ€”this knife would produce such a woundâ€”it must have been inflicted with considerable violence.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not probe it? A. Noâ€”the skin was cut. (The prisoner received a good character).

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 24.â€”
Confined Two Years.

191.
WILLIAM SALE
, stealing 1 pair of reins, value 6s. the goods of
William Minter; 1 whip, 1 pair of shoes, 2 coats, and other articles, 11s.; the goods of
William Hopkins: having been before convicted.

WILLIAM MINTER . I live at Broad-wall, Stamford-street, Blackfriars-road, and occupy a stable in Prince's Mewsâ€”this pair of reins (produced) are mineâ€”in consequence of information I went to the police-station, and afterwards to my stable, and missed the reins, and another pair that have not been foundâ€”they were safe the night beforeâ€”I found the prisoner and the reins at the station.

WILLIAM HOPKINS . I occupy a stable next to Minter. On Saturday night, between seven and eight o'clock, I put two coats, a smock frock, a pair of shoes, a whip, and a pair of reins into the stableâ€”I missed them nest morning, and found them at the police-stationâ€”these are them (produced)â€”I found the prisoner in custody with the smock-frock, and jacket on.

JAMES DRAPER (policeman, L 70). Between twelve and one o'clock on Sunday morning, 19th Nov., I saw the prisoner in Prince's Mews, about a dozen yards from Hopkins' stableâ€”I asked what he had gotâ€”he said a pair of reins, and a whip which were his ownâ€”that he had been dismissed from Mr. Pickford's service, and there they found their own reinsâ€”he had this coat and smock-frock onâ€”I took him to the station, and found on him a pair of scis
sors, shoes, and compasses which Hopkins claims.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought them for half-a-crown; I carried them openly. (The prisoner's father gave him a good character).

PATRICK STACK (policeman, L 123). I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted May 1847, confined three months and whipped)â€”I was presentâ€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

192.
THOMAS CASSON
. stealing 1 crane, value 30s.; the goods of
James Lys Sender, and others.

JOHN DEVALL . I am carman to James Lys Seagerâ€”he has three part
tnersâ€”they are distillersâ€”on Thursday, Nov. 9th. between five and six o'clock, I was in the cellar of the Duke's Head, in Mint-streetâ€”my van stood at the doorâ€”I came back to it, and missed this metal crane (produced)â€”it is to draw the pin off, and is Seager and Co.'s property.

JAMES BURTON (policeman, M 272). In consequence of information, on 9th Nov., between five and six o'clock, I went to some ruins in Mint-square, about 200 yards from the Duke's Headâ€”I heard a noise as of something breakingâ€”I got through the pailing, and saw the prisoner who I knew before, and another, run awayâ€”I followed them through the courts into the Mint, and there lost sight of themâ€”I went back, and found this crane in the broken state it now isâ€”I told another constable, and he took the prisoner.
Prisoner. I was hard at work at the time, you knew where I lived? Witness. I did notâ€”I did not see you afterwards, till you were taken.

JOHN DELANY (policeman, M 100). I received information, and took the prisoner on the 20thâ€”I said I wanted him on suspicion of stealing a pipe from a wagon, the property of Seagcr and Co., in Mint-streetâ€”he said he knew nothing about it, he was at work at the time.
Prisoner. Q. You knew where I lived? A. I did not, you change your residence so oftenâ€”I searched your old house, and all the places about, and could not find you.
Prisoner's Defence. I was at work till half-past seven o'clock.
GEORGE BATSFORD (policeman, A 465). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted Sept. 1847, and confined three months)â€”I was presentâ€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 33.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

193.
JAMES REID
, stealing 7 yards of printed cotton, value 5s.: also, 12 yards of silk, 30s.; the goods of
Thomas Weir, his master: also, embez
zling 3s., 17s., and 2l. 2s. 6d.; the moneys of Thomas Weir, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.â€”
Confined Eighteen Months.

194.
JOHN SMITH
, stealing 38lbs. weight of lead, value 8s.; the goods of
Henry Sykes Thornton, fixed to a building.

ALFERD SPICE (policeman, V 47). On 21st Nov., about twenty minutes past seven o'clock, I stopped the prisoner near the Swan at Stockwell, carry
in something heavy, I asked what he had got, he said some leadâ€”I asked where he got itâ€”he said he found it on Clapham-commonâ€”I said he must go to the stationâ€”I took it from him, and one piece from his trowsers, and another from his jacket at the stationâ€”it weighed 13lbs.â€”on 23rd I received information, took it to Mr. Thornton's, Clapham-common, and compared it with two pieces on the fowl-houseâ€”it corresponded, and had been recently cutâ€”I found two knives in his pocket with a lead mark on the edge of one.

ISAAC ABBOTT . I am gardener to Henry Sykes Thornton. On 22nd Nov., between eight and nine o'clock, I found some lead had been stripped off the fowl-houseâ€”it was safe the day beforeâ€”I saw the constable compare itâ€”it fitted exactly.
Prisoner's Defence. I found it on Clapham-common.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined Six Months.

div1.p:
195.
WILLIAM GILLARD
, stealing 3lbs. weight of almonds, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
George Duncan and another, his masters.

GEORGE DUNCAN . I am a confectioner, in partnership with John Boydâ€”the prisoner was in our employ, in the engine-house, adjoining the counting-house, from which I missed about 30lbs. of almondsâ€”these produced are of the same sortâ€”the prisoner had no authority to take themâ€”I did not give him any.
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Was not the counting-house locked? A. Yesâ€”I will not swear these almonds are the same that I lostâ€”I had not seen them for two or three days before I missed them.
SAMUEL BOYD . I am sometimes employed on the premisesâ€”I believe these almonds (produced) to be the same that were in a bag in the counting-houseâ€”I have not compared them.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you the son of one of the partners? A. Yesâ€”I have no particular employment thereâ€”the prisoner has been there two or three monthsâ€”I have not driven the engine since he has been thereâ€”I did before he cameâ€”I was not intimate with himâ€”I once made him a present of a pipeâ€”I never gave him any almondsâ€”I will not swear they are the same sortâ€”I fetched a witness, named Harris, before the Magistrateâ€”I said nothing to him about what he was to say.

THOMAS WRIGHT . I am in Mr. Duncan's service. I had only been there a week when the prisoner asked me to hold some almonds under my coat till he got outâ€”he gave me a bagâ€”when I got outside, I gave them to himâ€”he put them under his smock, and a constable took himâ€”he said Sam gave them to him, meaning Boyd.

GEORGE WILD (policeman M 94). On 10th Nov., about seven o'clock, I was in Great Guildford-street, in plain elothes, and saw the prisoner and another about 200 yards from Mr. Duncan'sâ€”he put his hand into the top part of his smockâ€”I said, "What have you got there?"â€”he said, "What odds is that to you? what I have got is my own"â€”I said, "I do not think it is"â€”he was working his fingers into the hole, and the almonds were running out of the bagâ€”I said, "Where do you work?"â€”he said, "At Mr. Duncan's; what I have got, his boy Sam gave me"â€”I said, "Who is Sam?"â€”he said, "You come with me, I will show you where I got them"â€”I took him to the shopâ€”Mrs. Duncan said they were stolen, she did not believe the partner's son gave them to himâ€”the prisoner said he didâ€”Mr. Duncan cameâ€”he begged not be locked up, and said it was his first offenceâ€”I took him to the station.

SUSAN GILLARD . The prisoner is my brother. I was at the gate of the premises with my father, and saw Samuel Boyd and the prisoner walking out
side the gateâ€”Boyd passed some nuts (I believe they were almonds) to my brotherâ€”I saw the kernel not the shellâ€”I was not close enough to see whether they were almondsâ€”they were not in a bag, but in his handâ€”I swear they were almondsâ€”they were not sugared.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

196.
WILLIAM GRIFFIN
, unlawfully obtaining goods by false pre
tences.

FRANCIS GANGE . I am a colour-manufacturer, of 4, Charles-street, Lam
bethâ€”I have a partner. On 19th Sept. the prisoner called on me, and wished to be shown some samples of coloursâ€”I showed him some, and gave him the price for cashâ€”he said, "I am in a very extensive way of business; I want them to reduce to artists' colours; I am an artists' colour-maker; I

supply Winsor and Newton, Barnards, and Newman; and if you can give me credit for a week or fourteen days, you will find it perfectly right, and I shall be induced, if 1 find the things suit my purpose, to give you an order to a much larger amount; but, at the same time, I shall require a little longer credit"â€”I let him have credit for fourteen days, but called in the neighbour
hood first, and found he had not lived there very longâ€”he had given me a reference, "John Turner, 40, Bromley-street, Commercial-road, East," and said he would satisfy me as to his respectabilityâ€”I went there, and found a person of that nameâ€”on 26th Sept. I called, and found the house shut upâ€”it was besieged with creditorsâ€”I went to Bromley-street, and could not find Turnerâ€”I was to call again next dayâ€”on 1st Nov. I found the prisoner at 58, Brick-laneâ€”he said, "My name is not Baker, my name is Charles Wat
son; I do not know that I ever saw you before; I have a twin brother, who is so much like me, nobody knows the difference; and you must be careful what you say, or I will make you pay dearly for it"â€”I said I was certain he was the manâ€”when he saw I was determined, he said, "The whole of it is, I have no money; but if you can take a bill for a month, you may depend on it I will honour it"â€”I gave him in chargeâ€”if I had known he was not an artists' colourman, and did not deal with Barnards', I should not have let him have the goods.

DAVID FRANCIS . I am house-agent to Mr. Beaumont, landlord, of 1, Earnest-street West, Beaumont-square. The prisoner took that house about the middle of Juneâ€”he said he was a draper in the neighbourhood; he wanted the house as a depository for drapery goodsâ€”he mentioned no other businessâ€”I found on 26th Sept. that he had left without notice.
Prisoner. I said my brother was a draper, not that I was. Witness. I am certain of it.
SAMUEL GREY . I am shopman to Jabez Barnard, colour-maker, of Oxford-streetâ€”he has no other shopman. The prisoner never supplied him with colours, he makes his own.

Prisoner. Q. I said Barnards' supplied me; did not I buy some goods there about three months ago? A. Yes, 15l. worthâ€”you represented your
self as an artist and drawing-master, and referred us to a Air. Turnerâ€”we never got paid.

JOHN JENKINSON (policeman, G 53). I took the prisoner on 1st Nov.â€”I searched the house, 58, Brick-lane, which a woman, who said she was his wife, said was hisâ€”I found this invoice of Mr. Gange's goods in a pocket-book.

MR. GASGE re-examined. I am certain the prisoner said Barnards' sup
plied him.
(The prisoner, in a long defence, admitted that he had the colours, but that, having disposed of them, and being defrauded of the money, he teas not able to pay for them.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.â€”
Confined Nine. Months.
(There was another indictment against the-prisoner, on which no evidence was offered.)

197.
AMBROSE JACOBS and
CHARLES DOWNING
, for unlawfully obtaining goods by false pretences.

THOMAS SMALLARD RICHARDS . I keep the Russian Tea Establishment, Bishopsgate-strect On 19th Sept. Jacobs came, and said he was going to open a shop at Welling on the next Saturday, and wanted some tea sent down on the Friday or Saturday; that he was going to be married; that his

wife's relations would take the principal part of it; and inquired ray termsâ€”I said the terms were cashâ€”he said he had tea and grocery to buy with his ready cash; and, if it was not convenient to find the cash, would a reference do, if it was respectableâ€”after some time, I agreed that it wouldâ€”he gave me the name of Charles Downing, of 23, Robert-street, Blackfriars-roadâ€”I wrote there, and received this letter (produced)â€”I thought it satisfactory, and sent the goods by the carrier, to be given to a man named Clarke, at the Spur Inn, in the Boroughâ€”he had promised to call on me on the Friday weekâ€”he did not call; and about 29th Sept. I went to 23, Robert-streetâ€”there was "Charles Downing, jeweller," on a brass plateâ€”I knocked at the door for half an hour, but could not get inâ€”I found that Downing had run awayâ€”I saw him at the police-court about the 20th Oct., and afterwards gave him in charge at his house, Princes-street, Lambethâ€”I have never received any money.

WILLIAM BECKETT . I am Mr. Richards's shopman. I packd up the tea, and sent itâ€”on 24th Sept. Iâ€”went with a constable to 1, Chester-street, Kennington-lane, and inquired for Mr. Jacobsâ€”we found Jacobs thereâ€”he was the same man I had seen at the shopâ€”I asked if his name was Ambrose Jacobsâ€”he hesitated some time, and said, "No, my name is Edward Jones"â€”I gave him in chargeâ€”he afterwards acknowledged that his name was Ambrose Edward Jacobsâ€”we searched his boxes, and found some bills which we had printed for him, appointing him an agent, and some lead which the tea had been wrapped in.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Did you get the bills printed expressly? A. Yes; when we appoint agents in the country we send these bills.

WILLIAM CLARK . I am a carrier to Dartford. I took a package addressed, "Mr. Jacobs, Welling"â€”Jacobs came to me at the Spur Inn, and asked if I had a chestâ€”I said, "Yes; where is it to be left?"â€”he said, "At the shop next to Waghorne's, the baker's"â€”I left it thereâ€”he took it inâ€”he had got down before me.

JOHN LINDLEY . I am a house-agent, of Derby-street, Argyle-squareâ€”23, Robert-street is Mr. Cubitt's propertyâ€”Downing took it of meâ€”I saw him write, and believe this letter to be his writing (readâ€”"I beg to say that I have known Ambrose Jacobs many years through having dealings with his father, and consider him a most respectable and business-like young man. Yours respectfully,â€”CHAS. DOWNING. ")

HENRY BARRY (policeman, M 455). On 20th Oct. I took Downing in Princes-streetâ€”I said it was for being concerned with Jacobs in swindling Mr. Richards of some teaâ€”he said he did not know Jacobsâ€”it must be a mistake.

JOHN BAKER (policeman). I went with Beckett to Chester-street, Kenning
ton-road, and took Jacobsâ€”he said he knew a person named Downing who lived somewhere near Bedford-row, but he did not know the street or placeâ€”I said Downing was in custodyâ€”he said he was not aware of itâ€”I searched and found these bills.
EDWARD LOWE . I am a printer. On 20th June, Downing took a house of me, 3, Play-house-yardâ€”he occupied it till Septemberâ€”I went there thenâ€”he was not there.

GEORGE REEVES . I am a builder, of Wellingâ€”I let the prisoners house there about the latter end of Mayâ€”he occupied it for two monthsâ€”the shop was always closedâ€”I never saw the inside till the landlord gained possessionâ€”there was no stock or anything thereâ€”there was a written bill on the shut
ters saying it would be open at prices unknown in the localityâ€”I have seen
him go at eleven o'clock at night and leave at five in the morningâ€”he was seldom or never there in the day.

WILLIAM CHRISTY . I am a watch-maker. About a week before Michael
mas Downing took a house of a relative of mine, and gave the name of Colnett.
RICHARD WALKER (policeman). I know Downing by the name of John Colnett.
Jacobs' Defence. I never had the tea, and never was in Mr. Richards's house; when I was first examined Mr. Richards swore I was not the man; he said 1 was, at the second examination.
MR. RICHARDS re-examined. I did express a doubt, at first because he was so dirty, and he came to meâ€”with his arm in a sling.

JACOBSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Six Months.

DOWNINGâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

198.
HENRY MEAD was indicted
for embezzling 6l. 16s., which he had received on account of
John Stephens, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

199.
BENJAMIN WALKER was indicted
for stealing 2 sovereigns, 4 half-sovereigns. 4 half-crowns, 6 shillings, and 3 sixpences; the moneys of
John Stokes: to which he pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Eight Months.

200.
WILLIAM CUTHBERT was indicted
for stealing 3 pairs of trow
sers and other goods, value 30s.; the property of
Horatio Nelson Clark; also 1 jacket and other goods, value 30s.; the property of
Robert Brown: to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Confined Nine Months.

201.
JAMES STANNIN was indicted
for stealing 10 lbs. weight of beef and suet, value 6s.; the property of
Thomas Smith, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined Six Months.

202.
MARY WILLIAMS was indicted for
stealing 1 purse, value 4d., 4 sovereigns, and 3 shillings; the property of
Jemima Smith: and
JAMES GILHAM
for feloniously receiving 1 purse and 1 sovereign, part of the same.

WILLIAMS pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 40.

GILHAM pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Confined nine Months.

203.
DAVID GREEN and
JOSEPH GREEN were indicted for
stealing 118 lbs. weight of fat, value 15s.; the property of
John William Messenger, their master.

JOHN WILLIAM MESSENGER . I carry on business in the Borough-market and in Rochester-street. The prisoners were in my service and my father's for many yearsâ€”John Green was the foreman of my place at Rochester-street, and David had to take a cart round to the butchers to bring in fat which was to be meltedâ€”on the morning of the 14th Nov. I made arrang
ements as if I were going out of tovvn, and placed myself in a loft which com
manded a view of my premisesâ€”I saw Joseph hold a sack open and a man named Puibrook filled itâ€”it was then taken in the yard, but before it was taken they asked David Green if he was readyâ€”(he was at that time harness
ing his horse to go out)â€”Puibrook then carried out the sack towards the cartâ€”I did not sec him put it in, but I saw the cart come out with the sack in it, and David Green was driving itâ€”I came down and stopped itâ€”David

said he knew nothing about itâ€”I took him and the cart to the stationâ€”Joseph was taken in about an hour afterwardsâ€”Pulbrook ran away, and I have not seen him sinceâ€”the sack contained rather more than a hundred weight of fatâ€”it was removed from the boiling-houseâ€”it was David Green's business to go out with his cart empty to fetch in goods, but not to take anything outâ€”this fat was in a state in which it never goes from my premises.

JAMES FOSTER (police-sergeant, M 1). I took Joseph Greenâ€”he asked if I wanted himâ€”I said "Yes"â€”he said, in going along, that it was a bad jobâ€”I heard the prisoners examinedâ€”what they said was taken down in writingâ€”this is Mr. Cottingham's signature to it (readâ€”"Both the prisoners say, 'It is our first offence, and we hope for mercy.'"

David Green. I beg for mercy; I saw nothing of the transaction till I got out of the yard; I was asked if I was all ready; I said, "Yes;" I got ready and drew out; as soon as I got out, my master came and jumped in the cart, and said, "What is that?" I said I did not know; he ordered me to drive to the station.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

DAVID GREENâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 45.

JOSEPH GREENâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 43.

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy by the Juryâ€”
Confined Six Months.

div1.p:
204.
WILLIAM LEGG was indicted
for marrying
Dinah Squire Rowe, his former wife being alive; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.

205.
WILLIAM FOX
, stealing 1 cake, value 3s. 9d.; 6 shillings, and 3 pence; the property of
Benjamin Verge: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.â€”
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

206.
ELIZABETH NICHOLLS
, ulawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
NOT GUILTY .

207.
CHARLES ROBERTS and
CHARLES HAINE
, for a like offence. MESSRS. SCRIVEN and CLERK conducted the Prosecution.

SAMUEL WRIGHT (policeman, P 172). About seven o'clock in the evening on 13th Oct. I saw the two prisoners and another person walking together in the Walworth-roadâ€”Haine went into Mr. Parsons's, and the other two remained on the opposite side of the streetâ€”Haine came out, went across and conversed with them, and they all went down the road, looking into various shopsâ€”both prisoners went into a shop in Crown-streetâ€”I took the other person, who was discharged.
JAMES PARSLEY . Haine came into my shop on 13th Oct. for some tobaccoâ€”he gave me a bad 4d.-pieceâ€”I gave it him back, and he went awayâ€”I did not mark it.

RICHARD HAMBROOK (policeman, P 109). I saw the prisoner and ano
ther person in Mr. Bolsom's shopâ€”before they went in, I saw them all under a lamp, and Roberts took something out of his pocket and gave it to Haineâ€”I went in after my brother officer, and took the prisonersâ€”I found nothing on them.

RICHARD DAVIS (policeman. P 55). I followed the prisonersâ€”I saw them go into Bolsom's shopâ€”Haine dropped a 4d.-piece in the shopâ€”I took it up, and found it was badâ€”I took Roberts down to the stationâ€”I found on him nine 4d.-pieces in this paper, in his left-hand waistcoat pocketâ€”I found on him one looseâ€”W.-piece and 9 1/2 d. good moneyâ€”he said, "You have got me to rights at last."
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These 4d.-pieces are all counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.

Roberts' Defence. I picked up the paper containing the 4d.-piecesâ€”I did not know whether they were good or badâ€”I gave Haine oneâ€”he went into the shop, and they said it was badâ€”I put it into my pocket, and in coming home I went into the shop for half an ounce of tobacco, and the officers came in and took us.

ROBERTSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 19.

HAINEâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined One Year .

208.
GEORGE GROVE
, stealing 1 tea-pot and stand, and other articles, value 32l. the goods of
Samuel Bendry Brooke: also, 18 spoons and other articles, value 24l. 15s.; the goods of
Harriet Kemple, his mistress, in her dwelling-house; to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.â€”
Confined One Year .

209.
WEST DIGGES
, feloniously receiving 1 cask, value 14s.; and 18 gallons of beer, 1l. 6s.; the goods of Sir
Henry Meux and another; knowing them to have been stolen. (See vol. xxviii. page 765.)

RICHARD LATIMER . I am clerk to Sir Henry Meux and another. A man named Abell was a carman in their employâ€”it was his duty to take out beer occasionally, and to take delivery-notes with it. On 9th Sept. I gave him two delivery-notesâ€”he was to deliver the goods to which they appliedâ€”I saw the dray when it was going out, and I observed, that in addition to the beer it was his duty to take, he had a kilderkinâ€”I mentioned it to Mr. Jenkins.

JAMES WILKINS . I am now in the employ of Sir Henry Meux and Co. On 9th Sept., before I went into their service, I was standing outside the gateway I saw Abell come out of the brewery with a loaded drayâ€”he asked me to go and drink with him, which I didâ€”he then asked me to walk with him, and we went to the Three Cranes-wharf, Upper Thames-streetâ€”, there was then on the dray five full barrels, two full kilderkins, and one empty oneâ€”we left at the wharf five full barrels, and the empty kilderkinâ€”we then went to Mr. Todd's house, just off the wharf, and left one full kilderkin thereâ€”we had then one full kilderkin on the drayâ€”we then went to Toolev-street, and then Abell said he hardlv knew where it was to goâ€”he said Charles Fair told him it was just underneath the railwayâ€”we succeeded in finding Digges's houseâ€”Digges was standing in front of the door, looking into the streetâ€”Abell said, "I have brought you a kilderkin of stout"â€”Digges said, "That is right, my boys, bring it in"â€”he went into the house, and I lent Abell a hand to get it off the drayâ€”he rolled it inâ€”I opened the doorâ€”Digges at first said he would have the empty casks moved out of the cornerâ€”he then said, "Never mind, it won't be in the way, pitch it up there"â€”Abell pitched it up on its head in the corner, about two or three steps from the barâ€”Digges said, "What will you have to drink, my boys, ale, pale ale, or stout?"â€”Abell said he would have stout; and Digges drew a pint of stout, and gave us two glasses to drink out ofâ€”while Abell and I were drinking the stout, Mr. Berridge and the policeman came inâ€”Mr. Berridge asked Abell what business he had thereâ€”he said he had brought some beer thereâ€”he asked him where the delivery-notes wereâ€”Abell produced some papersâ€”Mr. Berridge looked at them, and said they were not sufficient notesâ€”Abell then said he had forgotten themâ€”Mr. Berridge told the policeman to take us two into custody, and he said he should give Mr. Digges into custody for receiving itâ€”Digges said he would follow down to the stationâ€”the officer took Abell and me thereâ€”Digges did not coincâ€”I did not notice an) body at Digges's bar but Abell

and him, till alter we were given into custodyâ€”I then noticed there was a man there, just inside the door, on the right-hand sideâ€”he was not there when we went into the barâ€”Digges's wife was inside.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Will you undertake to swear that there was not a person at the bar? A. I will not be positiveâ€”I did not see him till after I was given into custodyâ€”he was standing in front of the barâ€”I remained in custody three daysâ€”I have not given evidence before nowâ€”I was not chargedâ€”Digges did not ask for the delivery-noteâ€”I have been employed in delivering beerâ€”we get a drop of beer if they like to give it usâ€”I had been to Digges's once before, a week before, with Joseph Wilkinsâ€”I did not know before that Digges was a customer of my master'sâ€”the barrel that I and Wilkins took we rolled down the court where Digges's cellar isâ€”I believe his house is the sign of the Sword and Buckler.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was it ale you delivered before? A. No, a barrel of porterâ€”Wilkins had the delivery-order, and he gave it to Diggesâ€”on the last occasion Digges did not ask for any.

CUTHBERT POTTS . I am a cooper, in the employ of Meux and Co. On 9th Sept. I saw Abell going out with a loadâ€”he had five barrels, an empty kilderkin, and two full oues, on his drayâ€”one kilderkin was double stout, and the other singleâ€”a kilderkin of double stout would be worth about 26s. 6d.

HENRY JENKINS . I am a clerk to Messrs. Meux. I saw Abell, with his dray loaded, on 9th Sept.â€”I attempted to follow the dray, but missed itâ€”Abell had no right to take any beer without a delivery-order, which was to be given to the publican, and a portion of it signed and brought back.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you search Digges's house? A. Yesâ€”I tasted the beer thereâ€”I found it was all odds and ends, a mixtureâ€”I could not make anything of itâ€”I think Digges had dealt with us from 1842â€”he had had a kilderkin of beer on 5th Sept., and a barrel oa the 2ndâ€”he has not had beer since 1844 without paying for it beforehandâ€”I believe there were only three exceptions to that rule, which were by the clerk's neglect.

COURT. Q. Was there any order for this kilderkin on that day? A. Noâ€”the order-book is hereâ€”I was keeping it at that timeâ€”no order would be executed except what appeared on the bookâ€”Digges has not had a kilderkin of double stout for some yearsâ€”I recollect that, apart from any booksâ€”we have in our knowledge the houses we send stout to, and that was not a house that had stoutâ€”the prisoner's credit stopped before 1844â€”he was in debt to the firm.

WILLIAM ENSOR THORMAN . I am clerk to Todd and Co. On the 9th Sept. Abell came with another man to our wharfâ€”he delivered five barrels of beer, and one kilderkin of stoutâ€”these are the delivery-notes with my figures on them.

RICHARD BERRIDGE . I am a clerk to Messrs. Meux and Co. On 9th Sept. I saw Abell leave the wharf with a kilderkin in his drayâ€”I followed him over London-bridge to a beer-house in Bermondsey-street, kept by Diggesâ€”he trotted the horse up to the-door, and removed the kilderkin from the dray into the houseâ€”I found a policeman, and took him to the houseâ€”I saw Abell and Wilkins drinking before the bar, and Digges standing at the back of it, and his wife, and no other person that I sawâ€”I asked Abell what business he had thereâ€”he said, "To deliver some beer"â€”I said, "By whose instructions?"â€”he said, "By Charles Farr's"â€”I asked him for the delivery-notesâ€”he produced the notes of the beer that had been delivered at the wharfâ€”I told him those were not the proper notesâ€”I gave the two men

and Digges into custodyâ€”Digges then said the men asked him to let them leave the beer there till they returnedâ€”I asked him how the beer earne to be in his cellarâ€”he said it was not in his cellar, it was there, pointing to where it was, by the bide of the bar, with a mat over itâ€”Diggesasked the policeman to be permitted to follow to the station, and to my surprise the policeman con
sentedâ€”he did not followâ€”we returned back to the house with a cab to seek himâ€”we found his wife, who told us he had left.

JAMES WILKINS
re-examined. When I took the kilderkin to Digges nothing was said about leaving it till called for.
WILLIAM HIMPHIURY (policeman, M 127). I have been looking for the prisoner, but was not able to find him.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know there is a place called The Old Sword and Buckler in that street.? A. Yesâ€”I saw the kilderkin when it was pointed outâ€”it was on the left-hand side, in front of the bar.

JOHN JOHNSON . I live in New-street, Horsleydown, and am a horse-dealer. I remember when Abell and Wilkins were given into custody at Digges's houseâ€”I was before the bar, taking a glass of aleâ€”I went before the Judge at Chambers, and made an affidavit thereâ€”Mr. Justice Pattison held the prisoners to bail in two 20l. suretiesâ€”I was in the beer-shop a minute or two before the two men came inâ€”during that time Mr. Digges was standing against the barâ€”I do not remember whether his wife was there or notâ€”when the men came in, they rolled a cask in at the front door, and pitched it up on its head. it the side of the barâ€”one of them said they had brought a kilderkin or a cask for himâ€”Mr. Digges seemed surprisedâ€”he made answer, "I think you must be mistaken; where is the paper" or "ticket;" I will not be sure which he saidâ€”I did not pay attention to what the men saidâ€”I finished my glass of ale and went out about my businessâ€”I was not in the house when the men were taken into custody, I was walking in the neighbourhoodâ€”in the time of my going out of the house, in came the policeman, and some gentleman with himâ€”I have known nothing of Digges but by going in there, and having a pint of beerâ€”to the best of my knowledge he has been there about six or seven yearsâ€”I live with my mother and father.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTISE. Q. What is your father and mother? A. They keep a marine-store shopâ€”I have no stableâ€”I have no license; if a gentleman asks me to look at a horse I look at it, and he gives me what he thinks properâ€”I have been at horse-dealing from a childâ€”when these men came in, they said they had brought a kilderkin, or a caskâ€”I will not swear that the expression was not "Digges, I have brought you a kilderkin"â€”I do not know where Digges's wife was; I did not see her; I know her; I hare not been talking to her sinceâ€”I have been in there to have a glass of aleâ€”I did not see her when I went in that dayâ€”I think she was there when I came outâ€”I went out just as the policeman went inâ€”I went back afterwards, and had a pint of beer with my aunt, who lives next door to Diggesâ€”she is in the general lineâ€”the beer came from the tap of Mr. Diggesâ€”ruy cousin fetched itâ€”they told me something, and I went into Mr. Digges's houseâ€”I saw Mrs. Diggesâ€”I did not see Mr. Diggesâ€”I did not hear he was gone away; I did not hear he was going to run awayâ€”I do not know how long that was alter the policeman had turned his backâ€”I was at my aunt's five or ten minutesâ€”I did not see Mr. Dirges for six or seven weeks afterwardsâ€”I had frequently been at my aunt's in the meantimeâ€”I have been to Digges's some
times to have a glass of porterâ€”I heard Mr. Digges was awayâ€”I understood he was going to in hardlandâ€”I never saw any bands in Diggess or any removed

I am no relation of hisâ€”I have never seen any barrels on my aunt's premisesâ€”I bought a horse last Friday for a man of the name of Seager, in White's-groundâ€”I bought it of a stranger, in Smithfield-marketâ€”I had half-a-crown for that jobâ€”I bought a horse on the Friday beforeâ€”I gave 5l. 12s. 6d. for it, and I got 5s. for thatâ€”I cannot tell when I bought one beforeâ€”I have bought and sold different things for peopleâ€”I am in the general lineâ€”my aunt is a marine-store dealerâ€”her right name is Harradineâ€”the name over the door is Humphreysâ€”I generally attend Smithfield every Fridayâ€”I have been in the habit of attending the market and repositories.
NOT GUILTY .

210.
HENRY SAVAGE,
stealing 2 loaves of bread, value 3s. 1d.; the goods of
Frederick Smith, his master: and
WILLIAM DICKINS
, felo
niously receiving the same; to which SAVAGE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.
FREDERICK SMITH . I am a schoolmaster, at Clapham. Savage lived in my service about six monthsâ€”this bread was my propertyâ€”I lost it on the 9th Nov.â€”these boots are mineâ€”I do not know Dickins.

THOMAS NEWMAN (policeman, V 252). On 9th Nov. I was on duty on Clapham-commonâ€”I saw Dickins sitting downâ€”I asked who he was waiting forâ€”he said for his uncle (the other prisoner)â€”he said he was a footman, but he did not know where he livedâ€”I waited for about an hour, and just after seven o'clock I saw Savage come to him, bringing a bundle, which he delivered to Dickinsâ€”I took themâ€”I found in the bundle this bread and pair of bootsâ€”Dickins stated he had come all the way from Bishopsgate-street to meet his uncleâ€”Savage said he got the bread from a baker's, which I found was false.

ROBERT COLLINS (policeman, V 108). I assisted in taking the prisoners I saw Dickins receive this property from Savage. DICKINSâ€”
NOT GUILTY.

211.
MARY ANN DICKENS
, stealing 1 map and other articles, value 2l. the goods of
Henry Rodriguez, her master; and
HENRY SAVAGE
, feloniously receiving the same; to which they both pleaded

GUILTY .â€”
Confined Four Months.

212.
CHARLOTTE LINGATE
, stealing 11 cigars, value 2s.; the goods of
William Isard, and 1 pair of cuffs, and other articles, 9s. 10d.; the goods of
Ann Henry, her mistress.

WILLIAM ISARD . The prisoner was in my serviceâ€”on 7th Nov., I thought it necessary to have her boxes searched, and found the property statedâ€”I could not swear to the tea, sugar, and calico, but I could to the other thingsâ€”these cigars are mineâ€”the others belong to Ann Henryâ€”she is single.
Prisoner. She is not, she is marriedâ€”her husband is aliveâ€”there were only four cigars that were hisâ€”I took them.

GUILTY . Aged 39.â€”
Confined Two Months.

213.
MARY LALEY
, stealing 1 sheet, value 5s.; the goods of
Jacob Dyer; having been before convicted; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.â€”
Confined Two Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

214.
WILLIAM MARTIN
, stealing 49lbs. weight of lead, value 5s.; the goods of
John Wormald and another, and fixed to a building; having been before convicted: 2nd Count, the goods of
Arend John George Walstab.

SAMUEL HARRIS (police Sergeant, L 6). Between eight and nine o'clock at night, on 13th Nov., I saw the prisoner and another carrying something heavyâ€”they saw me and ran away, and each dropped somethingâ€”the other got awayâ€”I took the prisonerâ€”I looked at what they dropped, and it was two bundles of leadâ€”I produce the one carried by the prisonerâ€”he was from two to three hundred yards from the shot wharf, and coming in a direc
tion from itâ€”he said he picked the lead up.

Cross-examined by. MR. PREXDEKGAST. Q. He was not in the same street? A. Noâ€”when in Duke-street, they crossed Stamford-streetâ€”I know the pri
soner was one of the menâ€”I have known him five or six yearsâ€”I was from twelve to fourteen yards from himâ€”the mens' faces were towards meâ€”I took the lead to the station.

JAMES BRADY . I have the charge of the estate in which the shot wharf isâ€”I attend to the repairing it, and receive the rentsâ€”the tenant's name is Walstabâ€”I believe his Christian names are Arend John George.

Cross-examined. Q. How came you to know his name? A. From hav
ing intercourse with himâ€”he has an agreement in which his names wereâ€”I would not swear it was not George John, or what name I saw him signâ€”he occupies a large range of warehouses, and one or two dwelling-housesâ€”it was originally a large Patent-shot wharfâ€”the lead was taken from the large warehouse, the shot tower warehouseâ€”he occupies it for the sale of patent fuelâ€”I have not seen the lead fitted to the roof.
THOMAS STOCK . I am in the office of Messrs. Webb, the occupier of those premises gave me the names of Aaron John George Walstab.

SAMUEL HARRIS
re-examined. I saw the lead matched on the flat-roof of the warehouse.

Cross-examined. Q. In what way did it match? A. This piece of lead was left on the roof, and this part matches to itâ€”it is the same sort of lead, and the same thicknessâ€”it is the piece the other man dropped that fitsâ€”I did not find as much lend as had been lostâ€”we could not make an exact match with any, but this one pieceâ€”there had been fresh marks, and these pieces correspond with these marks, and also in the length.

DAVID PEGRAM (policeman, L 161). I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction at Newington by the name of Charles Smithâ€”(readâ€”Convicted, July, 1847, and confined six months)â€”he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.â€”
Confined One Year .
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

215.
FRANKLIN ALLEN,
GEORGE BURTON , and
HENRY EVANS
, stealing 6 handkerchiefs, value 15s.; the goods of
John Mather; Allen having been previously convicted.

MARIA MICKLEBURY . I am housekeeper to Mr. John Mather, of Wal
worth. I hung some handkerchiefs out to dry in the garden on 28th Nov.â€”these are them (produced).

ELIZABETH REDDING . I saw Burton that morning in Mr. Mather's gar
denâ€”he was taking the handkerchiefsâ€”I gave the alarm.

WILLIAM SMITH (policeman, P 32). I met the three prisoners in the Walworth-road, about half-a-mile from Mr. Mather'sâ€”I stopped them, and asked what they had gotâ€”they said "Nothing"â€”I asked them to allow me to search themâ€”I found on Burton three of these handkerchiefs, on Evans two, and one on Allen.

Allen's Defener. A man came and asked if we would buy these hand
kerchiefs for 5s.; we had only 4s., and we bought them.
WILLIAM ATLER (policeman, L 110). I produce a certificate of Allen's former convictionâ€”(readâ€”Convicted Feb. 1848, and confined three months)â€”he is the person.

ALLEN â€ â€”
GUILTY . Aged 19.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

BURTONâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 14.

EVANSâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 13.

216.
ALFRED EDWARD MOORE, alias James Matthews, alias James Johnson
, and
HENRY HODGSON
, stealing 17 cubic feet of stone, value 24s. the goods of
Henry George, and others.

HENRY GEORGE . I have three partnersâ€”we are stone-merchants, and have a wharf at Rotherhithe, and a countinghouse in Southwark-squareâ€”about the 20th Sept., the prisoner Johnson called on meâ€”he inquired the price of stone, which I told himâ€”he inquired the terms, I told him one month account, and three months on approved bills, making four months cre
ditâ€”he approved of the terms, and said he would call on Mr. Hodgson, and name to him the circumstance, and obtain his sanction and guaranteeâ€”he called again on the 2nd or 3rd Oct., and said he had seen Mr. Hodgson on the previous evening, and he had consented to become his guarantee and secu
rityâ€”he gave me Hodgson's address, at Kingslandâ€”I called there about eleven o'clock the next morningâ€”I saw him, and said, I was instructed by Mr. Johnson to call on him relative to the purchase of some stone, and I believed he was the uncle of Mr. Johnsonâ€”he said, "Yes I am, and a very good lad he is, I have assisted him on some previous occasion, he has always been punctual in his engagements, and I shall be willing to assist him in this case"â€”I said the amount would be about 60l. or 70l.â€”he said as a young beginner he should not advise me to trust him in this transaction to a greater amount than 50l.â€”I told him I would do so, I would be governed by his re
commendationâ€”he then stated in general conversation that he was induced to do all the good he could, and he was then engaged in getting a youth into the Bluecoat-school, the son of a Mrs. Hutchings', at Rotherhitbeâ€”there were several letters lying on the table, one of which he handed to me as being from the Hon. Fox Mauleâ€”I returned to my counting-houseâ€”I saw Cooper, the foreman, in the after part of the dayâ€”I directed him to deliver the stone, with one qualificationâ€”I requested him to make inquiries relative to Mrs. Hutchins', as to the character of Mr. Hodgson, as it was in reference to his responsibility the stone was to be delivered.

Cross-examined by MR. HUGHES. Q. Do you recollect sending your man to Johnson's-place with the stone? A. No; I never sent himâ€”I never sent Cooper to say that I never delivered stone unless the carriage was paidâ€”Mr. Holman's carman delivered the stoneâ€”I cannot say by whose directionâ€”I wrote to Johnson, informing him that I never delivered stone unless the car
riage was paid, and then he came to my place and said he would send for itâ€”I consented to thatâ€”he said he had purchased 200 feet of York paving at our wharf, and he wanted moreâ€”to that I consented.

SAMUEL COOPER . I am wharfinger, in the employ of Messrs. George & Co. I remember Johnson coming to the wharfâ€”I bad before received a communi
cation from Mr. Georgeâ€”Johnson said his name was James Johnson; had 1 received a communication respecting him?â€”I said, "Yes"â€”he looked out ten blocks of stone, and put his initials "J. J." upon themâ€”he said he wanted them as soon as possibleâ€”I sent them by the carman the next day.
(MR. PARRY here withdrew from the prosecution.)

217.
ALFRED EDWARD MOORE, alias James Matthews, alias James Johnson
, and
HENRY HODGSON , were again indicted for
a conspiracy.

218.
ALFRED EDWARD MOORE was again indicted with
JOHN BENCH
for a conspiracy.

GEORGE DUNCAN . I am of the firm of Boyd & Duncan, of Great Guild
ford-street, Southwarkâ€”we are emery and glass paper-manufacturers. On 25th Sept. Moore came to meâ€”he pave his name "Alfred Edward Moore"â€”he said he was a grocer and draper, and lived at 2, St. John's-street, Colchesterâ€”he gave an order for emery and glass to the amount of 4l. 14s.â€”he wrote an address for me on the back of a card, which I gave to Benchâ€”Moore said that if I would inquire at Bench's he vvould give me a good referenceâ€”he said he lived at No. 4-1, Francis-street, Newington Causewayâ€”Moore said after I had seen Bench he would call againâ€”I saw Bench at No. 44, Francis-street, Newingtonâ€”I asked him if he knew anything of that party, producing the card at the same timeâ€”the name "A. E. Moore" was on itâ€”he said he, knew him ever since he was a boy, and he wished to know what was the nature of the transactionâ€”I told him, and he asked what quantity of goods he requiredâ€”I said, probably 20l.â€”he said he was perfectly good for that, and he would have no hesitation in trusting him for thatâ€”I was satisfied with thatâ€”I believed Moore to be a grocer and draper at Colchesterâ€”I packed up some emery and glass paper to the amount of 4l. 14s., and Moore called and took it awayâ€”I afterwards received a paper from him, dated Sept. 28, signed Alfred Edward Mooreâ€”I gave it to Cross, the officerâ€”I received the paper by handâ€”in consequence of that paper I went to 44, Francis-street, Newing
ton Causeway, to make some inquiries of Benchâ€”that was the latter end of September, two or three days after the order was receivedâ€”Bench was gone, and the house was shut upâ€”I returned home by the Blackfriars-road, and 1 saw Moore in Blackfriars-road standing outside an ironmonger's shop, mea
suring some stovesâ€”I stopped a few minutes till he had done, and then called himâ€”he did not answerâ€”he walked onâ€”I went and stopped him and asked when he came to townâ€”he said, "Yesterday"â€”I asked if he had been calling at our place, as I had been out some timeâ€”he said, no, but ho would do so either that day or to-morrow and give me some moneyâ€”he said I was to have the order ready that he wrote for, and he would take it away to-morrow when he came to pay me the moneyâ€”he asked what was the reason I had not sent him the goods he wrote forâ€”I had received but one paper containing an orderâ€”this is it (readâ€”"No. 2, St. John's-street, Col
chebter, Sept. 27, 1848. Messrs. Boyd & Duncan. Gentlemen, Having a friend of mine coming to town, I have forwarded this letter by him, so that if you have not sent the sweetmeats and liquorice I will thank you to let him have it, so that it will not cost me anything for carriage, and at the same time send me one ream more of emery cloth paper and half a cwt. of your best glue, for I have orders for some. I shall be able to send you a post-office order for 6l. next Wednesday. By attending to this you will oblige, yours respectfully, Alfred E. Moore"â€”This letter enclosed a card, on which was "A. E. Moore, Grocer and Draper, 2, St. John's-street, Colchester"â€”Moore came to me shortly afterwards, and I gave him into custodyâ€”about eight or ten days after I met Bench in Gravel-laneâ€”when he saw me he made to run awayâ€”I got the assistance of a policeman, and gave him in charge.
Cross-examined by MR. HUGHES. Q. Look at this piece of paper; is it your handwriting? A. Yesâ€”(read)â€”"Received of Mr. Mooreâ€”4l. 14s. for

goods sold. BOYD AND DIIXCAN. "â€”this is my invoiceâ€”I recollect attending at the police-office, and the evidence I gave thereâ€”I saw Cross, the police
man, thereâ€”we probably might go to a public-house to drink after the Court was overâ€”after I left the public-house I went down to Southwark-square with the policemanâ€”a female went with us, who had called at our shopâ€”she represented herself as Moore's wifeâ€”she stated there was some person coming to pay me some moneyâ€”I did not receive any money from her, but from Foster, I believeâ€”I got one sovereign and an I O U.

HENRY GEORGE . I am a stone-merchant. Moore went by the name of Johnson to meâ€”I saw him on 20th Sept., and then he represented his name to be Johnson, residing in Friar-street, Union-street, Blackfriars-roadâ€”I saw him again on 3rd Oct.â€”he did not say where he had been between then and 20th Sept.
HENRY BARKY (policeman, A 455). I have known Moore by the name of Matthews.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever know him in custody? A. No, but I have seen him use a house where thieves go.

SAMUEL CROSS (policeman). Moore was given into my custody by Mr. Duncanâ€”he said he must go, he supposed; it was a bad caseâ€”I found on him this pocket-bookâ€”I went to Friar-street, Union-street, Blackfriars-roadâ€”I made inquiriesâ€”he did not live there.

MOOREâ€”
GUILTY . Aged 25.â€”
Transported for Seven Years.

BENCHâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

218.
HENRY HODGSON , was again indicted
for obtaining 4 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, and 1 5l. bank-note; of
George Self, by false pretences.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

219.
CAROLINE HALL
, stealing 2 1/2 yards of cloth, value 4s. 4d.; the goods of
John Bryant and another: also, 1 blouse, 3s.; the goods of
James Robinson Cockburn; having been before convicted; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.â€”
Confined One Year .

220.
EDWARD MILLS
, stealing 1 clamp, value 6s.; the goods of
George Nott, his master.
GEORGE NOTT . I am a carpenterâ€”the prisoner was in my service. On 2nd Nov. I missed some toolsâ€”this clamp produced is mine.
RICHARD NOAK . I am foreman to Mr. Nott. I did not lend the prisoner the clamp.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. Are you his master? A. Yes; he was in the employ since July or Aug.â€”the clamp was at York-road, where he was at workâ€”many other men were employed thereâ€”if men took tools away, and returned them, I should discharge them.
GEORGE HORNSEY . I am a pawnbroker. I took this clamp in pledge of the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe he has been in the habit of pledging tools and redeeming them? A. Yes; the night before he was taken he called to redeem this tool, but he had not got enough moneyâ€”he came again, but it was too late.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.â€”
Confined Six Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

221.
ANN GREY
, stealing 1 bag, value 1d.; I half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, 3 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the moneys of
George Turner, from his person.

GEOROR TURNER . I am a labourer. On 18th Nov., about three o'clock in the morning, I met the prisoner in the New-cutâ€”she asked me to go with herâ€”I said I would have nothing to do with herâ€”she put her hand into my pocket, and took 6d. outâ€”I crossed the road to get rid of herâ€”she followed and clung to meâ€”I had had a little liquor, but knew what I was aboutâ€”she put her hand into my pocket, and took out this bag (produced), with a half-sovereign, a half-crown, and 3s. in it.
GEORGE WATMUUOH (policeman, L 105) I took the prisoner, and found on her half-a-sovereign, half-a-crown, and 1s.â€”I was with a constable who picked up this bag, emptyâ€”Turner claimed it.

Prisoner's Defence. He walked with me to the Waterloo-road, and told me he had been with some girl, who robbed him of 6d. and some halfpence; he wanted me to lie down in the street, and as I would not, he called "Police!" and said I had robbed him; the money I had was mine.

GEORGE TURNER
re-examined. It is false.
NOT GUILTY .

222.
MARTIN COOK
, stealing 1 box, 1 gown, 1 snuff-box, 1 shawl, and other wearing-apparel, value 18s. 6d.; the goods of the
South-Eastern Railway Company.

RACHAEL ROGERS . In Sept., 1847, I had a box corded up at the Brick
layers' Arms station, directed, "Miss Rogers, to be left at the Bricklayers' Arms station till called for"â€”I had written to Canterbury to desire it to be forwardedâ€”I went to the station more than once, but could get no tidings of itâ€”it contained a mahogany work-box, about a foot long, some ear-rings, a necklace, gowns, and other thingsâ€”these are the ear-rings (produced.)
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Were there not two pair? A. Yesâ€”this pair are gold.
ELIZABETH COOPER . I am single. About nine months ago I was living with my father, and the prisoner made me a present of these ear-rings.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Daniel Haines? A. Yes; he is my uncleâ€”I believe he is employed by the railwayâ€”he used to come to my father'sâ€”Cook did not say he got the rings from Hainesâ€”Haines brought a mahogany box there, nearly a foot long, and about six inches broad.
MR. BODKIN, Q. Was it before he brought the ear-rings? A. About the same time. (MR. BODKIN withdrew from the Prosecution.)
NOT GUILTY .

223.
CORNELIUS COLLINS
, stealing 2 quarts of peas, value 6d.; the goods of
Edward Gripper and another, his masters.
EDWARD GRIPPER . I am a wharfinger. The prisoner was in my serviceâ€”he had no authority to take peasâ€”I believe these split peas (produced) to be mine.

MORRISS RICHARDS . On 5th Nov., between nine 3nd ten o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner coming with-his son from Mr. Gripper's ware-house with this bundle under the boy's armâ€”I asked where he got itâ€”he said his father gave it himâ€”the father was not there thenâ€”I went to him, and asked if the boy was his sonâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I asked if he gave him those peasâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I asked if his master allowed him to do soâ€”he said, "Yes"â€”I took him and the peas.

GUILTY . Aged 35.â€”Recommended to mercy.â€”
Confined Six Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 18TH, 1848.
